My original review was totally wrong (see bottom)  once I pulled my head oput of my ass about FPS (A good session in Farcry 5 got me prepared).

pros

V good graphics.
Good story with plenty to do.
NPC character interaction superb and interesting (unlike Starfield) !!!
I will definitely have a 2nd play through on a different character if it has its own story too.
Lots of side quests.
Combat in normal is nicely balanced for someone that is not great and strafing jiggling about in FPS / dodging etc.
Did I say the graphics are gorgeous to look at ?!

cons
It crashes quite often - I am not used to games crashing |(by often once every 2-3 hours I am guessing). Its not my system which is high and and well up to date (ryzen 9 64GB RAM rtx4090)
Graohical lock ups rather than a full crash of the game but same issue and on 3 occasions with this I have had to do a full reboot of my system after force crashing the game.

Other than that I do not have anything else negative to say about it at this point !!!

Ugggg I don't know....It's boring and feels awful. The dialog is horrible. It's just too busy and in your face and does not feel good. The UI is atrocious. Clearly a lazy console port. Feels like Skyrim without mods, but worse. I'm sure it's really just a personal thing though - a lot of people are going to like this. And as for the dialog... I mean is it supposed to be self-aware cringe? I cannot really tell... I was never really into the cyberpunk thing so maybe it's supposed to be like that but I found it terrible. Just that usual cheesy millennial style of writing that tries to be clever and quirky but always falls short. For some context here I also could not get into the Witcher 3 so you probably shouldn't listen to me, lol. I tried numerous times because I really wanted to enjoy the story as I heard it was fantastic but the game play felt so awful I just could not get past that. Also I think maybe because I like mil-sim style combat games so much - when it's dumbed down to this level and damage numbers, bars and lights are flashing at you over enemies I just hate it. Anyways, I'm sure I'm in a minority here but I definitely regret spending money on this.

It took a few years, but Cyberpunk has greatly improved from a launch disaster to a beloved title. If you like the cyberpunk aesthetic and setting, this is the AAA RPG you're looking for. I did a playthrough as a netrunner, and am midway through a playthrough as a blade user. I highly recommend this if you have a GPU that can handle it.

It's a very good game, I would definitely recommend it.
The story line is very good, it has a very delicately written story. I don't know how much of an impact the values it inspired have on this, but it really has a story at the level of a high-level movie. To compare, the story is much better than GTA 5, and may even be better than the GTA 4 series (3 episodes). As for the game mechanics, the mechanics of motorcycling and some of the vehicles are really bad. But as the vehicles get better, the mechanics get better. (I don't know, maybe they did it on purpose so that it would be obvious that you switched to a good vehicle). Apart from that, there are many innovations in the game. They worked hard, even the quality of the side missions is top notch.
The only thing I regret about this game is: I wish it would be remembered as a legend instead of delaying its release date and remembering it with bugs (there are no problems at the moment, by the way).
Just buy it and have fun!!!

[h1] Cyberpunk is a fantastic and fun open-world game. [/h1]

I originally skipped out and overlooked on Cyberpunk 2077 from its initial launch in 2020 because it didn't look as appealing and interesting to me at the time. However, I decided and recently bought it at the end of 2023 on sale. I have to say it is a very good game. The stories and quests are interesting and the amount of customization options and stuff you can do in the game, is basically up to your desire and there's generally no limits. To me cyberpunk 2077 is like GTA but set in a futuristic city/world. Your able to do jobs to make money, go to clubs and hang out, and customize your character however you want. There's just a ton of stuff available to do!

What finally sold me on picking up Cyberpunk is finding out about the many mods from cars, to character customization options that are available to download by excellent and talented mod creators. I am having a lot of fun going around and doing jobs, interacting with people in the world and sometimes battling with the police and enemies, and also driving around my car collection. The environment and photo mode options are great too. 

If you played GTA or similar games and like open world style games or are like me and just want to do as you please with no set limits or structure involved, I highly recommend picking up Cyberpunk 2077.

Cyberpunk 2077 is a good open world RPG that falls just a little below Witcher 3 for me. If you like the genre, you won’t be disappointed with this game. The scope of this game should be commended. It looks great. The atmosphere is the strong point in this game. I felt like I was in blade runner. This dystopian futuristic world is ruled by corruption, gangs, and corporations and the map is huge. V is also a great, witty main character. 

I’m going to keep this review relatively short because honestly, this is not my genre. These games leave me with decision paralysis and lack of direction after the main story line is done. Some people love it, I’m just not one. I beat the main story in about 25 hours, but if you want to max everything out in this game, I can easily see it taking another 50 hours. 

The Good:
Like I said, the atmosphere is top notch. They nail the setting. Dark, misty, robotic, desperation, cooperate, rough, survival, futuristic, are all words that come to mind. The game is worth it just to experience the open world CD Projekt Red has created. 
Characters feel real and unique. They have their own motivations and personalities.
I didn’t run into any bugs, despite this game having an infamous buggy release.
Lots of side quests that feel good to complete, are fast, and aren’t overwhelming. 

Decent:
The combat was okay, too many health bars and too much screen planning for my liking. I didn’t like the cloaking abilities that some enemies have, or the large number of enemies that just run away. But there are a lot of options about how to fight. There were melee weapons, ranged weapons, snipers, quick hacks (my favorite), sneaking and assassinations, taking control of turrets. They were all decently fun. 

Bad: 
The main story line was confusing. It took too many twists, and had too many characters involved, by the end I didn’t feel connected to any of the decisions I was making. I won’t spoil any of it, but I’ll just say, they went for a detailed story, too detailed. I wish the factions were a little better defined, and my options were a little clearer about their ramifications. 

In conclusion, I bought this game on sale for $30. Definitely worth that price and probably worth full price. I don’t regret going through it for a second, but one time is probably enough for me. If you are looking for an open world RPG and are sick of the over saturated medieval fantasy settings, look no further.

10/10 game.

Have to say it was a rocky start.  I bought Cyberpunk 2077 right when it came out and it suffered from many game-breaking bugs.  When you put bodies down - enemies could see them through walls; cops were invincible and would be triggered over literally nothing.  NPCS would eerily stand there like a T for no reason.  

Well after 2.11 and the DLC, this game has totally 180'd.  It is beautiful and immersive; the character builds are fixed and more balanced.  It is a total improvement over the game at release.  

I am on my second playthrough.  First game I played as a netrunner and I was clapping baddies through cameras and melting their brains from far away on hard mode was pretty good.  This playthrough I'm using the sandevistan, freezing time and throwing knives at the bad guys on very hard mode.  

I have noticed that on very hard some of the boss-ish battles are pretty impossible.  Trying to hit enemies while other people are driving (little battle cutscenes) are virtually impossible without first max perking some of the skill trees.  Still this plays like a totally different game since the 2.11 update.  

I didn't play right after the 2.0 update; so I'm only making the comparison from release to 2.11; it's the difference between night and day.  If you refunded because it was horrible at release you should try it now.

Cyberpunk 2077 is a very mixed bag of ups and downs, featuring things that were executed nicely, while at the same time those that were executed horribly.

I'd lie if I said that the game doesn't offer anything good, it does. The world, the map, the characters (at least some of them), the music, it all clicks because this is the content that was initially designed before CDPR decided to rewrite everything from scratch, half-assing everything from now on. Unfortunately, this is FAR too little to consider CP2077 a good game.

The negatives however are everywhere. The gameplay is horribly repeatable, you can feel the content filler with every single step you take, going through uninteresting and outright boring "gigs" and "NCPD activities" that all play the same. Everything that was showed in the trailers and demos was fabricated, the world is empty, the content was cut horribly to the point that the game looks like it required another 2 or 3 years in development just to fill all those holes, let alone fix the bugs. The main story started with a bang, I noticed the amount of polish and effort that was put into the beginning of the game, which is on-par with the main quests of Witcher 3. However, the moment we start the whole biochip journey, everything looks like half-assed attempt to meet the deadlines and not bother about user experience. It's clear as day that this is where the real content made by ex-W3 devs ended, and the new vision of the project begun, the one which forced Keanu Reeves into the picture because of marketing deal, and not because he actually fitted for any role in what was originally planned. It felt exactly the same like beginning of Mafia 3, which also started with a bang, leaving a smell of ♥♥♥♥ for the remaining part of the game. If you ask me, I have no clue why CP2077 has better rates than Mafia 3 had, it has exactly the same problems, exactly the same empty world and exactly the same boredom.

I've finished the whole game and explored everything that game had to offer in order to review the whole product. No patch will fix severe lack of content caused by extreme cuts and half-assed execution of remaining part. You have only one attempt to make good first impression, and the impression of Cyberpunk looks like a game focused on meeting studio management expectations, tight deadlines and forced marketing, rather than offering quality product for your own enjoyment. It's definitely not the worst game I've ever played, but it dropped far below my expectations, which were already non-existent, as I knew that the game won't be anywhere close to Witcher 3 quality, yet even with that approach I didn't expect a game to turn out this bad. Considering the size of the studio and how many people were actually involved into whole this mess, I won't be as forgiving as I was e.g. with Mafia 3, as I really believe that CP2077 isn't a good game in terms of the content and gameplay, and the price tag doesn't reflect the quality of the product.

It's time to move on, this game is amazing, especially after update 2.0.

Original review, written after about 20 hours of game time:
Definitely recommended.

Updated three times, after 80 and 110 hours + at the end, 121 hours into the game:
This is one of the best games I have played. Probably not ever, but definitely in the last few years to a decade. The story is solid, the gameplay elements are solid, the setting is solid, the atmosphere is solid and the graphics.. even on my 5 year old PC it varies between awesome and jaw dropping with a perfectly playable FPS... (subjective opinion)

Full disclosure though: if you are sensitive to minor issues, like animation glitches, sound glitches or the likes, I recommend to wait a few more patches, probably a DLC or two for the game to be "fixed". They are not game breaking mind you, I am having a blast, but they are noticeable.. so if those break it for you, you have been warned.. otherwise, you will have a blast.

Some more details from the original review:
Technical:
If you do not use ray-tracing, the game actually runs well on high-ultra settings in 1440p even on a 1080FE. I have not actually measured FPS, but I can tell you this: I have not really felt a stutter or degradation in my experience.

Gameplay wise:
It is awesome. The game has so much content, that after 20+ hours of actively chasing quests, I have yet to make any real progress in my main quest line. The gun-play is fun, though at times enemies feel bullet spongy, which is a bit against Cyberpunk canon, where shots are supposed to be more lethal. Cybernetics are done in a way that blends into the game really well. There is somewhat scary about hunting cyber psychos with superhuman evasion, dodging your bullets like Neo from the matrix. :) The hacking in the game is also meaningful and blends well into the whole game-play.

My first real gripe with the game is the GTA-esque vehicle physics, where they seem to have too much mass compared to world object and they pretty much handle like speedboats on water. The other is the inventory system. For a game that focuses so much on looting everything around you, the inventory system would really need some beefing up to make it easier to manage. It is not horrible, but far from being great either.

There were some funny glitches I have observed and the enemy AI is not particularly smart at times either, especially if you "exploit" their easy to spot weaknesses, however at that point, it is more on you than on the game. If you play the game straight, the AI will pose a sufficient enough challenge and you will die if you are careless. :)

The game does a good job with auto saving and the save-load mechanism is actually quite well done and easy to manage.

When it comes to the RPG elements, I cannot yet tell how much of the dialogues have meaningful consequences behind them on the long run, but the world is full of lore and tidbits of info, either funny or just interesting that you can find in all kinds of places.

Overall, I tend to call this GTA: Night City or GTA: Cyberpunk ed. It of course has substantially more RPG elements, like attributes and perks and more dialogues with NPCs, but at its core, the game plays and feels like a GTA game would and with you mostly running or driving around in a big city, I think you will agree it feels very similar :) 

This is not a bad thing though, GTAs are great in their own right and Cyberpunk takes that formula to the next level through its unique setting and RPG elements.

UPDATE @ 80 hours
Still going strong, I reckon I am at about 2/3 of the content now :) At least that is my guess based on the remaining map markers. The story in the game is extremely good. Even the side gigs have variety to them in how you approach the problems they present.
- 1 CTD at around the 65 hour mark, graphics crash. Apart from that, rock solid.

UPDATE @ 110 hours
I am through with the gigs and crime events :) now its only the side missions and the main story left. Did a count, done more than 200 quests (gigs, side jobs or other activities) so far. Man there are some good stories in this game.
- Got 1 weird graphical glitch after an accidental windows update past the 1.05 patch (power outage forced my PC to restart, allowing windows to ninja-update on me). Driver update fixed it though. No hard tech issues since the freak CTD I had earlier.
- Noticed some strange sound artifacts as well lately, as in: sounds getting stuck.. reloading or quitting and reloading usually fixes it. Not frequent mind you, I think I have encountered it twice so far overall and only really noticed it the one time, as it was a very strong music sequence that got stuck on a loop :)

Final Entry @121 hours later:
I am done. The game is a masterpiece of storytelling. I didn't realize until the end how much the story got me, but it actually brought tears into my eyes when I finished. A fitting end to an epic and awesome story.
The variety in endings and how many of the things you do throughout the game influences them in subtle, yet meaningful ways is actually kinda awesome.

It has been a miracle for me to finish the game at all, as I almost never have the patience to play a story based game for this long, let alone replay them, but I can tell you this: if there is ever a story based game I would consider replaying, it is this one, just to see how I can make the story take a different shape.

DLC Entry: @250+ total hours
I binged the game for another 130 hours straight. The revised mechanics and UI are a lot better than they were at launch. If the game was a skull sized rough diamond back then, with the DLC, it is now a polished, cut piece of gaming history.

The DLC adds a meaningful, separately playable, yet also well integrated addition to the base game, As for the base game itself, it was still as good as when I first played it. Enjoyed every second. It did not evoke the same emotions, but that's not surprising for a replay, I still got misty eyed at certain points, which says a lot.

If you haven't played this one yet, you must.

After 4 Years you could think that they would have fixed the most basic shiet before even having the audacity to sell a DLC for this game. 

Like how is the Vehicle call-in System still broken to this day. You cant even play the radio half of the time, not to speak of the massive Framedrops which just randomly occur when theres literally nothing to render in the game???


But all in all its mostly working now and and the Story is really good. Theres also tons of stuff to do in the Game so i can recommend it now.

Mixed bag of a game. It runs so inefficiently, and sometimes, I feel like the entire idea of RTX is to grind out games faster and less efficiently using RT technology while artists don't need to create fake lighting. This feels like a proof of concept game that maxes out everything to 100%. 

It doesn't run on a lot of computers properly. It constantly needs to be rebooted, or crashes, causing 100% CPU hangs, needing a hard reset of the computer it's running on. 

It started off as a letdown, but the developers fixed it. As the 2.x updates rolled out, it now doesn't run on a lot of computers, and many spend more time trying to get it to not crash or run properly. For the performance aspects, I can not recommend this game. 

However, the gameplay, mechanics, and writing is great, and I 100% recommend it for that, and will continue to play.

A benchmark for modern RPGs. I loved this game so much, but Cyberpunk proved to be more than just a game for my friend Caleb; it was a transformative experience that mirrored his own journey of self-discovery and acceptance. As he navigated the neon-soaked streets of Night City, he found himself deeply connected to the game's richly diverse characters, each embodying the essence of bravery and authenticity in a world that often demands conformity. This connection went beyond mere gameplay; it sparked a realization in Caleb about the importance of living one's truth, no matter the societal pressures outside the digital realm. Witnessing the fearless expression of identity by the Cyberpunk characters inspired Caleb to embrace his own identity and come out as an active member of the LGBT community. He shared his truth with us, inspired by the resilience and determination of the characters he admired in the game. This act of bravery was a testament to the game's impactful narrative and its ability to resonate deeply with its players on a personal level. Cyberpunk 2077 didn't just offer Caleb an escape; it provided a mirror that reflected his strength and helped him find his voice. For Caleb, this was more than entertainment. It was a catalyst for personal revelation and acceptance, making it an unforgettable and life-affirming experience. I feel bad for his wife, but we were friends first, so I should just be happy for him right? Great game.

Phenomenal.

The game still has minor bugs, their worst harm being to immersion, but it's unfair to accuse the devs of laziness or carelessness. It's absolutely a product of blood, sweat, tears and love.

Taken as a marker chaser with shootouts and filler, much of its wonder is easy to miss. The lifeless feel of Night City's outskirts, a sense of overextension and regret; a borough that tried but just didn't get the biz to keep it breathing. How different the inner city feels after sharing your time and your heart with the nomads outside the city. The incessant commercials are just noise, the lights are just lights, the architecture's colours are bright but starkly artificial. How long before it draws me back in? How long before I'm trying to flatline some big shot gonk for a backstreet fixer and trying to ignore the casual, neon-bathed exploitation of it all? Then I get a call. Judy needs my help. She helped me out with a gig and now we're in something together. We got close. After all I've been through, I trust her. I drive to her place and... Oh god. Not long.

Now I'm cruising back to Dogtown in wheels I klepped from some gangoon leadheads, Retinal Scan's 'Gridflow' pounding on the radio, and Night City is my home.

[h2] Preem game. A must have.[/h2]

I played on release and was captivated by the game regardless of the issues it had. I've always appreciated the underlying beauty of the game. It has come a long way since then. And with all the improvements, the DLC, the story, missions, side missions, characters, Johnny Silverhand, cyberware, world design, music, combat, stealth, skills & everything else it has to offer, Cyberpunk has earned the spot in my Top 5 favorite games of all time. The redemption arc itself is worth enough for you to get the game. On my 6th playthrough at this point.

[h2] To Night City! [/h2]

If you can run this game with good graphics, it turns into an incredible piece of art really. If not, it is still an amazing game with massive content, incredible voice acting, a super immersive universe and setting and outstanding combat and gameplay. Ultimately the choices you make don't feel they have a huge repercussion, or not always, but it still a really incredibly polished experience at this point. Has easily taken one of my top 10 favourite games of all times spot, especially if you liked the Cyberpunk Edgerunners series.

While the game is not the Game Of The Century it was to be, it still is a great game by modern standards.

The Graphics on Ultra are easily the best I've seen ever and are probably the best things about this game. While I did run without RTX in the majority (95%) of the game. Graphics still were amazing and next gen. [h2] Graphics are 10/10 [/h2]

The Story while is short is still good and I enjoyed it. I just wish we did some more crazy stuff but at the end it is a battle against time. [h2] Story 7.5/10 [/h2]

The gameplay (specfically the gun play) is something that I loved and while it does start off to be bullet sponge, the more you level up and progress, the less of a bullet sponge it is and I have found it to be enjoyable. The Skills are also good and balanced, I ended up being a jack off all trades and superior at nothing so it's my fault but again skills are good and balanced.
Hacking is also simple and easy to learn but hard to master. There's also crafting of weapons but I never did any of that. You also get a lot of loot (weapons mostly) and when you sell them you get a lot of Eddies in the long run. [h2] Gameplay is an 8/10 [/h2]

Missions I've had no problems with in regards to being "boring" or "repetitive". The side missions such as NCPD scanner and the GIGS did become a bit of a chore to finish but I took breaks and finished it so I won't complain too much. [h2] Missions 7/10 [/h2]

I think the game Overall deserves an 8/10 and a big fat recommendation from me 👍👍👍👍👍👍👍👍

Side note: Optimization leaves a bit to be desired as running without frame gen on any graphical setting seems to not go above 120/130 fps on a 4080 and i7 14700k. But [b] enabling [/b] DLSS Frame Gen fixed it and I got 250+ fps in general.

- Graphics with path tracing enabled are phenomenal
- On a RTX 4080 SUPER with all settings maxed RT Psycho 2k Res dlss Q, between 90-140 fps, pretty good 
- Anti-capitalism ungodly based
OVERALL:  9.3/10

I only bought the game last year, so I wasn't around for its bad start and have an "objective"(ish) opinion lol.

I think Cyberpunk is a very good game, but I don't think it's a truly "great" game (in the ways that, say, Halo 3 or Skyrim are truly great games). It's obviously a very ambitious project, and I think it comes 75% of the way towards realizing that ambition (which is saying something). The gameplay is fun but not groundbreaking, the world is incredibly (in some ways ridiculously) detailed yet is still obviously artificial and somewhat dismissible, and the characters are fun, flavorful, and engaging yet don't quite reach the level of "aliveness" that the game is shooting for.

I think what attracts me to Cyberpunk (the game) is that it's a love letter to, well, cyberpunk (the genre). It clearly references and draws inspiration from almost every classic cyberpunk book and movie I can think of, and when I play the game I almost — almost — feel like I've stepped into my favorite cyberpunk stories. I think that if you like sci-fi, first person shooters, or open world games, you will probably like this game. I think that if you aren't naturally drawn to these genres then the game won't really convince you otherwise.

On more of a "what-if" note, I think that the game did actually have the potential to be truly great, but its scope was its downfall. The open world they mapped out for themselves is just too big, there are too many characters and side-quests, the level of realism they strove for was too high. I think if CD Projekt Red nixed one of these goals from the get-go (probably the insanely-huge world) and fully committed themselves to a more curated but deeper experience, the game would be truly groundbreaking. As it stands though they have done a truly impressive job, and as I said, the game is very good. I think it has probably achieved a measure of immortality on the level of, say, No-Man's Sky.

I have 2 major complaints with cyberpunk, 1) The missions in this game are shallow  Most of the time you go to a place and do one single thing and it takes at most 5 minutes.   There may be multiple ways to infiltrate a building or multiple avenues of attack, but at the end of the day, it's just, go here, then do one thing, done.  It simply was not satisfying.   And 2) the game is remarkably easy.   The quick hacks are cool but combined with weapons, cybernetics, grenades, and everything else, the game just became too easy.  And I was playing at the hardest difficulty.   Nine out of ten times I could defeat all the enemies anywhere without losing more than half my health.  The only legitimate challenge I regularly faced was a team of ~10 Arasaka soldiers randomly showing up to ambush me.  All the other missions and gigs were a complete walk in the park.  This game just gave me too many tools to deal with any problem that every problem became trivial.

It might have had a rocky start, but it came back so well. The main storyline is somewhat short, actually (unless you have PL Expansion, where the two stories intertwine nicely) but the side missions can keep you intruiged for hours on end. what might have been a short drive from one mission to another might be interuppted by tons of tiny little stories and nuggets of lore, each unique in its own way. The gameplay is insane, mechanics flow so smoothly compared to the glitchy mess that it was a few years ago. I found myself trying so many new guns, vehicles, and styles of gameplay as I progressed through. One last thing to mention; the graphics! Oh man, the graphics are so good. Especially with my 4090, the path tracing (or ray tracing if you're on a lower GPU) makes the game really shine with all the tiny little details that the developers clearly put a lot of effort into. Props to CDPR for really bringing back this beautiful game.

Decided to wait a couple of years to buy this game and it proved to be worth the wait. I haven't ran into any bugs in my playthrough (so far), the gameplay systems are very unique and fun, the characters are very much likeable and charming (especially Johnny/Keanu). The world building is also one of the best I've seen in a game, (IMO) just right below RDR2 and GTA5. The customization I expected too highly of but not to say that it's bad. I also accidentally started a mission for Phantom Liberty and man, it leaves a fantastic first impression! The story I feel was totally a bit too short but it could have just been that I was addicted and totally started to speedrun the main campaign of the story but even then, it was still quite a blast to experience. This one could also totally be a me thing but the photo mode is also quite a lot of fun. The game allows you to get creative with scenarios to screenshot your character in, I'd argue that the photo mode is equal to that of RDR2. 10/10!

A Triumph of Cyberpunk Dreams

As the neon-soaked streets of Night City enveloped me, I realized that Cyberpunk 2077 isn’t just a game; it’s a visceral experience—an intoxicating blend of dystopia, rebellion, and cyber-enhanced chaos. Here’s why it deserves a second look:

-Redemption Arc: Yes, the launch was rocky, plagued by bugs and performance issues. But CD Projekt Red didn’t abandon ship. Instead, they embarked on a relentless journey to polish and refine. The result? A game that now gleams like chrome under city lights.

-Immersive World: Night City breathes. It’s a living, breathing organism—a cacophony of street vendors, fixers, and desperate souls. The graffiti, the holograms, the rain-slicked alleys—they all tell stories. And V, our protagonist, is a cipher through which we explore this cybernetic wonderland.

-Character Depth: The NPCs aren’t mere quest dispensers. They have dreams, fears, and secrets. Judy Alvarez’s melancholic artistry, Johnny Silverhand’s rebellious spirit, and Panam Palmer’s fierce loyalty—they’re etched into my memory.

-Choices Matter: Every decision reverberates. Who you side with, who you romance, how you handle quests—it all shapes your journey. The multiple endings aren’t mere variations; they’re distinct narratives, each leaving an indelible mark.

-Keanu Reeves: Johnny Silverhand isn’t just a celebrity cameo. He’s a digital ghost, a punk rock prophet, and a mirror reflecting V’s inner turmoil. Keanu’s performance elevates the game.

-Soundtrack: The synthwave beats, the haunting melodies—they’re the heartbeat of Night City. Whether cruising in a Quadra or gunning down scavengers, the music amplifies the adrenaline.

If a neutral review were possible, I'd rate it so, but as it is, I can't give it a positive Vote. Of course this is purely my subjective view:

The game has a good start, but after the only one emotional gripping moment in the game, which was for me after  [spoiler] the theft of the Relic [/spoiler], it got bland and generic and I had the urge to just stop playing it several times. When finally forcing myself to finishing after 140 hours I was just glad it was over and I couldn't care about what happened to the main character and his friends.

I waited with my purchase for after the release of Phantom Liberty and was pretty grumpy to find it still as riddled with bugs as it is. None of them gamebreaking, but still a slap in the customers face after all the time given to get rid of them.

This is clearly no longer the studio, that created "the witcher 3". Not by a long, long way. The "Corpos" obviously just draining the impressive work done once upon a time.

+ Many many hours of gameplay
+ Very customiseable skilltrees
+ Graphics
+ Fighting system

- Many many hours of emotionally uninvested getting rid of one quest after another.
- Bugs Bugs Bugs (still!!!)
- The Moments that obviously should trigger emotional player responses feel like done according to a mathematical formula. (I mean, I don't  expect something so impressively stunning as Iris van Everecs "I am sadness" moments. But this game doesn't even get anywhere close to the storytelling and questwriting of those days. When for example,  [spoiler] So Mi reminisces/has backflashes about her past in the last Phantom liberty quest [/spoiler] I was just plain bored and couldn't care less.

Conclusion: Its a graphic- and gametime-wise big game, but had I not bought it at the 50% discount, I would have felt severely ripped off. It's ok, but in it's intention to become grand, it just got generic.
Worth the half price, but (for me) definitely not anywhere close to a milestone in game-history, that some reviewers seem to see in it.

I originally played through this game on the PS5. Bugs aside, I thought the story was pretty boring, mostly due to the poor writing of almost every supporting character. I found most of the game’s personality limited to the hit or miss optional content, where you’re either destined to strike gold or just gun down some random group of enemies that got thrown in to pad for time; no incentive provided other than a few eddies and maybe progress towards an achievement, sometimes with as little explanation as "these are criminals". It plays much the same as the original Deus Ex, only with an open world, driving mechanics, and decades of improvements in graphical fidelity, but are those few features really worth paying modern AAA prices for what is essentially a 20 year old game? Not in my opinion.

So why did I buy this game again? Well, there were a couple of reasons, the first of which is cross-progression. The implementation of cross-progression in the 1.6 patch meant that I could pick up where I left off without having to play through the entire game again. The second reason is mods. The restoration of cut content and addition of many much needed features (Such as flying cars and apartment customisation) have given the game far more longevity in my opinion. The last reason was the Edgerunners anime. It was an amazing marketing strategy which I clearly fell for.

Sadly, mods weren’t enough to salvage the experience. The game simply has nothing to offer after 100% completion; No radiant quests, no random encounters, no minigames, no mission replay, no new game plus. Hell, you can barely interact with the NPCs at any of the twelve bars the game has to offer, and that's not even counting the ones missing map markers. I know that this is a complaint a lot of fans take issue with, but the only counter-argument I've seen is "Replay the game with a different build". As I said in my opening paragraph, the 110 hours I've already sunk into the game made for a lacklustre experience, so why would I want to do it all again? Maybe if there was NG+, that would be a viable option... but there isn't. Most of my enjoyment came from just flying around Night City using the aformentioned mod, and so I think wanting some kind of sandbox content from the developers themselves is more than justified. Hopefully the upcoming DLC or even sequel is redemption enough, but at this point, I’m not confident.

Listen, I played Cyberpunk its release week on my PS4 Pro, and it crashed every ninety minutes nearly on the dot, and characters walked through doors without opening them and sometimes you had to reload a save so a bug wouldn't softlock you in a quest, and I absolutely loved it.  Covid had just hit full force and I'd just been laid off as a result, and I once accidentally played this game for over 24 hours straight.  I remember my roommate getting up, leaving for work, getting back from his shift, hanging out for a while, going to bed, and then getting up for his next shift again while I played a merc in Night City and took bathroom and food breaks every ninety minutes when it crashed.  Sure I was basically playing an alpha release, but an alpha of a game that absolutely rules.  

I'm probably working through my fourth or fifth playthrough right now and I haven't gotten bored.  This is the game that caused my carpal tunnel.  Even now I still drive faster than the game can load and fall through the map sometimes, it's really a late beta with the promise of a final release to come alongside the upcoming phantom liberty expansion.  I still haven't decided if I'll use one of my existing files or start a whole new one when it comes out, I wouldn't mind an excuse to play through the game again.  This game rules.

The story is incredibly written, all of the characters are distinct and awesome in their own ways, the dramatic moments are intense, exciting, and emotional, the jokes are funny, Keanu Reeves' character is always inserting his highly entertaining input into every situation and putting his whole (Lord forgive me for this) Keanussy into his performance.  Narratively this game is a 10/10.

The gameplay is incredibly fun, and in my opinion the current skill trees are actually a ton of fun to create a build out of.  I was initially underwhelmed by the small buff nature of a lot of the buyable skills, but since then the min maxer in me has come to really love the skill tree as it is, to the point I'm scared they'll change it too much with this upcoming expansion.  (I'm sure they'll just improve it though, these guys clearly know what they're doing).  Like I said earlier, I'm on my fourth or fifth playthrough right now, and every playthrough I've built characters builds that have been entirely different from each other, have played incredibly different in combat and even in social situations, and have all been incredibly fun mechanically in ways that are entirely different from each other.  The small buffs you buy with skill points are underwhelming at first, but grow into incredibly powerful builds that encourage you to play in ways that are diverse and engaging.  I keep trying new wacky builds and they keep being super fun.  It's honestly a little baffling to me.  Almost all of them turn combat into a puzzle, some where you have to be slow and methodical, and others where you have to be fast and precise.  I initially found the stealth mechanics underwhelming as well, but now I love them.  I feel they do a good job emulating the cyberpunk genre, where almost every job starts carefully and precisely and then by the end of it everything's gone to shit and you're just trying to make it out alive.  

I know I've already described two things as initially underwhelming, and that's too many things for this review to be trustworthy when I still claim that this game rules, but this game rules.  I swear.  Cross my heart.  There are many fantastic gameplay systems at work within this game, and all the rustier ones are getting updated with this new patch.  I love the way cyberwear is implemented, the various avenues through which you can improve your abilities and the insane ways you can combine them, the way every combat either makes you feel like a scrappy underdog, a superhero, or a god, the different dialogue options you're given that seem to cover every type of character you could want to play and do so effectively, and even the voice acting that at least never fails to take swings.  This is basically the perfect game.  It actually drives me crazy that this is the game that flares my carpal tunnel more than anything else because it's the one that caused it.  I can only play it like once or twice a week now, and I have to take frequent stretch breaks.  Infuriating.  

TLDR I love this game and my judgement is clearly clouded, but I'll shout its praises to anyone that will listen like a sweetly delusional missionary

Disclosure: I didn't have ANY hype for this game and actually laughed when I saw it, predictably, flop on release. I picked it up way after launch and at a steep discount. But as of the time of this review, after 120 hours put into this game, I can spout on and on about how good this game is. I can prattle on for hours about how immersive the world is, how some of the characters are written so well that you actually care about what happens to them in the world, how well the combat can be tailored to any player's preference, or how pretty the game looks on ultra settings with high-fidelity and amazing lighting engines. I can gush about the sheer amount of talent and genuine passion that leaks out of this game by a team that got dragged over coals for almost 2 years by releasing a literally unplayable mess, but stuck to their guns, fixed it, and didn't give up on it after 3 years.

But I won't do any of that. I don't want to type a thesis and I'm sure you don't want to read one. Instead, I'll say this: If you enjoy dystopian, sci-fi worlds with mountains of lore, immersion, gratuitous violence, and feeling like a god at the end of a play-through, if you like (for the most part) good voice acting and a world that sucks you in for hours at a time, then get this fucking game. Especially after the updates, Cyberpunk 2077 is finally the game that SHOULD'VE been released 3 years ago and is still kicking other game's asses to this day. I even got the DLC and have barely touched it yet because I'm still working on the vanilla content. This game is the first in possibly 4 or 5 years that actually has me reading Wiki pages to comb over lore because the world that CD has crafted is beyond fascinating to me. The last series that did that to me was Elder Scrolls. If you have any reservations, then get it on sale.

cyberpunk 2077 opened a hole in my heart and nothing has ever been able to come close to filling that empty void no matter how hard I've looked.

Hey there! So, I've been diving deep into the neon-lit streets of Night City with Cyberpunk 2077 on PC, and let me just say, it's been an absolute blast. The story grabbed me from the get-go, pulling me into a gritty, dystopian world where every choice feels like it carries weight, shaping the narrative in ways both big and small. It's this kind of storytelling depth that makes you feel truly immersed, like you're not just playing a character, but living their life.

The game mechanics are a standout feature, seamlessly blending RPG elements with fast-paced action. Whether it's hacking into an enemy's cyberware, trading bullets in a high-octane shootout, or just cruising around Night City, every moment in-game feels thrilling and engaging. The level of detail CD Projekt Red has put into making this world feel alive is nothing short of astonishing.

Now, let's talk mods. The modding community for Cyberpunk 2077 is vibrant, to say the least. Being able to tweak the game to my liking, adding everything from visual enhancements to entirely new gameplay features, has significantly extended my enjoyment and investment in the game. It's like getting a new game every time I try out a different set of mods, which is a dream for any tech enthusiast and gamer.

In conclusion, Cyberpunk 2077 is a must-play for anyone who's a fan of deep stories, engaging mechanics, and the freedom to mod. Despite its rocky start, the patches and updates have transformed it into a title I highly recommend. Whether you're in it for the narrative, the action, or the sheer joy of customizing your experience, Cyberpunk 2077 delivers on all fronts. Definitely a game I'm glad to have in my collection.

After ~105 hours of play time in which I completed nowhere close to all the 'interesting' content the game has to offer, I feel.

I feel slightly disappointed, I feel the game did not live up to its potential, that developers took the easy way out, and I feel conflicting emotions, but nevertheless, I feel. I can't recall the last time a game made me feel something. And that seems to be a common trope with CDPR. Despite all their flaws and shortcomings, their games make me feel. Perhaps that in itself should count for something.

The game is an extremely entertaining fps, with an elaborate narrative that, if you're anything like me, will leave you with a range of emotions, some positive, some negative, but it's a game I would ultimately recommend playing.

OK, in all honesty while  it says I only have 29 hours on steam I've been playing this game from launch. I probably have over 400 hours across all versions and I still didn't do everything yet or touch the DLC content.

 Originally I played on the cloud back when it launched and I was shocked by how the game manages to tell a story that could seamlessly be the plot to an action movie. Even with all the bugs it wasn't game breaking and it was a nice escape from reality winter 2020.  Then time passes, things got better and eventually the cloud service went under. They were cool though so I got a refund and then purchased this game on console to continue my adventures as V. After a 1.5 year break that itch for Cyberpunk was calling again and I decided to treat myself to CP2077 on PC. YES THIS GAME IS GOOD I LITERALLY BROUGHT IT 3 SEPARATE TIMES . (As a broke ass 20-something. If that doesn't say enough why are you still scrolling ya gonk? Just get the game already and be prepared to have a good time.

Most of the time I'm having fun with the game. Driving around Night City on my bike feels great, and I haven't used fast travel more than a couple of times during my entire playthrough - in stark contrast to Witcher 3 where travelling was so tedious I went out of my way to install a mod to allow fast travel from anywhere.

I've only ever played patch 2.11, so I don't know what state the game was in before that, but apart from three crashes during a 50-hour playthrough, I haven't encountered any game-stopping bugs. But I've encountered a few amusing ones: once my bike caught fire somehow and kept burning for several in-game hours before it exploded; I saw a homeless person hanging around and chilling out though he'd caught fire from standing too close to a campfire; I saw a traffic accident where one car t-boned another car and was launched about 20 metres into the air, flying above an overpass, and exploding when it hit the ground; that sort of funny little things... 

However, the game has one significant flaw: Johnny Silverhand, the GM's edgelord Gary Stu who's more central to the plot than you are, and who is an obnoxious, abusive douchebag without any redeeming features throughout the game - except at the very end where he for some inexplicable reason does a near-complete turnaround and becomes only extremely irritating for his final scene. I guess the devs thought that "hey, he looks like Keanu Reeves and is voiced by him, so everyone likes him (or will not at least actively hate him)", but not quite - he's not even an antihero, he's just an utter twat. Having finished one playthough, I'm seriously contemplating whether to ever start another one, because I absolutely loathe the character - which is a shame, because otherwise, the game has quite a lot to offer.

So, I'm recommending this with the caveat that if you can't ignore an obnoxious asshat character that butts into your game and ruins the flow of it from time to time, don't buy. On the other hand, if you have a high tolerance threshold for that, the other parts do mostly make up for it.

Gave this game another go recently, and I'm so glad I did!

There's SO much to do - if you want to do it, that is. There are storyline missions, but you can just ignore them and go for a wander if you want. I do that sometimes, just to take in the stunning scenery. Honestly, the level design, the graphics, and ambience, it's all superb. I often just load up Cyberpunk so I can take a stroll around Night City and admire just how beautiful it is.

Of course, I do the odd mission when the mood takes me! The battles and gunplay are great fun, especially when you start upgrading to automatic weapons. Even taking a walk down the wrong alley at the wrong time can end up in a glorious gunfight - with lots of goodies to collect afterwards.

I'm still in the early stages (story-wise) but I'm savouring every moment, and deliberately not barrelling through the missions. I want to make it last, because I'm just enjoying it so damn much. Absolutely stunning game.

(edit)
I said this 4 years ago when the game came out, I have not changed it at all. After 4 years, I still come back to this game. The city, the people, the characters, the romantic partners (mainly Panam), the combat system, the loot, THE HUGE LORE. This game has been polished more that any shoe out there. I find myself on my second preview just to relive the story. No game has ever sent me down so much of an emotional roller-coaster as this one. I couldn't stop thinking about it for weeks. Somehow the game is as beautiful as i remember, from the night lights, the ads, the detail, to even the sand dunes on the outskirts. Its a stunning view everywhere you go. Without spoiling anything, the endings make or break your emotional stability. And as i said, the characters! They are the highlight for me, you can really tell how much work the devs put into them. I think they might even be real. The combat is flawless now, gunplay is fun, the melee is good (mainly the dismemberment system), the hacking is a thrill. I wish i could find flaws in this game like you could at launch. I strongly recommend this game. It changed gaming for me, almost as much as it changed me back in 2020. My favourite game of all time. If you want a happy game, this isnt really that, just as Johnny Silverhand said, "Wrong city, wrong people". 
Thank you for reading, and I hope you enjoy it jsut as much as i did.

I am a 58 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 40 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching Ukrainian men French kissing canines on YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Looks like skipping this game for the first 3 years paid off, since the Witcher games have taught me that it's always better to wait for an "enhanced edition". Maybe Cyberpunk 2077 had a shaky start, but as of this version and all the revisions, with the expansion, this game is an absolute masterpiece.

I've loved the Cyberpunk 2020 setting for three decades, Transmetropolitan is one of the best graphic novels ever and I've watched Fight Club more times than I can count. I didn't expect to see all of them reflected in the game. I still didn't expect I'd love Cyberpunk 2077 this much, but it totally got me.

These days, basing a massive game (with a major budget) on 30+ years of old RPG lore just doesn't happen. I was falsely under the impression that 2077 would be a soft reboot, since the attitude of "this much backstory could be a burden in attracting new players, so let's just scrap the old lore" is so common these days. (Fuck you, James Workshop.) I was pleasantly surprised when I realized that pretty much all of the stuff from Cyberpunk 2020 is still canon and even a major part of this game's main story.

If you want maximum appreciation of the setting, in the Steam version's bonus content you can find a complete scan of the Cyberpunk 2020 original rulebook. While most of this time capsule will make you appreciate the details of 2077 worldbuilding, I'd recommend at least reading the short story/adventure "Never Fade Away", originally published in 1988.

The last time I got this emotionally invested and immersed with a game's story and characters was probably back with Mass Effect 2. The Witcher 3 got close, but I like Cyberpunk 2077 even more. The saying "In Cyberpunk, there are no happy endings" is quite true. Half of the possible endings had me in bittersweet tears and the rest were so cripplingly depressing they should come with a medical warning. As it should be. Case never saw Molly again.

One other thing about this game that I don't think has been emphasized enough is the music. It's also something that nobody's dared to do. Instead of licensing famous old 80s/90s hits for nostalgic emotions (like pretty much any movie trailer these days), the music in this game is original. There's something closer to 15 hours of new music and radio stations in this game and it's performed by actual artists working under Cyberpunk pseudonyms, with the titles and lyrics in-universe. Hell, they've even recreated some of the bands and tracks referred to in the old RPG books. While this is already quite insane, the soundtrack just bangs with really diverse genres represented, from black metal to obnoxiously cute lazrpop. I don't think anyone has ever done musical justice to a fictional setting this well. 

This would be worth the price just so you can ride your motorcycle around the massive, detailed city (or ride the metro, I guess) while listening to the radio stations and soaking in the ambience of Night City.

This game is one massive love letter to one old cult RPG and it's so weird that it isn't actually made by greedy corpocunt suits who just want to chase profits. Work of art, really. Thank you, CD Projekt and Mike Pondsmith.

If you're into modding or creating your own mods then there is a lot of stuff available on Nexus, from tutorials/guides to flying cars, so pretty great.

Definitely recommend this, good game, can't wait for the next one.

It's an absolutely beautiful game. Negatives up front: The tutorial and menus and just ...how to DO things are infuriatingly terrible. There's no explanation, nothing makes sense (ex: want to decode a cybershard? Can't do anything from the cybershard in your inventory. It's in a menu you can't directly go to, and that you can only* go to by manually backing out of a different menu, but even then, the option isn't visible until you hover over an unrelated tab). The GUI/HUD of your game shouldn't be a Myst level obscure puzzle. It was so bad, I almost refunded a game I was super excited to play. It took a good 15 hours before I wasn't stopping every 10 minutes to look up how to perform some basic task on Reddit. Also, now I can't stop listening to gangster reggaeton and it's driving everyone nuts.

Okay, that said, I really enjoy the game, and how much variety there is in how you can play it. Wanna go full GTA with nothing but car chases and bewbies and doin' crimes? You can do that. Want to make thorny ethical decisions and try to fix society? You can do that, too. I don't like the driving mechanic, so I seriously just run everywhere (and fast travel). There's so much gorgeous detail (even though I have all the graphics settings on "potato" because my computer's a few years old), every neighborhood has a distinct feel and population and visual style. It really feels like a rich, varied world. 

I haven't finished it yet, because I'm a sidequest junkie, of which there's a good variety, and they don't feel like makework. There are stories you can follow throughout all the jobs and gigs and they have some continuity.

It is kind of slow starting out but once you get most of the way through you start to see how it all wraps up and just wow, I don't think I know of any other game with that much thought put into the story, let alone the details in the world to back it up. I would buy more DLC if it existed. [B]Well, the story and gameplay of cyberpunk 2077 are great, but it's not quite there yet. There are a few things in the PC version that need to be fixed so that players can enjoy the game more smoothly. For example, the optimization of the game, some things that only load when you get close, like a car or something like that.[/B]


[B]Apart from these things, the game is very good. I'm not going to wait for an update to fix all this, so I'm playing the game as it is and even with these things, I'm having fun. The story is very good. The current lack of optimization makes the game feel like you're playing on an old generation console (PS3, XBOX 360) where games ran at 30 FPS. Because it's not optimized, the game has this FPS range, from 30 to 45 FPS. I believe that once they release future updates, this will be resolved and the game will be even more fantastic. It's not unplayable like the console versions, which will practically need a patch the size of a new cyberpunk to improve. You can play the game, but there's also that, right? You have to make sure you don't find it a problem to play at 30 FPS. Well, that's all I have to say, I'll keep playing the game![/B]

[H2]UPDATE[/H2]

[B]They fixed the game after some patches over the time. Now, this game is fully functional. Beside that, they added a new expansion who bring a new story to the universe of Cyberpunk 2077, i recommend it to y'all. Have fun! [/B]

I picked up Cyberpunk 2077 and Phantom Liberty on sale after all the updates and patches.   The game is 99.9% bug free, the graphics are the best I've ever seen, and the city is not only huge, but also a work of art.  Every district has a different feel to it, but the transitions between districts are natural.  One play through with side quests is over 100 hours.   I didn't bother with spoilers, just played how I felt, and the game was fine.  It's a dark game, kind of depressing, but I expected that.  By the end of the stories, I'm maxed out on everything and just kind of ready to wrap up the last few bits.

It's one of those games that I could probably let sit for a year and then come back and play it a different way.

Minor negatives include that there's not much point in gaining new cars or apartments... they're cool, but that's it.  Relationships are limited.  There's no base building aspect or car improving aspect or anything like that, and at some point your customization of your character will be maxed.  And racing is done on rubber bands... if you get too far behind, they'll wait for you a bit, if you get too far ahead, they'll magically keep up...  so every race comes down to whether they pass you in the final stretch, no matter what you do.

But these are minor complaints given how 'full' the world is, how deep the story is, and how amazing everything looks and feels.  By the time I'm done with the game I'll have paid about 50 cents an hour for my entertainment... considering inflation now, you can't get a quarter tank of gasoline or even a small drink or slider for that.  Prices have, what?  Doubled or tripled on anything that matters since 2020?  So it's a pretty good value for the entertainment.

Update: March 5, 2022...Alright, reinstalled after this latest update to check it out. I still don't like the driving but that's just me maybe. You are either speeding fast or crawling, no in-between. However, I am now changing my review to a thumbs up. It is quite fun now.

Original review below but let me update this...
The people who actually worked on this game did an amazing job with the time they were given. The managers/producers are the ones that gave us all the finger with what they released. 

Teased 8 years ago, but I only found out today that they just started PRE-production in 2016 which means they did this in 3 - 4 years.

Story writing, voice acting, graphics (on high end machine), world creation: Top notch
Being able to live in that world...not great at the moment but I hope with a few months work will get better.


----Original Review----
Lie...I get why they had to hype it up, they spent so many years making it and it feels like a game that could have been released a couple years ago.

Cool story and I love the idea of it but it could be sooooo much better. 

I've had the same cop outside my building taking a statement from the same guy for many days. I died and came back to life (story) and they are still there. I pulled my gun out and aimed it on a sidewalk in front of my building and a guy next to me got scared and crouched down with his hands over his head; he is still there in the same position after days and days in game. multiple cut scenes with invisible props that the characters interact with. Car driving mechanics, wow, just horrible. At 30 mph your vehicle turns like you are doing 100mph, start turning at the light and you are going to hit the sidewalk on the other side. There are just a lot of immersion breaking issues.

I will keep playing and finish the story but man, it could have been way better.

Knowing what I know now, if you haven't bought this yet then wait a few months and watch the updates/patches they release. If they are working hard on it, I would assume it will be great in 3 to 6 months.

Cyberpunk has really been cleaned up since launch.

I can appreciate that this is a great game for a certain kind of person, but I am not that person. 

17 hours in and I am so absurdly bored. The map feels empty, I don't like the music, the combat is lackluster, the progression system is lame, the story is uninteresting, and I don't feel any sort of connection to any characters. I got this game for 50% off and I still feel ripped off.

Cyberpunk 2077 2.0 brings this game to what the single player should have always been. It's just a shame there will never be any multiplayer.

The update improves the game in almost every aspect except for the in game driving which is still guff.  It fixes many of the issues that plagued all previous versions and adds new features that enhance the experience. 

Night City feels more alive and immersive. The new police system adds challenge and excitement, as you have to deal with more realistic chases and roadblocks. The combat AI is smarter and more responsive. The UI has been overhauled making it more user-friendly and intuitive. The loot, items, and crafting have been improved meaning the stuff you pick up actually helps you progress in the game rather than just collecting a load of junk.  You can also interact with NPCs more and order food from street vendors. 

Cyberpunk 2077 2.0 is definitely worth your time, especially on it's current sale.

Just simple list of aspects I like/dislike until I "finish" the game



[b]Map[/b] - Probably one of the best cities I have ever been in. It doesnt feel like some boring ass grid-system city design. There is verticality, imperfect road designs, and it just feels NATURAL. 

[b]Graphics[/b] - This game looks fucking beautiful. I am playing with full RTX and this game just looks great.

[b]Gunplay[/b] - If you compare gunplay to destiny then this game will lose. However, it is more than good enough and is executed fine. It won't blow your hat off but it is FAR from bad. (note: the sens right now just feels off. Like there is mouth smoothing. I can't quite figure it out but its just a little off)

[b]Atmosphere[/b] - Idk how to put this in words but the city and the areas surrounding have distinct "vibes". You can tell when you are in a rougher part of town and when you are in luxury. It feels alive when its suppose to and "dead" when its suppose to.

[b]Music[/b] Amazing. Radio stations are great and the base soundtrack fits the scenes perfectly. Props for the OST

[b]Side Quests[/b] As you would expect, side quests are amazing. Some of them feel like their own main stories.  I highly recommend you complete them and tbh if you purposely choose not too, then you are missing out.

[b]Story[/b] - So far the story has been what I expected. I did not expect some deep level thinking and a story about what it means to be human. I was expecting a story where you just "experience" the city and the characters take you on a journey.

[b]Characters[/b] - All perfectly voice acted (the ones I have ENCOUNTERED). I can't think of an AVA (bl3) in this game so far. Theres no character I wish wasn't in the game.

[b]Main Character[/b] - (MALE V) I never expected me to deeply care about V and how HE's feeling. I am more playing it like I am the character playing through a vessel. If that makes any sense. Don't hate me but I just couldn't give a shit about geralt for the first half of witcher 3 so this could be like that but I have to yet to care about V like characters from other games. Thats OK to me, it hasn't taken the experience down for me.

[b]Johnny Silverhand[/b] - Skillup claimed the keanu was a miscast. His reasoning was we love Keanu because he is a wholesome guy. However, Johnny is an asshole badass character. I disagree with this claim that Keanu was a miscast. seriously don't care how an actor is in real life compared to a character they ACT as. I have loved every interaction with Johnny and I love listening to the comments he makes towards your choices.

[b]Driving/Cars[/b] - Really sucks there is no car customization AT all. It got scrapped during development. I do sincerely hope they add it in a DLC down the road. However, the cars in this game just all look sick and unique. I don't think most of them feel "out there". 

Driving feels "ok" with MnK. I have used controller and it feels much better after tweaking with controller options. However, I don't think its as bad as the raging twitter/reddit people would want to tell you. It's "fine". Its perfect it could use slight tweaks.

My biggest gripe with "driving" is how ZOOMED in the minimap is when driving. You are flying 100mph and then you gotta slam your brakes and make a sharp turn because there is no way you knew you had to take that exit. Then you end up drifting and killing 3 small children and you feel like shit ;-;/

[b]Performance and Optimization[/b] - With my setup (specs below) I get around 60-90fps (unless I am in the dense and high population areas.) I run the game at mostly high settings and RTX on with DLSS-Q. 

This game needs some love on the optimization side. I don't know how much more CDPR can do to fix it but there has to be something. However, I do think we will just need to wait for more advances with hardware until we can get 100+ fps with RTX.

[b]RPG Elements[/b] Will update what I think of skills when I beat the game.

Kinda sucks secondary stats have such little effect when all that really seems to matter is DPS. Would like more detail and work done to weapon stats. For example, why do the sights in this game have -0.05% reduced ADS speed. You wouldn't even notice that.

Transmog systems people. Its 2020 and this SHOULD have been in the game at launch. I can't make my character not look fucking stupid.

[b]Romance[/b] - Pretty fucking big let down. You only get one person you can romance per gender and sexuality. For example as a Male V (straight) I can ONLY romance panam. There is no choice or anything... that is it. I have heard that the Male V (gay) option is downright horrible, but youll have to see for yourself or research.

Not many choice with escorts (if you care). Very slight differences in each sex scene.

Panam is waifu <3

**NOTE**: There is a character you meet early game that you can have a "moment" with. Don't want to spoil it but you can look it up if you want.

[b]Bugs[/b] - Oh boy where to begin...

- constant graphical bugs and light flickering during certain moments.
- bug where when I enter the vehicle I am floating 5 ft above?
- floating cars
- cars flying 1000 ft in the air for no reason
- characters t-posing
- charcters just straight up twitching
- Cars driving all over the place (cars will randomly fucking swerve to the side of the lane or cross it and if you are on a bike good luck)
- during "cutscenes" and riding with other characters in vehicles. The car will not feel like its on the ground and they never follow a consistent path. You will just feel like you are sliding on ice or just straight up teleporting.
- Randomly switching from night to day or from raining to sunny.

TLDR: Mostly visual bugs and immersion breakers. I have only crashed once and I think it was actually windows with how it happened. To the people that are crashing just update your drivers and make sure you are not overclocking as much. I had to turn down my gpu core clock when playing cyberpunk. Ran just fine with other games until CB2077.

Who would I recommend them this game too? Well there are Categories

"I waited 8 years for this game and fuck everything else": Buy it now
"I have outstanding hardware and can handle the bugs": Buy it now

"I would rather wait until things are patched up but not too long": Check at Christmas and if it isn't there yet wait till February
"I would rather wait until the game is patched and there are 0 bugs": Wait till next spring or longer

"I am not sure I have the hardware to run this game":  Check benchmarks over the next few days and if you can't get at least 60 then you will prob just have to upgrade your pc. Doubt patches will have substantial impact on fps in the long run

Really sad to see that more content has been delayed. The game definitely would have benefited from another 1 to 2 years delay. Despite all the bugs and missing features that seem standard, there was still a lot to enjoy. The side quests, main story, and the dialogue is what I really enjoyed. I am a sucker for the cyberpunk genre. 

I still have yet to crash in this game or have any game breaking bugs. Again, at least 1 extra year would have done so much for this game.

Edit: Feb 2024, After phantom liberty which is the one and only DLC for the game, I can say this game has been one of the best I have ever played. I loved phantom libery, it was a great expansion with fun content and a cool new place to explore. The patches and updates since launch have been outstanding. IF you do ever play this game, please just take your time and do all the extra content besides the main story. You will have a blast.

I've changed my recommendation 3 times from no to yes to no. Why? This game has a good story, strong characters and the best facial expressions I have ever encountered in any video game. A fully rendered neon lit city without invisible walls. On top of that the graphics, the setting and the vibes are all great. Sounds good no? No. The game play is the problem.

I play with a controller and I play on the hardest difficulty. Game play is stiff with many basic movements locked behind perks from the skill tree associated with reflexes. This gives a poor first impression. To add guns handle poorly, the only firearms I actually enjoy using are double barrel shotguns and large revolvers. Cars handle poorly which extends to vehicle combat. It is repetitive. Overall I've come to the conclusion that for me, the game simply isn't fun to play.

Waited a long time to play this until after all the major bugs were fixed. So far on PC I haven't encountered any apart from the usual minor glitches you get with most games of this size and scope, objects hovering in the mid air occasionally or NPCs glitching out etc.

This is up there with some of the best games I've ever played. The story is well made, the voice acting is amazing, the scripts are all very well written, the world is highly detailed and large enough to feel like a true open world. There's also a ton of side missions to do along with the main story as well as lot of lore to collect and read if you enjoy that kind of thing. The combat feels great too.

Overall it now feels like an extremely polished experience, at least on PC and as soon as I've finished the main game I will be instanly buying Phantom Liberty.

The only one thing I would love to see in a game like this in the future is AI interaction wth NPCS like demoed in the Matrix Unreal demo. Being able to interect with the city inhabants would make it feel more alive as currrenty almost every filler NPC just says the same few selected comments when you speak to them which kind of defies the point of even being able to talk to them in the first place.

This game greatly reinforced my existentialism and psychosis, my gratitude toward not living in an urban environment, my disappointment and depression toward the state of the world today and its daunting trajectory, and my immense disdain for the hideous, global dystopia that humanity continues to paint for itself.

I found that this game's themes and environments were too persistently uncomfortable and hit too close to home while the open-world genre feels too dried up by now to instill any sense of incentive or motivation to commit. Very grimy vibes overall. Impressive graphical fidelity, though, and the esoteric, religious/spiritual/philosophical/existential themes and references were very on point.

I could go for a walk through nature, maybe plant some trees and flowers, maybe boycott everything and never play video games again, perhaps start shaving coins and defacing currency, etc. etc. etc.

Yeah, I think this game was the one for me. The final nail. I don't want to contribute to the materialist, tech dystopia that breeds unimaginable nightmares at our collective expense anymore. Some fresh air and a monastery far away seems lovely.

Great open world play without being required to obsess over the main story-line.  I have half a million eddies and some fancy gear but haven't done anything past the meet at the diner with Goro.  Just so much to do and see.

Opening is boring as hell. Fetch quests with no combat, no guns, nothing but running around and opening doors for npc's. That's how the first hour of this game goes. How the first hour goes is how the rest of the game will go. I'll buy never buy from CDPR ever again.

Don't feel like I hate the game.. I like it, i do.. And I love Witcher so I trust CD Projekt RED. .. However they have to accept they did mistakes.. baiting us for things they can't give..

[h1] TL;DR: Game good now. [/h1]

I am a day one player, I was there during the disastrous launch of this game. I can say without hesitation that my first experience was a roller-coaster of bugs, crashes, and frustration, especially playing on a PS4! It was a mess. However, there was something about this game that kept me hooked.

Despite the flaws, this game managed to captivate me in a way few games ever have. It became the first game I ever platinumed, something  that I never achieved with other games, and I beat the game not once, but twice! I am a sucker for a good narrative, and Cyberpunk 2077 kept me playing because of its storytelling and characters and its fascinating world.

Fast forward to 2024, I am revisiting the game again (for the DLC), starting my third playthrough, this time on PC. With the recent updates, the transformation is remarkable. The world feels more alive, the improvements evident in every corner. Quality of life updates have polished the experience, making it smoother and more enjoyable than ever.

To those still on the fence about diving into Cyberpunk 2077, now is the time. The game has evolved from its troubled beginnings into something truly special. The narrative depth, the immersive world, and the unforgettable characters make it an experience worth having. Despite its rocky start, Cyberpunk 2077 has secured its place as my all-time favorite game!

I don't even know where to start with this game.
Short answer? ∞/10.  It has officially overtaken RDR2 as my favourite game.
Long answer?
Broooo, you've gotta play this game. This was actually my second playthrough since I bought it on steam after the 2.0 update. I had a great time during my first playthrough but I did not enjoy it as much as I did now, not sure why that was the case.
The story? ABSOLUTE FREAKIN BANGER.
Characters? Man I spent hours talking to them and hanging out with them. They feel real and I wanna hangout with them IRL.
Graphics? Literally next freakin gen, every single place looks beautiful. I probably spammed a bunch of SS as well. I literally spent hours just roaming around and chilling taking in the view, that's how stunningly beautiful the world is.

The game has insane replayability with all it's various gameplay mechanics. Want a stealth build where you drop in with your throwing knives and take them out one by one? Or want to run a david martinez setup? Or how about a high level netrunner hacking everyone in seconds? Sooo many fun aspects in the game to check out and try new things. I love that. I love that so much.

I mean I sat and finished side gigs, side missions and played through every main character's story arc cause of how fun and unique all of it was. Especially the missions that play with your morality scale. "The lesser evil", cannot be put better in perspective than some of these side missions. I don't want to spoil anything for you, but please, please do yourself a favour and try not to just play the main story. Explore the world and do side quests, you will not regret them.

That being said, there is a massive issue to all of this. Once you finish playing the game, you feel empty af. Like you've lost a friend, it's way too immersive that it took me a while to get used to other games. 
Honestly, if this game released in it's current state back when they officially announced it, people would have gone crazy over how awesome it is. Kinda sad that it did not reach it's potential glory and become a legend due to corporate XD.

But yeah, that's really it, there isn't much to say without spoiling anything. Just play the game. Enjoy it :D
