So this game has a lot of pros and cons.  For me, personally, the cons outweigh the pros.  Overall, the game is very Meh.  The game play is OK, and it certainly has SOME entertainment value.  I took the time to 100% it afterall.  Well let me go over some of the pros and cons.

**edit**  Bonus negative points for adding a payed DLC that included more achievements.  I 100%ed it before phantom liberty came out.

CONS

The difficulty curve is not very well laid out.  I played the game on hardest difficulty and found that the beginning was too hard and the end was too easy.  I had to play the beginning almost entirely through stealth and sneaking up on people, but by the end I could just storm through everything.  And when I say the end, I mean pretty early on.  In fact, most of the quests in the game begin to feel very quickly monotonous and a lot more like a chore than a challenge.  And I could have gone about doing it in multiple ways, whether I wanted to do it through hacking or slashing, pun intended.

And this leads to a second con...  The level cap is stupid.  Why design the game so that you can't get everything.  I understand why you can't respec as it would open up too much cheese, but preventing people from experiencing all the possibilities in one play-through is dumb.  Especially considering how repetitive the game becomes.

A third con, the story ending all kind of just plain suck in my opinion.  Like, there really is no happy ending.  There are just some that are less bad.  This, to me, just feels really not good.  If I am going to invest so much time and effort into a story and working for something, for it to end in such a shitty way kind of feels like the whole thing was just a waste of effort.  "Congratulation, you get a month of kind of happiness before you die" as the best ending is just crap.  Seriously, F that.

So when talking about story telling flaws, I have to touch on some personal pet peeves of mine.  The fact that I cannot romance the girl as a guy is just dumb.  Hear me out here.  This is a fantasy game.  A game people play to experience a fantastic or phantasmal reality.  Please, someone explain to me why anyone should be blocked the option to experience what they want to in the fantasy game.  girl on girl, guy on guy, girl on guy... why not just let them all be options?  To purposefully block a relationship option is doing nothing but pandering to the people who like that particular relationship option and blocking out people who prefer different choices.  If you want to put in gay background NPC's, sure... who cares.  Especially in this wold where people can change genitalia and reproductive systems with the sit of a chair.  like true gender swapping, not the lies that exist in the world today.  You can do that kind of stuff in a fantasy game.  So honestly, having a gay romancable NPC that limits her sexuality is actually anti woke really, as she won't even accept a gender swap as ok, because of what?  You voice hasn't changed?  The whole thing is just dumb.  In an attempt to cater to the woke mob, none of it makes sense.  And speaking of over-woke bs that annoys me, how does a "trans" character even make sense in this world.  I understand that trans issues are all over the place in our reality, but what the fuck??  This is a world where people are swapping their genders all the fucking time.  Sit in a chair for 5 minutes and get new organs.  How the fuck do trans issues even come up.  It's a FANTASY GAME.  Don't project this worlds issues into it.  Like, if it's not obvious by now, I am super anti-woke... but it's a fantasy game.  LET THE TRANS PEOPLE HAVE A WORLD WHERE THEY CAN GENDER SWAP AT WILL AND IT"S NOT A BIG CONTROVERSY???  Why project all the drama of our world into the game???  Just let people play out a fantasy.  

Honestly, who fucking goes, "I want to play a fantasy game.  In that game, I want to be bullied, harassed, and have no love partners that I like return interest in me.  Oh also, I really want the ending for the character I am role-playing as to be super shitty"  There is no grand satisfying payoff, at least story-wise, and we have this worlds drama shoved in our face.  It's unnecessary, and takes away from the goals of playing a fantasy game.

Also, all of the cars are dumb.  SO many cars, so much money, all very similar.  Buying new cars, apartments, in general was just a chore that felt overall very dissatisfying.



PROS

-Interesting skill tree... which is part of why it is so annoying that there are so many limitations on it.

-The game, at the times when the challenge level was OK, was fun.  Unfortunately most of the time it was too hard or too easy.

-It's pretty, if not a little repetitive at times



Anyway, I feel a little bad leaving a negative review since the company worked so hard to make-up for all of the games other problems it had at launch (bugs and such).  But honestly, overall, if given the chance to wipe my gameplay completely from my mind and know what I know now (like seeing this review) , I would have never played it.  So with that said, I have to mark it down.
Best game of this generation.

Well it's been 4 years or so since the game came out and after finally playing through the game I have some updates. 

To start, despite what many will say this game has not been "completely fixed", they haven't "gotten rid of all the bugs". This game is still a buggy mess and you will crash at least a few times/encounter game breaking bugs/Immersion breaking bugs many times in your play-throughs. Another issue I have is the 2.0 and onward updates broke nearly all mods made so far and there are ALOT that still haven't been updated.

However, this game is in a SIGNIFICANTLY better space compared to when it came out back in 2020. There are still some glaring and weird issues I have with the story like how little we get to actually interact with Jackie, how hollow the apartments feel, and certain quests feeling inadequate. The story has it's sore spots but kept me fairly engaged throughout, it's gameplay can be unique especially with the different play styles you have to choose from. 

I can finally say, especially with any sale coming up, that this game is entirely worth it. It may not be the greatest thing you have ever played but it can definitely keep you engaged for at least 60 hours at a minimum and get you fairly immured in the world.

Definitely think it is a great game now, especially after the Phantom Liberty update/DLC. Now I don't think its a God-Tier RPG, but it's really close to it. I hope that CDPR learned from their experience with creating this game, and I think that the sequel is going to be one for the record books for a better reason than this game.

This game is beyond fantastic.  Despite the tremulous release and the bugs still in the system, the developers have done a fantastic job.  I am excited to play the DLC when it comes out!

My initial review of this game was a very negative one, but after many many patches and a strong DLC this game is certainly one I would recommend to any person who enjoys FPS' or RPG's. 

While the RPG mechanics still lack overall depth the combat and gameplay loop are much more fleshed out now, especially with the inclusion of the DLC area/gigs. 

Not the genre-defining game it set out to be, but a very good FPS RPG with a solid story, great gameplay, and some good characters.

Overall this game rocks. It's a blast to play, super stylish, a little challenging on hard mode, and just feels really cool. You can beat it in about 30 hours and I put in 60 more just so I could get through all the content. In classic CDPR style the script and roleplaying aspects are just fantastic. Everything feels compelling. It's gritty. Your choices matter and, even if the ones that don't impact the plot's direction are always actually acknowledged repeatedly in dialogue, which just makes the story feel real.

Now the complaining part: Playing on Linux/Proton, even with a 3080 I had constant visual glitches. I don't know if it's because of Proton, but it seemed like about half the scripted movements weren't synchronized with sound, voiceover almost never synched with mouth movements, pauses between parts of dialogue, lots of weird jumpy movements, the same NPC model being used 5-10x on screen (there was one scene before a concert where I saw ~20 of the same fangirl model), tearing even with vsync on, weird bloom filter bugs, and a slew of other visual glitches that detracted from immersion. Despite that it was worth the time and playthrough 100%, but I'd recommend playing this on Windows where hopefully there are fewer bugs -- or writing back to CDPR so they can take another hundred stabs at quality assurance.

A super fun game that has been polished up very nicely since its initial release. This game will keep you entertained for hours on end, with an amazing main story, compelling and engaging side stories and a ton of different playstyles at your disposal. Melee, time slowing samurai wielding katanas, gunplay, netrunners hacking and making enemies commit suicide; there are many, many ways to build and customize your character. 

However, the game does have cons. IMO, the game is extremely repetitive. Most of the gigs are just "enter a building and kill everyone" type missions over and over and over again. You obviously don't have to do them all, but as a completionist it's very grinding and tedious. It suffers from what I call "Skyrim syndrome" where there are so many gigs and side missions that you can easily lose yourself doing a bunch, easily grow overpowered and get bored since the gameplay is extremely repetitive. Even on the hardest difficulty, if you can push through the initial punishing low levels and grind your way to a decent amount of money, with the right build this game becomes a joke. Netrunners can just hit tab and not even enter a room and kill everyone in an entire base. At some point you're just become crazy strong with an endless amount of money. After using your Sandevistan to slice up everyone with your katana in 5 seconds without even taking damage for the umpteenth time, the game loses its fun value. Even unoptimized builds just become OP at some point. 

Still, the voice acting and story alone is worth it, and obviously you don't have to aim to complete every nook and cranny of the game. Despite its repetition, you'll find yourself doing multiple playthroughs in order to try different builds and make different decisions. The driving is also a bit janky IMO. I give this a solid 8/10.

my initial review from launch in 2020 was negative (90 minutes of playtime). now in feb 2024 the game's in a much better state, i guess. it's good, worth playing. the world's pretty cool, story's good. combat's not much to write home about, at least until you're like level 50-60, and even then, i dunno. i did actually like the commitment to first person perspective. phantom liberty was great. seems like Deus Ex is dead for now but Cyberpunk 2077's nice in the meantime.

more:

i did almost every sidequest before beating the game and then got all the endings (except one that i apparently didn't meet the conditions for, but whatev). i was surprised how hard the endings hit, especially for phantom liberty. i had fun doing a bit of mild roleplay, given the opportunities throughout the game.

the combat usually made me wish i was playing a better shooter or better stealth game, since most of the time i wanted to play stealthily/non-lethally. if i actually killed as many enemies as the game put in front of me, it'd feel too ridiculous and unimmersive, so i tried to get by just knocking most people out. this became incredibly trivial by the late game with Overclock + System Reboot or whatever. melee was pretty bad, at least early on, so i didn't bother much with it. build variety seemed pretty good actually but doesn't really open up til late in the game, but with only one full respec available i didn't feel like getting funky with it. i just had some inefficient spread-all-over build and called it a day.

i wasn't too hot on keanu reeves after john wick but he nailed johnny silverhand. most people nailed their performance honestly. all the little facial expressions were real impressive in a game this big, especially in phantom liberty and especially with idris elba's character. i was glad that they had put the effort into making the conversations visually interesting like that, since they had committed to the first-person perspective. the phantom liberty theme song during the credits really knocked me out, man, i swear it alone did a ton of the heavy lifting. i don't really get emotional but that tugged even my heartstrings, man.

Updated review 2/20/2024

[u]12/5/2023 - Update 2.1:[/u]

It's getting there.  After the 2.1 update, I can finally say that I recommend the vanilla version of this game, flaws and all.  



Pro's:
- Graphics
- World design
- Voice acting
- The main story, sort of
- The side stories
- Gigs
- Apartments
- Clubs
- Arcade games
- Vehicles to drive
- Cop chases, if you're into that.
- Gangs in shootouts.
- Joytoys

Cons:
- Lack of player control.  The game is constantly taking control out of the player's hands during the main story.  May as well be a interactive movie really.
- Some side activities put behind a story wall (racing, rollercoaster, shooting gallery).
- Shooting gallery is a one-time event.
- Fighting arena is a quest and locked out once completed.
- Limited choices in the main story that actually matter.
- Extremely limited amount of minigames to enjoy, outside of questing and story.  Literally just a couple of arcade games.
- Everything feels static, even with the overhaul update.
- Lack of interactive elements in the world, outside of the story.
- Lack of drinking animations, outside of the story.
- Lack of eating animations, outside of the story.
- Limited activities to enjoy, outside of fighting, story, reading shards, and gigs.


This kind of game makes me wonder what the point of crafting an open world is.  A looking glass is quite boring to me, and this game definitely gives off that vibe.

Thankfully the modding scene really improves this game, but I refuse to recommend this game solely based on mods, as the vanilla game on it's own merits, falls short.

If you love Deus ex, you will love this game. Mixed with open world branching paths. This game really is a fully next gen game. The characters, the story, the world, everything is engaging. Gunplay is a bit hollow feeling, but the rest of the game is spot on.

Be Aware that you will need a beast of a GPU to play this above 1080p. I have a 3080 and only get 40fps with all on ultra. DLSS Quality mode ups that to a playable 60.

Bugs Bugs Bugs. The fact that I can't stop playing this game despite all the bugs is a true testiment to the great game that it is.

Story is epic, side missions also fully flushed out storylines. Loads of odd jobs and things to do at any point.

Graphically, this game is incredible. The first believable city in any game ever. However the bugs that plague this game do take you out of immersion.

If you haven't bought the game, wait till you have a PC that can run it. Would recommend waiting 6 months or so for bug fixes to come out. 

My plan is to smash it through and 100% it now, then play again in 6months or a year on hardest setting with a different playthrough/build when the bugs and performance are fixed.

UPDATE: Am playing it through the 2nd time now. And god damn. What a masterpiece. Best story RPG I have ever played. Even Don't skip cutscenes some times.

Thank god they continued development on this game after the bad launch. Praise to the developers and the studio for sticking it out and salvaging this masterpiece. Just goes to show how delusional CEO's and publishers have become with what's possible in what timeframe/budget. Awesome game, awesome art. Better open-world than GTA.

As someone who bought this game on release and replayed it again over the course of patch 2.0-2.11. This game shows that when the bugs and glitches are fixed what we are left with is a true gem of a game and story that shines evermore brightly thanks to the patches and support of CDPR over the last few years. Thankfully on launch this game had a solid foundation of an impressively breathtaking world, atmosphere, characters and of course the story. Even with it's "less than stellar launch" to say the least. CDPR still does have the ability to craft a story that captivates the player into the world that CDPR has painstakingly created over the course of Cyberpunk's years in development. Now after years of patches and a DLC I'd say this game is where it should have been at launch. There are still some minor graphical bugs that I have experienced in my current playthough ( patch 2.11) but nothing that will hurt your overall experience with this game.  Though the dialogue reputation system still isn't as fleshed out as I would have liked.

If you are on the fence to try out the game. I'd say with the revamped combat system released in (patch 2.0) along with the rich story and characters that CDPR has created from Mike Pondsmith's universe it's a gem to experience.

'Overpromise, Sell, Underdeliver'

CD Projekt Red made a concerted effort to salvage what had been one of the most disastrous video game launches in history. Despite their efforts, significant promised content is still missing from Cyberpunk 2077, even with the release of the DLC expansion, 'Phantom Liberty.' While I've enjoyed playing the game and have completed several playthroughs, it's unimaginably sad to see the vast potential the game has, while also being the biggest disappointment in my steam library.

'The fact that fixing bugs is now considered a redemption arc shows the direction in which the industry is heading, and it only worsens with companies attempting to follow suit.'

Amazing game!

Still ultimately a rather mediocre game which makes it bad when you consider the sheer amount of time, resources, and money was poured into this game’s development. DLC changes nothing. 

There’s been a lot of cope and borderline delusion within the gaming community that many have with this game after 2.0 and Phantom Liberty that I’m exhausted by it.

2.0 brought huge nerfs to many builds, guns especially. Melee was already the best build prior, now it’s the most viable build by a huge margin that requires the least amount of effort. 

A subsequent patch brought level-scaling into this “RPG”, transforming a game that was originally a cybernetic-filled power-fantasy for 3 years into an action game where all the enemies are bullet sponges and your progression is ultimately meaningless.

Cyberpunk also puts the least amount of effort into being an RPG. Your background doesn’t matter, you have no impact on the main story, and the story itself is extremely linear with many unskippable sections. Character customization is some of the worst I’ve seen in a AAA “RPG” and offers little freedom in character appearance.

Driving is a complete travesty. Vehicles seem to hold no weight or friction with the ground and the handling, acceleration, and braking is all over the place. Heard it’s better on controller but I shouldn’t have to bust out another peripheral to use a basic mechanic. 

Story itself is also notably boring and filled to the brim with pointless fluff due to how the endings play out. All of the endings within the game make all of your efforts meaningless, which means the game is a slog to play through again as you know the story is not only long but filled to the brim with ultimately pointless events. The writers also throw out all logic and previous established facts in favor of making dark, unfulfilling endings that basically spit in the player’s face.

In the end, Cyberpunk is still a bad game in my eyes. 2.0 may have made the game more stable but overhauling the perk system to be a worse version of the previous one, adding level scaling so that all of your character progression being pointless, and nerfing builds and weapons makes this game still bad in my eyes.

Hopefully Witcher 4 and whatever the ORION sequel is will be good but CDPR has a massive black mark in its image in my eyes.

(Post final updates) The new stamina System kills melee combat for me for 100%, you can get 3 swings in before feeling like a wet noodle with your swings... only until late game do you feel like you can swing your sword around before rework patch, I was cool with the cyberware changes but melee feels boring and unfun now. this takes my review from a 5/5 to a 2.9/5, the gunplay is passable but nothing out of the ordinary and hacking everything to death from a distance feels boring to me. **((Review below was before Rework!!! apply this review if you are playing cyberpunk pre-rework))**
On my 2nd play-through basically doing mostly every side gig and crime spots and getting to max level and i intend on doing a 3rd and maybe a 4th, 5th, etc after installing some mods, to make it clear, ive played the game twice before considering mods for a few reasons; 

1) DLC. Any updates to Cyberpunk will likely break any mods you install so ive been waiting on DLC announcements, seems likely to drop around Q3/Q4 this year. 

2) Wanted to enjoy the world in its "vanilla" state without modding, helps you understand the basics and how the game operates as an RPG shooter, even discover tech like mantis blade hoppin for faster moment in the streets or relying on base rarity satori for the entire first playthrough and pretending to be Genji half the time. 

While i recommend this game~ i suggest get it on a sale as this game isn't without it's "quarks".

The police in this game without mods are terrible, they can't even chase you in cars cause they have no driving A.I. other than scripted events and when you commit crimes cops spawn out of thin air literally behind you, ie where you currently are not looking towards, while that kinda kills immersion, you'll end up not wanting to do your typical "GTA rampage" in this game cause its just not fun to fight the police. 

Game subtly breaking in ways over time(Menus taking longer than normal, slow downs happen, drop in visual fidelity, map waypoint acting goofy as heck, terrain popping), good thing there are many times it "auto saves" and has multiple backups in case things go south, which playing though the game once or twice will train you to notice when this is about to happen so you can preemptively restart the game at a safe spot. 

and a common problem is sometimes the elevator buttons break cause they're tied to a graphics bug and it doesn't let you press it cause the screen prompt never changes or stays black. fixes upon reloading a save. 

While i have listed all these negatives about the game, Fans can come though can pump more life into a game you really find fascinating and that's another reason why i've waited on modding, cause i wanna enjoy this world as long as possible~ i wanna keep exploring Night City, have over 250 hours playing up to my second character so far and even now when i drive around the city, it still feels so unfamiliar that i wanna keep driving around, cruising all the streets to see whats around the next block, it's just so vast that you truly feel like a tiny grain of sand in a giant world. 

Even if you just play the story once, very much worth it just to have as a game you can then chill and have a fun time cruising Night City's streets.
Compatibility issues

It's such a shame that this game had such a terrible launch. What we have now in 2024 is absolutely an amazing game. Everything from sounds, visuals, game-play and story all line up great. With my 2080S and R9-3900X, the game runs fairly well on High settings (cant do ultra/ray-tracing etc), I had a solid 60fps for *most* of the game, with noticeable drops only in the high clutter areas of the DLC zone. Sound quality is great, loved all of the musical choices, with the voice acting work being amazing. I think Keanu Reeves and Idris Elba absolutely killed it in their roles. 

Game play is fun and the various skill trees feel diverse enough that each tree feels distinct. I personally did a throwing dagger build for my hard play-through. It was a bit clunky at first, but once I got a few of the perks and decent daggers, it was amazing being able to run around and chain stun and/or one-shot mobs. 

I also have to mention that the DLC Phantom Liberty is possibly one of the best DLCs I've played. It doesn't necessarily add much in the way of new game-play content like some DLCs might, but the additional story that you get is fantastic and the final shootout scene was so good.

Hey, choom. You're here to figure out if this game is worth it or not. I got you. I'll give you the facts, then how I feel about it. Here goes. 


STATS: Tiered from S+ to F- (S,A,B,C,D,F)

Sound: S
Graphics: S
Optimization: B+
Bugs: B+
Gameplay: S-
Story: S+
Immersion: S+
Characters: S

Overall : S

FEELINGS:

Best game I have ever played. Never felt more like I was part of their world. So much to do. So much to see. nothing, and I mean nothing wrong with taking the back streets (there's a lot to do there). The game is so choc-full of interesting things to lose yourself in, it's almost overwhelming how much people throw at you, to the point I seriously considered just shutting my phone off and going back to my apartment to sleep (in-game). Amazing. 

Besides that, the city and the people just draw you in. (Almost) everything looks amazing, and it's backed up by an incredible soundscape that absolutely immerses you into the beautiful hellscape that is Night City. If you've got at least a decent GPU, you can crank it to 11 and forget what reality is like I did. 

And the gameplay! AHHHHH! Swords! Throwing knives! GUNS GUNS GUNS! You can even sneak up on people and knock them out if you're an over-thinker like me! Million and one ways to approach a situation, and the game responds to it. Speaking of responding, this game has got Baldur's Gate-level memory and flow. I've had so many moments where I pieced something together myself, thinking I was clever, only to realize the devs had thought of that and accounted for it. That, and just... 10/10 storytelling. The characters... whew. Not gonna spoil it for you.

The weakest part of this game are two issues: hardware optimization and the bugs that show from time to time. First off, the game hogs CPU. I have an 11700f and it can get as high as 97% usage while playing. Whew. I played around with the graphics settings a little and managed to get my benchmark at a smooth 59 average FPS, only to notice I was still getting 8-10 frame drops in various parts of the city. Weirdly enough, turning some settings back up brought the frames back. Completely backwards, but good... I guess? 

There also seems to be a small memory leak somewhere, as I start losing frames around maybe the two-hour mark. Which leads me to my next issue: the bugs. Janky shadows, footstep sounds disappearing now and then, weird physics ragdolls and uncanny twists/movements. once saw two stacked boxes start vibrating and spin on the spot. Not sure what happened there. Anyways. There are probably more bugs that I've missed, but while I can say they can be annoying, the rest of the game is so good I really don't hate these bugs like I might otherwise. Cyberpunk really is that good. 

P.S. I've had one, singular crash. I smacked a boss enemy as they were crossing a barrier and that just absolutely toasted the game. No idea why. But in my 62 hours played, that's the only crash I've had. 


CONCLUSION:

Get it. Best game I have ever played. Never felt more like I've been part of a fantasy world before. If you like single-player games that you can get a lot of hours out of (and have a hell of a time doing it), this is the one.  

That's all for now, choom. Gotta delta. Got a city to burn. 
Sincerely, Venom Steak (aka Joe).

60 hours in. Finished main game and DLC. I would say that story in game is good, Just everything else is at best unpolished.

Combat system in many regards is dull. Enemies are bulet spunges and even headshoots are not so deadly.
While I get it when you fight some more mech than human enemies, when "normal enemie" after headshot from sniper rifle still stands and is able to alert others then I'm a bit "annoyed". Melee combat might be more "action paced" and I havn't give it proper chance, but still gun fights I would expect to be more action than constant drag. 
It can be changed with mods for way more deadly guns for both sideds, headshot is deadly also for player untill you are chromed up a lot. But game also assumes at few points that you can start fight without any cover vs few enemies and those points can be frustraiting to load save back only becuse you die just after start of encounter and got flatlined by some stray bullet over and over untill you get some luck with getting to any cover and regaining control over fight.
Would not count it as bad per se, just not my type of combat system. Also it might be better later on and I havn't gave it enough chance but after ~10h I was so bored in combat so I've moded it out just to keep playing at all.

Driving... I don't get how game with so much travel while driving can have so bad driving. Maybe with pad and more granual control it would be better but on keyboard it was very rarely plesant experience. While still not great I would say only vechicle that was "acceptable" are bikes.

Bugs. First ever I've played is in 2.1. So game is declared "finished". While nothing was geambreaking, few times I was forced to either to restart game as something gliched (blury vision stayed for good after relic malfunction, some quest locking item was not possible to interact with) or go back to previous save and replay part of game (I think it was only once). Sometimes it is enough to go away until lost sight of gliched object but if not save/load doesnt solve it, reloading game is required. And if you go far away from point of some decision NPC might progress with quest futher, so better to save and restart anyway.
Additionaly some minor stuff when car havn't loaded and npc riderd around without it, NPC havn't loaded in time on curb and I've "discovered their existance" only due to getting police on my tail for ramming them with car.

Interfaceing with world. Some guns/bodies my fall in to textures and be unaccessable. Some items are accessable only from narrow angle/distance and activating it might be a bit annoying. Some zones are simply of limits to cars, not blocked by some obstacle but car will stop on its own and wont go futer or will hit invisible wall, while on foot you can go through. While those were kinda places where you would not be expected to drive (like up stairs to some pedestrian zone) some visible obstacle would be better choice.

Endings. [Spoilers ahead, nonspecific but still]... [spoiler]While generaly I was ok with them, one is hidden. To access it you need to do one certain conversation in very specific way. And game doesn't give any hint to it while still you get comment later on suggesting it is kinda "best choice" to not risk death of any of friends. I just don't get why going solo is hidden option for last mission.[/spoiler]

Romance. I'm not attached to it's existance in game but it is in game so it is also part I would judge it by.
Untill choosing romance option it is quite OK. But after finishing main story for that NPC and taking romance option it felt so hollow. 
You can meet up just to only have same few lines of text constantly. 
I would expect to have some discussion about progress in story, getting advice/getting reaction to choosen actions.

A Masterpiece

After more than 3 years of patches and an incredible expansion, it's a full experience.

The gameplay is good but at the end of the day, it's simple.
It never gets stale, but won't change or improve much, throughout the game.
The biggest negative for me was the lack of visual body augmentations, and lack of unique clothing.
Npc's are walking around with the coolest metalic arms, legs, faces, and unique clothing that you cannot get access to.

Cyberpunk's themes of hopelessness feel really poignant at a time in our lives where we are inching towards the ultra capitalist dystopian future that is everpresent in Night City.
A hopelessness that everyone of us have felt toward a system, a structure that strips us of our agency, and makes us feel worthless.
The game is filled with tragic characters that are like us, fighting for their place in a world that detests them.

The highlight of this game are it's superb npcs, River, Judy, Evelyn, Panam, Jackie, Takemura, Reed, Kerry and of course Johnny.
With their own personalities, outlooks on life, fighting for their own cause, most of them against an everpresent exploitative structure.
There are so many moments with these npcs that are truly memorable and unique, [spoiler]swimming with Judy[/spoiler], [spoiler]wrecking the Yacht with Kerry[/spoiler], etc.

A really good game, hopefully CDPR learned their lesson and is able to iterate on what was done here, and their next entry in the world of Cyberpunk can be truly what everyone wanted 2077 to be.

Even though I really enjoyed it, the base game did not have much of an emotional impact on me. I could always remove myself from the experience. Now I know why. Before Phantom Liberty, the game gave you choice to raid Arasaka alone. You didn't risk anyone's lives except yours.

Enter Phantom Liberty, always kept me on edge, not knowing which character was going to get killed in the next quest, whether someone was lying through their teeth or being sincere. So Mi, Solomon and Alex all felt like true friends. Eventually you have to choose an ending which ultimately someone else suffers because of your choices. I feel so depressed like I had actually hurt a friend in real life. If Cyberpunk 2077 taught me anything, it's to not grow so attached to fictional characters. I'm going to feel the repercussions of this game for a while.

it's gr8 m8 !

... it's not as bad as I thought it was going to be, but it's not as good as it should be either.  Glad I waited for a sale but also glad I bought it.  I do recommend it and would say it's about a 7 out of 10.

One big issue is that firearms, at extremely close ranges, have a delay between when I shoot and when the hit occurs.  There should be no perceptible delay between firing and the rounds striking the target but it feels like it's somewhere in the 0.25 second range which is ridiculous.  That's the kind of delay you'd expect at a moderate range, not at a distance of under 50 feet.    A .22 rim fire round can travel at over 1000 feet per second, 0.25 seconds would put it at 250 feet, 50 feet should only take 0.05 seconds, and a lot of the shots I've fired, and had a delay on, are likely at 25 feet or less - a 0.025 second delay at most, so why is there such a massive delay for short distances?

The vehicles handle like garbage, it's beyond terrible.  There's no excuse for that and it's definitely something I don't like.  I tend to walk around a lot instead of taking a vehicle.  Yeah, it's that bad.

Crafting is pretty bad and it doesn't make much sense that you can do it anywhere at any time.  No crafting benches required.  Wish they'd gone a slightly different route with item rarity, it works but it doesn't feel like it's the right fit for this game.

The world is not empty, but it often feels kind of empty even in the middle of the city.

I kind of like the random stuff I can stumble across, like crimes in progress that I can choose to ignore or interact with but I have an issue with the items strewn across the world.  I find it kind of ridiculous that so much junk is just lying around that I can pick up or steal with no consequences.  I do like that I can always loot a few items from enemies, I tend to dislike games that don't let you loot what enemies have, but this game does allow you to pick up some weapons and items, though it's certainly not everything the enemies would be carrying.  I don't seem to pick up much ammo from enemies, or cash/credsticks for that matter.

Combat isn't that bad even with the firearm delay issue.  Character customization isn't bad either.  I don't mind the story so far, and in fact at times I really feel immersed so that's nice.  The UI isn't terrible but could be better - especially the inventory management.  I like the overall look of the game, and it runs pretty well on my older system with just a few things turned down a bit.

I did like the idea of the brain dance, and how you can go through a scene to evaluate things.  It was a nice surprise, I didn't know about it before I played.  It's done fairly well.

I do like the variety in gear, weapons, and options for dealing with situations.  It reminds me a bit of the original Deus Ex.  I can try to be sneaky, go in guns blazing, or use other methods.  Having a high tech skill comes in handy to bypass security systems as does being extremely stealthy or being an absolute physical beast or expert with guns.  They did a pretty good job, for the most part, letting me try to play my way - except for the few sections where you are forced "use this garbage pistol" instead of the weapons I actually have equipped.  That shouldn't be a thing.

So, it's no Witcher 3, but overall it's certainly not a bad game.  I think it was a very ambitious project that just didn't quite work out but it's certainly worth playing.

Cyberpunk 2077, the highly anticipated open-world RPG, offers players an immersive and visually stunning journey into the neon-lit streets of Night City, a sprawling metropolis teeming with life, danger, and opportunity. Set in a dystopian future where mega-corporations hold unchecked power and cybernetic enhancements are the norm, Cyberpunk 2077 presents a rich tapestry of storytelling, exploration, and player choice.

One of the most striking aspects of Cyberpunk 2077 is its breathtaking attention to detail in crafting the world of Night City. From the bustling markets of Japantown to the seedy underbelly of the Combat Zone, each district feels alive with its own distinct personality and culture. The sheer scale and verticality of the city are awe-inspiring, inviting players to explore every corner and uncover the secrets hidden within its neon-soaked streets.

At the heart of Cyberpunk 2077 lies its deep and immersive narrative, driven by a cast of memorable characters and morally ambiguous choices. As V, a mercenary seeking to make a name for themselves in Night City, players will encounter a diverse array of allies and adversaries, each with their own agendas and motivations. From the enigmatic rockerboy Johnny Silverhand to the ruthless corporate fixer Dexter DeShawn, the game's cast is brought to life with stunning performances and nuanced writing that keeps players guessing until the very end.

But perhaps the most ambitious aspect of Cyberpunk 2077 is its commitment to player agency and choice. Throughout the game, players will be faced with a myriad of decisions that will not only shape the fate of V but also the future of Night City itself. From choosing which factions to align with to determining the outcome of key story missions, every choice feels meaningful and impactful, allowing players to craft their own unique experience in the world of Cyberpunk.

Of course, no discussion of Cyberpunk 2077 would be complete without mentioning its stunning visuals and immersive atmosphere. The game's cutting-edge graphics engine brings Night City to life with breathtaking detail, from the gleaming skyscrapers of the corporate sector to the gritty alleyways of the combat zones. Combined with a dynamic day-night cycle and weather system, the result is a world that feels alive and vibrant, begging to be explored and experienced.

In conclusion, Cyberpunk 2077 is a monumental achievement in gaming, offering players a rich and immersive experience that pushes the boundaries of storytelling and player choice. With its stunning visuals, compelling narrative, and deep gameplay mechanics, it stands as a testament to the power of interactive entertainment to transport players to new and exciting worlds. While not without its flaws, Cyberpunk 2077 remains a must-play for fans of the genre and anyone looking to lose themselves in a dystopian future unlike any other.

Okay, after my 2nd playthrough of the game following the Phantom Liberty 2.0 DLC, I can confidently say Cyberpunk is one of the best open world rpgs ever made. Some of the best parts of Cyberpunk are the worldbuilding, atmosphere, and immersion. The story telling might not be the best out there, but I believe it to be far above average with a unique sci-fi theme. The game is not perfect by any means and I acknowledge it is most certainly not a game for Everyone, but some people will find it to be incredible. I suggest everyone to try the game at least especially if you're familiar with the cyberpunk aesthetic.

Like I said the game has flaws, but they aren't fatal to overall enjoyment of the game. In some ways the flaws add to the charm and identity of the game itself. It really feels like the modern day Skyrim. Not perfect, but a Skyrim with no jank would've been less iconic which is why we still see many people playing the original over SSE. Cyberpunk is the same way. Of course many of these flaws can be fixed with mods like the atrocious driving for example.

Despite its flaws, I feel that Cyberpunk more than any other game I've played, was built with a personal touch. I found myself increasingly more impressed by how many things were clearly constructed by a human with intent and not copy pasted. From side character dialogue to city scenery, level layout and cut scenes, I feel CDPR tried as hard as they possibly could to make the world feel real and lived in as well as give many side quests the same gravitas as the main story. The issue is a city has so much density and time as a resource is not infinite so the areas where sacrifices were made may at times make the game feel more low budget. I think this was the biggest negative for Cyberpunk and why so many people felt their expectations were not met, which is why I recommend going in to this game blind and enjoying it for what it is. People had such high expectations pre-release that anything less than a literal simulation of a real life future city wouldn't have measured up which is simply not possible with modern technology.

Ultimately Cyberpunk will be a memorable and iconic game for me even though many did not like it. The game is fun and worth it for the price which is really all that matters.

[SPOILER FREE] After about 100 hours in Cyberpunk 2077 and the Phantom Liberty expansion, I was very pleasantly surprised by the quantity and quality of gameplay on offer from CD Projekt Red.

To be fair, my first time jumping in was after the acclaimed 2.0 update from the game studio, so I have no experience with the game's perks and mechanics pre-overhaul. I had, however, heard the game was a crappier Grand Theft Auto clone with nothing new on offer.

And that is just untrue.

You can build your character with the perk trees and accrue different cyberware to enhance combat, stealth, and dialogue, yet the fundamentals seemed very similar to GTA. Still, the story still was intriguing enough for me to want more. The cast's performances were all of the highest caliber, the branching paths dictated by your actions and dialogue choices had that trademark CDPR handprint, and the world was so meticulously crafted, with each district and remote region all feeling distinct and having a personality of their own. And with numerous endings, you'll want to play it again because the satisfaction of completion is not enough, strangely, but because the investment you feel in characters such as V, Johnny Silverhand, Panem, among others. My only true complaint with the base game is that there is no New Game Plus mode, yet I suppose I understand CDPR's decision on that matter since it would break some of the lore and world building of the story that you experience.

As for Phantom Liberty, don't expect a bombastic shoot-em-up action FPS that I initially expected. Instead, a slow-burn (not boring, there is a difference) that delves deeply into the politics of this world, taking its time to introduce a plot enshrouded by deception, espionage, drama, and investigation, while sprinkling in the combat and action throughout tastefully. With elements reminding me of Mission: Impossible, James Bond, Alien: Isolation, Blade Runner, among other great political thrillers and spy movies, I feel this expansion aligned with what most initially expected with Cyberpunk's initial launch over three years ago, with an emotional climax that I didn't quite experience with my first ending of the base game.

I did initially play the first 50 hours of the game at no cost to me, borrowing from a friend's game library, and ended up purchasing the Ultimate Edition because I knew that Night City would be place I will return to again and again, choosing different lifepaths and discovering the numerous different outcomes I almost chose first time around, and discovering so much more that I know I completely missed. 

If you enjoy modding your games, you may also want to visit Nexus for a mod that increases the level cap (The cap is only Level 50 in the base game, Level 60 with Phantom Liberty) to take advantage of the dozens of shiny new toys and skills CDPR shoves into this mammoth of a title.

Parents' Guide: The violence is not extremely gory, probably on par with what you would find in a Bethesda Fallout game. The game does have quite a bit of sexual content, yet does allow you to censor nudity in the Accessibility menu (thankfully, as I have two young kids who watch me from time to time). The language is course and pervasive. Not sure if there is a mod that disables the coursest language (F-bombs, C-words), however I am sure they exist.

Overall rating: 8.8/10

When I first played this game it was maybe a year ago and I spent 20 minutes and quit, tried again another time but never followed through. I thought y'know the game seems cool but the characters are all assholes and I feel like people are just dicks when I start talking to them.

Overall I liked this game. I think it is definitely worth it at sale price. I was one of the people hyped for this game at launch and then disappointed by it. They definitely seemed to have fixed it with 2.0 update and it is worth playing.

 The main story is pretty short and I feel like you don't get a lot of time with your late game build even if you do all the side missions.

 To me, Night City itself was the real star of the show. Might be in my top five game settings of all time. Beautifully done, dystopian, Cyberpunk city. I would like a sequel in this universe. Doesn't have to be Night City but another futuristic city would be cool to explore. 

 Lots of good voice acting. I really liked Keanu Reeves' contribution. He really made Johnny Silverhand. There are tons of well acted side characters as well. I did not buy the DLC but it would probably also be worth it on sale. 

 Combat is pretty fun and varied, but, it is also easy to find the few things that work for you and just never, ever deviate from them. In that sense it can be a little samey if you don't force yourself to change things up. The automatic weapons (assault rifles and sub-machine guns) to me were kinda meh. The real fun, in my opinion, lies in swords, pistols, stealth and hacking, aka netrunning. 

 The time on this review is the time it took me to do basically everything you can during a play-through save a few things. I'd say I'm at 97% completion or so, not counting achievement hunting.

What a fantastic fps/rpg. One of my favorites I've played in recent memory. Fantastic characters, interesting quests (both side and main), intriguing story and satisfying choices all throughout. Gameplay had satisfying variety and I enjoyed it giving you the option to play how you want, even if it's not the most viable. Fun amounts of customization. Played it with the Phantom Liberty DLC, which I saved for last and was the cherry on top of an incredible game. 

I was also surprised how stable it was over my entire playthrough, with only two very serious bugs encountered throughout my 130 hours exploring everything I could find. Didn't have internet for most of my playthrough, but another compliment to CD Projeckt for allowing me to play the game without internet connection, and not even logged into steam, seemingly DRM free. Something you can't do anymore with any other AAA game.

Performance was also solid on my 2080 with only 4GB of vram, was getting solid 90fps with some DLSS settings enabled, but no visual hit to my untrained eye. Just make sure you have it installed on an SSD.

**Original Review** I have been waiting for the game devs to do some fixing and following the changelog on their website since release. Despite being broken at launch I didnt leave a negative review because I did think CDPR would do right by us in time and fix it. However, when I tried the game again most recently I had a revelation that I don't know if you can fix the games biggest issue through a patch - Its just not fun. Even when it hits all its notes, and this still few and far between, I just find myself wishing I was having a good time rather then actually having one. I have a lot of respect for the CDPR team and still consider them some of the best in the biz, but despite a good story and interesting characters, I cant recommend this game even as an investment for future patches. I'm not seeing a No Mans Sky or Sea of Thieves trajectory here and that makes me sad.

I refunded CP in GOG on launch. It was an embarrassing, buggy mess. Now I bought it here.

CDPR admitted their mistakes, rolled up their sleeves, and in time turned this game into a jaw-dropping, cinematic experience.

Writing, atmosphere, style, combat, exploration, driving together blend into a very impressive game.
CP2077 is not a "true" RPG - it lacks roleplay depth  and real consequences in dialogue. It is not really an immersive sim - there are no emergent synergies. It typically offers an illusion of choice, unlike Deus Ex.
It is a *mostly* linear, well written and directed cinematic experience.

However, CP2077 strikes a great balance. Every mechanic is satisfying enough to form an amazing game. There are quite a few approaches to combat and "classes" to play as.

It's a "Ghost in the Shell" futuristic type of cyberpunk, not a retro 80s or "near future grounded" cyberpunk.

My respect to CDPR for admitting and addressing their mistakes. Not everyone could pull that off. Chad move.

[h1]My thoughts on Cyberpunk 2077 revisited.[/h1]

After revisiting Cyberpunk 2077, I have to admit, my opinion of the game has changed. Yes, I still have to acknowledge the numerous bugs and horrible AI, but despite these shortcomings, I found myself enjoying the game much more than I initially anticipated.

I'm a picky gamer, and it's been years since I've spent more than a few hours playing a game per week, but with Cyberpunk 2077, I clocked in 80 hours of gameplay within the first week. The story is fantastic, the gameplay is exciting, and the dystopian setting is brilliantly executed. Even now, months after playing, I find myself missing the game.

However, after 100% completing the game, with all main and side quests, collectibles, and vehicles bought, I found myself with nothing left to do. This highlights the lack of new content since launch. CDPR's few updates have been minor fixes, and the promised DLC is nowhere in sight.

Additionally, there are numerous features missing that should have been in the game since launch, such as character appearance customization, relationships, romance, player choices, vehicle customization, and realistic NPCs.

Although I came into the game with high expectations, I still found myself loving it. CDPR didn't make the perfect game, but they created a world that caught my attention and kept me engaged. Despite its flaws, Cyberpunk 2077 is a game that I will not forget.

In conclusion, my opinion of the game is a mix of emotions, but the positives outweigh the negatives. I have changed my review, even though it meant erasing over a thousand upvotes in the process.

[spoiler]Okay, forget the bugs, forget the console BS, forget everything surface level.  I'm going to tell you exactly why this game is a massive pile of lies.
Every single thing that was promised through the marketing is either outright not in the game, or is hopelessly underdone, and the various bits and bobs you do get here are very poorly done.

Story:
V is NOT the main character here.  After the first few hours this becomes "The Johnny Silverhand Show" and everything starts revolving around him.   If you're obsessed with Keanu Reeves, you'll probably enjoy it, but if you were expecting a deep and branching storyline you'll be sorely disappointed.

RNG:
Pretty much every piece of gear you get will have totally random stats.  This goes both for container loot, enemy loot, and even crafted gear.  It feels less like a proper RPG, and more like you're playing Borderlands.  It's not the worst thing in the world, but it feels very out of place and leads to constantly changing out your gear after every fight.  Your loadout will never have any sort of permanence.

Lifepaths:
The lifepath system that was so heavily anticipated is totally pointless.  The first ten minutes of the game are unique, but then the entire rest of your playthrough will be identical no matter what lifepath you chose.  You'll occasionally get some extra dialog options, but they amount to flavor text and nothing else.

Romance:
You get 4 options total, but can only access 2 per playthrough depending on V's gender.  The romancable characters are pretty well written, but the sheer lack of variety is disappointing.

Customization:
Very lacking here too.  The character creator is lackluster, even compared to much older games, and you have no option to alter your appearance later in the game.  Clothing, weapon and vehicle appearance is completely out of your hands.  If you want to look like a cyborg, too bad.  You get to be a plain jane human with some lines on your skin if you want.

I could keep going ad nauseum, but I think I've said enough here.  It's not a bad game, but it is NOT the game we were promised at all.[/spoiler]

EDIT:
So, it's been a while.  Plenty of updates, and many more hours of playtime have gone by, and frankly these words are long overdue.  Do some of my original points still stand?  Yes, absolutely.  However, considering the No Man's Sky degree of glow-up this game has received, I'm willing to overlook my previous gripes.  I respect all the extra work that CDPR has put into this project, and I can confidently say this has risen into my top 10 favorite games.

Verily, noble denizens of the digital realm, attend closely as I unfurl my quill and summon forth a paean of praise for the opus known as “Cyberpunk 2077.”

In this tapestry of silicon and circuitry, wrought by the alchemists of CD Projekt Red, we traverse the neon-lit boulevards of Night City—a metropolis teeming with rogues, renegades, and rhapsodies. Behold, the protagonist, V, a mercenary of singular mettle, ensnared in a web of intrigue and cybernetic sorcery.

The tale unfolds thus: V, a cipher for our own desires, grapples with the specter of Johnny Silverhand—a rockstar turned insurgent, whose consciousness echoes within V’s neural lattice. Keanu Reeves, that luminary of the silver screen, lends his visage to this digital revenant, though his performance, like a blade dulled by time, lacks the luster of his co-stars.

Yet fret not, for the heart of this saga lies not in the stilted cadence of its thespians, but in the myriad quests that weave its fabric. Side missions, like constellations strewn across the firmament, beckon with promises of intrigue, heartache, and revelation. Each choice, a filament spun upon the loom of fate—shall we aid the downtrodden nomads or dance with corporate devils? To romance the rogue AI or unmask the enigma of a cybernetic ghost?

And lo, the cityscape! Night City sprawls like a dragon’s hoard, its skyscrapers scraping the heavens, its alleys echoing with whispered secrets. Neon glimmers like stolen stars, and the streets pulse with life—a symphony of chrome and chaos.

Yet, as with any grand opus, blemishes mar its visage. Bugs, like digital imps, cavort through its code, disrupting immersion and rending the veil of illusion. Alas, poor rendering! Alas, clipping textures! Yet, these flaws, like wrinkles upon a time-worn visage, do not diminish the soul of Cyberpunk 2077.

For within its circuits, choice blooms like a rare orchid. We sculpt our V—gender fluid, visage scarred, backstory etched in binary. Shall we wield the blade or the netrunner’s code? To augment our flesh or transcend it? The world, our oyster, awaits our whims.

And so, I raise my goblet to thee, Cyberpunk 2077—a flawed masterpiece, a digital sonnet, a brave new world where pixels and poetry entwine. May your patches mend thy wounds, and may your legacy endure like the echoes of a long-departed rockstar.

Fare thee well, Night City, and may your neon burn eternal.

Notes:
Graphics are excellent - if you turn on RT Overdrive, that is. Otherwise, they're still pretty good, but nothing to write home about. Aesthetics are where it's at though - the visual design of Cyberpunk is great and is very well-realised here.

Gameplay is fine - car controls are shite but shooting feels "alright" in my books. Wish the default movement speed was a bit higher.

Story is decent so far, but not as immediately gripping as The Witcher 3 or Baldur's Gate 3 were for me. Mostly carried by an excellent main voice cast and a decent, if mixed, cast of side characters. Standouts for me are Evelyn, Dexter, Jackie and Viktor. The protagonist, weirdly enough, isn't that fun to listen to after the initial cool factor wears off. My advice is that the female voice is better than the male one, so play a fem V.

The game is far less buggy now than at launch but still has some rather rough edges. I bumped against a ladder and died instantly just now. Weird. The game's performance also tanks every single time I bring up a menu, and the initial loading screens are laggy as shit too. That's on great hardware - a Gen 4 NVME drive, 5900X and RTX 4070 Super with 64GB of RAM. Alan Wake and other RT games seem to have similar issues with opening/closing menus, so maybe that's why.

I wouldn't pay full price for most games and this one isn't an exception. Get it and the apparently excellent DLC on 50% off or something.

Update Feb 2024 (Patch 2.11 + Phantom Liberty DLC):
Despite disastrous launch at 2020, the developers have been constantly updated the game and fulfilled most of their promises. Kudos to CDPR.

Massive overhaul to the talent tree, perk, and cyberware systems. Now each build feels more "specialized" rather than the original talent progression which feels more like cookie-cutter "jack-of-all trades". Although at the end-game (level 45+), the combat felt relatively easy (except the MaxTac team at 5th wanted star).

The Phantom Liberty DLC brings a fresh air with its amazing espionage story and superb soundtracks. The end credit song "Phantom Liberty" deserves award.

The graphics is still one of the best looking even in the 2024. Addition of path tracing really improves the realism.

Still unplayable and staggeringly uninspiring as an open world game. It's enough to look for 30 seconds and it becomes painfully transparent that NPCs are just a thin facade, without any life or real complexity programmed; repetitive low-quality animations and statically standing groups everywhere. And it's enough to drive around for 2-3 minutes to see horrible glitches and vehicles randomly spawning over each other, or into your car. Not to mention the random dead ends everywhere where super soldiers shoot you dead instantly - absolutely does not feel like a real city where you can drive around and reasonably get to places. The game even plots routes for you that you cannot use because at some point you reach "turn around, there is nothing here". Finally, the spawn system is incredibly primitive, constantly producing duplicate, triplicate, etc. vehicles and NPCs, further eroding any hope of immersion.

Generally almost everything that is not connected to the story line feels shoddily made, even after years of additional development work. Probably plays well as a simplistic, linear, story driven action RPG, but that's not what they aggressively marketed this game as.

🌟 Overall Rating: Very Positive

Having plunged into Cyberpunk 2077 in December 2023 with the fully updated experience, the Ultimate Edition and DLC in tow, I found myself immersed in a futuristic adventure. While the base game was solid, the customization options, particularly for the body, lacked realism. Thankfully, the modding community, with gems like HystBody, Unequip mods, Nightcity Alive, Realcollour III LUT and more, breathed new life into the game.

⚙️ Mods Enhance the Experience:

HystBody Mods: A game-changer for realistic body customization.
Unequip Mods: Adding flexibility and immersion.
Realcolour III LUT: Elevating visuals and atmosphere.
Night City Alive: More engaging NPC's and making night city worthy of its reputation. 

🎮 Base Game vs. DLC:

The base game was enjoyable, but the DLC stole the spotlight. Kudos to Kurt Hansen, Mr. Blue Eyes, and the DLC creators for a captivating narrative. Exciting hints of potential space and air travels left me eager for more.

👏 Shoutouts:

A salute to Kurt Hansen for exceptional work.
Tip of the hat to Mr. Blue Eyes for an intriguing presence.
Shoutout to all the modders. 

🌌 Future Expectations:

The DLC teased grand possibilities, sparking excitement for what's to come. Fingers crossed for space and air travels in the future.

🚀 Conclusion:

Cyberpunk 2077, with the aid of mods and stellar DLC content, evolves into a remarkable journey through Night City. A testament to the community's dedication and a promising sign for the game's future. Despite the base game's solid enjoyment, the need for mods to enhance the experience slightly hampers the overall score. Exciting possibilities teased in the DLC leave room for optimism. A futuristic journey with notable highs and a reliance on community enhancements.

🌟 Overall Rating: Positive (8/10)

I understand why this game has good reviews, but it wasn't for me. It's very story-driven, and I didn't enjoy exploring and do side quests much. That sense of aimlessly wandering in an open world and enjoying it just wasn't there, unfortunately. I bought it on discount and don't regret it. I'll definitely see through to the ending of the story because it immerses you nicely in the cyber world and story is top tier. However, as an RPG game, it didn't feel all that great. Also, there are quite a few small bugs here and there. Some bugs are minor annoyances, while others are pretty frustrating. I was happy to see that there weren't any game-breaking bugs, although my phone glitched once and I couldn't call anybody until I restarted the game. Personally it wasn't the game I was looking for, but for people who enjoy fps story-driven shooters with open-world elements, i would say its definitely a great game for you.

Like most things in life, timing is everything. I bought it on day one. Played for about 10 hours before realizing that there were too many things half-baked. Now, I know CDPR. They don't make mistakes like these. The bugs and errors that arrived during launch was simply due to them not being finished. You could almost feel the devs and artists at CDPR begging for this game to not be released. 

I put it away for about a year. 

I then made the wise move to complete Starfield. I know. I know. But it was a blessing in disguise. After finishing Starfield (which I did enjoy because I'm a masochist and I like boring old Bethesda fetch sims).

The news of 2.0 dropped. Then DLSS 3 support. The mod community was already hard at work doing their best to fix the game along side CDPR. All these moments created a perfect storm. In the end, we got an amazing game. Was it the fully promised game? Of course not. It never is. But this is truly a special game.

The pacing, the story line, the many options on how to solve a problem. It really does immerse you in the world. I love exploring worlds. I can just walk the streets of San Andreas or New Hanover for hours. I found Night City an excellent place to just wander around. To me, that is the hallmark of a true living, breathing city. 

It falls in the top 10 of all time, with RDR2, GTAV, Farcry3, and Skyrim as far as open world experiences go.

Haven't gotten to PL yet so no opinion there. Also haven't finished the game so no opinions there.
BUT, from the 11 hours I have spent on this game, I can't get enough of it.
When this game was being marketed, I really didn't care. I was too busy playing Space Engineers and reading Iain M. Banks' The Culture or The Expanse, and then Halo Reach was announced for MCC alongside a PC port of the entire MCC over the coming year, so that (and Halo Infinite's marketing) occupied my brain at the time.
Plus, my old PC didn't have a hope of running this game. It had trouble running the games I was playing for crying out loud, let alone a brand new game.
And then the virus hit, and everything (but MCC) got delayed. So when the game launched in late 2020, after a message stating that it would be delayed to 2021, I was surprised. And the launch was a steaming pile of crap.
The game was a bug-ridden mess with a lot of incomplete features, some of which wouldn't be finished until 2023 with the 2.0 Update and the release of the Phantom Liberty expansion.
But, the story was there and by god it was amazing. And I didn't care.
Over the intervening years, I started getting interested. I had a coworker recount his experiences with the game to me, including some story beats because at the time I didn't care to play it. I had friends play it. I watched Ghost in the Shell: Standalone Complex. Retook a class at college which reminded me that William Gibson's Neuromancer exists (and I still need to read what is often called the founding work of the cyberpunk genre, despite Blade Runner and its source material by Phillip K. Dick [grr steam censor I'm using it as the last name of an author and not as profane language] predating it by 2 and... many years, respectively). Edgerunners came out in September 2022 and I had friends praising it. And I still didn't care.
I watched Blade Runner, and I loved it.
Then Phantom Liberty dropped, and my friends adored it. And I was interested. At some point in time a friend and I, in partial preparation for him playing through TTW with mods, looked at guns from Cyberpunk 2020. They were kinda cursed. We also listened to all the music performed by Refused under the name Samurai, a punk rock band from the universe which began the rockerboy/girl movement. And it got me into Punk Rock as a whole.
And then the game went on sale in October of 2023 (before the Ultimate Edition released), and I decided to get the 2077+PL bundle.
Now I care. Now I understand. Now I've seen Edgerunners and yes, it is a fantastic show. Now I have Who's Ready For Tomorrow stuck in my head on the regular.
Now I intend to join a Cyberpunk 2020 or RED campaign with my discord buddies whenever that starts.
Now, I got the chips and enhancements.
Now, I got the attitude right.
Now, I got the metal beneath my skin.
I'm chippin' in.

Also there's a job you do for Delamain where you recover rogue taxis and one of them is just GLaDOS from Portal. That alone is more than enough for me to recommend the game, on top of the names of a lot of jobs being shared with songs I adore.
The guns are super wacky though. At least amongst the rifles and "heavy" weapons (aka LMGs). Not Fallout 4 Assault Rifle levels of wacky, or BSG Viper Tardis-ammo supply levels of wacky, or even Halo CE Assault Rifle magazine-size levels of wacky, but wacky nonetheless.
Cyber done

To start, after the less than succesful launch of the game, CD Project Red not only managed to make the game functional but also extremely fun. There are many playstyles to choose from, many ways to play, I believe that anyone can find a way to enjoy the game.
There were some minor bugs and glitches, like bodies and objects clipping thru the floor, but nothing that I encoutered thus far has been game-breaking, mostly just something that I could laugh at and move on. The stability has also been improved greatly, as before the game crashed my pc and I had to reinstall windows but as of the latest version, it has not crashed once.
Now on to the visual aspect, the game is stunning, now I was not able to use all the graphical settings this game has to offer but even then, it was an eye candy. My only gripe would be that there are sometimes some texture compression issues, for example, low resolution mud covering tiles that are in full detail is a bit jaring, but it is something that you notice only on closer inspeciton.
There were some severe frame drops, however I cannot definitively say that it was because of the game or my hardware.

All it all, even if tha price at the moment is a bit steep for my taste, I don't regret a single dime I spent on the game. It is a lot of fun and I definitly recomend giving it a try.

I bought the game on a 50% discount. And I have to say, if your computer is strong enough to run Cyberpunk 77 easily and efficiently, I recommend the game. The customization options are endless and great for creating a character which really speaks as yourself or someone completely opposite. 

And the story is beautiful, all the choices are so in dept and change the story further and it's so interesting to see a Cyber-futuristic world closely as it could be in real life within a couple hundred years or so.

Summary) If your pc can run the game, and you can afford the game. Go right ahead ahead. It's a great game, beautiful story and I love it. But I'd recommend to wait for a discounted price, just for the sake of saving money.

There is so much to say about this game. Peaking my interest after the anime released, Cyberpunk 2077 is not just a game, but an immersive experience with a complex narrative, driven by the player's involvement in the world. Night City isn't the most interactive or intuitive city in all of gaming by any means, but the latest updates really bring the world alive. Being able to interact with each of the gangs across the different sections of the city, engaging in high speed chases with the police or gang members. And I have to praise this games for its beauty, this game is absolutely stunning. Driving around Night City after getting every single ending and getting 100% on the base game, I can say with confidence that I still find it entertaining to just watch the beautiful world around you as you cruise around. I have many critiques of the game, especially considering the time I have dedicated to it, specifically in regards to AI behavior, and the lack of in-depth opportunities to explore the buildings in Night City. Some of the quests, specifically 'Pyramid Song,' has been broken since I got the game, and only functions with the proper mods installed. When being driven by one of the NPCs, it is likely that their movement will be stiff, and they will run over citizens without a second thought. V's movement can be kind of strange at times too, and if you want to see how weird it is just look ar your shadow when you are using mantis blades. It is kind of disheartening when the game breaks and you are engaged in the game play, but these bugs are very few and far in between. I would say that other than Pyramid Song, my experience with the game has been nothing but positive. I can't recommend this game more, from emotional stories, to interesting side quests, and most of all, Keanu Reeves following you everywhere you go. I've never felt cooler in a game than when I walk in a room and immediately kill all of the enemies as a netrunner. This game is not perfect, but I would say it is my favorite modern AAA game, and it does not garner the praise it deserves. 

Hope you all enjoyed this game too.

Certainly! Let’s dive into a concise review of Cyberpunk 2077 in 2024:

Title: Cyberpunk 2077: A Reborn Future

Overview: After a tumultuous journey from its rocky launch, Cyberpunk 2077 has transformed. The neon-soaked streets of Night City now beckon with renewed allure. Here’s the scoop:

Pros:

Revamped Stability: Bugs and glitches have been patched, making the game more playable.
Expanded Content: The Phantom Liberty DLC and the 2.0 update injected fresh life into Night City.
Engaging Story: Dive into a tangled web of conspiracies, personal quests, and moral choices.
Visual Splendor: Neon skyscrapers, cyber-enhanced characters, and gritty realism.
Cons:

My Honest Review After Finishing The Game As A First Time Player

I purposefully ignored playing Cyberpunk and all information regarding it for years till it could get massively fixed up (which the 2.0 update sure did). I went in blind to this game. I watched the anime and loved it I consider it a masterpiece 10/10. I went in with high expectations fitting a game like this. Could run it at 2k at 60FPS on my new gaming PC. I will make it clear that story driven games aren't usually my thing, I prefer gameplay driven over story driven, but on occasion I will enjoy a story driven game like Witcher 3. I also don't fan over many games.

Went with female V on a whim. I think the voice actor nailed it. I went with the corpo lifepath. Hard difficulty. Then melee mantis blades build as soon as I randomly found a ripper doc that sold them because I think that was the first thing that caught my eye about the promotional art of the game. I was a fucking blender by mid game, especially with the Sandevistan which let me casually take out like 6 people at once.

I very much enjoyed the game at first. Exploring and meeting the characters of this world, the early game twists and turns. I loved Johnny as a character and think he carried most of the story on his back, maybe too much because it quickly became all about him. For the most part I thought the story was fine, even if it felt like I experienced it a little choppy due to the strange pacing, traveling far from point A to B or getting into a fight or someone hitting me up to do another quest, on top of days of IRL work in between some sessions.

The more I played the more I realized how jank the gameplay is and dragged it down. At it's worst I compared it to being like Skyrim. There were many times where a fight happened and I was just like "Oh okay." then easily killed them by flailing around in the room then did a loop around the room looking at the floor to get their loot (Such a weird system. Why not have auto loot if there is going to be so many fodder enemies?). I did that shit dozens of times to get back to a long ass cutscene that sends me to another long ass cutscene then maybe a jank boss fight.

A few bosses just spawned oblivious allowing me to just instant kill them if I wanted, or standing still or coming out shooting backwards. The worst was 2 bosses that refused to spawn leaving me scratching my head as to what I was supposed to do to finish the quest and restarting and reloading back was the answer. Sometimes the yellow enemies on the street would attack me and when I killed them the police nearby would see this and aggro at like 2 or 3 stars which was annoying cause I was just questing.

Traversing the world was fun, especially with the charge jump and the motorcycle, but at the same time I encountered annoying stuff there as well, like hitting an invisible car and flying off my bike over a wall onto the street below and dying putting me 15 minutes back. Or getting a random enemy car driving me off the road suddenly and into the bay and having to very slowly swim around and find a ladder to climb out.

All these little things added up to be really fucking annoying and broke my immersion several times. Whenever I found myself getting into the story and gameplay some dumb shit would happen to break that.

The graphics are top notch. Some of the best I have ever seen. Voice acting is some of the best I have ever heard. Music was killer too. No complaints there. Those are some of the best parts of the entire game.

The main story is what I played most of, doing some other quests at random while waiting for the next main story contact to call back. Finished the game around level 37. The story was really good, but I don't consider it amazing. Johnny was my favorite part of the game so I did his quest line to become his best friend, which led me to the Path of Glory ending. I loved this ending. I thought it was awesome. V gets purged of Johnny, became a legend of night city, gets to live several months longer, and choose to go out with a bang. That is how I interpret it. We all gotta die someday. That's a fact.

I was massively disappointed upon learning what the DLC Phantom Liberty was. The way it was hyped up I thought it was going to be a Witcher 3: Blood and Wine level expansion. Like a huge expansion of the game. Something V does after the main game somehow. It isn't that at all. I was so let down by learning that I didn't even bother playing it. I didn't give a fuck by that point lol.

The only boss fight that I genuinely loved in the game was Adam Smasher. He was awesome. There was story buildup to him and he lived up to his legend. He was powerful, scary, merciless. Took me a few tries and I was genuinely enjoying fighting this killing machine head to head with my build. Then this stupid shit happened and just filled me with hate. When he entered phase 2 he got himself stuck in the air and I easily killed him after that point. The height of the gameplay felt like it ended on a wet fart. Here is the infamous picture I took of it.
r/cyberpunkgame - My Honest Review After Finishing The Game As A First Time Player

It was also weirdly mind blowing to me to learn that this game doesn't have multiplayer of any type and procedural generated missions or side activities to do with them GTAV style. It feels like this game was made to be that type of place where like 50 players could all be hanging out doing stuff if they wanted, showing off their builds and fashion. Like hanging out with your friends in Night City would be awesome. That would have made me give the game a bonus point for the community interactions.

Gameplay: 1/2 Graphics: 2/2 Music: 2/2 Story 1/2 Fun 1/2.

7/10 Total score: Good. I think it is a genuinely good game with the potential to be amazing.
