After it's inexcusable launch condition, it's tumultuous life from it's first patch to update 1.63, and to the Golden Standard brought in 2.0 that should have been the game at launch, I can confidently say that Cyberpunk 2077 is [b]DEFINITIVELY[/b] CDPR's greatest game.

Completely different game in 2024 to the one we've had from 2020-2023. I would say it is fair to completely dismiss the merit of all reviews before version 2.0 launched in late 2023 due to being mostly outdated. 

If you love CDPR's games, RPGs, First Person Shooters, and even a mix of all three, then surface level, this game is for you.

I wouldn't have recommended this game back in 2022, but I definitely recommend anyone who loves RPGs or Single-Player FPS to pick this game up now. I believe that the game w/ it's DLC is worth the full price of admission, but nevertheless I would always recommend getting games on sale, and if you catch this on sale, don't even hesitate, buy it.

This is probably my absolute favorite game on this planet but still it was a hard decision to say I recommend it because of a very crucial flaw. This review will contain heavy spoilers about the ending so please, if you don't want to read that stop now.


On the plus side, this is probably the best game I ever played. The atmosphere, characters, stories, graphics, action, it all comes together to create one big amazing blast of a game. It actually reminded me partially of living in California. The team must have had heavy design advice from people living there or did their research pretty well. I could write pages about all the good things, especially after they got rid of all the bugs. I clocked in 81 hours and still think I will play one of the endings again or look for missed side-quests just to have some closure. Which brings me to the big negative part.

Again, spoiler alert, this is about the endings. For a game of this grandeur I really don't understand why they must have thought long and hard how to give people the most depressing, unsatisfying miserable ending they could have come up with. 

Early in the game it becomes clear the main character is dying. So what is now clearly priority number one. Not dying! All the time the player's quests are some part in some elaborate grand plan how he could potentially avoid his demise. In the normal game with the normal endings however, that will just not happen. The best thing possible is to help everybody who is dear and near to him to escape into some peaceful wilderness to start a new life, which obviously won't be very long for our hero but that is not shown. So there is at least a hypothetical ending where after some miracle happens.

So Phantom Liberty comes out and one of the earliest things the player gets sold on again is, a chance of not dying. Cool so the player fights long and hard, infiltrates parties, makes tough decision who to support and in the end it's again for nothing! Either the player is back to the situation before the storyline departed into the add-on, which means they will probably die, or they won't die .... but...

So now comes the part why I almost want to say I do not recommend this game. The game designers must have thought hey, we have this ending here where the hero does not die but that's actually too nice for the players. We need to add a few plot twists that they feel miserable and know his life is still f**ed up. Ok, number one, take away all friends and lovers. That's not enough... ok take away all his equipment and invent some illness why he never can wear that stuff again which takes away his source of income and lets him be at the mercy of every small punk in the street ... wait actually make that point even clearer by having him beaten up by random strangers so everybody know the rest of his life will be miserable.  I really want to swear heavily in this review but let me just ask, why why why why why? There are also mayor holes in that story as well, it wouldn't have to be that bad but it seems the designers really wanted the player to either die or be as good as dead. 

So there you have it. On one hand the best game I ever played, on the other hand all endings of the original game and the add-on suck needlessly and ruin the whole experience. 

If the designer ever want to repair this without spending too much time on it, do the following: After the showdown in Phantom Liberty but before the player gets the call to get the cure, allow them to meet Hanako at Embers. After having fled with Panam, call them about the cure. Player gets the cure, can fall into coma and not wear implants if you insist on that nonsense but after they could go back to the Nomad tribe and live somewhat happy in the tribe. Minimum extra scenes to code up and finally at least one halfway decent ending.

Of “Cyberpunk 2077” and Its Many Facets

In the year of our Lord twenty hundred and seventy-seven, a wondrous creation emerged from the forge of CD Projekt Red. Aye, it bore the name “Cyberpunk 2077,” and its visage was as varied as the stars in the firmament.

The Protagonist, V, and Their Unfathomable Burden

Thou, as V, didst step forth into the neon-lit labyrinth of Night City. A mercenary, a blade for hire, yet fate didst intertwine thy path with that of a long-departed minstrel—Johnny Silverhand, his name echoing through the ages. Keanu Reeves, clad in mortal flesh, lent voice to this spectral troubadour. His performance, though stiff as an ancient oak, didst anchor our tale.

The Cityscape, Aflame with Possibilities

Behold, Night City! A sprawling metropolis, its sinews woven of circuitry and vice. Within its labyrinthine streets, choices bloomed like wildflowers after a tempest. The central questline, though brief, didst pull thee inexorably, yet 'twas the side quests that whispered secrets in thy ear. Each decision, a thread in the grand tapestry of thy destiny.

Bugs, Like Fleas Upon a Hound

Yet, fair scribe, let us not veil the truth. Bugs, like gnats in summer, plagued this digital realm. CD Projekt Red, in their ceaseless toil, didst release patches—like salves for wounded code—but still, the maladies lingered. The Xbox One and PlayStation 4, frail vessels, groaned under the weight of Night City’s neon burden. Verily, I counsel thee to seek refuge on sturdier platforms.

Verdict, Carved Upon the Stone Tablets of Gaming Lore

And now, the crux of our tale: Is “Cyberpunk 2077” a gem or a tarnished bauble? By the scales of justice, I declare it thus: A unique and splendid RPG, its characters vivid as stained glass, its narrative a mosaic of intrigue. The freedom it grants, akin to a falcon soaring o’er the moors, beckons thee to partake.

So, dear reader, if thou dost seek a realm where neon mingles with the arcane, where cybernetic hearts beat in sync with the pulse of rebellion, venture forth! For “Cyberpunk 2077” awaits, a digital saga etched upon the annals of time.

I was enjoying the game until in the first mission of the prologue, The Rescue, where the AI partner Jackie soft locked my game. Right after taking out the boss, Jackie stood in the doorway I needed to pass through to progress. He would not move. Apparently this is a bug that happens frequently throughout the story missions if you don't move fast enough and the only fix is to reload the last quick or auto save. 

A ally AI that doesn't block your path is something that's been fixed since before 2004. It's a small issue, but it completely destroyed any desire to play the rest of the game.

Had a rocky start, but it showed how much the developers cared to put in effort to revive the game and make it playable. Other games should be taking notes from this, instead of focusing on releasing in-game content, focusing on improving the game is much more important. Cyberpunk really proved that a game can go from a 0 to maybe a 10.

In spite of a launch nothing short of hellish, CD Projekt managed to create one of the most beautiful games of the past decade. 

Cyberpunk 2077 has its shortcomings. Every step of the way, you are reminded of what could have been if not for the cluster fuck in late development. The main storyline is way too short and cut of much significant content. The side jobs are uneven in terms of quality and writing. The various gigs lack substance and get old after a while. The combat can feel weightless at times : shooting a shotgun rarely feels good.

And yet, it only takes one sunrise, one look at your vertiginous surroundings, one song on the radio perfectly timed with some random encounter, one well written quest to fall in love with Night City all over again, to get lost in its vibrant world filled with so many points of interest and cool locations, many of which are hidden at first glance. 

Most importantly, it doesn't take much to grow attached to your V. - whether he is corpo, street kid or nomad -, Jackie, Johnny, Panam, River, Judy and all the rest of these amazing characters. By the time the curtain goes down, they are more to you than pixels on a computer screen ; once the credits start rolling, you are left with the memories of a lifetime.

The only expansion, Phantom Liberty, brings it all to new heights with heartbreaking storylines, beautiful and unique locations. It is a true testament to what Cyberpunk 2077 always aimed and overwhelmingly manages to be : a rapturing piece of art.

The game in it's current state is so unstable there's a merged thread of 47 pages of just crash reports since just December.

Performance issues that result in gradually degrading performance the more you play mandating a restart every 30 min to maintain more than 50 frames on decent hardware. The game somehow actually ran significantly better for me during 1.0 release than it does now.

Most of those bugs that got the game originally lambasted are still in the game; sliding NPCs, floating cars, overlapping dialogue, traffic driving into walls, etc. It doesn't feel like anything has been fixed in this regard?

So I don't understand why everyone says this game is fixed now?

Now, long story long.... [u](After Phantom Liberty)[/u]

[u]Story:[/u] It is great but [spoiler]do not expect a "happy" ending in any case (Happy endings are an obsolete and fictional idea)[/spoiler]. The cut scenes are very well made. If you have played Witcher, then you know or at least have an idea how the story will shape according to your choices. So just a heads up.
[b]Phantom Liberty:[/b] These games teach life lessons so much better than any school or subject and the teachers are the characters and you know what the interesting things is? You can APPLY these lessons in YOUR REAL life! (I mean it)

[u]Gameplay:[/u] Great game-play and mechanics. I have played almost all Grand Theft Auto games, Watch Dogs and all other Open World games too and it does not feels weird or anything like that to get used to the mechanics of this game. On the contrary, it feels better than others and more realistic (to me at least).
[u]Update:[/u] The cyberwares in this game are so fun! Do not underestimate these at any time. Whenever you get the chance, [spoiler]just go to a ripperdoc ASAP and get them installed in your futuristic android body <3[/spoiler]

[u]Exploration:[/u] Night City, huh? Oh boy, it takes time to get the stuff done (Like Side missions, activities, etc.). During the story, it does not seems that big of a deal but once you start to do other aforementioned stuff, you will see what I mean. The side Gigs are [spoiler]good and if you want to immerse in them a bit then it is possible too, the Cyber-psycho stuff is also great to test your one-on-one fighting skills but the NCPD stuff is really repetitive and time consuming (kinda annoying)[/spoiler]
[b]Phantom Liberty:[/b] Boy oh boy, "Dog Town" is such a unique and memorable place that you are gonna adore and remember. Everything that you do here which gives you reward (which almost everything does), gives you a worth it reward, in some way & you want to do other stuff apart from the main story too.

[u]Battle/Combat:[/u] It felt really good to fight enemies whether it is with a weapon or your "futuristic" hands. The sword combat in this game is so satisfying and makes you feel like a [i]"SAMURAI"[/i]
[b]Phantom Liberty:[/b] Personally in my play-through, I wasn't able to get my hands on "new" weapons or mods having new features but the things that I do got my hands on, they were just too good!

[u]Vehicles/Handling: [/u]Driving is very good in this game and the vehicles are just so well designed and feels like real as if they really exist in real life.

[u]OSTs: [/u] Really good with exceptions of a handful: These handful are just "Boom babyyy"! Loved them.

[u]Dialogues/Conversations/Relations:[/u] Like I already mentioned in the [b]Story[/b] section above, the conversations really will immerse you in even for the side missions! The accent of dialogues is really well done too. Now comes the complicated part in human history; RELATIONSHIPS. So, relations in this game are [spoiler]well done and depends how you choose to proceed with them. And, don't worry about getting intimate with the character who you feel like she/he is for me....this game doesn't disappoints here neither ;)[/spoiler]
[b]Phantom Liberty:[/b] Just one thing, CHOOSE YOUR WORDS WISELY or else...

[u]MVP:[/u] [spoiler]SAMURAI. Rockerboy. Kerry Eurodine's best buddy. Alt Cunningham's lover. Rogue Amendez's wanna be BF. Wants to SMASH Adam Smasher. Johnny SIlverhand. Love you Johnny!!!! Thank you for such a memorable and awesome experience of my life. i will cherish this game due to Johnny being in this game too. My Nostalgia 15 years from now. [b]Keanu Reeves[/b], Thank You![/spoiler]

[i][b]Note:[/b] [strike]I haven't played the Expansion: Phantom Liberty, yet. I will edit this review after playing through that too.[/i][/strike]
[b]Phantom Liberty:[/b] Played and Completed

[u]Conclusion[/u]: I enjoyed every single aspect of this game. Can't think of anything that annoyed me. Also, I have read through the tough times that CD PROJEKT RED went through for this game and boy oh boy, I never expected that this game will come this far! Overall experience was [b]Awesome[/b]! Adios to the every single individual who contributed in the making of this game directly or indirectly. Many many congratulations to CD PROJECT RED for this milestone and wishing you best of luck for your future plans.

[i]So much work has been put for making the assets of the game too: Like Music, OST, soundtracks, vehicle designs, weapon designs, not to mention the Advertisement posters adn commercials too, etc. Hats off to the team for making this game as real and immersive as possible in today's day 'n age.[/i]

& to you, the one reading through the end, as well: Well done, you really want to get the best bang for your buck that's why you are going through stuff like review and all, right? :)

Note: This review was made on the 2.1 version of CP2077 and Phantom Liberty.

The developers have managed to put together one hell of a city, running on one hell of a graphics engine. It looks good on most system configurations, but given the top of the line it really outdoes itself. It's a feast for the eyes and at least one main reason to go through it all.

The city is also one very nice playground for your amateur climber and parkour fan. Especially with the right leg cyberware and the ability to dash and air-dash. That alone has made exploring the city a lot of fun, trying to get to the weirdest places.

Immersion is also at its peak while playing, and the setting just oozes style. It also has one of the coolest mechanics for narrative exploration, via the braindance mechanic. It's somewhat similar to what Rocksteady's Batman game did, for the investigations, but a lot cooler. I really hope they choose to and manage to expand this into something even more full-fledged in the sequel.

In terms of gameplay, it's a considerable improvement over Witcher 3, especially in terms of possible ways of getting through combat encounters. And I was surprised and chose to get through most of it in a full stealth build, and only later, after maxing that out, chose to also expand into a netrunner build. A veritable wizard of the cyberpunk setting. I will want to try a pure melee build sometime in the future, but I do worry about the lack of quickhacks, as versatile and impactful as they are.

The overall story is good, with some nice plot points along the way, both in the main and in the Phantom Liberty expansion, but especially the endings of each of them. They just ooze high production value. Also in the narrative department, while it has plenty of side content, via gigs and jobs, and a few of them do have sizable narrative arcs, spanning multiple missions, I have to say that most of them are fairly forgettable or serviceable. Somehow in this department it feels like they fell short of Witcher 3's optional content, that you could easily mistake for main content. I do hope I don't just have rose-tinted glasses, but I suspect I do not. 

Another issue with the side content, and this is due to the setting in general (and this is definitely more of a personal issue) is that the whole setting feels more like GTA, with plenty of satire, than Blade Runner. And I would've loved it if it were more of the latter than the former. There's also a dissonance between the two visions, both of which are present in CP2077 but they clash with each other; where one tries to take it self seriously and give a philosophical outlook on this type of dystopian future of mankind, while the other is just crass and unsubtle and disarms that critique from being taken seriously by the person experiencing it.

Another negative is the itemization, balancing and economy overall. In terms of itemization and economy it's still pretty poor and unremarkable. Money still has no value since you can easily exploit it. Having done a 100% run, and having completed all the side content before tackling the main stuff, for a good 1/3rd of the game I had maxed out everything on my character in terms of leveling and haven't changed my gear for that time at all. With the latest patch they also made everything scale to the player's level, so there is a constant difficulty curve generally speaking, which makes all enemies feel pretty much the same. Except for the 0.1% of encounters which can have incredible and sometimes impossible difficulty spikes. I could not, even after a lot of attempts, overcome the Adam Smasher fight on the hardest, Very Hard, difficulty. All of this indicates that there's not a lot of balancing by hand done in the game, and CDPR just threw up its hands and resorted to an auto-scaling difficulty, which results in mostly unremarkable combat encounters. Luckily the skill and cyberware systems have been overhauled in the 2.0 patch, giving considerably more options. Too bad they couldn't also balancing the whole experience by hand, to ensure a certain player difficulty curve.

But even with all of these significant negatives, overall the game is an absolute joy to experience. The quality of the main story and content, and the effort that was put into realizing Night City as probably the best dystopian cities in gaming; all of these manage to overcome the negatives, especially if you do not dilute the whole experience by delving too much into the side content. I unfortunately went for a completionist run, and did experience a lot of the negatives, but I hope they manage to improve on these in the sequel

To wrap things up, I'd like to mention the soundtrack which is also pretty fantastic, with plenty of amazing moody pieces, combat themes and everything inbetween. I did not care very much for the radio stations, but that's just me. I generally prefer to ride my bike across the cityscape with the radio off, just taking in the mood of the city. And it is a grand city indeed. Probably one of the best city settings in any game. And I do wonder how they'll try to improve on it in the sequel.

All in all, I'd have to give it an 9/10. And a definite recommendation.

It goes without saying that Cyberpunk 2077 started In an incredibly rough state, and I think regardless of how the game Is now, It's very important for us to never forget that. 
Cyberpunk was a glitchy disaster that barely even functioned on old gen consoles, to the point of being pulled from the Playstation store entirely.
With that being said, Cyberpunk 2077 right now Is an incredible Game that will surely remain In my top of all time list.
It's honestly shocking how good this game looks. Not just in pure graphical fidelity, but In the details and density of the world. Every little spot In Cyberpunk feels lived In, and that's a true accomplishment.

It's also Important that you understand what Cyberpunk 2077 Is, because It's not exactly advertised properly In my opinion.
This game Is not some huge sprawling RPG with countless builds and monumental story altering choices that many of the trailers would have you believe.
Builds are absolutely a thing and there are story altering choices to be made, but at the end of the day, Cyberpunk 2077 Is an Action game first, and RPG second. 
This however Is not a bad thing.
One of the biggest strengths of Cyberpunk Is the high quality bar for the Main Quest and the Side Missions.
Often times, these feel totally indistinguishable. 
Side Missions never really feel "Side Mission-y".
Some Side Missions have whole storylines with multiple endings even.

The last point to touch upon Is the Superb Writing, mainly between V and Johnny Silverhand.
V and Johnny are what make Cyberpunk 2077 special.
Getting into this would require a heavy delve Into Spoilers, so I will leave It here and just hit you with a hardcore Recommendation from me.

This is me talking, who is on his 5th playthrough now playing as a "ninja netrunner"

But for those wondering, it is worth every single penny that you spend. 

As for me, i keep wanting to return to the game when im playing other games lol.

They have fixed a lot of glitches

[h1] THE GREATEST GAME I'VE EVER PLAYED [/h1]

After completing the main story twice & Phantom Liberty once (v1.61 to v1.7, then v2.0 - v2.11 on the 2nd playthrough) completing all the Gigs, Side jobs unlocking all but 3 of the potential endings (all tied to Phantom Liberty) along the way, I can honestly say that Cyberpunk 2077 is the best game I've ever played!

It's storytelling & characters are very brilliantly written by the team at CDPR, you'll grow to love, hate, laugh & even feel their moments of grief, I've not been so engrossed or felt so immersed into a game's plot, storytelling, it's characters & chain of events leading to the multiple endings which even then branch off to 1 or 2 epilogues from the (now since Phantom Liberty's release) 7 possible endings Cyberpunk 2077 has to offer since playing Fallout New Vegas or jumping back further Metal Gear Solid. Some of the endings in this game really did "hit it where it hurts" & left me thinking "I should have done this" or actually regretting the decisions made to get to that particular ending.

[h3] CYBERPUNK 2077 [/h3]

Presentation wise, this game is absolutely beautiful, it looks incredible, it sounds fantastic & it also runs very smoothly. It's easy to control (I use a control pad for my PC rather then a Keyboard/Mouse), the key bindings for those using a controller over a keyboard & mouse are mapped out brilliantly so I didn't need to tweak any settings to "meet my preference". The amount of customisation this game does offer you from Controls, HUD display, Visual Effects, Depth of detail to ease performance, even going as far as having the choice to optimise the colour layout for those who are colourblind is amazing!

There's a huge variety of weapons, cars, bikes & abilities gifted through Cyberware on offer, from the basic to the unbelievably powerful to the down right hilarious. Main Missions & Side Missions have a lot of depth & length to them & alongside that, being a Merc for hire, you have the option to work for Fixers around different districts of Night City in some very interesting & extremely varied Gigs which reward you handsomely if all are completed. You can assist the NCPD in resolving various criminal activities gain much needed Street Credit (for unlocking better Weapons/Mods/Cyberware), cash as well as extra experience & practice with combat to help you into the Gigs & Side missions a bit more prepared.

Issues I had before V2.0 (basically things that felt underwhelming or frustrating mostly to do with progression etc, not faults with the game that were being fixed) mostly revolved around how Clothing contributed to armour, Cyberware was 2nd nature & crafting & getting to specific perks was an absolute grind at times. It was really, unintentionally more complicated then it needed to be. But all of that changed with 2.0 & the improvements have literally been game changing:
- The crafting system is more simplified & faster.
- Cyberware is now a massive priority for Skills, Passive bonuses & giving you Armour
- Weapon mods & upgrading are overhauled.
- The Perk System makes any perk chosen feels it has it's always useful
- Bike Handling & Driving in general feels a lot more smoother
- Clothes are just cosmetic (but can still be sold or broken down for crafting materials)
- Combat & Boss Fights are a lot harder
- With Phantom Liberty, vehicle combat was added

There is a lot more pre-planning & experimentation on offer, your core skills upgrade as you play giving you perk points to spend every 2 levels they increase & bonuses to the perks they are attributed to in between, for example the "Net-runner" skill is upgraded using Smart Targeting weapons, Hacking targets or objects such as cars, cameras, turrets or explosives or it can be increased from Intelligence based skill checks unlocking certain doors. Being able to freely refund spent Perk Points helps you pick & choose whats best for the build you want & just makes trying out every potential option even more fun & gives you limitless freedom to re-spec your character without having to restart the whole game again.

[h2] THANK YOU CDPR [/h2]

The team behind this have done an unbelievable job in keeping this game "up to standards" after it's seemingly broken launch in 2020 (I bought this game in 2022, knowing nothing about it's launch or the game itself). The dedication that CDPR has shown to not only resolve all flaws but to then totally overhaul the game's mechanics for Version 2.0 (Phantom Liberty) on-wards is dedication that doesn't come often, especially in the modern gaming industry, where money seems to be the only priority & customer satisfaction is at the bottom of their list of priorities. Any technical faults I've had with the game, such as unreported bugs, the team at CDPR actually bothered to contact me after these issues were reported, to learn more about what was going wrong & then contact me again once the issues were addressed in the next patches to check everything was resolved, just showing how much they actually cared about customer satisfaction. And even now, it annoys me that most just "expect more" & show little gratitude to how much time, effort & money has gone into this game since it's launch in 2020.

We're now on to Version 2.11 & coming to the end of patches or major updates as CDPR moves on to The Witcher 4 & Cyberpunk Orion and apart from a bug in Phantom Liberty which disabled the protagonist's phone until restarting the game (instead of just until the mission I was on was finished), there has been no problems with Cyberpunk's stability, visuals or performance.

This is one of my favorite games of all times. I love the story, setting, choices, exploration, variety of tactics, open world, graphics, and especially the sound track. All of the minor little details create an environment that is very immersive and bring the game world to life. I only started playing in 2023 with version 1.61. In 150 hours of completing the 4 main endings (not the secret), and all available side missions/NCPD scanner missions, I only experienced 2-3 crashes. However there are still a lot of minor bugs that I found annoying from time to time. The 1.62 patch seemed to fix some of the graphics bugs (NPCs and cars disappearing in parts especially) but introduced so many more that sometimes it feels like "death by a thousand paper cuts". Still, this did not prevent me from playing through it a 2nd time with a very different character build of V.

This is a good game. Far from perfect, but good. I enjoyed most of my hundred hours in it. But you probably should not expect The Witcher 3 here, even though I had some complaints about that one, too.

Firstly, it's a shooter, not a slasher. Personally, I find it as a good shooter myself. It was fun shooting at things here, although, I was usually using like 2 guns (a submachine gun for rapid fire and a gun with a silencer for more precision and stealth and I changed the exact models only a couple of times). With a perk from Phantom Liberty, which started highlighting vulnerable areas it became even more satisfying. My only complain is that NPCs practically never threw grenades at me, which prevented me from getting 2 related achievements. I think I saw a grenade from NPCs maybe once. Don't know if I was just too efficient killing them or it was a bug, but this felt strange to me.

Secondly, I think open world here is even less interesting. This is partially because I prefer "middle ages" to "modern" or even "futuristic" setting. But partially because side quests are... Mostly forgettable. I am not talking about NCPD hustles, but about gigs and actual side quests. There are some good ones or, at least, those, that do have good moments, but for the most part they feel like fillers and have little to no visual impact on the world of the game. They can be fun even without that, of course, but overall nothing special. And I think the best ones were "spy" missions, where you needed to investigate things, and depending on what you've found (or not), whom you talked to or not, results changed. I think Witcher 3 had way more truly interesting side quests.

But I think the main point of attraction here is the main story and Phantom Liberty. Main game's story does have side quest lines, which are engaging, too, but they are nothing compared to the main plotline and Phantom Liberty. Those truly immerse you in the story. You are not a talking head talking to other talking heads: all cinematics are done from your first person perspective and you do feel in the action, and it is good. If you watch it as a movie - you probably will still enjoy it.

Choices are still mostly flavor, though. There are certainly some, that do change the available endings or particular details in those endings, but for most part it's pure role playing without real consequences. But the endings... Those... They differ a lot. Neither is perfect, in my opinion, there were little things, that irked me, but each one of them stirred either deep emotions in me or made me think. Not just about the world, but about my own life.

And this is great. There are too few games with stories like this. You can see real progression for Johnny and V. Something that felt clear-cut in the begging truly becomes muddled by the end of the game and making certain decisions does become harder. Surprisingly, what most would consider "bad" choices do lead to somewhat better endings. They are bitter, but they do feel... Real, I guess?

This is, actually, another good thing about the game: it feels real. Yes, some things are futuristic here, since it's the future, and some are exaggerated and overly pessimistic, since cyberpunk genre implies that, but there are lots of things, which are relevant to us now. It makes you ask yourself things. For example, do you really want a world where you can feel this level of loneliness tearing you up, making you insane just because you want to survive?

If this does not make it a good story, I don't what does. And with a fun gunplay, and some interesting mechanics related to cyberware - it is really a good game. Even if the original release was really bad. But that's also a lesson: if you care to put in time and effort - you can build a good thing, which will be remembered.

I'm updating this review after finishing the latest 2.1 patch + Phantom Liberty DLC.
The game is overall good now compared to before, but some of the problems that were in the game when it first released are still present.
Here are issues that are still within the game:
-lethal vs non-lethal combat as a game mechanic is still half-baked. The developers clearly wanted to do more with this feature but for one reason or another didn't fully flesh out this mechanic.
-inventory management is still somewhat cumbersome
-the cyberpunk genre as a whole has some themes/motifs that are severely outdated. Japan and China are real countries people, we don't need to wildly speculate on how they operate.

Here are major improvements made since the launching of the game:
++The Phantom Liberty DLC has a great main quest and the actors for each character are top notch. Even the side quests/gigs provide great vignettes for life in Night City.
+overhaul of the talent/perks system has made gameplay more fun
+car handling has improved
+transmogrification
+crafting system overhaul
+more properties are available for purchase

I've been wanting to play this game ever since it was announced (mainly because Keanu Reeves was involved, and I had just discovered Bill and Ted after watching the John Wick movies). When it came out my uncle bought it and I was DYING to get it as well, but he told me not to since it was extremely buggy.
I was sad, however It slipped my mind for the next couple of years until recently when the 2.0 update came out. People were praising it and saying that it had finally be what they hoped for when it was first announced. It took this as my signal to finally try out to game, and to my pleasant surprise, it was more than I had hoped for.
City setting had always been overwhelming to me coming from small towns, but even with the huge buildings it doesn't feel like it's going to topple down and crush me. 
Though my problem with the setting is that non-important NPCs (meaning not involved in the story) get no depth, and sometimes the same character models are used over and over. 
With the level of graphics I completely understand the character model thing, but having some sort of interaction would be much preferred.
Anyway, this game isn't totally world-view changing, but I love the characters and the story! I would definitely recommend playing this game since most of the critiques relating to the bugs are now outdated.

After coming back to Cyberpunk a few years later, the game has made significant improvements and is worth the investment.

The Good:
-City design, buildings, ads do a good job of recreating the feel of cyberpunk as a genre
-Lots of options for how you want to approach challenges
The Bad:
-Most missions are 70-80% sitting there while people talk at you, with very little choice in how you want the dialogue to go.  Many conversations happen while you are literally in the passenger seat as an NPC drives you somewhere.  It's like a masterclass in taking control away so you feel less like a player and more like a viewer. 
 The actual gameplay parts of missions where you sneak or hack or fight your way through levels is so short it feels like an afterthought.
-On top of the above, story pacing is glacially slow.  The opening action setpiece that actually gets you invested in your character and the world happens after ~6 hours of tutorials and filler missions.  And this pace doesn't let up, I frequently put the game down and came back weeks later because it feels like there is just too much filler in between the meat of the game.
-Extremely backwards tutorial system has entire missions to teach you obvious things like to sneak by going when guards aren't looking, but almost no useful information about how to manage less intuitive systems like attribute points and crafting materials.

While the cyberpunk universe usually isn't my cup of tea, I found myself dedicating nearly 200 hours to this game, ensuring I secured every achievement. My drive? I simply can't stand leaving things incomplete.

After playing through this game and its DLC, I've got to say, it was a mixed experience for me. Despite my usual reservations about cyberpunk themes, I could see the effort CD Projekt Red invested in the main story. They might not have gone all in, but the dedication and hard work are undeniable.

On the positive side, the game's graphics were a high point, offering a visually stunning experience that fully immerses you in its world. The ability to customize your character is another aspect I appreciated, allowing for a personal touch in the cyberpunk universe. However, I felt the customization options were somewhat limited and could have benefited from further expansion.

One of the game's delights was discovering Easter eggs and the inclusion of real-world celebrities, which added a layer of excitement and connection to our reality. The battle mechanics and the diverse array of skills available for characters to learn added depth to gameplay, enhancing the overall experience with strategic elements that kept engagements feeling fresh and varied.

On the other hand, the main storyline and its various endings did not captivate me. I found them to be lackluster and devoid of the uniqueness or intrigue I had hoped for. Night City, despite its initial allure, quickly became monotonous. The repetitive nature of the missions and the sameness of the locations contributed to a sense of tedium that overshadowed my explorations.

Moreover, the characters, particularly those available for romantic relationships, were a disappointment. They failed to provide the emotional depth and support that would have enriched the protagonist's journey, leaving a gap in the narrative engagement.

In conclusion, while there were elements of the game I genuinely enjoyed, my overall experience was dampened by a storyline and character interactions that failed to capture my interest. This sentiment is likely amplified by my general apathy towards the cyberpunk genre. However, my frustration peaked with a technical issue that prevented me from achieving the final game achievement. Despite having completed all other achievements, a glitch that blocked actions necessary for progressing and accessing the last achievement left me unable to complete my goal, adding a sour note to my concluding hours with the game.

Shifting focus to the DLC, it's as if we're discussing a completely different game. The narrative within the DLC captured my attention and admiration. What stood out to me was the impactful decision-making, where choosing between two paths led to genuinely heartfelt consequences. Unlike the main storyline, the endings here were far from predictable or mundane. They were thought-provoking and engaging, showcasing a refreshing depth that was absent from the original campaign.

The variability and uniqueness of the characters within the DLC were remarkable. Each character brought a distinct flavor to the story, enriching the experience with their individuality and compelling backstories. This diversity in character design added layers to the narrative, making the world feel more alive and complex.

Moreover, the way the DLC's story unfolded based on the choices I made was impressive. The different trajectories that events could take depending on my decisions added a significant replay value and made my choices feel impactful and meaningful.

As the DLC drew to a close and the credits began to roll, the combination of the emotive music and beautifully animated summary of the DLC's story moved me profoundly. It was a rare moment where a game elicited such a strong emotional response, to the point where I found myself moved to tears. This emotional resonance was a testament to the exceptional storytelling and artistic execution of the DLC, setting it apart from my experiences with the main game.

WOW! That itch for Deus Ex is definitely scratched as this immersive world throws you in the middle of a vast city. Filled with corpo greed, love interests, and a plethora of ways to navigate the world. I would say there are multiple options for every encounter and each side quest doesn't feel like it takes you away from the main story. Instead it fleshes out the world of Night City, and adds to your love of the space you occupy in this megalopolis.

Choice even effects your combat as you can by a sword wielding cyberninja or a gunslinger or a silent agent throughout the whole game. It gives you the option of being as lethal or non-lethal as you want, and some missions are enhanced by not killing your enemy. Not to mention this game has 4 different endings that I know of. Unlike some games (ME3) which emphasize choice and in the end makes that choice seem meaningless by having the same ending in different flavors, this game actually allows you to play through an epilogue. Each one vastly different, and that continues to immerse you into the world.

I also am a huge Deus Ex fan, and as I mentioned previously, and this fills that void. The different conspiracies that fill the city like veins in a body are so embedded and are so interesting to learn about. Some quests will let you wander around after in a daze of "What just happened" in a good way. It just keeps having you craving more and there are lots of articles and emails to read that flesh out these different plotlines. I'd suggest no skipping anything. As each little item adds to the world that you're living in. Speaking of living you can have a variety of places to live, and each one is equipped with a room that you can flesh out with legendary weapons that can mount upon your walls. So I suggest not skipping through anything, in this living breathing world!

The graphics are amazing though the filter that is the stylistic overlay for the entire game can sometimes make it feel like its running slower than it is. Otherwise it really feels amazing to be able to run anywhere in this city. To experience things that don't even tie into the missions in anyway and are just fun as far as immersion. I can't imagine what this game would be like in VR. I can only assume it would be amazing.

I'd be remiss if I didn't mention the voice acting! Especially lady V's voice and her sidekick Jackie! Jackie is hilarious and I suggest you fall for his antics and make him your favorite side character in the while game.

In the end I can't recommend enough taking a dive into night city and experiencing these city streets for yourself.

I had zero issues with the game at launch and really enjoyed it. Update 2.0 offered me about 20 frames per second worth of performance by utterly GUTTING the graphical fidelity of the game without any means of disabling the changes (2060 Super). To be frank, the game-play experience is not so fun or compelling that ANY user would choose extra frames per second over graphical fidelity (it's a single player story telling game, after all, and not a competitive shooter.) I used to be able to "wow" my friends by sitting them in Night City and letting them run around. Now, the game looks like an upscaled Xbox port. 

Consider skipping the purchase of this game if you're still interested in playing it. Not only will older versions of the game improve your graphical fidelity, but you'll also skip the annoying third-party launcher that you must download in order to launch the game every time.

[h2][i] "I just want the world to know I was here. That I mattered." [/i] [/h2]

You would think a game that released three years ago as of this review's posting that we'd no longer have a swarm of bugs, minor and gamebreaking. haha. lol. lmao even. I've only lost a couple hours thanks to employing the ancient canticle of extra save files, and I urge you to do the same. Despite this, it's... it's a great game. It really is now, despite itself.

The perktree overhaul, netrunning a la Watchdogs but better, a whole litany of awesome weapons generic and unique, and some pretty cool cosmetics - the latter being only valuable to those who use the photo editor to pretend they're good at taking pictures, like me. Also, obviously the graphics are downright gorgeous, this game possesses some of the most beautifully crafted visuals of the current age. Hell, even the face animations look nice.

The writing is like a rusty rollercoaster: it's got the sickest loops and scream-inducing highs, coupled with some really odd curves that cause permanent whiplash. The consequences of rewriting the game to better place Keanu Silverhand in the game are noticeable, and for the most part the rewrite does its job well - helps that Johnny Reaverhand is so well written too - but in the case of the [spoiler]Voodoo Boys[/spoiler] questline, or the latter half of [spoiler] Judy's [/spoiler] questline, you'll see some readily apparent cracks. 
But even then, it's a credit to the game's portrayal of the lore of Cyberpunk that the former is a notable discrepancy from how it ought to be.

Still. It's a great story, from beginning to end, and a bombastic good journey along the way. Despite it's many problems, I ultimately do recommend this game for most people looking to appreciate a gritty cyberpunk world or a damn good RPG.

Honestly I was probably one of the first & only to ever vouch for this game being enjoyable. After completing multiple endings in the first week of release, so hyped I couldn't even notice the issues that plagued the game, I'd like to say that this game still remains...in my mind at least; one of the best games I've ever played. Just has a soft spot in my heart as a Cyberpunk genre enthusiast. Regardless of it's issues. I find this to be a game I come back to constantly. Even if I take frequent & long breaks away from it. I can't speak on the DLC but this game is worth playing.

I'm here to discuss the difficulty of the game. Cyberpunk 2077 gives you the option to choose one of three difficulty settings. I picked the hardest difficulty because YOLO! The hardest difficulty is too easy. I can only imagine how easy it would be on the other easier settings.  
  
There was one part of the main questline and I had to escape a skyscraper by going into the parking garage to get picked up by an AI taxi cab. Guys with guns were waiting for me... 

I just I was running back and forth playing hide-and-seek with a group of 6 bad guys, peeking my head around the corner to do a bunch of cyber attacks, running around to the other side of the pillar, doing cyber attacks over there, running back to the first side, cyber attacks, run back to the other side, cyber attacks, run to the other side again... This was the only fight I've experienced where it was actually difficult on the hardest difficulty setting and that's because if I tried to fight with a gun I'd do barely any damage (like 4 damage) and if they hit me, they took like 80% of my health with each bullet they hit me with. 

It took me like 30 minutes to do that single fight. It was cheesy, imo. Playing hide and seek for 30 minutes is not what I'd expect from a "hard mode" option. The boss that I fought 30 seconds before reaching the garage died in like 3 minutes or less, so WTF?????????

It turned out I had not used any of my skill points at all, so I was unknowingly handicapped??? Anyway, I've beefed up my guns and skills so now everything is kind of easy again. Almost too easy. The only time I die is when I'm trying to joke around and do something dumb, like accidentally stand on my own grenade.  
  
I can understand the desire to play on easy as the storyline is awesome as hell, but I highly recommend playing only on the hardest because if it's any easier than this... geez.

Cyberpunk 2077 is an ambitious open-world RPG developed by CD Projekt Red, set in the sprawling, dystopian metropolis of Night City. Despite its highly anticipated release, the game has garnered mixed reviews due to a plethora of technical issues and gameplay shortcomings.

Visuals & Atmosphere: Night City is a breathtaking marvel, pulsating with life, neon lights, and a gritty cyberpunk aesthetic. The visuals are stunning, immersing players in a vibrant, yet sinister, urban landscape.

Story & Characters: The narrative weaves a complex web of intrigue, betrayal, and personal struggle, offering branching storylines and meaningful choices. The characters are well-written and memorable, each with their own motivations and agendas.

Gameplay: Cyberpunk 2077 offers a mix of first-person shooting, hacking, and RPG elements. The gunplay is solid, but the melee combat feels clunky and unpolished. The hacking mechanics add depth to encounters, allowing players to manipulate the environment and enemies.

Technical Issues: Unfortunately, Cyberpunk 2077's launch was marred by numerous bugs, glitches, and performance issues across all platforms. While some have been addressed through patches, the game still suffers from stability issues and graphical glitches.

Conclusion: Despite its flaws, Cyberpunk 2077 is a captivating journey through a dystopian future filled with intrigue and danger. While it may not live up to the immense hype surrounding its release, it still offers a compelling experience for fans of the cyberpunk genre. With ongoing updates and improvements, the game has the potential to realize its full vision and become a classic in the genre.

A reasonably enjoyable city-based Open World game. Not quite up there with the likes of GTA, Saints Row or Sleeping Dogs in terms of sheer enjoyability, but it's OK for what it is. The worst thing is that more than three years after it was released it's still broken. It still takes multiple attempts to get into the game because it often crashes while loading. There are still frequent random crashes in the game. You still fall through the road at random intervals while driving. It's still being fixed, so maybe some day it will be just a perfectly average open world game, but it's not there yet.

To keep it short and sweet, the game is absolutely now in a state that would be worth playing, especially with the Phantom Liberty expansion. Pick it all up on a sale, and chrome up. I played at release and another playthrough on every major update. This is definitely the most "alive" Night City has been yet.

Into further detail - My only gripe is things like most Gigs and nearly all NCPD Scanner missions get pretty stale. Go to this place, kill these people, done - for like 90% of it. Doing anything other than the main quests is basically like you being Night City's Batman and fighting crime. At least the different gangs in different areas of the city means that the people you kill look different? I'm not angry at the fact that you have lots of things to do, because being able to reset your attributes one time, and perks any time is a huge plus. Keeps the grind interesting with the fact that you can try any build/weapon combo in a single playthrough.

Cyberpunk takes elements of Deus Ex (arm claw blades? Check!), Arkham Knight (being overwritten by another personality? Check! Ghostly detective playback scenes? Check!), GTA (want that car? Check!), and Dying Light (loot everyone and everything? Check! Crafting? Check! Complicated progression systems? Chjeck!) and mixes it all up with a sprinkle of Keanu on top. You'd think that would be the best game ever? Well... it should have been. Much improved since the update, the gameplay is good, just not AS good as any of the above in their own niche. To its credit there are a LOT of progression upgrades, and it's an excellent feature that you can refund all your upgrades whenever you want and reinvent your character class. There's also way more granularity than Deus Ex in how you can upgrade your cybernetics, and a similar nuance to Dying Light in the weapon variety and upgrades. You get a lot for your money here. But nothing feels entirely NEW. My biggest gripe is with the story, which takes a while to get going, and didn't grab me at all at first. Unlike Deus Ex, whose story kept me replaying dozens of time - this one just doesn't have the hooks or atmosphere to merit even a single rerun. 25 hours in now, I am mildly hooked, but I am still not entirely sure what's going on. I am more interested in my character progression, and how to weaponise the new car I've bought. The world you inhabit is HUGE by the way - I doubt I will ever see all of it. Compared to Deus Ex's tiny, or even the sprawl of Dying or Arkham - it's impressive, but the areas are also somehow forgettable and easy to get lost in. This IS a good game, it just isn't as brilliant as it should have been. If you loved Deus Ex - this is as close as you are going to get to scratching that itch for now...

This game does not seem like a 9-year-in-development masterpiece. In fact, it's not a masterpiece at all. Aside from the routine complaints (buggy, lacking AI, clunky stealth and combat), I'd say Cyberpunk's main problem is a lack of identity. It's hollow, lacks a true immersive feel, and is trying to be 3 or 4 different genres all rolled up into one package, but never really mastering any. Plus, the main quest is entirely too short. I know, I know, "It's designed to be re-played multiple times," I hear you saying, but I'm having the trouble finding the motivation. All-in-all, viewing this game objectively, past all the hype and expectations and standing on it's own, Cyberpunk 2077 is an average game that has its moments to shine. Having put 90 hours in, I'd say (reluctantly) it was worth the $60. Shame we didn't get what was advertised, though. 7/10.

It took it a minute to get going, but it is now equal to the Publisher's well-earned reputation for quality.

I've still got reservations about the game. The first time I played it was before the 2.0 patch. And god knows how flawed the game was back then. 
Post-2.0, my mind hasn't fundamentally changed. A lot of the most egregious problems have been ironed out, but if you're going to to go at it on a purely technical level, the game is still pretty basic. The hacking is pretty much just magic with a sci-fi filter, the progression system makes more sense but is still a quite basic RPG skill tree. The graphics are great on paper but struggle with some very noticeable stuff at medium distances. 

But also, I don't think any of that matters all that much. Because I don't think any of that was ever the focus. I strongly hold the opinion that every cutscene is a failure of the game developer to properly utilise the unique medium that video games are. Cyberpunk is, in my opinion, among the absolute best games to use the options that the medium offers a storyteller. 

The thing that stands out about this game is how purpose-built it seems to blow you away on its first playthrough, everything after be damned. And without getting too philosophical, that in itself represents the experience it tries to convey really well. Night City gives you one shot, and you either knock it out of the park and become a legend or you'll rot in the gutter. Who cares what happens after. The same applies here. And they sure as hell knocked it out of the park. 

And I think that is wonderfully refreshing to see. Replayability is often - rightfully so - praised as one of the greatest features a game can have, if it's done well. But it's not the be all and end all. In that praise, it's easy to forget how precious a first time experience can truly be if that's what a game excels at. Cyberpunk sports some of the most well-written characters in the industry. It forces you to live through a story of a never-ending, gut wrenching struggle. And I mean it. You'll be invested in your own fate and the ones around you. And when the time comes to make the hard decisions, you'll make them, because you have to, and you'll feel like shit. 

All of that won't be the same anymore the second time around. And I couldn't care less, because the first time is so damn special. 

None of this is to say that even the first time around it's perfect. But I like to see the good in things. Try to see what the people who made them were trying to achieve and judge how well they did that. In order to do that, it helps me to focus on one thing. Yes, the way the side- and character stories interact with the progression through the main story can cause some strange pacing at times. But if you can look past that for a moment, brush it aside when it bothers you a lttle and push on through what really matters, and the game will take you on a one of a kind ride. Only one per customer, though.

I cannot give this game a positive review even though i kinda enjoyed it after 3 years of postponing.
With the release of 2.1 update and Phantom Liberty expansion it was supposed to be the second coming of polish jesus, but hear my thoughts please. The great expansion only highlights how bland and mediocre the original game was and to extend - still is. Because all they added is some features that you could have added with mods if you wanted to, cringe "dates" with your companion where they re-use voice lines from the main story and what? Finally made the progression system and itemisation somewhat coherent? Wow, something that shoudve been in the game 3 years ago? And they still dont allow players to bind items on different keys, even for such a basic industry standart feature you need to install a mod. For the supposedly latest biggest update the game is still in many ways a broken mess held with a duct tape. It still looks ugly af unless you remove the green tint, vignette, crouch vignette, tweak some DLSS files in order to ease on the artifacts caused by Ray Reconstruction, melee finishers are broken, what happened to distant LOD quality anyway? Why the black levels are raised in both SDR and HDR when they are perfectly fine in Witcher 3? Why all of a sudden this game wants to consume up to 48 gigs of virtual memory?
When you look at the expansion you see things that shouldve been in the original game - non-generic gigs with tough moral choices, high quality textures and assets, iconic guns that actually use unique models sometimes and not just recolors, the levels of tension building during story missions not to mention two separate ways that lead to completely different playtrough and even can unlock a new ending based on your choices. A reminder that in the original "The Pickup" Is the only quest that actually affects further events in a meaningful way.

Sadly the game still has some bugs, namely around quests spawning. There is some strange system of checks that triggers follow up quests and it makes for a frustrating experience getting through all the quests in a chain that you want to finish

10/10 story

Ah, Cyberpunk 2077. A well thought out game that wasn't thought out well enough.

The story is strong (and covers themes that makes full use of its setting - this is a game that wears its Neuromancer inspiration on its sleeve and is all the better for it). The gameplay is tight, especially with the new changes in 2.0 (I've played 1.6, and the differences in the 2 patches are so stark they might as well not be the same game). It provides dialogue choices that felt well acted and natural (although Keanu's delivery is admittedly stilted, though there's some charm to it. Cherami Leigh as female V is great. Male V is also no slouch). The questing is great, though the pacing for the side-quests feels off compared to the main story. A timer could have been introduced to lay stress on the player - but then alas that's probably too hard to rework. The questing is mostly the issue here. There's a large cognitive dissonance between dying from brain cancer but still having all the time in the world to build your street rep and steal cars and all. I think Read Dead Redemption 2 nailed the balance. But its game design was slower, more deliberate; and you're a man looking for forgiveness. Cyberpunk's gameplay lends to fast paced dopamine rushes and gameplay that should be a part of Doom Eternal. The gigs are impersonal. You've no amends to make to Night City. Yet declining all these side missions for role-play purposes locks you out of much required experience and more importantly, meaningful content. It all doesn't jive.

Yet recommended. This is a game I thoroughly enjoyed despite its flaws (which are many). For whatever CDPR's faults for rushing it, there are obvious signs of dedication and work that went into Cyberpunk's birth. This is the equivalent to listening to your favourite artist's weaker albums (Hail to the Thief by Radiohead, First Impressions of Earth by the Strokes) where you can't help criticise the lows because the highs are absolutely amazing. Hoping that Cyberpunk Orion improves on whatever was learnt in the development of 2077. The track-run of CDPR shows hope for this: the leap from Witcher 1 to Witcher 2 was huge and largely for the better.

I am a 55 year old biker and trucker father, and probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 15 now. My son got this game from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 12 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he let me borrow his controller. Me and my son then played in turns and I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

After experiencing everything this game has to offer, I can definitively say that this game lived up to what it should have been from the get-go. Never forget what this game was at launch. But now, this game truly is a masterpiece and that can't go without saying. From doing playthroughs ignoring side quests and characters to fully deep diving into each and seeing all of the many endings of the game, most leave you with a feeling that can't quite be defined in one word. Which is great, leaving an impact is the most important part of an ending. Of the now seven endings which includes the DLC ending, only two endings left me feeling not much or just satisfied. More than likely, your first playthrough will not be these two, as personally, my first ending was the most rare one, "The Devil."

Combat has been greatly improved since launch, as when I first started playing, around 1.4-1.5, combat was jank and uninteresting. I didn't branch out of an all melee build and refused to change. Now, I've tried out every cyber enhancement, every kind of weapon ranging from snipers to pistols because there are that many good guns that deal decent to major damage. It actually feels fun to switch up loadouts now due to how many fun guns there are. Being a netrunner also has its perks now. If you fully commit to being a netrunner and hacking your opponents and the environment, the game can be a fun point and click game that has enemies blinding themselves, to shooting allies, to killing themselves like LowTierGod is in their head commanding them what to do.

The music deserves its own recognition as only a little bit of the music is on streaming platforms like Spotify. The game has plenty of noteworthy and powerful pieces that are scattered throughout the game. Some of my favorites are ones I heard on my final playthrough, so don't expect to hear them all in your first playthrough.

Customization genuinely feels really vast and fun to experiment with. You can change your general appearance in game as well as clothing. The clothing combinations are genuinely endless, I didn't latch to any particular set of clothes as there are way too many great combinations to style your character on however you see them. Want a nomad look? You've got it. Business suit and rich class? Plenty. Street kid and punk? Loads. Being able to tweak your character's face and body also was a great addition. I wasn't fully satisfied with my character going into my last playthrough so I tweaked her around three times total. So the stress of having to get my character just right from the get-go wasn't an issue like other games.

This game was a blast for the majority of its run, and there's loads of stuff I haven't even mentioned in this review. I loved this game, even my earlier runs when the game wasn't fully optimized. Now, its incredible. (Still, I'd wait for sales. They come here and there so go save some money too!)

Cyberpunk 2077 is not just a game, but an immersive experience that transports players into a fascinating dystopian future. From the immersive story and stunning visuals to the multi-layered characters and gripping combat system, this game is a true feast for the senses. With the new DLC "Phantom Liberty", Cyberpunk 2077 reaches a new level of immersion and offers players even more content to immerse themselves in the world of Night City.

The story of Cyberpunk 2077 is a real highlight. As a player, you take on the role of V, a mercenary in a dystopian vision of the future of Night City. The story is full of intrigue, violence and moral dilemmas that keep the player constantly on edge. The decisions you make have real consequences and shape the course of the story in unpredictable ways. The characters are incredibly complex and well-developed, from loyal friends and allies to ruthless enemies.

The graphics of Cyberpunk 2077 are simply breathtaking. The developers have created a richly detailed open world filled with impressive graphics and visual effects. From the glittering lights of the skyscrapers to the dark alleys of the slums, every corner of Night City is a visual masterpiece. The character models are incredibly realistic and the animations fluid and vibrant.

The combat system of Cyberpunk 2077 is as fascinating as it is challenging. It offers players a variety of ways to defeat their enemies. From firearms to melee weapons and cyber implants, there are countless options to take out enemies in different ways. The extensive skill and ability system allows players to customize and improve their character according to their preferences.

With the new DLC "Phantom Liberty", Cyberpunk 2077 offers even more content and possibilities for players. The DLC expands the game world of Night City with new missions, characters and stories that take players even deeper into the dystopian future. With new challenges and rewards, the DLC offers an exciting addition to the main game and provides hours of fun.

All in all, Cyberpunk 2077 is an absolute masterpiece that redefines the boundaries of what a video game can be. With a gripping story, impressive graphics, fascinating characters, an interesting combat system and the new DLC "Phantom Liberty", it is a game that simply has to be experienced.

Cyberpunk 2077: A Glitch-Fueled Love Letter to the Future (With Bonus Keanu!)

Yo, edge-runners! Forget the haters, forget the launch hiccups, because Cyberpunk 2077 is pure, unadulterated neon nirvana! Prepare to dive headfirst into Night City, a chrome-plated playground pulsating with life, danger, and more glitches than a malfunctioning neuralink. But hey, who needs a stable connection when you can ride a glitching car straight into a cyberpsycho mosh pit? It's like an interactive fever dream, and we wouldn't have it any other way.

Reasons to Jack Into This Digital Oasis:

Night City: It's more than just a cityscape, it's a living, breathing entity. From the mega corporate towers scraping the sky to the ramen-fueled back alleys, every corner pulsates with possibility (and the occasional exploding car, but hey, that's just Night City charm).
V is for YOU: Forge your own legend as V, a chrome-clad mercenary with more customization options than a black market ripperdoc. Katana-wielding samurai? Sure! Glitching netrunner? Go for it! Just remember, choomba, even the biggest cyberware can't fix bad fashion sense.
Choices with Extra Spice: Sure, some paths might be pre-determined, but who needs linear narratives when you've got branching storylines, impactful decisions, and enough side quests to keep you busy until the next expansion (speaking of which...).
Phantom Liberty DLC: It's here, baby! Dive deeper into Night City's underbelly with new missions, characters, and enough story twists to make your cybernetic head spin. Plus, who knows what other surprises CD Projekt Red has cooked up? Maybe Keanu Reeves returns with a jetpack (don't quote me on that, but a chrome cowboy can dream)!

But Wait, There's More!

Sure, there might be a few technical hiccups (think of them as cyberpunk easter eggs!), but the developers are constantly patching things up, adding new content, and listening to the community (remember, choombas, even the loudest complaints can't drown out the roar of a tricked-out motorbike).

So, is Cyberpunk 2077 the perfect game? Nah, but it's a damn good time. It's a love letter to the genre, a playground for the imagination, and a testament to the power of sheer, unadulterated glitch-fueled fun. So grab your katana, download the expansion, and jack into Night City, choomba. You won't regret it (unless you forget to save, then maybe a little).

P.S. Don't forget to check out the mods! They're like cybernetic implants for your experience, making everything even more glorious and, let's be honest, sometimes even more hilariously glitchy. Just remember, moderation is key. You wouldn't want your brain to overload and short-circuit in the middle of a heist, would you?

P.P.S. Seriously, watch out for those falling cars. They're more sentient than they seem.

Story and missions wise, ive never seen a game with cinematic side-missions of this calibre, every single mission outside of regular or small missions made me feel part of something bigger and or more serious, like they actually had an effect on the game world rather than "Go here, talk to boring NPC, Bring thing back" like in Skyrim, Oblivion etc. It doesnt feel like im talking to a wall with bad voice acting. 
None of this feels copy and pasted so far at 51 hours in, after doing both story and side missions. 
Things i dont like are the fact you cant tune cars, the pedestrians feel like one giant homologous unit or hivemind, and id definitely want more interactivity with the buildings as looking at them is great but I do want to venture inside at least a few of them.

Patch 2.11 review.

The patch was released on Jan 31st, 2024. I leave this review on February 11th, 2024. 

The same day the review was left I wanted to go back and complete Cyberpunk after I took a break in early autumn 2023. So I updated the game, uninstalled all mods, then installed 11 mods. 4 of them being utility, allowing other mods to work: Redscript, Red4ext, Mod Settings, Cyber Engine Tweaks. Others were not adding anything new, but enhancing the base game: Immersive First Person, Always First Equip, No Intro Vidoes, Immersive First Person Camera Fix, No More Out-Leveling Vendor Items, JB Long Sleeves and Immersive Driving.

When I lauched the game, my PC froze for a quick sec, then I received System Service Exception BSOD. I tried launching the game without mods, even deleted every single one of it, and turned off mods in the launcher. Received the same BSOD again. I was not able even to go past the splash screen with Cyberpunk logo where you have to press Space to proceed. 

I found a solution online, and the game launched, and I was even been able to load in my save and go back to the starting apartment to collect the reward for completing all gigs in one of the districts. Then, when I tried to leave the apartment complex, the game crashed to the desktop, and AMD Adrenalin claimed to record driver crash. I was using 23.11.1 instead of the latest 24.1.1 driver version, as any other game I played at the time, did not want to work with 24.1.1.

So I installed all mods again, and tried to launch the game. The game launched, and allowed me to complete a date with Panam quest. Then the game crashed again, as I was trying to leave the apartment building after I threw a knife at a TV screen in the elevator. 

After that the game refused to start again, so I found a solution again. The issue was that the game would not work if I remap controls to my liking. So I removed all mods and disabled them in the launcher, and renamed files that contain controls, and another file that is supposed to do something with razer hardware and it's lighting, as it was claimed that this file can also cause crashes (I do not have anything from that brand). I believe renaming those files would force the game to regenerate them, restoring the default settings.

So it helped, I was even able to drive around the city and have a small shootout with the cops. Then, I alt tabbed, and received a green screen of death saying that Critical Process Died. So I found a solution again, one guy on Reddit said that it may be caused by corrupted shader data, so I cleaned up shader cash via Disk Cleanup tool, restarted the system and then additionally made a shader reset in AMD Adrenalin.

As soon as I pressed Play button in the CDPR launcher, my computer crashed so hard, my primary monitor lost connection whilst the secondary one was showing nothing but glitches in different shades of pink and yellow. 

I am done. Why should I, as a consumer, waste my entire Sunday afternoon to make a AAA game work?Instead it systematically borks itself and my computer every time I try to launch it, and all this while I have a severe headache and high temperature, but I still have to search for a solutions, instead of enjoying the game.

From now on, CDPR is dead for me. I may try to give them another chance in a year or so. But as of now, with such attitude toward the end user, I might as well never play their previous games as well as not buying the new ones.
