One hell of a ride!

This is Night City... don't go looking for a 'happy' ending. The game will let you make your own choices. You decide who your character is, and how they will play. You will get the ending you.. well.. deserve. 

The game has come a long way since the clusterfck of a release. Sure, there are still some occasional glitches (you car might spawn on top of a building, loot might get stuck under a wreck with no way to retrieve it, etc.) but.. in general, it is pretty polished. 

My recommendation is to make save points before taking on quests that feel like a decision point. You might be surprised at the outcome, and want to try another path. You have many options. 

Also, the DLC is a MUST. The story there and the gameplay is even better than the main story, if even harder to figure out what is "right". Night City, and Dogtown especially, is a grey world.

Disclaimer: if you're reading this expecting an unbiased review, you've come to the wrong place. I absolutely adore this game, and this is basically just an excuse to gush about it even more than I already have...

Cyberpunk 2077 is the first game in over ten years to break into my list of top five video games of all time. No other game has gotten me so interested in the lore and history of its world, made me draw up full character outlines ahead of my next playthrough, caused me sleepless nights pondering the fates of my favorite characters. It truly is breathtaking, and to this day—after four full playthroughs—I still can't shake that feeling of excitement ahead of a new run.

Part of that excitement includes the prospects of playstyle, how you want to approach the obstacles put in front of you; will you use brute force, tearing enemies to shreds with a shotgun, machine gun, or your cybernetically modified [i]Gorilla Arms[/i]? Will you perhaps take a more discrete approach, using your implants to turn invisible and slip by enemies like a shadow? Or how about hacking the planet; taking over cameras, turrets, hell, even taking control of your enemies and forcing them to blow their own brains out? Or just say fuck all that, and mix things up - sneak your way into position before unleashing a rain of hellfire on your enemies, become a cyberninja jumping and dashing all over the place before slicing your enemies into pieces with a katana or [i]Mantis Blades[/i] implanted into your arms, or become the most skilled mercenary Night City has ever seen using only your guns and wits without installing a single implant. Phantom Liberty and the 2.0 update have only widened the possibilites and turned 2077 into the game it was always meant to be.

Honestly, I doubt I could name another game (that I've played, at least) that handles the locale it takes place in as well as Cyberpunk 2077 does Night City. It feels exactly like it should: lived in, grimy, and unforgiving – with so many interconnecting stories and cool little details around every corner. As a fan of other cyberpunk media (some which inspired Cyberpunk when it was created back in the 80's by Mike Pondsmith and R. Talsorian Games, others which may well have been inspired by Cyberpunk itself) – films such as Blade Runner (and 2049), literature like William Gibson's Sprawl trilogy, games in the vein of Deus Ex and System Shock, and that's only scratching the surface – NC feels like the amalgam of them all.

But what would Night City be without its people? From the faceless megacorporations and their drones who would do anything in the name of profit, to the lowly punks eking out something resembling an existence on the street. What seperates Cyberpunk 2077 from its peers is without a doubt its cast – key players like Johnny Silverhand (famously portrayed by Keanu Reeves) and our protagonist V are at times even overshadowed by the likes of "side characters" such as Goro Takemura, Judy Álvarez, and [b]Panam Palmer[/b] (the best character in the game, no question). Their one common denominator, however, is that we don't get enough time with them. I would play entire games focused simply on them, from roaming the Badlands alongside Panam, to a prequel set in 2020s Night City with characters like Silverhand and Rogue... I could go on. Above all, 2077's characters leave you simply wanting more of them.

What I think prevents a lot of people from really getting into Cyberpunk is that they are not willing to play by its rules – they go in expecting a totally free-form RPG where you can be anybody and do anything. That is simply not the case. 2077 should be approached the same way one approaches the Mass Effect trilogy: you're going to play as Shepard/V, even though you can influence his/her personality and background through your choices, fact remains that you are only in the driver's seat of their story. If you can come to terms with that, a fuckin' great story awaits you. And if you have the patience for it, I highly recommend multiple playthroughs to explore the variety of branching paths available to you. If you have the time, do three different playthroughs as the different lifepaths (my personal order was 1. Male/Streetkid; 2. Female/Corpo; 3. Male/Nomad – my favorite turned out to be my third and final run) – that's when the game truly opened up for me, when I could plan ahead of my second and third playthroughs; what choices I would make, what ending path to pursue, etc.

I'm so incredibly happy that Cyberpunk 2077 got the second chance it deserved, and with the release of 2.0 and Phantom Liberty the general public's perspective on the game is [i]finally[/i] starting to shift, and people are beginning to recognize it as the magnificent game that it truly is. It really is true that a thing of beauty never fades away.

Whatever happens with the rumored sequel codenamed Project Orion, that we had the opportunity to experience 2077 and Phantom Liberty is something I will always be thankful for. I can only hope that we will get some very happy returns when we do eventually get our hands on it (Panam, I'll be waiting for you...)

Review (Phantom Liberty included) (Significant Spoilers! Play first!):
[spoiler]
Cyberpunk 2077 is a game not necessarily driven by its gameplay. The gameplay is solid, even great at times, but in my opinion other aspects stand out. In that regard it is much like CD Project Reds last game, The Witcher 3. Solid gameplay, but the world, story and characters are what keeps one playing.
A few points I want to talk about.

Gameplay:
Put points in cool (It is Cyberpunk, how could you NOT put points into that!?) and reflex. Take a Katana, and you can deflect or even reflect bullets. At higher levels, chrome let’s you slow down time to a point, that you are literally unstoppable. Gameplay that makes you feel like a badass.

Characters: 
Characters in this game are memorable, complex and show development. Some are your best buddy, and you hate others. Some betray you and others can be betrayed by you. The dialog is well written, and conversations are interesting. One comes to mind, it is between Johnny and V while on a Yacht. The Yacht is inside a harbour which is part of a side mission, but no marker indicates that something can be found on the Yacht [4], which ties into my next point.
J: See, V? People in the city're eating' out of tubes, sleepin' rough, and here... Golden shitters. Where's the shame? Wheres the Fuckin' shame?
V: I don't know, Johnny. Lemme just ask the next billionaire I bump into on the street - tell 'im Johnny Silverhand asked.
J: No need to ask anything. Just spit in their face.
I like it for three reasons: (1) It characterizes Johnny, (2) It describes life in Night City and (3) it poses a real question.

Quests:
I was surprised, how much content is hidden in side missions. But not just filler content, I would argue that some of the best missions can be found there. For example, the whole story arc with Kerry can be missed. Some of the best, albeit very minor “characters” are found in side missions (Looking at you, Brendan and Skippy). Therefore, it feels very rewarding investing time in them.

Music: 
Music is a strong theme in cyberpunk. 
(1) At one point I was driving around when something caught my attention. The song I was listening to on the radio was written like a rapper living in Night City would write it, complete with locations and slang. That is immersive and shows dedication to the world building.
(2) Johnny Silverhand is a Rockerboy, which is a real class in Cyberpunk 2020. There are missions involving Samurai, his old band, where you can play guitar or listen to the band. This fictional band is on streaming services, which ties nicely to the next point.
(3) All mission names (after “meeting” Johnny) are song titles. And not random songs but ones whose motif relates to the mission and which Johnny would listen to [1, 2]. 

Cyberpunk 2020:
Cyberpunk 2077 is built upon the tabletop roleplaying game (TTRPG) Cyberpunk 2020 by Mike Pondsmith. Apparently, the polish translation of the TTRPG was done by early CD Project Red members [3]. A copy of the rulebook is included in the game – cool! Some aspects are very faithfully to the original. For example, the abduction of Alt is a short story inside the rulebook as well as one of Johnny’s songs, albeit with different text. Those are some details that are probably very cool to find for long time fans. But more importantly, they captured the feeling of Cyberpunk. 

Endings:
V: “A happier ending, for everyone involved?" 
J: "Here? For folks like us? Wrong city. Wrong people.” 
Creating an ending with closure and as little loose ends as possible is hard. The endings in Cyberpunk 2077 did it. Yes, they did it multiple times! They are filled with hope, bittersweet or just heartbreaking. Vastly different in tone and implications, only hinting at things or leaving them to the imagination. You can give up on V’s goal – what even is V’s goal, you could argue that it changes over time - or you can do everything to reach it. But beware, you may have to [i]pay the price[/i].
I feel like V’s story is over, and that is a good. 

Hinting and Foreshadowing:
The Ripperdoc Viktor can often be seen watching the recording of a boxing match. Near the end of the story V can ask him, why he is watching that match over and over if he knows the outcome. He answers that he is wondering, why his favorite lost, what was his mistake, he fought well. He concludes, that his only error might have been, that he went into the ring against a stronger opponent - Which has beautiful parallels to V’s story [5].
There are a lot of these details and foreshadowing. Some on the nose, others hidden. But, as with many aspects, most things are in the game in the way they are for a reason! 

The World:
The world is beautifully crafted. Graphically it is breathtaking. There are so many details (Places, People, Dialogue, Graphics). Night City comes to life. Hell, it might even be the ultimate villain of the story.

The Bad:
I do not want to give a one-sided review, but let me emphasize, they these points are just minor. I was missing shuriken as weapons, some animations of finishers were missing or lacking, some bugs and even a crash or three occurred. The launch in 2020 was apparently abysmal. 

Final words:
Cyberpunk 2077 is by no means a perfect game, but it is nonetheless a masterpiece. I still think about it after finishing it and it made me write this review - which are signs of a great game.

Basically open world, budget/knock off Deus Ex Mankind Divided. The environments are all pretty bland, one dimensional and forgettable, as are the unlockable abilities (instead of a cool new ability, usually just a % buff/debuff). The combat is the same as DX with bad AI. Inventory is just plain bad.

If you enjoyed stalking around buildings, learning AI paths and sneaking into an area that has a few skill checks in it, CP77 scratches that itch, albeit barely.

Combat is relatively poorly implemented in vanilla, with all enemies being stupid bullet sponges that have no tactical skills, and weapons all being pea shooters. Realistic combat overhaul is a must for this game, I cannot recommend you even think about playing without it. The enemies are less noticeably dumb when they kill and die in under a minute. 

If you want a coherent, relatable, well written story, you may not be in luck. The story is messy, with badly written dialogue full of impenetrable shorthand that seems awkward by design. The characters range from semi likeable to unlikeable morons who serve as vessels for mission giving and nothing more. Characters are introduced, killed and betrayed so quickly it's all a blur.

The world is insanely unfinished. Large swaths of the map are inaccessible by default due to being abandoned part way through development. Many intended interactive elements are awkwardly removed, like chairs you can't sit on and vendors you can't talk to. 

The intro to the game is a betrayal of several pre launch promises. Your life path is totally irrelevant to the majority of the game, as are all your decisions. You still go to the same places and do the same things no matter what, bar a couple of token variables flipped.

The soundtrack has some real bangers that I listen to outside the game (Dead Pilot anyone?) but there is NO synth wave, which is a huge mistake in a cyberpunk game.

The constant injection of modern politics gets very grating. 

Game is badly optimised even nearly a year after launch. Just runs sloppily and has a whole lot of performance oddities and spikes. Built in AA is lacking, as is the MANDATORY sharpening filter, which is full of grain and noise. Most effects should be disabled and replaced with reshade (including removing green filter). 


tl;dr:
*without mods, 5/10 broken
*with mods, 7.5/10 playable semi broken pseudo RPG
*extreme quality issues, expect possibility of refund for technical reasons
*WAIT FOR BIG SALE, over 25% off at least
*crappy spyware launcher that you are forced to install for no reason and isn't listed on the store page
*needs 40+GB space free at all times to update
*can't change your keybindings because there are duplicates of the same binding (crouch toggle, crouch hold, sprint toggle, sprint hold) and the game won't let you save changes unless EVERYTHING is bound
*of course the walking speed of the player is 10% faster than any NPC so you have to spend all of the VERY LONG dialogue scenes stopping and starting just like witcher 3

These developers are utterly useless. This is a s**tty Witcher 3 mod.

It's pretty easy to see why most reviewers gave Cyberpunk 9/10 score ... it was mainly because CDPR made this game whose last game was The Witcher 3 (arguably the best game ever made). However, cyberpunk falls way behind what Witcher 3 was. 

Pros: Whole lot of quests/missions to do in Night city, graphics are top notch (if you have a rig to turn everything on), decent main story.
Cons: Abysmal bugs (graphical glitches to quests getting bugged and cannot be completed), horrible AI (if even by accident  a civilian dies, the cops just spawn next to you and start shooting), forgettable characters (I mean someone who made Witcher 3 and gets this wrong?), terrible crafting system, life paths (what life paths? they converge within first 20 mins of playing).

All in all, this is a forgettable game. CDPR marketed this game as like the second coming of christ and it falls short on every aspect. Best I can give is 9/10.

Edit: After 2.0 patch and phantom liberty expansion, the game is worth it. It has been improved a lot since launch.

145h for 100% Achievements

TLDR, if the game seems interesting to you, play it. It's worth your time, with great gameplay / visual / audio / music / story. In more detail: 

Ok, I need to give context here. I played around 40h of Cyberpunk when it released in 2020, but that was mostly the open world stuff, and then I left it due to another game and I didn't return to it until Phantom Liberty released in 2023. At that stage, I went and finished the main game with all its achievements and the same for Phantom Liberty. 

145h later, Cyberpunk 2077 is an amazing game and anyone that likes open world games, first person shooters and a story driven game with high production value, should play it. 

To take the easy things out of the way, visually and graphically is pretty much one of the current benchmark games we have to check what our PCs can handle. It's not consistent throughout though, clearly certain areas had more dev love, but that is to expected with a world of that size. There are so many moments that you stop just to admire the vistas in front of you, and ofc cutscenes and overall characters are really well executed. 

Audio and music are top notch, with many songs worth listening long after you finish the game.

Music and visual, add so much on driving in Night City. Driving is fluid and fast, and picking the radio station that you like, and driving around this beautiful world is incredible, to the point that I ended up driving to most places instead of fast travelling. 

The world is very big, but most importantly, densely packed. There are many many quests and overall mission types scattered around and its hard to stumble in one of them every few blocks. Many of them are the classic mission style you would expect from open world games, but still, under the setting and due to the core gameplay, they work. 

Gameplay is improved vastly with 2.0 update, and skills matter more now, you can customize your character to your liking, find fun weapons and overall end up becoming a very fast and effective killing machine (if that's what you like). Solid gun-play and the movement abilities you unlock allow you to maneuver around any combat scenario in a pretty satisfying way. 

Last, and most importantly for me about Cyberpunk, is the story and setting. 
Main game provides a solid story with memorable characters and an amazing 'side-kick' that works so so well! The game is well written, and it provides multiple paths throughout the story that affect your relationship with some of the characters but also the outcome of the game. It has multiple endings, and amazingly, each ending is not just a cutscene, but around 2 full hours of story and gameplay with unique missions. Really well done and it's worth 100% to explore all endings. 

And then they released Phantom Liberty, which is more like a spy/thriller type of story, connects a bit to the main one, and it's again, really good and worths your time. 

To wrap it up, Achievements in the game are straight forward, and all achievable in one play-through, but for that to happen you need to keep multiple saves throughout the later story so you can go back and replay certain parts to get the different outcomes. And that is the case for both main game and dlc. But was totally worth it since you reward for that was all the multiple endings the game has.

One of the best games I've ever played. As someone who's a big fan of open world games, Cyberpunk 2077 gets my cut as one of the best open worlds I've come across.

The story of the game recognizes that in a cyberpunk world, poverty is still a rampant problem, corruption only increases with power, the rich still get richer, and those in the dregs of society continue to suffer. Despite the world being filled with brutality, hedonism, and cyber-psychosis - there are underdogs that would fight for truth and a better world. This attack on the "system" is what makes playing this game, especially in first-person, so interesting and engaging.

Haven't come across a single immersion-breaking bug. There's tons of gameplay and great idling. Highly recommend.
The 2.0 patch really helped this game.

Hands down my favorite RPG by a landslide. Even after 100%ing the game I still can't get enough of Night City and sometimes start new games immediately after I finish the previous one. I wasn't around for the launch but was there pre-2.0 and it only got better with the launch of Phantom Liberty which is like a whole other game itself on top of the main story. Going in I didn't expect much due to what I've heard before about the state of the game on launch but was blown away when I found out my first 5 hours was just the prologue. Sure, there's features that were promised to be there on launch that are still missing and I'm not excusing their absence. However what we got is still impressive. During the story I really resonated with some of the characters and their questlines and even V themselves. They all felt like I was talking to a real person other than some other generic NPC in any other game that's about to hand me a fetch quest. Even after one of the game's endings any characters you met and engaged in their stories will call V and give some commentary on their actions. Gunplay and build variety is satisfying and is fun to experiment with and come up with challenges on how to play, for example pistol only. There's tons of weapons to choose from ranging from a lead pipe to a lock on explosive shotgun, with iconic variants that have unique looks and effects. There's also tons of side jobs dotted around the map that even have stories of their own to either tackle along the main story or blast through after you've finished and have the best gear. Either way you'll be busy for hours. So if you're still on the fence about getting this game, do it. You won't regret it, choom.

INDUSTRIAL SOCIETY AND ITS FUTURE
Introduction

1. The Industrial Revolution and its consequences have been a disaster for the human race. They have greatly increased the life-expectancy of those of us who live in “advanced” countries, but they have destabilized society, have made life unfulfilling, have subjected human beings to indignities, have led to widespread psychological suffering (in the Third World to physical suffering as well) and have inflicted severe damage on the natural world. The continued development of technology will worsen the situation. It will certainly subject human beings to greater indignities and inflict greater damage on the natural world, it will probably lead to greater social disruption and psychological suffering, and it may lead to increased physical suffering even in “advanced” countries.

2. The industrial-technological system may survive or it may break down. If it survives, it MAY eventually achieve a low level of physical and psychological suffering, but only after passing through a long and very painful period of adjustment and only at the cost of permanently reducing human beings and many other living organisms to engineered products and mere cogs in the social machine. Furthermore, if the system survives, the consequences will be inevitable: There is no way of reforming or modifying the system so as to prevent it from depriving people of dignity and autonomy.

3. If the system breaks down the consequences will still be very painful. But the bigger the system grows the more disastrous the results of its breakdown will be, so if it is to break down it had best break down sooner rather than later.

4. We therefore advocate a revolution against the industrial system. This revolution may or may not make use of violence; it may be sudden or it may be a relatively gradual process spanning a few decades. We can’t predict any of that. But we do outline in a very general way the measures that those who hate the industrial system should take in order to prepare the way for a revolution against that form of society. This is not to be a POLITICAL revolution. Its object will be to overthrow not governments but the economic and technological basis of the present society.

5. In this article we give attention to only some of the negative developments that have grown out of the industrial-technological system. Other such developments we mention only briefly or ignore altogether. This does not mean that we regard these other developments as unimportant. For practical reasons we have to confine our discussion to areas that have received insufficient public attention or in which we have something new to say. For example, since there are well-developed environmental and wilderness movements, we have written very little about environmental degradation or the destruction of wild nature, even though we consider these to be highly important.

THE PSYCHOLOGY OF MODERN LEFTISM

6. Almost everyone will agree that we live in a deeply troubled society. One of the most widespread manifestations of the craziness of our world is leftism, so a discussion of the psychology of leftism can serve as an introduction to the discussion of the problems of modern society in general.

7. But what is leftism? During the first half of the 20th century leftism could have been practically identified with socialism. Today the movement is fragmented and it is not clear who can properly be called a leftist. When we speak of leftists in this article we have in mind mainly socialists, collectivists, “politically correct” types, feminists, gay and disability activists, animal rights activists and the like. But not everyone who is associated with one of these movements is a leftist. What we are trying to get at in discussing leftism is not so much movement or an ideology as a psychological type, or rather a collection of related types. Thus, what we mean by “leftism” will emerge more clearly in the course of our discussion of leftist psychology. (Also, see paragraphs 227-230.)

8. Even so, our conception of leftism will remain a good deal less clear than we would wish, but there doesn’t seem to be any remedy for this. All we are trying to do here is indicate in a rough and approximate way the two psychological tendencies that we believe are the main driving force of modern leftism. We by no means claim to be telling the WHOLE truth about leftist psychology. Also, our discussion is meant to apply to modern leftism only. We leave open the question of the extent to which our discussion could be applied to the leftists of the 19th and early 20th centuries.

9. The two psychological tendencies that underlie modern leftism we call “feelings of inferiority” and “oversocialization.” Feelings of inferiority are characteristic of modern leftism as a whole, while oversocialization is characteristic only of a certain segment of modern leftism; but this segment is highly influential.

After 4 years it's safe to say, this game has gotten better.

It is likely you have heard of the abysmal start Cyberpunk had on release, but that version of the game is a small dot in the rearview mirror of what the game is today. The atmosphere of Night City speaks as a new example for what an immersive game can be. The city is alive with things to do like fighting crime, random encounters, shopping for guns or cars or clothes, and dealing with chromed-out monsters flesh out the world as you move from quest to quest. Each of the offered playstyles are unique in dialogues as well as the gunplay, ranging from weapons that penetrate cover to ones that can simply fly around cover, truly giving you a sense of identity to your character. Cyberpunk allows you to make your own V to express how you live in the world in both combat and in role-playing. It’s a game with enough narrative agency to control how the story goes from the lifepaths at the start to the endings born from your decisions. Everything in the hours between depends on which characters you decide are worth your time. You can help an ex-cop find a missing person, a fiery grease monkey on the fringes of her family, and more. The stories told in both the main quests and side-quests are both touching and thrilling. Human stories sprinkled with bionic action sequences. 

Among its countless patches are several passes of rebalancing and re-working and patching to make a game that feels streamlined and balanced. The game has gone from a tangle of clumsy mechanics that trips over each other to a cohesive network of systems that actually feels pretty player-friendly. For example many of the health items have moved from quantities you find on the ground to simply recharging the item. One of the playstyles gives you a suite of hacking abilities to take out entire rooms without drawing a weapon. The Cyberware you can install gives you even more ways to play. The clothing system has been rebuilt to use an expansive transmog system to further create a character that is truly yours. There’s even been a photo mode added.

I've been waiting to write this review, wanted to give it at least 10 hours of gameplay.

The game is incredibly buggy, glitches with flickering NPCs and UI, running through people.

The whole AI seems like a placeholder to me, something they put in in the early dev stages and forgot to finish.
Cops spawn out of nowhere when you shoot someone without anyone seeing you. The stars you get make no sense.
Running around a corner makes them forget about you.

On missions, enemy AI is also incredibly buggy. You get spotted in one area, kill everyone present and move to another area and they somehow know about you and see you immediately, as if they saw you through the walls.

Pedestrian AI is unreactive, bumping into people doesn't do anything, just plays a single animation. They don't fall, they don't stumble, they don't say anything, nothing at all.

The driving mechanics seem really weird, synthetic, not natural. Running into cars or people is not enjoyable as it would be in GTA.

The character building system is too shallow, not too much space for really custom, unique characters. They advertised something completely different and it turned out to be a lie.

Overall, the most frustrating thing about the whole game is that the world feels lonely. No cop cars, co taxis, no buses, no vans. Can't enjoy being a villain like I would in GTA, just terrorizing the city. 

Imo, the biggest issue is the faulty AI. Without this issue, I might have enjoyed the game a bit more.

UPDATE 4 (Feb 7, 2024): God dang it, I must say that the game feels and plays much better now. Don't know why, but I just feel immersed, pulled in. Changing my initial opinion from not recommended to recommended.

UPDATE 5 (Feb 10, 2024): Wow ... I got further into the story, esp. the parallels to the main plot, and I must say that this is one of a few games that could talk to me emotionally. It really managed to pull me in. Not gonna spoil, so just gonna say that even a seemingly unimportant side character who has a couple of side quests is so well-written and believable that I just can't think of any other game that was able to do this to me. The closest would be MGS, but even that was mainly through cinematics, whereas here it's through choices you make regarding the characters.

Got the game after the 2.10 patch, so haven't gone through any period of massive bugs etc.

This game captures the cyberpunk genre almost flawlessly. The city is full of details, interesting areas, citizens, punks, gangs, police, people of all sorts. Many side quests to the main story, plenty of ability to ignore the main story line and just do your own thing for a while.

Character customisation, wow, so much to do, not just skill points and a tech tree, cyberwear, weapons, clothing... everything you need to create and style your character how you want. There are also plenty of stat points and skill points so you can go into multiple skill trees easily, so you don't feel like you need to specialise into only 1 niche.

Quests, decent variety of quest types, driving, killing, sneaking, stealing, assassination, rescuing and multiple ways to complete. Questing options available based on your skill strengths as well, adds to the benefit of your character specialisations.

Overall, there are a lot of nice things they have put into the game that work well together, to provide an overall immersive experience into the cyberpunk world.

Despite being overhyped and buggy at launch, I still found this game quite fun to play. It has improved a lot since then and I would now recommend it to anyone who likes the core gameplay concept of looting/shooting and exploring dialogue trees in a detailed and intriguing futuristic setting.

Cyberpunk is one of those games that is replayable even without mods, or even DLC. With lifepaths offering you a background to roleplay your character as, and the updated skill trees, you can play about any way you want, with many side objectives to distract you from the main questlines. My only "disliked" part is that there is absolutely no New Game Plus option internally in the game.

All in all, this game is much more than "Futuristic GTA".

Cyberpunk is a very personal and imaginative experience and tells a foreboding story of what may be to come in the not-so-far future.

It's been a while since a computer game has glued me to my chair for 60 hours with barely a break between work/sleep/game. 

Mechanically its a well conceived system of running, gunning, hacking, driving/exploration, crafting and all of the RPG good stuff, albeit a little bit poorly documented - you barely know what exactly your stats do. What does Evasion: 1 mean? 1% ? 1 out of XXX? What exactly does Armor: 324 mean? Will 200 hp be alright for the next 3 levels? All interesting RPG questions that concern me as an RPG player that are not very well explained.

You get to have a 'build' AND play a curious hybrid of FPS and Melee, with various gadgets such as slowing time or hacking people (kinda behaves like spells). 

Maybe wait before getting though, because designers have put a lot of effort into making this a very immersive experience which is sadly mired in visual bugs that break your immersion ever so often.

Cyberpunk 2077 is THE real AAA game, it required 2 years of polish but the result is astonishing.
This game immersivness has no challenger if you allow(and force) yourself to take your time, to let Night City breath into you.
The story telling, whole directing and narrative is incredible, Cyberpunk 2077 is the first game that manage to make me feel like im a part of a Villeneuve or Nolan movie. The writing is surpringly good and the voice acting top notch, it's violent, gritty, mature, everything you should expect from a Cyberpunk game.

However the game still has issue feature wise... The RPG aspect of the game is limited in the gameplay, LifePath being sacrified into a 10sec trailer did a huge damage to RP, and the player fail to learn Night City, the faction, gank, and urban legend... I will never understand that choice, specialy after crafting such a beliveable and immersive city.
Cyberpunk also constanly harass the player with Phone Calls (Quest/Gig) from unknown people, instead of making use of the Fixers and AfterLife to take missions at your own pace.
Game pacing suffer A LOT from this, it feels way too condensed, you never have to take your time to enjoy Night City to feel somekind of progression. The three main story quest are played at the same time for no reasons. artificialy stressing the player with a "bomb in the head" gimmick.
Clearly it has that console player/action pacing built, in a game who could have been a better RPG/simulation.
The game has also no money sink, car spawn and repair automaticaly, everything is incredibly cheap, and the player reach millions while still be asked to do errant job... 
As usual the player snowball very fast into becoming unstoppable, the game is also a bit too easy.

Some issue can be tweaked with mods, so I won't punish the game too hard about it...
Anyway Cyberpunk is a real experience, Night City and these characters are like no other in the actual gaming era. We can also tell that a lot of care have been injected into this game despite being a AAA for modern audience.

Cyberpunk 2077 was an Epic Journey for me, accompanied by masterpiece soundtrack.

8.8/10

Best open world RPG today
Easily rivals GTA V in the open world genre. More freedom and customizations, guess being filled with chrome feels more exciting than plain old gun and run.

Nowadays this is a fantastic, polished and gigantic game. Somewhere between FPS, adventure and RPG, I totally recommend it. Technically is stunning. There are some plots really emotionally touching. The mechanics are really fun. Discovering the bast city is rewarding. Characters are really well written. There are some caveats, however:
- Some minor tasks are very repetitive. However, they are not compulsory nor they advance the plot, so you can do them at your own pace.
- In general, the game is easy, maybe too easy, if you are experiences in similar games.
Overall, I totally recommend it. Forget about past bugs, the launch, the flop and all that noise. This game is beautiful, the plot is deep and rich, visually is fantastic, the sound and music are perfect. Play it.

This game is at its greatest state right now - the combat mechanics probably the pinnacle of what CD projekt red has achieved. I am quite surprised regarding their affinity for shooters and considered them to be RPG veterans and that's that. 

The character development in Cyberpunk 2077 is unfortunately not as strong as it could be, and the lifepaths are disappointing variations to an otherwise rather linear story. 

Nevertheless, the world and its writing is absolutely incredible and is undoubtedly the strongest aspect of the game. I strongly recommend this game to RPG fans with a strong desire for satisfying, fast-paced combat. If your main desire is player choice and creating a character that you can self-insert as, cRPGs are better suited to meet your needs. 

Night City is gorgeous and brimming with areas that you can explore. There isn't too much variety in terms of loot outside of weapons and cyberware... If you like cosmetics, there's a ton of loot when it comes to clothing. Other than that, it just boils down to crafting components for weapons and quickhacks. Traversal is amazing and you will LOVE to explore Night City, it's full of life and interesting locals. I adore the aesthetics and the various Gigs / side missions you come across. The star of the game is still the main mission.

Finally, the soundtrack is a 10/10 especially if you're a fan of synthwave. Play the game and enjoy the ride - it's full of goosebumps... And you WILL feel badass as V.

Simply put, the game is a fun time.

Night City is a beautiful landscape to feast your eyes upon, easy to lose yourself by simply driving around, and the world is simply an interesting place to be in. The story, even though I enjoy the different options and directions you could take, it was a fun story. If you want a story which reminds you of 80s action movies, you'll enjoy this. I don't think the story is super thought-provoking or a narrative masterpiece from what I played, but it's a fun journey to go on and decide your fate with. The ending I ended up with for me was worth the journey. The Phantom Liberty DLC story was definitely better than the overarching main story, but I still feel it was in the same vein of 80s where you are in for a fun time.

Overall, it was a very fun time and recommend it to those who are looking an RPG to simply escape in by exploring the world of Night City.

[h1]"We shouldn't fear change itself, But only who we might change into."[/h1]

[h1]Introduction[/h1]
Cyberpunk 2077 is an open-world, action-adventure with RPG elements that was released in December 2020 and sought to set the world alight with its gritty story and stunning graphics. Unfortunately, the launch didn't go as planned, as the release was buggy and far from the game we expected. Fast forward to now, almost four years later, and the release of version 2.0 and the expansion, "Phantom Liberty", has seen the game revitalised. But is it enough to bring Cyberpunk 2077 from the dead, or did it just get a few extra breaths?

[table]
[tr]
	[th][b]🟩 Positives[/b][/th]
	[th][b]🟥 Negatives[/b][/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td]🟩 The story, while confusing and poorly paced at times, is still enjoyable and full of unique twists and turns to keep you on your toes.

🟩 Graphically, this is easily one of the most beautiful games on the market, but you will need a literal powerhouse PC to pull that kind of performance from it.

🟩 The soundtrack matches the visuals, the music selection is impeccable as well as the general ambience of the city. With high-quality voice acting and dedication to make every district unique in its own right.

🟩 One of the best casts of companions in gaming who develop organically as the story progress and feel like real people.

🟩 2.0 saw a lot of rejuvenation to the original CP2077 formula. The rework to the skill trees, the addition of train travel and being able to spend some time with your romance choice, to name a few.[/td]
	[td]🟥 More bugs than an entomology lab.

🟥 No, seriously, there are A LOT of bugs in this game, some old, some new, and some game-breaking.

🟥 Visibly scripted quests ruin immersion.[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[h1]Story[/h1]
The story of Cyberpunk 2077 sees our main protagonist, V, awakening in Night City, starting in one of the three unique origin stories: Nomad, Streetkid or Corpo.

After getting to know your story, the situation in the city and meeting some key people, V and his best friend, Jackie Welles, get a job to steal a rare piece of Arasaka tech. For the remainder of the prologue, V spends time gathering intel and coordinating a theft that will set them up for life.

But with all the best-laid plans, this doesn't go as expected, and V ends up with an engram of the legendary rocker boy, Johnny Silverhand, stuck in his head. From this point on, V has to find a way to remove the tech in his head before it wipes away his entire personality and replaces it with Johnny's.

The storyline in Cyberpunk 2077 is intriguing and well-written for the most part, and its only major letdown is it's inadequately paced when completing side quests between main quest missions. In many of the side quests, you begin to build this relationship with Johnny Silverhand and slowly start to let your walls down as you get to know each other, then immediately lose this entire relationship when you return to a scripted main quest.

[h1]Gameplay Analysis[/h1]
[h3] It's the code you live by that defines who you are.[/h3]
CP2077 lets you play in nearly any way you wish, giving you multiple access points to any quest and usually providing a fair chance of coming out alive on the other side.

But a primary part of being able to do this is choosing a build that fits your playstyle. With the expansion, this is a bit easier as you are given ten additional levels to put into whatever you wish, but not impossible without it as long as you plan a little. And you have the choice of melee, gunner, netrunner, or a variant of those combined, depending on your preferences. The first two are pretty straightforward in what they entail, but netrunning is not as clear. It's practically your ability to hack enemies and things in your environment and cause damage from afar without firing a bullet.

[h3]There are no clean hands. But it is important how they become dirt.[/h3]
There are a lot of quests and side hustles to take part in across the city and quite a few impactful choices as well.

Many of these side quests hold engaging plotlines and provide unique rewards for completing them, such as iconic/unique weapons or vehicles.
It's unlikely you will unlock everything on your first playthrough, as there is a lot, and some of it is behind tough decisions you may not want to make.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3156325787

[h3]"Truth" and "Good" are values proven to cause division, whereas beauty is universal.[/h3]
Cyberpunk 2077 offers a ton of customisation options to create a V that is truly your own. From near-limitless clothing choices to the type of vehicle you prefer to drive, you will likely find something that fits you.

Very few clothing choices offer significant benefits to V, and they are more just an expression of yourself than anything. You gain most of your actual armour and bonuses from the cyberware you choose to install and what skills you take.

All the cars and bikes handle differently from each other and offer you different benefits such as more armour to take fire and hits to faster and lighter vehicles for losing heat quickly.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3156324652

[h3]2.0 and all that it brings.[/h3]
The 2.0 update brought a lot of positive changes to the game, but with those changes came a lot of bugs and issues on its own. It was pleasant to see the balance of cyberware and rework of the entire skill tree systems, as well as the implementation of the train line at long last, despite never seeing a moving train once in the game. On their own, these are really positive changes that warrant praise, but I would have preferred a cleaner experience than a more complete one.

[h1]Audio and Visual[/h1]
This is still one of the best visual experiences in gaming to date, but as I mentioned above, you need a literal powerhouse of a PC to get that kind of performance out of it. That's not to say it's not without its imperfections, because it has many of them and plenty of visual bugs and issues. But when it's running as intended, and you're looking out at the city, and the sun is setting, there are few better moments than that.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3156323915

The audio is much the same, very high-quality but not perfect. The soundtrack and all the music in the game are impeccably well chosen and fit the game and its world to absolute perfection. The atmospheric and animation audio is decent but suffers from the occasional bugs, and some of it is frequently recycled.

[h1]PC Performance and Specifications[/h1]
With the game set to Medium (Raytracing) with some custom adjustments to my usual preferences, the game ran at a steady 60 FPS the entire time. I did encountered a lot of bugs whilst playing, of both the visual and gameplay kinds.
🟧 A lot of bugs and glitches. Quests not starting when they should, cars falling out of the sky, NPCs and loot disappearing into the ground, etc.
RAM: 32GB (Under Load Usage: 46.8%)
CPU: i9 10900KA 3.70GHz (Under Load Usage: 30.5%)
GPU: MSI Ventus RTX 3080 (Under Load Usage: 40%)

[h1]Final Thoughts - Good[/h1]
[url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2529084785]Review chart here.[/url]
While I love Cyberpunk 2077, it's hard to recommend it as it has a lot of glaring flaws that really taint the overall experience. The decent story and somewhat fun gameplay loop are lost entirely when the immersion fades away because of teleporting police (yes, this still happens) or all your loot falling through the ground. It's certainly a worthwhile game on sale, but at full price right now, you're probably best saving that scratch for something less frustrating.

I originally threw the game a thumbs down at launch due to the terrible performance. But despite all the flaws, I could definitely acknowledge the draw of what Cyberpunk 2077 was offering, and felt the pull of Night City.

Like many people, I figured 2.0 was as good a time as any to finally test the waters... and I'm glad as HELL that I did. Without the barrier to entry that was the launch period instability, combined with the quality-of-life improvements they've added along the way, Cyberpunk 2077 in its current state has cemented itself as now one of my favourite games of all time.

The crowning achievement of the game is its living, atmospheric open world. Night City is dense and sprawling, with countless nooks & crannies hiding that could be hiding anything as small as some loot or as big as a full-blown side quest. It's a joy to explore, a pleasure traverse, and generally immersive to just simply exist in as you soak up the ambience.

The other draw is where the RPG elements start to come through; and that's through the deep skill trees, progression and buildcrafting, and how the direction you take will drastically affect your approach to gameplay. I felt like combat was pretty rough and janky to start with... but once I started learning the nuances, and began to get some upgrades under my belt, it began to transform into something totally addicting. This game really does let you play out your wildest augmented cyberkpunk merc power fantasies. I've rolled a few characters now because I just wanted to check out more playstyles, and so far each one has been very viable and very fun.

There are only a few gameplay shortcomings, that honestly I probably would have just been able to live with... except I don't have to, because this is PC gaming and we have mods! Most of my gameplay has been augmented with the aide of just a few minor mods and their dependencies:

1. [b][url=https://www.nexusmods.com/cyberpunk2077/mods/9358]Unlocked Attachments[/url] (w/ Phinix Silencer Audio Fix)[/b]: my first playthrough was a stealth ranged one, and it's absurd to me that there are so few silenceable weapons in the base game. This is the first mod I grabbed, so that I wasn't restricted to using basically just pistols and the ONE silenced sniper rifle that exists in this whole city.
2. [b][url=https://www.nexusmods.com/cyberpunk2077/mods/11035]Craft All Scope Variants[/url][/b]: the numerous styles of weapon scopes in this game also come in a variety of colours - not that you'd know, since the name & icon are always the same. This quality-of-life mod utilises the scope icon variants that already exist in the game files, so you can tell whether a scope is bright pink or fluorescent green BEFORE you put it on your gun.
3. [b][url=https://www.nexusmods.com/cyberpunk2077/mods/5544]Vanilla Clothes Atelier Store[/url][/b]: because finding clothes in the base game is a painful experience... just hoping you get lucky and they appear in chests, or when shop stock refreshes. I find it really hard to believe that online shopping wouldn't exist in this capitalist dystopia.
4. [b][url=https://www.nexusmods.com/cyberpunk2077/mods/4070]Silent Silencers/Throwing Knives[/url][/b]: pretty optional, mostly only felt like I needed this on a throwing weapons build, but it made it a lot more fun to play when every enemy in the game wasn't able to suddenly pinpoint my exact location from an axe I threw from atop a building 50 meters way.

An area that's both a strength & weakness would be the plot. CDPR have done a great job building out a believable game world out of the original game's lore, and paired that with an remarkable campaign and series of side stories that would make for incredible entertainment in almost any medium. Unfortunately for the game though, I had the unshakeable feeling of that old friend and late-2000's gamer hot topic: ludonarrative dissonance. In the opening hours of the game, you're basically TOLD you have a time limit - a fact I was so convinced of thanks to the gravitas the game places on this revelation that I actually had to check Google to make sure I wasn't REALLY battling against the clock.

That kinda takes a lot of the wind out of the sails of the plot, and it exacerbates my other issue which is the DELIVERY of it. It feels like you're being hurried along constantly and being pulled in all sorts of directions by all the side characters. Rushing back and forth between questlines as I progressed through my playthrough, I was frequently lost as I scrambled to remember what I'd previously done with this character days ago. It's very free-form and open how you approach the various plot branches, but a little better direction and perhaps less insistence with NPC's all demanding you come meet up NOW would have gone down well.

Those complaints aside, they didn't ultimately end up diminishing my enjoyment of the overall story too much - I was still satisfied with the outcomes my choices led me to, and the ending I landed on as a result. And considering just how good everything else is... the moment-to-moment experiences this game offers... it's impossible not to come away obsessed.

I wasn't interested at first, but after the Anime I bought it and I am really trying to love this game. I must say I like the gameplay, I really do! And although the main story is pretty bland (V is boring. Sorry but I never cared for the Everyman trope. And Jhonny is a dick. I had a major bug where the game crashed so often I had to constantly restart! After much tribulation to try and fix it, following every guide to no avail, I may have found a solution. It is not a perfect solution, though, as it gives me other problems; among others, the most obnoxious is the Frame Rate that sometimes drops consistently. And it also still crash sometimes. Anyway, now that I have finally completed it I must say that i liked it. As I said, the main story is kind of meh, not even close to The Witcher 3, so It is not a 10/10. Not even close. Ironically the side quests are a lot more fun and interesting than everything the main story have.

I didn't like this at first.  Too much real life style walk here-do this, wait for shit to happen, talk about nonsense.

Thing is, that's what this game offers I haven't gotten from any other RPG lately that I can recall--ACTUAL roleplaying.  I felt like V.  I reacted to people who aren't real.  V became a real person and I was really getting into how he might think or respond to a situation, not how *I* would respond.  I can't explain why, but that makes me keep coming back to leave nothing undone.

Gunplay is mid at its best.  UI is not the best.  Time-slow trivializes every combat I've encountered regardless of difficulty.  Hacking can do the same.  None of that matters.  Game is fun and immersive as hell, voice acting (and this cannot be stressed enough) is TOP NOTCH.

Pick it up.  Wait for a sale if you want.  But you should play it.

The sheer scale and detail of Night City are nothing short of breathtaking, and one of the most captivating aspects of Cyberpunk 2077 is its rich narrative and the fact that every decision I take change the story line of the game. I highly recommend trying this fantastic game.

[h2]Probably the best game I've played recently. [b]Just as good as BG3 - just in a completely different way[/b][/h2]

So, I finished the game and now I think I am in a good position write an honest review.

Both Cuberpunk 2077 and Phantom Liberty are... geez... [b]9.5/10[/b].

To start with - finishing both story lines took me 80 hours. Did most side gigs, explored a lot and did even more sightseeing.

[i] Take into consideration I played everything on maxed out visual settings [/i]

So, point by point.
[h2] NIGHT CITY and SURROUNDINGS [/h2]
+ Absolutely immersive. Huge, dark, crowded, dystopian and brutalistic;
+ The visuals are out of this world. The city lives. I spent good couple of hours just... admiring the place;
+ Neons and reflections. Dark alleys and those damaged people;
+ You sink into that place. It really resembles a real city with all those nooks and crannies;
+ It can leave you depressed for real;
+ Badlands kick ass to, with their post-apocalyptic desing and vibe;
+ Visual variety of different districts (darn, the cloth on unfinished buildings in Pacifica reacts to the wind...);
- Roads could make more sense. Especially the intersections on highways.

[h2] MECHANICS AND COMBAT: [/h2]
+ With 2.0 there's a lot of builds to pick from. 
+ Level cap of 60 allows to fully max 3 stats so one can be Netrunning Stealth Juggernout with Tech Affiliation.
+ Different feel of weapons to pick from. The variety is awesome. 
+ OBLITERATION. You can literally shoot your way through enemies or just do things silent.
+ Chrome - a lot to pick from.
- Vehicle control could be better. Some cars drive better, some less, but bikes, that should be the most agile of all feel like trucks with no turning radius.

[h2] STORY and SIDEGIGS [/h2]
+ I came here to have fun... not to feel... 
+ I'll just say that - finishing both storylines (CP+PL) left a gaping hole in my soul. 
+ The story is concluded. The end. Not much left untold and it feels good.
+ Lots of branching out smaller storylines. Each having it's own conlcusion.
+ Some things feel really bad, like [spoiler] letting Judy leave Night City [/spoiler].
+ There's more than one way to run things.
+ I really wish they've made more DLCs...
- I really came here to have fun and laughs... instead they made me feel stuff.

[h2] COMPANIEROS: [/h2]
+ They feel real and alive.
+ Johny is a pain in the butt in the beginning but the way the relationship between him and V evolves is... geez... it's good.
+ Interactrions with other people, random texts, talking sweet nothings. Make them feel more alive. 
+ Romances are generally good but
- It hurts that CDR scrapped the possibility to romance Judy as a male V :( 

[h2] CONCLUSION: [/h2]
[i]
The game left a gaping hole in my soul. The story is damn good, the choices are damn difficult, partings hurt deeply. The City is immersive and breathtaking. Brutal, unforgiving and sometimes all choices are bad choices.

I RECOMMEND THE GAME WITH ALL MY HOLLOW HEART.
[/i]

This game was a huge disappointment on launch, everybody knew that. It was probably the buggiest game I have ever played. It was unoptimized, stuttery, and hot garbage all around. I picked this up a week after it released not knowing too much about the state it was in. I could've left it at that; a broken promise of a game that I wouldn't give a second thought. But I stuck with it because despite the gaping flaws, it was still a very intriguing universe to play in. After a few years, it has come to be one of my all time favorite games up there with Titanfall 2, Left 4 Dead 2, and others. Cyberpunk has had the most dramatic glow up in my opinion, especially with the recent 2.1 and 2.11 updates and Phantom Liberty. I love the world, the characters, the fighting mechanics and cyberwear, and Night City as a concept. It truly feels like the game that was promised in the beginning. This game is fantastic, and I will continue to sink my time into it. The modding community is wonderful as well which is always great to see with a game as intricate as this one. If you get the right cyberwear and build up your perks accordingly, fighting the gangs and other enemies can be a fucking amazing power fantasy. I really hope they keep updating the game and expand upon the universe. 10/10

Honestly this game is fantastic I did not buy it on release since I saw all the problems it had, bought it around 6 months ago when I saw it was on sale, just to give it a shot. Did not have high hopes for it, mostly just wanted to kill time. And well, I've played around 300 hours at this point. The main plot is similar to Neuromancer (the book that technically started the cyberpunk genre as a whole). Definitely not as intriguing or dense as a Deus Ex plot, however, even with a simplistic main story line the in game world more than makes up for it. If there is anything Cyberpunk achieved is creating a feeling of absolute immersion in a beautifully chaotic world, the constant stream of ads and the neon drenched streets of Night City, the constant gang wars, the random conversations between NPC'S on the street. The city feels alive like no other open world game has ever felt before (besides Breath of the Wild). This level of immersion is further exacerbated by how fleshed out and interesting all the characters are. From V, Johnny, Songbird, Reed and much more. This characters are complex, they are more than just people who give you missions, you actually feel like listening to what they have to say, their dialogue feels organic (unlike a certain Starfiled game)  they all  have emotional depth, backstories, they are all morally grey, which in turn makes them feel so humanized and relatable, even within a crazy world of talking guns (I love you Skippy) and bullet blocking swords. But not only does the game shine in this regard, the gameplay is amazing. So many build options, insane amounts of weapons, tons of missions, and tons of ways to tackle said missions. The movement is GREAT, with tons of verticality and very fluid movement, funny enough the worst way to move around the city is actually driving, it feels very stiff, but not to terrible either. Also, the game never directly tells you how to solve a mission, you can choose from a bunch of options, from pure carnage, to tactical stealth,  hacking (hacking is so fun) and sometime you can even complete a mission through the correct dialogue choices alone. Overall, yup, this game is great, and I will argue that CDPR deserves all the praise by taking something that was dead at launch , not giving up on it, and with care and passion making it an absolute must play banger. Oh and buy the complete edition, Phantom Liberty truly cranks up the base game to 11. I would argue it just should be played as the whole experience.
Incredible game with next level world building and almost no flaws except the bugs which I hate but I can tell that CDPR genuinely wants to improve the game.

I spent hours googling crash-to-desktop bug fixes before I could play this game for more than a few seconds. 

It was totally worth it.

The writing is great. The gameplay is great. The visual design is spectacular. I'd wanted to play an open-world cyberpunk game like this for many years, and it has exceeded my expectations.

I've gone with a Body-heavy build with lots of regenerating health. I'm playing this basically like Halo but with dialogue and exploration. I'm having a ton of fun with that. The gunplay is good, I don't feel like I've been missing out by mostly ignoring stealth and hacking. 

There's plenty of complexity to get my teeth into, but nothing that's given me choice paralysis. Most build choices I've made have had immediately noticeable effects that changed how I approached fights. That has been very satisfying. I never played before the 2.0 patch; I don't think I missed out.

Some systems are underexplained, but fan wikis etc. have been helpful. One I want to highlight is that health and grenade "consumables" are actually reusable items with cooldowns, not items you can run out of. This works nicely! I tend to hoard items, like many RPG players. This system's motivated me to use items often in combat, and I've enjoyed that. It adds depth and variety, and a reason to try out new tactics with no fear of "wasting" limited-use resources.

After I solved the crash-to-desktop problems that kept me from starting, I haven't noticed any other glitches. Frame rate dips in heavily populated areas, but nothing unreasonable for a PC as old as mine, and I've been pleasantly surprised that my frame rate has never dropped noticeably during combat.

As a devoted enthusiast of the cyberpunk sub-genre of sci-fi, my fascination with dystopian stories began with literary classics like "1984" and "Brave New World,". It was then mixed with science fiction, and philosophy of existence, consciousness and artificial intelligence which lead me towards the works of Philip K. D!ck and William Gibson. After reading their novels, I was engrossed in cyberpunk media through film and video-games. This is where my passion for "high tech, low life" type of science fiction started to take root.

Upon Cyberpunk 2077's release, my anticipation led me to dive headfirst into the game. Initially, while I found enjoyment in some side missions, the main plot failed to engage me completely. Luckily, I encountered no game-breaking bugs, and graphical issues on my GeForce 1660 Ti actually never affected my experience. Completing my first play-through with the suicide ending, I've left the game feeling somewhat underwhelmed. The game was good, but it was nothing special for me at that time.

Returning to the game in June 2023 after various patches, my second play-through ended with a completely different experience. I came to understand that my initial disconnect wasn't the game's fault but rather my oversight. Ignoring crucial elements—romance, cyber-ware upgrades, and crafting—hindered my immersion. Exploring these mechanics in-depth transformed how I approached game play, which in turn offered a renewed sense of excitement and depth.

After dedicating over 380 hours, exploring the game across all difficulties and completing all of the achievements (including the Phantom Liberty ones), Cyberpunk 2077 has left an indelible mark on me. While trying to explore every facet, I've discovered that this game has an incredible ability to evoke a range of emotions, from heartbreak to elation.

With the continuous updates and the DLC, Cyberpunk 2077 has surpassed even my initial expectations, evolving into an experience beyond what I could have hoped for. Its adaptability to different play-styles and its vastness—especially in vertical exploration—encourages exploration and rediscovery. I eagerly look forward to revisiting this game every year.

In summary, I wholeheartedly endorse and recommend Cyberpunk 2077. Its evolution from an over-hyped shovelware, bolstered by consistent updates, has exceeded all possible expectations. It trully showcased the transformative power of videogames -  it showed that when developers care for what they create, and when they dedicate themselves to improving the game, they can overcome even the first horrible impressions, and step into the greatness. To me, Cyberpunk is one of the greatest games I've ever played and I can only hope that it will reach the cult status and be remembered along with the other amazing games that will - Never Fade Away!

Update 2.0 finished the formerly unfinished mechanics of the game and replaced what were undercooked gameplay mechanics with well-balanced , more enjoyable ones. On top of this it fixed numerous bugs and cleaned up glaring inconsistencies or issues in quests.

In short, gameplay-wise there's no misgivings left to stop me from recommending the game. As others say, update 2.0 basically finished the game.

Bugs-wise, there are still more bugs than GTA V for example, but thanks to update 2.0 there are less bugs in C2077 than in Skyrim or Fallout 4 (not sure about Starfield, haven't touched it)

Graphics-wise, the city is packed full of visual detail. You really need an RTX GPU and at least an i7 CPU. I've done potato gaming on older laptops, so I can say from prior experience that this won't be running on a potato.


As for my thoughts on actual gameplay: I enjoy this way more than any Bethesda game. The combat is better balanced and more interesting, and the writing is professionally done (Bethesda didn't have professional writers for Skyrim or Fallout 4). The things you do on one end of the city can have an impact on the other end. Connections you make through normal mercenary work end up saving you trouble later down the line.
Cyberjunk to Cyberpunk

And it came to pass, in the land of Night City, there arose a wanderer named V, whose origin was of lowly birth or of exalted lineage, as the teller of tales so chooseth. And V didst walk the streets of corruption and neon, where the serpent of technology and the dove of humanity didst struggle in eternal enmity.

And behold, there was in the city a relic most coveted, which promised the secrets of immortality. But verily, its power was hidden, as the deepest mysteries of the Most High. And V, with heart bold and companions diverse, didst embark upon a quest to uncover this sacred and profane mystery.

In the days of V's journeying, many were the trials and tribulations. The corporations, mighty and cold as the north wind, didst plot with guile, and their armies of metal and circuitry were as a plague upon the land. But V was cunning, and with silver tongue and iron fist, didst navigate the treacherous waters of deceit and violence.

And lo, there came unto V a spirit, digital and yet most human, named Johnny Silverhand. And Johnny was as a prophet of old, crying out in the digital wilderness, a voice against the tyranny of the corporeal overlords. Together, they didst forge a bond, strong as the cables that doth bind the earth to the heavens.

Yet, remember, O reader, that the path of V was not one of mere flesh and blood, for the soul of humankind was intertwined with the machine, and the question of what it meaneth to be alive was as a riddle, wrapped in a mystery, inside an enigma, encrypted in the most arcane code.

So, let the tale of V be told, of battles fierce, of friendships wrought in the crucible of adversity, and of choices weightier than the heaviest of cybernetic implants. For in the chronicles of Night City, the deeds of the brave and the cunning are as a light unto the darkness, a testament to the enduring spirit of humanity amidst the chrome and neon shadows.

Thus, the tale unfurls like a scroll, full of sound and fury, signifying everything to those with ears to hear and eyes to behold the electric dreams of the cyberpunk age. Amen.

Storywise the game is one of the best . The writing is really damn good. And as of patch  2.0 the gameplay is pretty damn good as well. i had gotten the chance to play through the game long back back when it was on patch 1.2-3 ish. and compared to then its a day and night difference . now the different builds you can have in the game actually changes up your playstyle in a significant way . the only thing i miss from the old version is the silenced revolvers. 

and the dlc improves upon the base game in a lot of ways as well. your choices feel more meaningful throughout. theres more stuff to do . the gigs are way more interesting with fun stories and encounters. the only real problem with the dlc is the fps drops . sometimes it drops to well below 20fps. after the latest patch 2.11 it hasnt ever dropped that low but its gone down to around 25 once in a while. restarting the game seems to fix the fps drops temporarily. in the base game im averaging around 55-60 btw.

the game has been improved a lot compared to launch. the combat is much better. so is the driving. and a lot of the bugs have been fixed. but i still wouldnt call this is a polished game ;)  some side quests still have audio bugs . rn the scanner doesnt seem to scan a good number of dead bodies which im 90% sure wasnt the case before. cars still sometimes spawn falling from the air. the el capitan vehicle stealing missions are currently bugged. no matter what you do a lot them end up failing automatically once you reach a certain distance from the destination. i still cant close the windows in my megabuilding apartment since the romantic hangout. also the radioport seems to stop working for like 2 seconds whenever i start climbing a ladder.

anyway the game is still great and definitley worth playing . the main story missions and 90% of sidequests as well are completely bug free. its got a great story , really good gameplay and phenomenal music. definitely one of the best video game soundtracks ive ever listened to.

One of the most immersive experiences in gaming available today. The star of the show is the expertly crafted Night City itself. There genuinely isn't any environment so rich, believable and yet beautiful. You can be standing anywhere in the vast city looking anywhere in any direction and you will be met with a breathtaking view. Despite this immersion, the game does not compromise on the gameplay level. With update 2.0 the gameplay is transformed into an unbelievably fun and amazing sandbox experience with an astonishing amount of build possibility. You can approach  a 100 people and each would be playing with their own set of guns, cyberware, and perks, a build optimised entirely for them. The combat is fluid and fast, and lets you experiment and enjoy in many ways. I will say there is a lack of difficulty. Even on Very Hard, after level 50 you will become a God with your only concern being how spectacularly can you dispatch the next enemy. While the power is fun, I do wish there was more challenge to the combat other than a couple well designed boss encounters. Finally the story is amazing. Both the base game story and the expansion story are beautifully crafted to deliver real and gripping emotional roller coaster. These stories have had a profound impact on me and I cannot emphasise enough how well executed they are. 
That said I wish to come to my only issue with the game: cut content. The base game is the most affected by this. Megabuildings are the most prominent feature in the skyline and entirely inaccessible in every meaningful manner. The Corporations and gangs are severely atrophied. Even the base game story feels like there was a lot more planned for it and there definitely are pacing issues due to this fact. And it is important to not forget that this game is not an RPG. It is very easy to become lost within V and become a person on the streets of Night City, but other than playing a personality, meaningfully altering the story is missing. This is corrected in the Expansion to great extent though and it is probaly the cancelled content that resulted in a far more linear experience narratively speaking.
Despite it all Cyberpunk 2077 is one of the best games available today to play today, and it absolutely worth playing. It is fun, emotional, thought provoking and immersive. If you haven't played it yet, you should do yourself a favour try it out.

Probably one of the worst "open world" "rpg"(yes, those are in quotes for a reason) games I have ever had the misfortune to play. The only slightly redeemable aspect WAS the gun-play, but after reinstalling it I found that somehow even that had become ruined. My first playthrough I forced myself to get the living legend end. This time I think I'll just save disk space for ARK dlc or something. Because even ARK has a better story/main questline than this game. Cyberpunk's "story" feels like a D&D oneshot that got dragged into a full campaign because the player got side-tracked and bored with the main story. Kinda like Baldur's Gate 3 in all honestly, but at least that game has pretty adequate suspension of disbelief that allows you to enjoy the story... although like Cyberpunk it really makes no sense that you should do anything other than the main quest, at least until you reach aforementioned suspension of disbelief part. Cyberpunk just straight up makes no sense as to why somebody with ONE MONTH TO LIVE would be running around stopping cyberpsychos, buying cars, making money or doing LITERALLY ANYTHING that isn't getting cured(the main quest); because UNLIKE Baldur's Gate 3 you DON'T have anything stopping that month from running out tomorrow.

Cyberpunk 2076 would have been a better game by miles, with the events of Cyberpunk 2077 being either a sequel game or final DLC to you and Jackie's misadventures; instead of having Jackie be wasted on tutorials, a montage and consigned to an easily avoidable death. In addition, having Jackie(and not V) be resurrected by the chip would have been a MUCH better story than the force-fed junk given to us, because now maybe the reason V is doing all of that is to help Jackie by earning enough money or something, instead of being handed the solution on a silver platter and being given LITERALLY every incentive to ignore it and NO reason(beyond roleplay) not to do so.

The performance of this game on my hardware has significantly improved since I first played on patch 1.6 with low-med settings at 1440p, putting me below 30 fps average, and being unable to hit 60 at 1080p lowest settings. I came back after patch 1.63 and downloaded some potato-pc mods that allowed me to complete the game, although, without the ability to render most things, including all hair, leading to an average of still below 60 fps, but more playable.

Now, as of patch 2.11, with the same setup, I am able to achieve 60+ fps average on med-high settings 1440p. This absolutely insane performance increase really tells me how rushed this shit was to release. Horribly optimized at the start, but, honestly they should change the spec/requirements section to something less powerful than even a 1060.

Everyone already knows this and have their own opinion, so here's mine.

Pros:

- Story: 10/10
Judy is almost one of my favourite characters ever in any entertainment medium (anime,games,tv). So the quality of story and writing and characters are amazing

- Side Quests: 10/10
Not a single boring one

- Gameplay: 8/10
Standard Deus Ex Mankind Divided stuff but lesser fleshed out. I really don't like perks that increase few % here and there

- Level Design: 10/10
Night City is amazing (graphics, side quests, traversal by foot/vehicle, verticality)

- Performance (CPU): 10/10
Uses all cores to their max unlike unreal engine nonsense single threaded

Cons:

- Grinding: 6/10 
Not too much is required if you do some amount of side quests(which I highly recommend doing). Then there are GIGs (low quality nonsense just for grinding which if possible you should avoid). I hate these skill trees where additional slots are unlocked or some % / numbers increase. We have to go into menus quite often to do this. And we keep selling junk all the time, in my opinion which is a waste of time

- Enemy/ NPC AI: 6/10
Leaves a bit more to be desired compared to Red dead/ Last of us 2, metal gear solid phantom pain etc.

- Stability: 7/10
Bugs are there, but nothing game breaking  (though I played on 3080 Ti and 6800xt)
They used to really takes you out of immersion but not anymore

- Performance (GPU): 7/10
This is really not optimized for AMD cards for ray tracing which is a shame. They should have had a setting for Ray traced reflections (low, high,medium) like they had for Ray traced Global Illumination. To be fair, for non-ray tracing, they gave lots of options to tweak. Also they were VERY slow to implement FSR 1.0 and FSR2.0 . This game can't run properly without DLSS which is a bit sad, even on highest GPUs with good settings. Also there should be higher texture quality setting for people with more VRAM instead of some pop-ins and in general not so great textures on some people

Overall, I would say play this game, especially after 2.1 patch if you haven't already
