(SPOILER FREE)
TLDR: Must play once in your life time. Spend time with it, immerse yourself in it and this game will stay within your heart forever. 


Gameplay: 
 Buggier than Skyrim and still rough around the edges. However, it is very enjoyable and with its good modding capability, you can change many elements of the game to suit your flavour. Even without mods, the game offers many unique play-styles, but there are some strategies which you would definitely want to follow regardless of what you choose for your character. Off the top of my head, the Tech tree is a must have for any build for increasing cyberware capacity, investing in dash and air dash skills in the Reflex tree for greater movements, and break down extra weapons for upgrade components instead of selling them (especially tier 5).


Graphics:
 With the right hardware setup and the game's Ray Tracing and Path Tracing capabilities, its visual is unmatched. With mods, the game can look very close to real life (no exaggeration). As a start, I recommend Nova LUT mod by theCyanideX in Nexus mods.


Sounds:
 Great voice acting, especially by Cherami Leigh who plays female V. I have never felt as sympathetic and attached to a playable, main character as much as female V, if it weren't for her performance and the strong writing. The way she changes her performance as the story progresses to match V's character growth was very good and I believe nobody could play female V as well as she had. The music was also very good and I loved the way the game introduced real bands and singers into the game as fictional bands and singers, with their own backstories and unique interactions. The biggest issues I had relating to the game audio were: poor sound quality from some voice lines, and minor game bugs which cause the audio to become too quiet/loud/silent. The drop in quality of some voice lines was most likely due to some recording sessions not taking place in professional studios during covid quarantine, and it is most notable in the Phantom Liberty DLC.


Writing: 
 The world building and the atmosphere is very rich and unique. It is very easy to lose yourself in it, especially if you like cyberpunk genre. The writing for the dialogues are mostly very good but sometimes, they don't quite make sense, either due to cut content or bugs... Regardless, I thought the issues were minor in comparison to the good. In addition, there are many layers to the stories and the world of the Cyberpunk 2077, which will give you ample opportunities to really dissect and ponder on their meanings.

 Out of all the multiple-choice games I know, no games finish their stories as well as this game has. The ending of a story is the hardest part of creating a great story. This is especially true for games with multiple choices and endings, in which writers often resort to creating simple solutions out of the blue, at the end of the game (i.e. Mass Effect 3, Deus Ex: Human Revolution, and etc.). Many popular films, games and comics have great beginnings and middles but a lot of them fail to give logical, satisfying, memorable, and thought provoking conclusions. Which is why I believe that a good ending is what separates a great story from a good story. 

 Cyberpunk 2077 succeeds in delivering outstanding conclusions from multiple branches of choices. None of the endings felt forced or out of place, and they all meaningfully answer the question that you are being asked, since the start of the game (won't spoil what it is, you will have to figure it out yourself by playing). All of them reflect the choices you/the protagonist make throughout the story and I am sure after you complete the game, you will be thinking about the characters you've interacted with and their world for a long time. The way the game concluded its story is the main reason why it is now my favourite, and I am not sure if I will experience something as profound and good from a video game, again. 

 To anybody reading this, if you can immerse yourself in this game's world, you will have an unforgettable experience that will take you through one of the best emotional roller coasters a game can offer (assuming you haven't spoiled yourself with the plot of the game). Out of all the games I could have played, I am really glad it was this.

It's got guns, titties, weiner if you're a little limp in the wrist and enough side content to keep your ADHD-addled zoomer brain engaged. All this in mind, CP truly is an experience to remember.

AMAZING

HONEST REVIEW

Main Story - 7.5/10 - very good. Nothing absolutely mind blowing but good. 

Phantom Liberty Story - 9/10 - way better than the main story. 

Game Endings - 2/10 - The majority of V's endings are terrible, ruins the vibe and the game. 

Weapons 7.5/10 

Overall Map - 8/10 - The city has a soul. Very immersive. Night City is a beautiful tragedy. 

Characters - 10/10 - They absolutely killed it this one. All characters feel iconic and unique in a good way. 

Main Character (V) - 8/10

Johnny Silverhand - 11/10 - Through the roof. One of the best, if not the best character in a video game. 

Dogtown - 8/10 - Very good but too small. 

Homes - 4/10 - A disappointment. Can only get apartments. Not even a house or a mansion. 

Side Missions Overall - 6/10 - Some are pretty cool I guess. 

Cyberware - 9/10

Skill Tree Overall - 8/10 - There should be more relic skills. 

Police - 7/10

Combat System - 8/10 - Feels fast and nice but lacks a bit of smoothness. 

Music/Soundtrack Overall - 9.5/10 - Samurai carried this one. Never Fade Away is actually good. 

Cars Overall - 7/10 - Weaponized vehicles could be better. Need more, nicer cars. 

Car Customization - 0/10 - Absolutely terrible. Rayfield color changing is all there is, seriously? No modding, no body kits, no good stuff. 

Clothes - 6.5/10 

Romance 6/10 - Can't make love to them when inviting them over, Can't date Judy if your male, can't date Kerry if your female, V should be able to romance any. The players should get what they want. 

Message to Cyberpunk 2077 developers or whoever works on this game: For this game or its sequel, make better endings, better vehicle customization, better romance opportunities, better homes and not just small apartments, and make the game more smooth, especially the combat system. 

Cyberpunk Overall - 7/10

All the best elements of a Bethesda rpg, GTA V, Bioshock/Systemshock rolled into one game with its own unique aesthetic style and a story-rich world that gave me all the feels. Definitely worth all the eddies at any sale point, don't miss out choom.

The extensive nature of Night City, and Dog Town in the expansion pack, give a huge number of different things that you can do at your own pace. The introductory Part I is great the first time through, but is a little obnoxious if you want to replay the game with a new starting character because it is necessarily restrictive, particularly the hotel main quest sequences. I realize that it has to be for the story, but it is boring on a subsequent play through. Decisions in the game come back to haunt or pleasantly surprise you later and you have little idea at the time that you make them. The vast number of outfits, vehicles, weapons, weapon mods, etc. is staggering and very interesting. The attribute/perk system is much improved in the latest version. The only story issue that I have personally is that most of the endings are real downers. Did they learn nothing from Fallout 3? I don't want to invest hundreds of hours playing a game to come away thinking that it was never going to work out well for the character, no matter what I decided. Too "Emo". You would think that there would be some kind of "happy" ending to attain. If you decide to do the "romance" options, you have only one option for your character and you almost have to read online to determine who that is and how not to screw up the dialogue in order to make things work. Answer a question wrong and many, many hours of game play later, you are missing an option in the dialogue. Like other games, as you level up, you find more great and iconic weapons. Unfortunately, at that point, you don't have much game time left to use them. If you have the Phantom Liberty expansion, try to get to it as early as possible to improve the game equipment in all parts of the city. Overall, I enjoy the game a lot and have really enjoyed it much more during the second and subsequent times through. And yes.... that is Keanu Reeves and the "Mayhem" Allstate guy.

UPDATE: 02/06/2024 - After having played through Phantom Liberty - which just adds to this extraordinary title - I'd just like to say that everything I wrote abut this game below in regards to how it will be remembered in history has already come true. If you haven't played it yet there should be nothing holding you back :-) 

After 320+ hours I can honestly say this is the best game I've ever played. Yes, it was a horrible launch and I had so many crashes but now with all the patches that have come out I've been sucked into this game like nothing else. I did every ending (including the secret one) and now I'm about to do the whole game again as a male V. The combat is so fun and all the different creative ways I can approach a problem can cause anything from sheer comedy to butt clenching mayhem. Don't let anyone tell you that the story isn't deep or the characters are shallow. When I read those reviews I know right away that the reviewer didn't actually play the game. I did every single thing there is to do - I cleared the map until there was nothing - and there are so many tiny nuances to discover about each main character that it staggers the mind to think how they even story boarded it. Thanks CD Projekt Red - can't wait for some DLC.

By the way, let's not even mention the huge modding community that has evolved and how that opens up a whole crap load of new things to do. Game isn't going anywhere and in the future it will be written about calling it a  pioneering master piece.

You take on Night City, a corrupt and power hungry futuristic city in America. As a nobody, gun-for-hire mercenary named V. Survive and make a name for yourself in Night City.

[b]The Good[/b]

+ Breathtaking open world city with a crazy amount of content. Taking on jobs that all have unique and interesting lore and story attached, building up reputation that comes with its kinks and establishing relationships all in itself already leave an unforgettable experience. Voice acting, animations, sound design and soundtrack, incredible. It's mesmerizing what has been built here, very impressive considering the scale of this game. It is in every way a technical leap in gaming.
+ Side quests that don’t feel like side quests, because they're on par with the main quests in terms of quality, and don't feel like the usual 'filler' content we're used to in games so big. They're some of the most fun I had in the game.
+ Combat system that resembles Borderlands, and other 'looter' games. There are tons of weapons to play around and tinker with. You can also upgrade your body with all sorts of kinky parts and weapons as well, to discover different approaches to encounters.
+ Character customization is solid. Not only is there really great character creation, you can also change your character during your playthrough at any time, to really personalize your character as you're playing.
+ Great roleplay aspect that really makes the game feel more immersive and responsive to your personal input, thought it's not a true RPG experience so therefore not a selling point. Still the way the dialogue options you choose change how conversations go is satisfying and keeps you engaged.

[b]The Bad[/b]

- The performance, far from a perfect experience, but it is solid enough that most players won’t have major issues. One of the visual bugs I encountered was the rain, it makes the lines of objects jagged and ugly. Though, there is a community mod available to fix that.
- While I do love the sheer amount of content. Trying to do it all can prove occasionally challenging, since the objective may prove to be confusing or buggy.
- [strike]Driving feels sluggish at times. I found myself hitting a bunch of things inside the city because everything felt a bit crammed up.[/strike] Improved in the 2.11 patch all around.

[b]Thoughts[/b]

There is so much content in this game that I could continue to go more in-depth, but I feel like you might have a pretty good idea of what to expect now. The major bugs that were present on launch are pretty much no longer a thing, and you are not left with the feeling of there being more to be desired, it's a very expansive and especial experience start to finish.

Would I recommend it? Yes. This is now a must play. Whilst it does still come with its fair share of issues, the great outways the bad by a lot. [strike]I will update this review when I have finished the Phantom Liberty expansion.[/strike]

The Phantom Liberty expansion, let's talk about it. It's great. Strong narrative, has a more fleshed out and satisfying ending than in the main game, well if you choose the right option. It also adds some nice final touches to other characters' stories. Overall a much worthy playthrough if you enjoyed the main game.

Edit: It's been a few years of massive updates, so I feel I should expand on my review.

This game was phenomenal when it released and has only gotten better. There were a lot of reports of bugs and optimization issues, but I experienced very little of these even on my GTX 1080 that I had at the time. Now, the game has had massive overhauls and content updates since release and it's only improved the experience. Replaying it again for Phantom Liberty, it feels like a different game. The skill system has been overhauled, the combat has been tweaked, mods have been going strong, and that's not even mentioning the mind-blowing narrative of the expansion (which was added on top of an already phenomenal plot). Visuals are breathtaking (especially with ray tracing and LUT mods), performance has significantly improved, and overall gameplay feels much smoother.

Overall, even with the rocky start, CDPR has proven that they care about this game and about their fanbase. Can't wait to see what they have in store for the sequel!

This game is supposed to be 'fixed' but its still a mess. Car's spawning upside down and in the ground, getting stuck on shit, fucked up inputs the list goes on.

Yea the game is pretty good but its a mess with bugs, saw a few t-poses, clipping a bike in a railway and now, the game is unplayable, i am, unable to use weapons, I cant pull them out, maybe i can fix it by going to a main mission, or waiting for some cut scene but I'm getting quite tired of the bugs at this point. If you dont mind the bugs, i recommend the game without a doubt, since it has some beautiful scenery, a nice story (or at least from what i can get to at this moment) and the progression system is also pretty good since you increase on street creds and it unlocks what you can and cant use, main problem with the game is the gangs and police, since they seem to get angry out of no where sometimes and the police appear like Houdini or something. 
Final conclusion, game is a mess, even though it was announced in 2012, a decent amount of time to make the game, but what came out was a crunched, rushed game that from launch day to now we still have problems. Solid with graphics, story, progression and characters, but buggy, rushed, sometimes unplayable with a sprinkle of magic police men appearing out of thin air.

Vers 2.0 and beyond update

Now considering that the game has recently had a pretty big update all around, i think that i can say that this game is polished enough to the point its a solid recommendation, the police system is a lot better, the way cybernetics works also is much better, even if it got a bit of a nerf (which is still good since being allowed to put as many however you wanted seemed a little too much to me). New options for the apartments, dlc options and more, they all seem like positive changes that make the game a lot better. One thing i do recommend is to have a bit of a beefy system if you want good graphical looks, especially for raytracing

Played original build out and the new Phantom Liberty.  It was much more complex and took longer to 'power up' on the old build but had item scaling issues that made them obsolete.  Story was good from the beginning it was just some issues with graphics that seemed under delivered.  The new build is streamlined and much easier for gear crafting and leveling, but seems almost too easy to 'power up' quickly and makes the remaining game barely a challenge.  Overall the changes balanced the game more and stopped making items obsolete within the new system, but having experienced the original intent the clothing serves nearly no purpose anymore.  I find myself using stealth at first for survival, but once leveled and chromed stealth is pointlessly slow unless story driven.  Combat is fast and exciting theme music, vehicle chases are intense, and story has drama of all sorts, so its a great game overall.  Can only lay the foundations for an even better sequel.   Definitely buy this game chooms!

Excellent post-apocalyptic first-person hybridish shooter.  I played this game 30 years ago pencil and paper along with Shadowrun and always loved both systems. Although the start of CP2077 was buggy, great work getting those bugs and storylines fixed. I highly recommend this game.

The game has come a long way. Right now, it is close to what I feel a current bethesda game should be. The open world is beautiful, the story line largely fits the world and setting, the game play is fun, there are a large number of builds and ways to play giving you reasons to replay it, just to see how other builds could do missions, and how it does or doesn't effect the plot. The issues the game has is its still a bit too linear, thats not terrible but it would help if your actions had greater impact on just how the story will end if for no other reason than to give added reasons to replay the game.

Still it is worth a play, and its nice to see a big studio redeem a bad product.

Patch 2.11 completley broke custom keybindings.
I had the dodge/dash ability relocated to one of the side buttons of my mouse because its objectively better and more intuitive that way. Now every time I try to load a save file the game instantly crashes. It works fine again when you reset all keybindings to default, then you can change the bindings again while you are ingame. That works, well, as long as you don't wanna reload a save file. Either because you died or you just want to replay a section of the game or a certain fight. Then you have to do the whole shenanigans again: Reset bindings, load your save, change bindings. Every time. This is a well known issue by now. You can make it work, but honestly? F that. It's extremley annoying and an embarassing oversight on the part of CDPR and I won't deal with this shit. Of course 1 negative steam review won't even cause an itch on their ballsack but I needed to blow off some steam. Review will stay until this issue is fixed.

in hindsight, the general opinion of this game has gone so many different directions over the past 4 years. cd projekt red somehow managed to release an insanely good stand-alone game in the Witcher 3: Wild Hunt in 2015, go on to release Cyberpunk in 2020 in what will be remembered as how 'not to release a product,' and now in 2024 it is in people's graces. 

CDPR takes Grand Theft Auto's successful open world gameplay loop and combines it with the Witcher game's impressive story telling and narrative design and you are left with cyberpunk 2077. combat and progression systems feel amazing to interact with (a personal negative from Witcher 3). the world and characters make for an unreal level of immersion that i think is really captured by how well the first person camera is done here. there are just so many levels of content to sift through, whether you're a completionist, there for all the hidden lore bits, or just want to shoot gangsters in the face, something is present for everyone. 

cyberpunk is the best kind of game. one where you can tell that the people who created it give a shit. it is a slow burn, and it's of my opinion if you beat it in under 50 hours played you missed out on so much of what it has to offer. a seemingly increase in modding traffic (NexusMods) spells a good future, too. an easier glimpse into seeing if you'd enjoy this game is watching an episode or two of Edgerunners on Netflix. they go hand in hand together very well. 

just remember, in this city you can't miss twice.

In all seriousness, it's really more of a 9/10 because of how many bugs I encountered, but that won't change the fact that Cyberpunk 2077 is out to be one of my favourite games ever. It has a strong story with wonderfully fleshed out characters that left me feeling empty at the end of it all (in a good way). Not to mention, the combat is incredibly fun and visceral once you really get a build going (check [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aceFr4K9D-Y]this video[/url] out). It's just such a superb game that is absolutely worth the asking price, especially if it's on sale.

The Phantom Liberty expansion is phenomenal and easily ranks among Hearts of Stone and Blood and Wine. The spy thriller angle they went with for the story was awesome and works really well as a Cyberpunk version of James Bond/Mission Impossible. The new area, while appearing small at first glance, is pretty dense and packed with stuff to do. It's a very good addition if you liked the base game.

As mentioned before, the only real complaint I have are the silly amount of bugs I encountered. It really took me for surprise considering that this game has been out for at least 3 years at the time of writing. I also can't speak for how the game was before the big 2.0 update as I played the game after 2.0 was released. There were so many bugs that I just had to keep a list:

- Got softlocked during [spoiler] 3 [/spoiler] different endings that prevented me from progressing [b](1 of those has been fixed from what I know, but I'm not sure about the others)[/b]
- Your character sometimes appears completely naked for a split second when looking into a mirror (and I do mean completely) before loading your actual outfit 
- Duplicate of my character stood behind me when I was looking in the mirror ([url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3147195871]screenshot[/url])
- Yet another mirror bug where my equipped weapon glued itself to my hand 
- Somehow managed to teleport myself back to a ladder I climbed half an hour ago by drawing my weapon. This just so happened to trigger during a side quest, causing me to receive a very angry text and fail the quest
- Broken melee finisher animations. You only do a slow-mo attack instead of a fancy animation
- Overlapping controls on controller since 2.1 -- sometimes I accidentally read a shard I picked up instead of scrolling down on the loot menu, or I unintentionally turn the radioport on and off when scrolling between security cameras
- Fell through the ground while running once. Thankfully the game saved me from the void by teleporting me back to before I fell
- Hands randomly disappeared when using arms cyberware (like gorilla arms) so I couldn't see my hands when I held a weapon or when I interacted with anything during cutscenes
- Music during hacking minigame disappeared midway through a playthrough
- A random NPC persisted forever floating above the same road and would never fade away from existence even if I drove to the other side of the map. I also encountered a flipped over police car that was doomed to a similar fate until I intervened
- The game continuing to think I was escaping the map's boundaries and then teleporting me every 30 seconds even though I only went out of it once and remained in the boundaries ever since
- Can't loot from certain enemies even though there's an icon showing that they are lootable
- Perks having no effect during an important DLC quest and continuing to have no effect after completing it
- Some lines from a certain character had a filter on them, making them speak as if they were talking through a phone
- Couldn't save or go into a menu after impersonating someone else for a quest
- When stepping into a specific area, the game auto-completed a random side quest that I had never started before, which would've bugged out the rewards for it if I went on to start the actual quest
- Some passive skills were completely broken
- Arms cyberware were downgraded to the lowest tier when loading a save from the 2.01 patch, forcing me to spend materials to upgrade them back to where they were

Don't let this list deter you from buying the game because it is indeed a brilliant game, but do keep in mind that the game is very prone to bugs. Some of these bugs have been fixed since I last played, and hopefully more of them will continue to be fixed as more patches release.

What can I say... this game has a special place in my heart. Night City is a mesmerizing playground with its breathtaking skyline and an abundance of little details that make every corner worth exploring. The immersive universe the game presents is unparalleled, and I can't get enough of it.

The story is a masterpiece. The living, breathing world of is a testament to the attention to detail, from the quirky professions of its inhabitants to the eclectic mix of futuristic cars and fashion that adds layers of authenticity. One of the standout features for me is the immersion, you genuinely feel like you're part of something unique. The characters are not just pixels on the screen; they're individuals you can relate to, form attachments with, and even feel a pang of sadness if something unfortunate befalls them.

This game... is just amazing. It has easily secured a spot as one of my all-time favourite games. <3

This game polarized like not many did - there are two big camps
[h3]The lovers[/h3] i.e. the die-hard CDPR fans, will defend this game at any given time for any stage of development and any design option chosen by the developers.
[h3]The haters[/h3] still hate the game because of its stuttering beginning and needing yet another DLC to get "the full experience".

If you ask me, the truth lies somewhere in between.
[b]Was the game perfect upon release?[/b] NO.
[b]Has CD Projekt Red (the developer) fixed these major issues?[/b] Yes!

Shortly after release, I played a good portion of the game and enjoyed it.
With the release of the new DLC I started a new run.
And guess what, I enjoyed this one even more than my first experience!

EDIT: My 2024 review as of right now.

I played cyberpunk sense day one. When I review games, I usually go on the basis of three things. Game-play. Story. Art design and graphics. I'm not going to make this a long review, but a detailed one.

Game-play: 2024 Cyberpunk compared to 2020 Cyberpunk has dramatically changed so much that the game is polished now, and if they had waited a couple more years, the game would have been better, yet releasing it early gave feedback on what the game is now, even if the game came out bad.
The cybernetics, weapons, upgrading, and moments are really good, including the skill tree aspect. Driving can be a little less inspiring yet good enough. NPC are better now, and the choice-making in diolog is still linear but really enjoyable in decisions. The UI has changed and is reasonably great. There are many positive developments in the game-play department that
CD PROJEKT RED is done for the game now.

Story: The story of Night City is sad but happy at the same time, like a bipolar man off and on with his meds. The story is outstanding in my opinion; there are so many different endings that it took me a minute to do all of them. There are lots of quests and side stories to do that have a lot of lore. lots of Easter eggs from the board game as well. I'm not going to spoil it. The story is just good and worth playing.

Art design and graphics: The art and graphics are stunning. The model designs and overall textures are not that bad for a game like this. There are only a couple games other than this that make me immerse myself in the graphics and art design of the game. I'm not saying it's realistic, and you don't need a game to be good-looking to be immersed, but dammm, this game looks amazing. My favorite part is at night, with all the lights from the neon signs and projections. Now the ugly truth. You do need an "ok" PC to make the game look good and run decently, sadly. The good part is that, with the latest patch and playing it in 2024, this game runs so much better than ever before.

DLC Bonus: The DLC is fun, worth the $30, and brings more excitement to Night City. This review is only on the main game, but as a bonus, I would say to get it. It's as good as the main story.

Conclusion? Sweet and simple, buy the game. It's fully relaxing and runs well. Buy it on sale and have a good time playing it.

Anyone who tells you this isn't a game worth playing on PC is an insane person and you should not listen to any opinion they have. No, this game will not solve world hunger and end all war as some people seem to expect. Yes, the optimization is bad. Yes, there are more bugs than there should be. Yes, there are missing features. However...

The game world is unbelievably immersive. This game has the best-feeling FPS combat I've ever experienced in an RPG. The writing is incredible. The story is engaging. The side quests in this game are more fun than the main quests in most other games. Gameplay styles and level design are impressively varied. The soundtrack is amazing. The amount of actual CONTENT you get in this game is unbelievable. 

This is not a GTA game, so don't expect it to be. This game is about building a character and experiencing stories in the game world. As far as I am concerned, no game exists that does this better than Cyberpunk 2077.

Update: I had this opinion on launch week. Obviously, the game is far better now after 3 years of major updates. You need to play it. Just be sure you have a somewhat-beefy PC, because this game is demanding on your CPU and GPU.

I will die on this hill when I say: 

Fans had no patience to wait for this gem of an IP from CD Projekt Red to finish and are the true blame for the company's decision to have this game rushed in bad unfinished state during COVID.

That being said, here is the real verdict after 78 hours of just the base game:

CyberPunk 2077's universe is the true show stealer with it's beautiful tragic story told in a very similiar pace as BladeRunner. as a matter of fact, this game is very much a much more indepth version of BladeRunner if John Wick happened to cross over within that universe. Why did I mention John Wick? Keanau Reeve's plays another character that also never misses a single head shot to a point he is actually in your head now! 

Cyberpunk's gameplay is a typical action RPG with a lot of technical elements that makes it fun for Run and Gunners and Stealth combat. you can hack machines to either distract enemies or insert Viruses in everything to infect them. there's even a hack to make enemies unalive themselves. Sad but deep. Upgrades extend to how you can resolve quests and add more options in choices. there's a lot to explain so I'll just keep it up to here so you can figure the rest out.

Overall, this game redefined the sci fi genre and takes a psychological approach to the universe. 

Game has undergone so many patches to where I can say that it's not a scam to purchase! 
Definitely wait for a sale especially if you wanna get the Liberty City DLC with it.

Music is a BOP "I Really Wanna Stay At Your House" has always been on repeat (the Netflix show Cyberpunk Edgerunner is to blame for that).

Very fun engaging game. Paced very beautifully.

Bonus points: it also carries mini games in forms of arcade machines that do get very addicting at times to where you should beat their high scores.

Verdict: YES/10

I bought this game when it was on sale, not expecting much because of the rocky launch, but wow, this game blew me away. It has a spot amongst my favourite games.

Pros:

Story/Characters 

The story of this game has a very interesting premise, and is then fleshed out by the characters of the game, who are in my opinion the one of the best parts of the game. Creating characters you care about in something like a TV show or movie is hard enough, but in a game? Even rarer. Cyberpunk does it best of all games I've played. Johnny, Panam, Takemura, Judy, Rogue, Jackie, etc etc. I could go on and on. Even V, the player character, has plenty of character and does a good job of being a likeable character in their own right while still leaving room for self-insertion. It's awesome to experience the plot of the game alongside characters who actually have personality. The voice actors and animators do a great job furthering this idea with emotional acting and lots of unique animations, which is a joy to behold in 1st person. The soundtrack also is cool and unique, and really compliments the scenes it is used in, particularly the emotional scenes.

World

Cyberpunk has a massive world rich in detail and lore, and further makes the experience even more immersive alongside the characters and story. You can get lost in this world and feel apart of it very easily. The core story of the game also centres around what makes the world of Night City tick, such as the Arasaka corp., and the characters also represent a wide range of groups of people and affiliations in night city, so experiencing the world is made easy by following the main quest and progressing character focused side quests.

Combat

The combat system is at its core fun and satisfying, with loads of room for build crafting. You could be a super agile cyber-ninja, a walking talking tank, or a Ghost in the Shell-esq hacker who kills their enemies with their mind. The cyberware system is just straight up cool and there are tons of unique weapons and weapon types to chase and spec into if you want.

Choice

The story of cyberpunk is extremely choice oriented. There are multiple different endings which are all very different which can come about from your own decisions. The decisions are also very far reaching: a seemingly smaller decision you made hours ago can come back to bite you in the ass later, which on one hand can be slightly annoying however it makes the game even more immersive. You really have to think about what kind of playthrough you want.

Graphics/Art 

Cyberpunk is a stunning game, albeit not super well optimised compared to some other games. But if you have a system which can run it at minimum on low settings and get a stable 60 fps like me, then the game will still look fantastic. The general aesthetic of the game and the designs of the world, characters, weapons, cars, etc are all well thought out.


Cons

Some of these are a bit nit-picky, be warned

The biggest con to me is probably the AI, which to be honest is still pretty terrible. The police will just spawn police cars out of nowhere during a chase to ram you, the AI just clump together in groups of enemies and slowly walk towards you during combat, if an enemy sees you just before you kill them silently, even if they dont shout or anything before they die, the whole camp then knows you are there, and EXACTLY where you are, and they are all coming to kill you. Same with the police: if you kill one but they dont have a chance to shout or radio or anything before they die, doesent matter, the police are now hunting you.

Janky/buggy

The game, while soooo much better then launch, still feels a bit janky. For example, in melee combat. An enemy swings a melee weapon at you and you dash away at the last second? Guess what, that swing is still locked on to you, and the AI will slide all the way across the room in the same animation to still land the blow anyways. Stuff like that makes things like boxing almost impossible on higher difficulties. Some other things are a bit jank as well, like how if you get hit by a car, there are no rag doll physics, you just get an indentical ugly animation played every time. There are also some bugs in the game. It was rare that it affected my plathrough in any meaningful way, but it is still obvious to me that the foundation of this game was rushed out before it was ready.

Too much choice?

Some of the major story options, such as an ending which lots of players believe to be the best ending, are locked behind seemingly insignificant dialogue which you cant change later. The game sometimes needs to make more distinction between what dialogue will have a massive impact later. Its possible to miss tons of amazing story content and gameplay in the game, and theres no way to go back and experience it unless you got lucky and saved beforehand, or if you start a new game.


But overall this game has come a long way and is now one of my favourite games. If you were put off like the launch like i still was but only a few weeks ago, try the game now and see. Play at least up to the heist mission about 3-5 hrs in, as that's where I was hooked and where the world opens up a bit.

Damn good game, incredible story and characters. CD project red has done such a good job at bringing Mike Pondsmith's gritty well crafted dystopian world of Cyberpunk into the Video game format.

This game is honestly not good. Putting aside the bugs that will likely be patched out, the game as a whole is very underwhelming. The city is somewhat detailed, but it is poorly designed, one step over an imaginary line and enemies go from pushovers to powerhouses. The Story is really unengaging, and for a game touting choice and world impact the main line of quests feel incredibly linear. There are some entertaining side quests, but on the whole there is no real attachment as you get all these side quests from people essentially texting you, you don't get any sense of why you are doing something. I honestly cannot explain how much I don't enjoy this game. I am too tired to continue this, just know that the game is not good.

Edit: It's since been updated a bunch, and after a more thorough look, there are some fun quest lines putting aside the honestly underwhelming main story, and the skill trees have seen great improvement. I cannot recommend going down the Reflex tree to unlock air dashing enough, you can b-hop so fast you become a menace on the battlefield.
Cyberpunk v2.0+ is a different game comparing to what was at the beginning. For those whop dropped I recommend to return and give a second chance.

It's important to note that I'm reviewing Cyberpunk 2077 post-launch 3 years after its disastrous launch date and despite all of their scummy marketing, and have no expectations of ever being compared to GTA because that'll be fucking hilarous.

Amazing universe, world building, tons of history about Night City and the universe of Cyberpunk and NC itself, different cultures and slangs, cool cars, music and body modifications, et cetera. The fact that in this universe the cyberware and human modification have come together and have terms like overheating, optics and others is so cool as a PC builder myself.

Excellent use of sounds and good choice of music and most importantly, REALLY, GOOD, SOUNDTRACKS.

Incredibly clever writing and amazing memorable lines and dialogue

STYLE

Endless Replayability

RPG mechanics with multiple trees and dialogue options that actually matter with multiple different outcomes

Non-repetitive missions

Auto-Save features. This is very important because I like to mess around and choose the right decision you all know what I mean.

Some really good compelling characters and life-like personality!

What I don't like

-The very design of being strictly first-shooter. I have to first get this out of the way I am no means a video game designer, and the developers and designers have the right to have their own vision for how the game should represents. But honestly this is probably the only game that I could complain that it really, really does not work.  From the very first article or news from a tweet that Cyberpunk 2077 is confirmed to be in played entirely in first person view I wasn't happy. At all. In fact, I'm not the only one. Hell, this game felt and plays like a Far Cry clone. So being in first person.. what the hell is the point of character costumization and stylistic clothing?? I can't connect to V if he's never appared in any of the cinematics or scenes at all. First person shooter games are good for silent protagonists but not for our boy or gal talkative V it just doesn't work! You can drive vehicles around in third person with press of a button, so why the hell can't atleast have third person cam whenever V falls down or gets ejected out from vehicles? The game felt very awkward 

-Bugs. 3 years, one revive and a show later and somehow, this game still has some bugs left but not game breaking, I mean obviously not as terrible as the launch. Some animations don't work, some NPCs just straight up be standing on air, enemies oddly mispronounces the player.. lol. there was one time i was standing near a car and once the NPC got into the car it exploded right in front of me for no reason at all but it was still pretty hilarous. Another "bug" happens often but whenever I hit the button to call my personal vehicle most of the time it'll appear on above the highways far from where I'm standing on. The worst part is the vehicles I'm driving on sometimes does not respond to the keys. There are few instances of pop-ups of NPCs and other objects appear on screen and disappearing said objects and NPCs. There is STILL NPCs can T-Pose! But not as often but sitll.

-Brain dead AI. Not all but sometimes the NPCs just stand there even if you're detected and won't attack you, sometimes they're restritected into their own space and sometimes they T-Pose.

-No build up to the plot, poor or lack thereof explanation of things like gangs like Tyger Claws or Maelstorm.

-Story felt very rushed. Not even 5 minutes atleast in my play through of corpo into the game and you're already having a montage with X on how you're becoming known gangster around Night City. I felt X died too early and I hated it. 

-Mundane parts like the BD sequences needs to go. away.  Atleast a skip button.

-Needs QoL improvements like renaming save files, how the HELL does this game does not have the aim toggle option???

-Broken physics. Car and bike physics felt much to be desired.

-Plenty of cut content. I always have trouble believing of what happened in the first 15 minutes of beginning of corpo path because it felt rushed and turns out? There's whole ass cut content behind it that led to this that apparently almost EVERYONE chose this life path have been butchered just like that. Sure almost all games have cut content but Cyberpunk desperately needed that corpo path mission specifically. Like I said, everyone is in disbelief and confused once they've chose that path and after 10 minutes left disappointed.

-Mediocre gameplay. It's essentially first person shooter masked with little bits of RPG mechanics like dialogue and skill system, and hacking to hide the fact its nothing more than a first person shooter, yes it has mechanics you'd expect in an fps nowadays like sliding but theres this one redditor that described it perfectly; jack of all trades, master of none.

-Despicible characters. I loved V, Johnny, Jackie, River and few these guys did phenomal acting and others however there are characters in this game that come and went abruptly. For example, there's a hotshot named Meredith where you can speak to as an option then never seen her again? Unfortunately both love interest are so despicable in Cyberpunk namely Judy and Panam. They both needed your help constantly and whine like you owe them something but never stop and ask you, as V's plan or have conversation same goes for Claire.

-Terrible driving and bikes. I feel the vehicles in this game are not as precise as I thought it would be. Driving vehicles in this game felt they weight more than a freight train and plays unresponsively.

-Is EXTREMELY linear. Unfortunately Cyberpunk 2077 suffers a lot from having limitations, less freedom in an open world games. I have encountered many different issues where you can't drive around in specific areas like the markets areas, the game literally stops you from getting into areas you haven't unlocked yet, there are some cars like the gang cars you can't drive.

-Not very memorable missions or game in general. Unfortunately right after your best friend died is the moment where the game became repetitive jumbled mess with going after Arasaka and then crying that you, as V might not live for very long and I dont mean that as pro your-best-friend character, but literally I don't find anyone else compelling, or relatable, or memorable in any way.

6\10 
Do I recommend this game? Nah, there's plenty of great alternatives imo. But is it great game worth playing? Ehhhh..

If you clicked this review just to find out if they patched the bugs, yes, they did.

Cyberpunk, as a genre, hasn't been fully realized in a videogame--until now.

Back when this game first came out, I disregarded it as another buggy failure from money-hungry businessmen. The usual kind of AAA garbage. It's not. 

2077 is the first game I've ever played that does a good job of putting me in the kind of world William Gibson conceived of in Neuromancer. The attention to detail, slang, vistas, story concepts, and overall atmosphere are almost perfect. The game is almost worth that alone. But is it any good as a game? Yeah, mostly. Naturally you have hacking which is kind of like magic. I would approach a group of enemies, spread a damage over time ability, make the toughest one commit sudoku, prevent another one from seeing, and go in with my shotgun to clean up the mess. Stealth is well-rewarded and seems encouraged in the majority of cases, but I don't have time for that. Still though it's worth mentioning there's a robust suite of stealth-friendly abilities.

Story wise the game does what good cyberpunk should do. Keanu's acting is superb in this. I've always considered Johnny Mnemonic his best acting role, and this is about on par with that. The issue is I'm not so sure I like that character. It isn't that it's a bad character. It's just it doesn't leave much room to disagree with him. In the end he's your moral compass. If you do something he disapproves of, you made the wrong choice. If you do something he agrees with, you made the right choice. I was annoyed with him chiming in on everything to the point where my rebellious nature kicked in and I mostly did the opposite of what he said, barring any obvious betrayal. 

[spoiler]I ended up with the worst possible ending. I went corpo because I envisioned myself as part of the dystopia, not a reaction to it. So in the context of a cyberpunk story, I'm either neutral or an anti-hero. My thought that was by "siding with" Arasaka, I'd end up taking my boss's place and we'd probably return Keanu to his body or he'd dissipate into the ether of cyberspace with his girlfriend happily ever after. Instead, I was treated to a lengthy dissection of my version of V as a character and cast into the numinous great beyond while old man Arasaka became a god. All that work, and I don't get to achieve godhood, or at least get my old job back?[/spoiler]

The key takeaway, or caution, about the story in this game is that you don't have as much choice as it leads you to believe. The dialog options are more like "What line would you like V to say next?" and not "There's a fork in the road--which way are you going?" That said, all of it is done reasonably well, even though it kinda feels like you're a character in Keanu's story, not the other way around. It's a good thing Johnny is such a well-done character. But I can't help but wonder, why not just make Johnny the main character for fuck's sake?

Still, it should be emphasized that despite you having less control over your destiny than the game would have you believe, AND despite that all the possible endings are mix-ups of similar things, all of which end up a bummer/cliffhanger...Cyberpunk 2077 still has a serviceable story. And if you like stories, and you like cyberpunk, this game is worth your money.

Update: Just downloaded the 2.11 patch. At some point they also revamped chracter progression, and overall the game feels better to play. I stick with the basic idea of my old build: hacking to get control of an area, then go in with a shotgun and clean up. Although at this point I don't have a choice because I can't respec again. Whatever, some games choose to go with forcing permanent choices, and this is one of those. I ended up getting the ability to dash and air dash, which is too much fun to not use. I also put some points into katanas, which is kinda redundant because my short range combat is already handled by my shotgun. Whatever, blocking bullets with a katana is cool. I wish they'd change how the mission tracking works. It keeps defaulting to the latest one in my log, but I'm trying to clear out all the gigs before I start with Phantom Liberty. This will also help me come to grips with the mechanics and get some weapons tailored to my playstyle.

Oh and lest I forget, we now have full DualSense support. It's cool because the RGB will flash red/blue when the cops are after you. You can hear radio shit in the little speaker. I don't know if I'm totally on board with the haptic feedback because it seems unnecessarily stiff, but maybe I'll get used to it or there's an option.

From zero to... Hero?
Almost! While Cyberpunk 2077 has improved a lot since it's launch and most of the promised features are here, the open-world immersive sim that we were led on to believe it would be is still not here; What is here, however, especially with the DLC included (Which adds a very good side-campaign and very fun new area to get lost into with great side-quests), is a phenomenal open-world action game with some RPG mechanics.
The open world gameplay is something to write home about, with no real dull side-content; The level design of the city you'll be playing in (Night City) is amazingly fun and intuitive with something to discover around every corner. The city feels very much alive and you can interact with a lot of things. Sure the NPC's don't have any advanced schedules if you follow them around and there is a lot of set dressing. But in the moments you're walking or driving through, everything feels great.
A lot of thought went into the story and lore of the world and it oozes atmosphere. The slang people talk in this game is catchy as well.
I sometimes feel like there is a bit of a clash between the seriousness of the main story and the overly colourful and goofily advertised open world, but I think the devs did this to get a point across about our world as well.
It's still not a perfect game and there are some NPC interactions that I wish were more fleshed out, the story sometimes clashes with the things your main character is capable of doing which can break immersion a bit and sometimes the AI is rather silly, especially when driving; But there is a lot of fun to be had here, the vibes and style of the world suck you right in and some of the main characters are a good time to witness.
The combat, which in the end is the bread and butter of the game is very customisable and there are a lot of diffrent playstyles to specialise into. You can become a stealth master and never even have to touch a gun anymore or go in with your bare hands and everything inbetween; The cyberware you can install and the diffrent perks really make a difference and there is a lot of fun to be had, even with the side-quests which offer a lot for any playstyles; Though the non-DLC ones can become a bit repetative.
Either way:

Story: 8/10
Characters: 9/10
Gameplay: 8,5/10
Vibes: 10/10
World/Level design: 9/10
AI: 5/10
Graphics: 9/10
Fun factor: 9/10
Bugs/Glitches: Average amount

Cyberpunk 2077 has been a rollercoaster of an experience for me. Initially hesitant due to the infamous launch issues, I decided to wait until the game achieved stability. Once I delved into Night City, I was captivated by its immersive atmosphere. The neon-lit streets, gritty characters, and futuristic setting created an engaging environment.

The storyline, admittedly, started off at a slower pace, but it truly hit its stride after the tower mission. The narrative picked up speed, unveiling a captivating and thrilling adventure that kept me hooked. The game's depth and complexity became more apparent, showcasing the attention to detail that CD Projekt Red is known for.

However, no journey in Night City is without its glitches. Despite post-launch patches, a few bugs persisted, occasionally disrupting the otherwise seamless experience. I couldn't help but yearn for a more polished interface and dialogue system akin to Red Dead Redemption 2, which excelled in immersing players in its world.

Despite these minor drawbacks, Cyberpunk 2077 offers a remarkable gaming experience, especially if you can overlook the occasional hiccup. If you're willing to explore a vibrant and chaotic future, I highly recommend giving it a shot now that the game has stabilized.

Following the game's 2.0 release, I had a very fun time with the game. Would absolutely recommend!

[h2]The Good[/h2]
The gunplay is satisfying, the melee is ALSO very satisfying (having BOTH is a rare thing in games!), the story is good, the gameplay feels good. The movement is strong, impactful and actually meaningful in completing missions. The DLC is very good. Build diversity is very high, you can play this game however you want and almost any weapon/skill combination that is fun to play is also very [i]strong[/i] to play. RP potential is high.

While the game's story is mostly linear, there are definitely a couple of meaningful story and gameplay choices that caught me off-guard. I was pretty amazed when I took up arms against a faction that didn't sit right with me, and the game actually [i]let me do it.[/i] Most other games would have railroaded me into gritting my teeth and make me keep helping them. Many games would lock you into dialogue until you choose the obvious dialogue option that basically says "*Fight!*". This game lets you just draw first. The agency that this game gives you without feeling like locking you into binary choices is very well-done and extremely refreshing, despite the fact that the story is [i]somewhat[/i] linear. Don't expect a deranged amount of branching paths like you would find in Mass Effect or Dragon Age, of course.

Game's soundtrack is also good and fits the mood of the game.

The life paths do a very, very good job of adding RP potential to the game. They don't add much gameplay-wise, but it's that bit of extra flavor that really makes your character stand out.

The difficulty in this game is excellent. There is a difficulty selector that you can change pretty much any time. The harder difficulties are PROPER hard.

[h2]The Bad[/h2]
The player's "life path" could [i]maybe[/i] have been a little more impactful in terms of how quests, the story or even the gameplay plays out. It usually amounts to small dialogue options and sometimes a "shortcut" into an alternate quest path/dialogue tree that you would normally need a skill check for to reach. The intro sequence you get based on your background is at most 30 minutes long, and it quickly all combines into the same "main path".

The game should make it a little clearer that trying to be a "jack of all trades" doesn't work. I had friends warn against me trying this, so I didn't try. Instead, I focused mainly on 2 big attributes and their skilltrees, and only took small dips in the other skilltrees for things like extra cyberware capacity.

Because of how the game's skill scaling works, dialogue checks are not absolute values, they do not require a specific Cool or Body or Intelligence level. Rather, there are "Easy", "Normal" and "Hard" check levels built-in, and the requirements for each of them increase as you level up.

This means that you can find doors leading to an alternate path that requires Body 7 to force-open. You're Body Level 6. So you dip 1 extra point into Body so you can force these doors more easily. But now your character level is higher, and suddenly [i]the same door[/i] requires Body 8 to force-open, leaving you behind the curve. This felt weird to me.

Again I don't consider this design decision an issue, and I think the developers definitely intended it to be this way. I just wish they had made it a little more clearer that you shouldn't try to "spread out" your points. If I had to say ONE bad thing about this game, it would be that they don't make this clear enough.

• القصة رهيبة فيها الكثير من المنعطفات الغير متوقعة وتجربة قصصية لم أعش مثلها من قبل.

• ما مليت من كلام الشخصيات أثناء الحوارات وأختيار المحادثات وذلك لأن طريقتها رهيبة فالشخصيات تتفاعل وتتحرك ويتغير المشهد بشكل مستمر.

• إستديو CD PROJECT RED صنع واحد من أكثر عوالم الألعاب المستقبلية جمالاً وبنفس القدر عالم بائس كئيب، وحشية العالم والطبقية العنصرية وغيرها من الأمور التي جسدها الاستديو في عالم اللعبة.

• رسومياً Cyberpunk 2077 هي أجمل لعبة لعبتها في حياتي، لن اطيل الكلام هنا لانه لا يعطي اللعبه حقها رسومياً.

• في بداية اللعبة كان أسلوب اللعب عادي مثل أي لعبة إطلاق نار ولكن مع التقدم في اللعبة فاجأتني بتقديم طرق جديدة للعب مثل القدرات البدنية والقفز مرتين ونظام مهارات أعطاني حرية اختيار طريقة لعبي المفضلة، وحتى قيادة المركبات فيها خواص جديدة يمكن إضافتها والقتال وأنا في المركبة وغيرها.

• عدد كبير من الأسلحة وطرق القتال وتنوع كبير في اللعبه فتقدر تعيد اللعبه وتغير أسلوب اللعب وتجدد وتنوع في خيارات القصة.

• طريقة تقديم بعض الشخصيات في القصة الأساسية وتقدر تكمل قصتهم في المهمات الجانبية وتعرف عنهم اكثر وترابطها مع القصة الرئيسية.

• تنوع المهمات شيء رهيب وأنا جلست ألعب مهمات جانبية كثير ومستواها ممتاز واللعبه فيها تنوع رهيب وفي مطاردات ومهمات اكشن وقتالات ومهمات هادئه وغيرها.

لم يعجبني ❌

• التفاعل مع العالم محدود فمجرد تحاول تتفاعل مع شخصية جانبية ينكشف غطاء العالم وينكسر الاندماج، أحبطتني اللعبه في تفاعل العالم مع بعضه او شخصيتي V.

• الذكاء الاصطناعي يعاني من مشاكل القدرة على القتال فمرات كثير يكون معلق او يتحرك بدون هدف. 

• واجهت مشاكل تقنية لم تكن كثيرة لدرجة افساد التجربة ولكنها مزعجة مثل تعليق اللعبة (جهازي مجهز باحدث القطع) ومشاكل في الترجمة تتداخل مع بعضها، وبعض المشاكل في المهمات والأخطاء التقنية.

يحتاج تحسين ⚠️

• نظام إختيار حياة سابقة لشخصية من 3 خيارات كعضو مؤسسات أو من الشوارع والرحال كانت محبطة وما قدمت شيء يستاهل.

• الحوارات الخاصة التي تتطلب مهارات عالية أو قدرات معينه ما تساهل حقيقة وتمنيت شيء أحسن.

• قتال بعض الزعماء محبط نوعاً ما ومافي تنوع كبير مثل المهمات واللعبه بشكل عام، هو صحيح ما حسيت إنها سلبية كبير ولكن لازم تتحسن في الأجزاء القادمة.

ملخص رأيي 🔖

لعبة Cyberpunk 2077 قدمت لي تجربة فريدة من نوعها ومتميزة بقصتها وعالمها الرهيب، وفاجئتني بأسلوب اللعب المميز.

التقييم النهائي 🔴

This is probably one of the most immersive experiences I've had. The first person view makes the game feel so much more authentic, and the first few hours when everything is new are magical. Overall, the atmosphere of this game is its strongest part, you really feel like Night City is a real place, and you are a part of it.

The combat gets better and better as the game goes on. For the first few hours it is kind of mindless and uninteresting, and as you level up you get access to toys that make it very satisfying. The problem is, by the time you feel powerful and the fun is at its peak, the game ends.

This is an immensely detailed and enormous open world, that you could get lost in for hours, but the main story is frustratingly short. You are supposed to do side missions in between the main missions, which are generally high quality, but even with these the game just ends way too early. There are also filler copy-and-paste missions, which are, bar the cyberpsycho sightings, not worth the time. It's not that the game is short, but it feels short, because there was so much more potential in this huge and polished world.

The side missions are good, especially the ones where the game does not take itself seriously. The side characters range from fully fleshed out and well-written to intolerably annoying and cliché. 
The main story is over with a snap of a finger, and could have used an extra chapter, but it is engaging while it lasts. Keanu's performance is amazing, and he really carries the game on his shoulder.

Now for the bad part: the driving, even with a controller, is horrendous. Every car is either horribly understeery, or uncontrollably oversteery. I found myself using the fast travel option a lot more because of this. Compared to something like GTA, its just plain old bad.
After a while, the "role-playing" element fades, and it is hard to take the emotional moments of some side stories seriously. You basically become godlike in terms of power, but no one actually acknowledges it. 
The bugs that made this game famous on its release are mostly patched, and the remaining ones are more funny than annoying. I encountered one scripting bug throughout the whole game, but all in all I was positively surprised about how polished the experience was. 

I wouldn't pay full price for it, but I definitely would recommend buying it on sale. It is solid fun, even if it has its flaws.

EDIT with Phantom Liberty:

Fixes most of my issues with the game ending early. Probably the best content this game has to offer, tightly packed and fun. Really unoptimized compared to the rest of the game though. Must play.

Here is my updated review. I keep going back to this game. I love it. It isn't the best game ever made, and it isn't as well made as Witcher 3. BUT... I love this game! It is so much fun! With the amount of hours that I have played, it is clearly one of my favorite games of all time. I love that the graphics can scale from a Steam Deck to beyond a 4090. I will probably be checking this game out every time I buy a new GPU and I will probably get sucked into playing the game a different way than last time.

Cyberpunk doesn't really have a Good/Evil moral system. That is a weakness and that means that decisions don't feel as diverse as other games, but almost every mission does have a choice that does change if someone lives, dies, likes, or hates you. The positive is that decisions feel more natural to choose between.
Not a huge gamer but had fun playing this. It's not an ordinary game at all !!!

There is something so compeling about distant future. The posibilities that may happen like augmenting a human body or connecting your conciousness to a network. Well in Cyberpunk, that's where you experience all those kind of stuff. 

I bought this game on the day of release and instantly fell in love. Set in fictional city in USA, NightCity. This ''never give up'' story with an unexpected outcome is something that can influence one life. It is very moving and depressing at the same time. There is also addition for the story in form of Anime CyberPunk Edgerunners.
The combat in this game is great. The variety of playstyles is countless. From gun blazing and going wild, to being sneaky and undetectable. Along the journey, you will encounter a bunch of quests which are made great, there is passion in each and one of them. Graphics are phenomenal aswell as the audio-composure.

On the other hand, the driving model is OK, and what I mean is that it works, it just works. And also can't forget about the bugs on the release (note: Most of them are fixed and the game is in great shape now).

In conclusion, I reccomend this game to anyone who likes very fast combat and very compeling and moving story. I think a lot of people can find enjoyment in this game as well as I did.

While I'm enjoying the game and the story, there is one major bug... This game-breaking bug that I've come across where you cant use or equip your weapons after completing certain quests/missions. The only way to reverse the bug is to either sleep with one of the joy-toys or put all of your inventory into storage (your trunk) and take it out again. Even then there's no guarantee it'll work. I've also learned that this bug has been a problem since the game's release in 2020. I'm posting this review in 2023... You'd think they would have patched it by now, but no... I've heard that people have had to restart their play-throughs because of this issue. 

The game can be a buggy mess at times but still pretty damn fun overall. Reminds me of GTA - but cyberpunk and with actually good, fun, shooting mechanics. There's also RPG elements to the combat - which means skill trees. Which I absolutely love. I will recommend with caution - especially if you have and older PC, but definitely worth it if you catch it on sale like I did.  :)

Treat the game as if there is no auto save because it is not your friend. This game crashes more than drunks on holidays and the auto save feature doesn't account for how frequently the game crashes. This causes you to start over at the last save point; if you're lucky. I've saved before a crash and had to go back to save points to get around a crash loop. Auto save quits at times and manual save won't work; frequently saving will warn you so you can restart before you progress too far. This is frustrating because this game isn't stable and it's like four years old. There are so many bugs that cause you to lose game play and time. 

Overall I like the game but I just turn it off when it crashes so I don't play too much anymore. The game is alright. There is plenty to do with main missions, side quests, random baddies biding their time. Lots of weapons, different types of weapons, upgrades, weapon upgrades, outfits, and ways to make the story your own. Voice acting is pretty damn good as well as the story. Open world adventure with a pretty huge map to explore and investigate. Controls are good and the graphics look great. Game mechanics are nice too. Dev's even did a few clever things to make the world seem more immersive and thought out.

Vintage chocolate chip cookies

Ingredients
150g salted butter, softened
80g light brown muscovado sugar
80g granulated sugar
2 tsp vanilla extract
1 large egg
225g plain flour
½ tsp bicarbonate of soda
¼ tsp salt
200g plain chocolate chips or chunks
Method
STEP 1
Heat the oven to 190C/fan170C/gas 5 and line two baking sheets with non-stick baking paper.

STEP 2
Put 150g softened salted butter, 80g light brown muscovado sugar and 80g granulated sugar into a bowl and beat until creamy.

STEP 3
Beat in 2 tsp vanilla extract and 1 large egg.

STEP 4
Sift 225g plain flour, ½ tsp bicarbonate of soda and ¼ tsp salt into the bowl and mix it in with a wooden spoon.

STEP 5
Add 200g plain chocolate chips or chunks and stir well.

STEP 6
Use a teaspoon to make small scoops of the mixture, spacing them well apart on the baking trays. This mixture should make about 30 cookies.

STEP 7
Bake for 8–10 mins until they are light brown on the edges and still slightly soft in the centre if you press them.

STEP 8
Leave on the tray for a couple of mins to set and then lift onto a cooling rack.

RECIPE TIPS
FREEZING THE BISCUITS
If you’ve frozen the biscuits, take them out and arrange them on a lined baking sheet. Once defrosted, pop them in a medium oven 190C/170 fan/gas mark 5 and heat for 2-3 mins to crisp up. Don’t leave them too long or they’ll dry out.

You can keep the uncooked dough in a sealed container in the fridge for up to two weeks. Simply take some out, dollop on a lined baking tray and allow to come up to room temperature for 5 mins before baking

Pre 2.1:

Alright, listen up, choombas! This game had all the hype, all the expectations, and let me tell you, it delivered in some ways, but fell short in others.

First off, Night City. This place is a damn masterpiece. The neon-soaked streets, the towering skyscrapers, the gritty back alleys - it's everything you'd expect from a cyberpunk world. The atmosphere is spot on, and it truly feels like you're living in a dystopian future.

Now, let's talk about the story. CD Projekt Red tried to weave an epic tale of rebellion and corporate greed, and they did a decent job. But there were moments where the pacing felt off, and some plot lines didn't get the attention they deserved. It's like they tried to cram too much into one game, and it suffered because of it.

Gameplay-wise, it's a mixed bag. The gunfights are intense, the hacking mechanics are solid, and the character customization is top-notch. But there were some bugs, glitches, and AI issues that took away from the overall experience. It's like trying to jack into the Net with a faulty interface - frustrating as hell.

Look, Cyberpunk 2077 had the potential to be a game-changer, a true legend in the gaming world. And while it falls short in some areas, it still manages to capture the essence of the cyberpunk genre. It's a flawed gem, but a gem nonetheless.

So, if you're willing to overlook some rough edges and dive headfirst into Night City, give Cyberpunk 2077 a shot. Just remember, it's not perfect. Stay rebellious, chooms!

Yes they did the impossible, they fixed the game and it's much better than what I have played 2 years ago.

Pros:
1. They really nailed the details of the night city. Here u can hide bodies in the trash, 
open car trunks, RIDE A RAIL TRAIN AND ACTUALLY STAND UP WHEN RIDING IT

2. Driving experience is improved. Different cars feel drastically different to handle 
and I'm actually having fun driving cars around now instead of just fast travel.

3. Cops are crazy. Tried multiple times but got killed b4 reaching highest police alert level.

4. On retrospective, the story is very good. My 2.5th run now and I just realized how many details
they hid in the story to let you appreciate the ending more.

5. Got randomly jumped by gang bangers and they can actually kill u very easily. 2 years ago the
game wasn't this hard and I like it.

6. Lots of mods out there for this game.

7. They made the inhaler a skill with CD instead of just consumables. 2 years ago I had to stock
these inhalers up b4 going to a big boss fight and they made the fight so easy. Now I actually
had to try more than 1 time to beat a boss.

8. Bosses are harder. There is this high testosterone woman right and she beat my ass up. Let me
tell u I can't even remember her in my 1st run coz she was like weak af. Now I have PTSD
remembering how she charged like a fucking bull into me during the fight.

Didn't play the DLC yet but heard it's a banger.

Cons:
1. NPCs were mocked as zombies 2 years ago now though they are greatly improved, but at some part
of the city you still feel like those are zombies. One time I saw an NPC standing in the middle of
the road taking a phone call and it was very out of the scene. So I drove away his sport car and
crashed it.

2. Upgrading weapons requires a little bit of too much materials. Half story in and I was only able
to upgrade like 2-3 weapons let alone crafting new ones. I'm sure there is a mod out there to
fix it though.

Yeah not many cons here. Great game, 10/10. Try the game before u die.

[h1] Yes [/h1]

[H1]Cyberpunk 2077: great open world action RPG in a bleak setting[/H1]

[H1]So what's it about?[/H1]
CP:2077 is an open world action RPG with multiple paths. The setting of Night City is huge and looks absolutely amazing. Night City is ruled by corporations and there is a huge rift between the haves and have-nots. In a way it's back to the Dark Ages as the Internet as we know it no longer is available and information is broken up, in another way it's more advanced than nowadays with nearly everyone having their bodies modified with 'chrome'.

 The story telling is excellent and you will notice that many seemingly unrelated events, missions and details are all pieces of the puzzle. [SPOILER]But be warned this is a dark story with no happy ending.[/SPOILER]. There are multiple endings and with different backgrounds of your character and different romantic partners depending on your gender there is the option for replay ability.

[i]Warning: this game is not for the faint of heart - there are some seriously disturbing (side)quests.[/i]

[H1]The good [/H1]
[olist]
[*]The city looks amazing with so many details, side quests, vehicles and multiple routes to take on your adventure. Just looking at the commercials, TV shows and mini games makes me wonder how much time was spent - every time you start the game you discover something new. There are so many small details to discover - a NPC transfers money to you using their neural interface? You'll see their eyes light up while they are using their tech. 

[*]CP2077 goes for full immersion with a tactile approach to the environment and no loading screens (except when you start the game or use fast travel). This works very well and gives the game an experience that most other games have not achieved yet.

[*]There is a good tutorial to learn how to take down enemies, how to perform stealth and hacking operations and in general how the systems in the game work.

[*]The music and sound effects are amazing. The music is also dynamic bringing atmosphere to each scene. It's done really well. 

[*]The story is really good - and the side quests offer a more in-depth perspective in this reality. 

[*]You can craft better weapons and attachments using items you find and bought in the world. There is an extensive range of shops available and the amount of crafting options is stunning: weapons, cyberdeck, implements, attachments and more. Then one day you discover there are weaponised cars: rocket launchers, machine guns, an upgrade that allows you to move faster or jump higher so you can play parcourse in the city and more.

[*]I like that after the pro-logue you can do basically anything: you want to dive in the main story? Then go ahead. You want to do a lot of side quests? Then that's fine too. You want to just drive around exploring the city? It's all there for you to do. 

[*]I love the scanner where you look at the environment for clues and ways to solve your objective. At certain quets there is also a playback function available of reality when you have the right hardware (in-game). This allows you to experience the game through the eyes of someone else finding details that this person might have missed or wasn't interested in but that can benefit your mission.

[*]When you want to get into a building there is usually a way - either by hacking the camera and remote access, breaking the windows or climbing and slipping through an industrial shutter. It's up to you if you want to sneak around, or just come in guns blazing.

[*][SPOILER]Johnny Silverhand works really well as a companion[/SPOILER]

[/olist]

[H1]The not so good[/H1]
[olist]
[*]I bought the game on Steam why should I still see yet another launcher before I can play the game? As a Netrunner this is unacceptable. Use the following steps to start without the launcher:
[code]
1. Open steam
2. Right click Cyberpunk 2077
3. Click properties
4. Click set launch options
5. Type: --launcher-skip and click ok.
[/code]

[*]The game overwhelms you with a large number of quests and it's not easy at first to see the difference between a main quest and a side quest. I played by sorting the quests in the order I got them - this meant doing a lot of side quests but it was fine for me as I wanted to see everything. The experience varies from basic to elaborate. While basic is still good, it shows that more was planned but had to be cut.

[*]Even on hard the game is not challenging. Pretty soon you are a Terminator and no one can stop you. [SPOILER]And then you meet Adam Smasher - that fight was so unbalanced :-([/SPOILER]

[*]At one point you experience flashbacks; the super bright white screens were not a great experience :-(.

[*]With sniper rifle you can see further than you can hit - your shots are not being registered as if there is a maximum range; likely an engine limitation. If you notice this you need to get closer to your target. 

[*]The mirrors don't seem to work unless you "activate" them. 

[*]It is not explained well that mods to weapons are permanent and that weapons cannot be upgraded. This is only different for Iconic weapons which can be upgraded and have their mods replaced. 

[*]I missed a faction reputation system: when I attack a gang they should be looking for me if I get recognised but this just doesn't happen except for some scripted events. The same should also apply to continue committing crimes - at one point you should become a fugitive not being able to just hide and wait and perhaps do time in prison with missions to break out. 

[*]The cops are perfectly fine with you murdering their colleagues or driving in their vehicles while standing next to you. 

[*]The metro is like an after-thought: while in most situation CP:2077 goes for an immersive experience; taking the metro is underwhelming: the transition to the metro is just a loading screen. The romantic / soft porn scenes feel forced, with just a couple of options and they never change.
[/olist]

[H1]The DLCs[/H1]
Three DLCs have been released:
[olist]
[*][b]Cyberpunk 2077 Bonus Content[/b] offers extra digital goodies for CP:2077.
[*][b]Cyberpunk 2077 REDmod[/b] gives you the ability to mod the game in different ways: custom scripts, animations and sound
[*][b]Phantom Liberty[/b] (included in the Ultimate Edition): think of it as CP:2077 on steroids. It's really, really good and massive: I highly recommended playing it. I found it better than the main game and takes quite some time to complete. It also offers new mechanics and skills to the game. 
[/olist]

[H1]Bugs and glitches[/H1]
CP:2077 had a large number of bugs and glitches at launch: it’s one of the reasons I waited with purchasing it. All of the larger issues have been fixed but there are still a couple of glitches; if you notice these, a restart will help. It’s rare though and the game and DLC are fine as they are. Just save often (like in any game (F5)).

[H1]Summary[/H1]
CP:2077 went for full immersion and from the start you feel you are part of night city. It brought back the feeling I had while playing Fallout 3 or Mass Effect 2.  Don't believe people that say it is like GTA5, because it is not, and that's fine (we have GTA6 coming soon™ anyway). 

The story is amazing and if you just play for that you will have a great time with many twists and your choices will affect the outcome of the final story – many times there is no good or bad choice. There are still some bugs and glitches present but nothing is too game breaking. 

[H1]Should you buy it?[/H1]
"Wake the f**k up, Samurai. We have a city to burn." Yes! It’s highly recommended. Also get PL from the start.
