Cyberpunk 2077 - From Rocky Start to Redemptive Triumph

Cyberpunk 2077 is a game that has journeyed from a turbulent launch to a resounding redemption, ultimately delivering a gaming experience that encompasses a gripping story, engaging gameplay, robust player development, a sprawling map, and a richly woven world narrative. CD Projekt Red's dedication and the addition of an anime series have transformed it into a true gem in the gaming world.

Storytelling and Narrative (5/5):
Cyberpunk 2077's story is nothing short of a masterpiece. Set in the sprawling, neon-drenched Night City, players assume the role of V, a character whose fate is intricately tied to the city's web of politics, corporations, and underground factions. The narrative is a thrilling rollercoaster ride filled with twists and turns that keep players on the edge of their seats. Choices matter, leading to multiple branching storylines and outcomes, providing a true sense of agency in the game's world.

Gameplay (5/5):
The gameplay in Cyberpunk 2077 is a dynamic fusion of action, stealth, and RPG elements. Combat is fluid and customizable, offering a plethora of ways to tackle challenges, whether it's through hacking, marksmanship, or close-quarters combat. The depth of character customization, including cyberware enhancements and skill progression, allows players to tailor their experience, resulting in each encounter feeling fresh and uniquely engaging.

Player Development (5/5):
The player development system in Cyberpunk 2077 is deeply satisfying. As you progress, you gain experience points that can be spent on enhancing your character's abilities, cyberware, and attributes. Watching your character evolve from a novice to a cyber-enhanced powerhouse is immensely rewarding and adds a layer of depth to the gameplay.

 Exploration (5/5):
Night City is a sprawling, breathtaking open world that feels alive and brimming with detail. The scale and verticality of the city are staggering, inviting players to explore every corner. The diverse districts, each with its distinct atmosphere, provide a genuine sense of place. Whether navigating the neon-lit streets or ascending towering skyscrapers, Night City's size and intricacy are a marvel to behold.

World Narrative (5/5):
The world-building in Cyberpunk 2077 is exemplary. From the omnipresent advertisements and propaganda to the rich lore embedded in conversations with its denizens, every facet of Night City tells a story. The game tackles profound themes of transhumanism, corporate dominance, and societal decline, offering a poignant commentary on our own world.

The journey of Cyberpunk 2077, from a rocky start to a redemptive triumph, is a testament to the commitment of CD Projekt Red and their love for the game and its community. The addition of an anime series expanded the game's universe and breathed new life into it. Cyberpunk 2077, in its current state, stands as a shining example of what dedication and support from developers can achieve. It's a must-play experience that help defines the open-world RPG genre and has earned its place as a modern classic in the gaming world.

I've completed all endings including Phantom Liberty, and got to 100% achievement completion. It wasn't the gameplay that got me there. It was the world building and the story. I'm among those who purchased the game on release and opted to wait for CDPR to fix the game.

The gameplay on its own isn't anything too special. It's a looter shooter with an abilities system. The vehicles could be better, as handling for the majority of them just feel really heavy and kind of bad.

But the story... the world building... the characters are so incredibly believable... The human experience is so vivid in this world. I wanted nothing more than to keep playing the game after getting 100% completion. But I'm ready to put it down now and let it become a fond memory. I hope CDPR continues to add to this universe.

A Deep Dive into Cyberpunk 2077: A Day One Player's Perspective

Introduction:
Having spent over 600 hours immersed in the sprawling dystopia of Night City, traversing its neon-lit streets and navigating the complexities of its narrative, Cyberpunk 2077 has been an exhilarating and, at times, tumultuous journey. As a day one player who has explored the game extensively on both Xbox and PC platforms, the experience has been a roller coaster ride filled with highs and lows. With the release of the Phantom Liberty DLC, CD Projekt Red has not only addressed some of the game's initial shortcomings but also crafted an expansion that stands tall among the best in the gaming industry.

Graphics and Design:
Right from day one, Cyberpunk 2077 showcased a visual spectacle that was both stunning and ambitious. The vibrant, cyberpunk aesthetic of Night City is brought to life with a meticulous attention to detail, from the towering skyscrapers of the corporate districts to the gritty alleyways of the combat zones. The lighting effects and reflective surfaces contribute to an immersive experience that captures the essence of a dystopian future. While the game faced criticism for performance issues on release, subsequent updates and patches have significantly improved stability on both platforms, allowing players to appreciate the game's visual splendour.

Gameplay and Mechanics:
The gameplay mechanics in Cyberpunk 2077 are a mixed bag. The open-world exploration and freedom of choice in approaching missions provide a sense of agency, but issues such as AI behaviour and occasional glitches can be distracting. The gunplay and combat mechanics, though not groundbreaking, are solid and satisfying, with a variety of weapons and cyberware augmentations to experiment with. The inclusion of the DLC Phantom Liberty introduces new weapons, cyberware, and vehicles, enriching the gameplay experience and adding depth to character customization.

Story and Narrative:
One of Cyberpunk 2077's strengths lies in its intricate narrative and well-developed characters. The main storyline, revolving around the enigmatic Johnny Silverhand and V's struggle for survival, is compelling and emotionally charged. The choices players make throughout the game shape the outcome, offering a level of replayability. The Phantom Liberty DLC seamlessly weaves into the existing narrative, introducing new characters and story arcs that expand the lore of Night City. The DLC's writing is sharp, maintaining the gritty and thought-provoking tone established in the base game.

Phantom Liberty DLC:
Phantom Liberty stands out as a shining example of how post-launch content can elevate a game. The expansion introduces a captivating storyline, taking players deeper into the conspiracies and power struggles within Night City. The new areas to explore are meticulously designed, offering a fresh perspective on the city's diverse districts. The addition of new missions, side quests, and a compelling antagonist enhances the overall experience. Notably, the DLC's emphasis on player choices and consequences adds an extra layer of complexity to an already intricate narrative.

Technical Improvements:
Over the course of the past year, CD Projekt Red has been diligent in addressing the technical issues that plagued the game's launch. Numerous patches and updates have significantly improved performance and stability, mitigating crashes and glitches. The commitment to ongoing support and improvement is commendable, turning Cyberpunk 2077 into a more polished and enjoyable experience for players who stuck with the game through its initial challenges.

Conclusion:
For a day one player with over 600 hours invested in Cyberpunk 2077, the journey has been one of evolution and redemption. The game's visual and narrative strengths have always been apparent, but the technical hiccups at launch were a significant setback. With consistent updates and the outstanding Phantom Liberty DLC, CD Projekt Red has not only addressed those issues but also elevated the overall experience. The game, in its current state, is a testament to the developers' commitment to delivering a memorable and immersive cyberpunk adventure. Phantom Liberty, with its engaging storyline and thoughtful additions, cements Cyberpunk 2077 as a contender for Game of the Year, showcasing the potential for redemption in the ever-evolving landscape of the gaming industry.

When this game launched... it was trash... i knew it was going to be trash, and it was. it was undercooked and just not ready. they knew that (the marketing team), and they pulled the pin anyway. i WANTED to like it. and honestly, i enjoyed it for the shit show that it was. but... CDPR, in my opinion, did what we all hoped that they would despite all of our discourse. 

the game wasn't "trash" on launch. but it definitely wasn't good. 

i'm giving that its own paragraph just to push the latter part of that statement. CDPR did, however put their noses to the grindstone and make it better over the years. so incomprehensibly better that it does boggle my tiny brain. they took the horrible shit we said to them. they listened. they tried to be better and did end up being better. 

i felt betrayed how bad this game was on launch. but...  i also knew what they did with the witcher series. which, to be honest was great. didn't mean i was gonna give them a free pass and not talk a serious amount of shit. which i did. 

but..... the state that this game is right now. the perseverance that this team has shown... i really can't give this game anything less than 9/10... if the launch weren't so horrible, it would honestly be 10/10. 

the storytelling, the believable and honest dialogue, the  grit. the willingness to tell a compelling story amidst social media scrutiny of stupidity or validity (depending on how you look at it). it's just unmatched in games these days. 
they didn't want to just rehash a bunch of microtransaction garbage and game mechanics that we're all just supposed to be used to and accept now. they told an interesting and original story, and also had a pretty fucking bad ass soundtrack. not just the original score, but also the radio. 

i'm drunk and making a review. but... steam asked me to, so no apologies. 

after 3 years.... this will probably be remembered almost as much a masterpiece as the witcher series. at least, in my broken-ass brain.

Finally got my hands on this after upgrading my PC (which was long overdue). I have to say, I am not disappointed in the slightest. Yes, I suppose I am fortunate enough to have gotten it when most of the broken stuff has been ironed out, but do not let the early version of this game put you off. It is a fantastic game with incredible amounts of content, you will have plenty to do. One of my favourite things about it is the attention to detail, you will notice it very quickly and will love every aspect of it.

As with any game, there's a few hiccups here and there, NPCs acting a bit weird when you're just roaming the world, that sort of thing. If you are on the edge of uncertainty of buying this game, I would say go for it! It is absolutely a gem in the sea of shit triple A games, but also just games in general of the past few years. Worth. Every. Penny.

The setting in this game is maybe my favorite of all games I have played. The world feels alive and the misery, brutality and inequality of the cyberpunk society is on full display. Corporations have a huge negative impact on the lives of the everyday citizen, and most are resigned to this fate.

The graphics are incredible. In particular, the facial animations of all the NPCs and the landscape views you can get of the city are stunning. The facial animations and the way the map is designed combines for one of the most immersive games I have personally experienced.

The main story, and the "important" side quests around the more prominent NPCs are well written and sometimes quite heartwrenching. There's good variety here and there should be something for everyone. There's additional content in terms of gigs which are voice acted. I quite enjoyed doing the gigs as they fit quite well into the game and story since your background is that you are a merc - it helps a great deal that they are voice acted well.

(2.1 Update)

We've waited years for this game to be fixed. Little by little, they tweaked it, added things, balanced the mechanics, and opened (most of) the settings to be changed for maximum playability. Now, after all this time, we can safely say that the programmers working hard day-in and day-out to polish this dream to as close to perfection as they possibly could, have once again broken everything and sent many of us back to square one. They are never going to fix the most basic things, like keybinds. Nobody can fix people who say "just get a controller", that's a different problem that the developers aren't responsible for. What they are responsible for is the fact that keyboards have hard-coded commands that, after all this time and all the complaints, they still refuse to get rid of. Screw you if you play with keyboard and mouse, this is soft-core porn for people who use controllers.

Regardless, you can't really fix something that is fundamentally broken from the ground up. The main character is dumb as shit regardless of the dialogue options, and acts like it doesn't know anything or have the ability to think. Even if you try to bash your way through the game, the plot tries to force you to care about characters that either have extremely limited interactions, or are about as deep as a wet shoe. Meanwhile you're most likely a murderous cyborg pretending to care about things that have nothing to do with the primary gameplay. At the very least, let me have an observant main character that doesn't need everything spelled out for them. It used to be embarrassing. Now it's insulting.

How many years will I have to wait before I can use E to walk forward? Either get rid of hard keys, or get rid of the rebinding menu in settings. Or, at the VERY LEAST, fix the reset that happens every time I exit settings, and remove the rebinds in the menu that don't actually change regardless what I try to set them to. I'm on QWERTY, but I've seen AZERTY people having the same problem. It really is an issue of not caring about people who use keyboard and mouse, which is a significant number of people who play this game.

A flawed masterpiece.  The launch was rocky, I didn't even play this for a year (I bought it originally on the PS4 PRO.) I completed it a few times on PS4, after patch 1.6 made it playable on ps4, if you were patient.

Got myself a PS5 in anticipation of better performance, I wasn't disappointed. I had a couple of macbooks die a year after and switched to a desktop PC+Linux and here I am on Steam, actively.

So on a RTX 3060 and an i5 this is pretty great, and mods really bring my interest back to the game. 

I have complaints, but they're mostly about unskippable cutscenes, and things I can now use mods to get around.  The CDPR choices, of gameplay elements to mess with, from one patch to another is pretty irritating.   You take time to tune a build for your play style, and they screw it completely. Despite it all, I love this game, and CDPR have done something really special.

I played the game at launch (on Stadia). Had very little bugs, but the experience felt...off. Couldn't put my finger on it at the time, but something (outside of the bugs) just didn't make me want to stick around. 

Fast forward a couple years later, Stadia's now dead, and I repurchased Cyberpunk 2077 on Steam, particularly to play on my Steam Deck. Well, to keep it short, the game has changed immensely. From the systems in place (specifically the skill tree) and the overall feel. It's seemingly a night (city) and day difference.

Is it the game we were presented those so many years ago? No. Is it a fantastic game. Very much yes. Especially now. 100% worth the price of admission.

Contrary to what many people may say, this is a really fun game underneath all its glaring problems (there is a lot, don't get me wrong, but there is a lot to enjoy as well). The world, graphics, characters and soundtrack are downright amazing. The gunplay starts off a little janky but you do get used to it over time. The biggest problem is definitely the performance. There are bugs and glitches that made me reload previous saves multiple times, but I did get past them.

Overall, I really enjoy this game despite its flaws, but hopefully they will be fixed in future updates and patches. My score is 7.5/10

(Edit: 02/01/2024. This game is way better now. It's absolutely worth it. CDPR managed to pull off a No Man's Sky with the game.)

Cyberpunk's a lotta fun when u ain't got someone in your ear telling you it's glitchy.

Now while the game had it's infamously ridiculous optimization issues at launch, and was quite literally just unfinished, and still has it's occasional quirks today, the game is still ultimately my most played game on Steam. Jester me all you want, I have made myself a citizen in Night City for more than 20 days straight and have loved every moment. Besides the crashes.

IMO: I've been waiting for companies, other than Rockstar, to make an outstanding open-world experience in a huge city landscape, and I think Cyberpunk 2077 takes the cake GTA V gave us and lit 20 more candles, added 2x the amount of not-so-tasty showcase icing with some LED strips at the bottom of the base. To give us, what is now a statue of what used to be an edible treat. Everything feels fresh and new and I'm excited to continue exploring the world. Even after a 3rd complete playthrough. The VAs feels like they really tried to make these scenes have emotion in them, and it doesn't come off as cringe-inducing. Keanu can sound like an over-dramatic-anime-boy sometimes, but you soon realize there are reasons he acts the way he does. The bugs have been really inconsistent, even when I first bought the game, so that has been really pleasant. I think overtime, we will get everything we were promised by the devs, just like for No Man's Sky, but even for an "unfinished game" this game is and was quite incredible for PC users at launch. 

P.S. Please implement the option of making a custom radio please, the music in this game is great, but it's somewhat limited to genres and each radio has a very small amount of songs in them.

A boring, broken and lifeless rpg that fails to deliver on many of it's promises and over a year later is still being overhauled by the devs and will be into 2022. The characters are mostly annoying, the story is average, there's nothing to do in the city outside of story missions other than some repetitive combat side quests, the police are brain dead and are implemented worse than in game from over a decade ago, there's no car customization, the clothing options are a joke both in design and because outside of a couple cut scenes, you'll never see them without a third person view, there's little outside of the main story to do with the various factions and gangs, they wasted time on three beginnings that have little meaning beyond the tutorial, the most interesting companion is gone by the end of the first mission, the most fun looking part of the game is a montage that looks like the game we should have played, public transportation is oddly cut, driving mechanics are awful, the streets are practically empty of people and vehicles, I could go on for pages about what's wrong with this game so I'll spare you and just say that if you haven't already lost your hard earned money to this smoke and mirrors hustle, don't even consider it at any price outside of free and free won't make it a better game. I don't think this game can be saved and it seems we'll have a long wait to find out. There are plenty of other games on the market worth your time. This game will stand up as the prime example of the era of "sell now fix and finish later" games that AAA publishers are trying to peddle. There are many examples, but this will be the one we always remember because it should and could have been so much more.
 EDIT JAN 2024:
Still a busted broken mess. Every update that brings in new features keeps adding more problems. Patch 2.11, over three years after we were asked to pay for this, is still a mess and added tons of technical issues and this trash company is taking a social media victory lap like they accomplished something. It's pathetic. It's clear CDPR punched way above their weight with this garbage game and now they're not only bragging but acting like the sequel is going to be amazing. These clowns can't do what Rockstar did over a decade ago and they're arrogant? Pathetic. It's a bad product, full stop. Don't buy at any price.

I wasn't sure about this one when I got it earlier this year, i saw too much of the problems when it first came out and figured it was a half baked game all round. Yeah, it can still be fairly buggy and it's not perfect. However I was so surprised at how emotionally invested I was in the main story. I like this game a lot, probably one of my favourites. I'm gonna write a positives and negatives below. But overall my enjoyment of the game out-ways my dislikes.

vague spoilers ahead

POSITIVES:
 Main story. There's a level of misdirection in the beginning that I think really works in the story's favour. So many characters and points you think are gonna be important only for the game to really punch you in the face and leave you in a gutter, but in a good way? I love that the main focus of the story is more emotional than you think it's gonna be. Themes of personal identity are always super interesting to me and that is at the core of the story. I also love stories with a strong base in social/political themes. Obviously this game could just be enjoyed as a fun shooter. But I love how integrated the social and political problems of the world is to the quests. I think about what my actions would mean for the world around me, even if its just a small side quest with no actual consequences in the game. 

voice acting. This can really be a deal breaker for me sometimes. The voice acting has to be a good mix of believable and genuine but still slightly overacted and punchy and I think this game walks that line really well. I especially appreciate the work the male voice actor did for V. Too many male main characters are voiced with a lack of genuine emotion. V felt very real to me. You can really hear it in his voice, they weren't afraid to make him emotional. I love that.

City design. I am genuinely quite impressed at the scale and detail of the city in its appearance and layout.  It looks and feels like a city that came about over time rather than designed. the roads are as winding and confusing as real cities. It's something I have only seen games like GTA do well. On top of that, barely any loading screens. It is quite impressive that you can drive from one end of this map to the other, walk into every shop on the way, and never see a loading screen. Obviously it results in bugs and some crashing but i still commend the effort. It really helps with the immersion. 

Queer and Trans characters. Now there are some issues with the character creator for this topic which I will cover below. However, it is still so uncommon to have a game that just lets you have a tarns character so that alone is really appreciated. As a trans person it made me feel so much more connected to V. Sure it's not important to the story, but i don't need that. I would love for my real life to feel more like that. There is also a main-ish character who is openly transgender and that makes me very happy. You don't just get to avoid talking to them just because you might be weird about it. She is treated just like any other character in the game and i respect that.

music and soundtrack. They did a bang up job of the mains score. I listen to it so often. I don't know what to say other than its just so good. Each moment and situation has a score that fits and really extenuates the moment. And then the radio music is just fantastic. It really helps to make the world feel real.

Combat. In my opinion the combat is really fun. There's so many options for how to approach a fight and ways to combine it all. There's you standard guns and melee weapons but combine that with brain hacking, vehicle combat and cybernetic augmentations. It really does give you a variety of ways to enjoy combat.

NEGATIVES:

Pacing. Maybe it's just me, but I find the pacing of the main quest really feels at odds with the rest of the game. This is an open world RPG with a lot to explore and many side quests well worth doing. But the main quest has such a sense of urgency that interferes with my immersion. I found myself feeling silly for going off doing fun racing side quests and gigs when the main character seems to be in the middle of a major crisis and is fighting against time to help himself. I think the main story just needed to give the player a bit more breathing room early on before pushing them into the main plot.

Trigger warning. This isn't a huge issue to me personally and not by any means my biggest problem. But i was surprised at how dark some of the plot points could be, even with just side quests. There's a lot of upsetting topics and I don't have any problem with exploring those things, I actually think the story telling around it all is really good. But this game has a lot of triggering subjects such as suicide, rape/sexual harassment, drug abuse, snuff films and i guess technically terminal illness. These topics aren't super explicit and in your face, but they are themes and topics that are very much a part of the main game and worth knowing before hand. So i just wanted to put it in my review for those who may benefit from knowing.

Character Customisation. I was quite disappointed at the boundaries within the character customisation. What is there is really cool. The best options are with the hair. The tattoos and mods and eye colours are very cool. But there's just not ENOUGH of them. You have basically 5 tattoo options. which is wild to me because there's endless possibilities there, and it just seems it was not given much attention. Even little things, like the fact that you cant have two different coloured eyes. It seems silly to complain about but it would have been so easy to include, so why not? this is a cyberpunk future where body modification has endless possibilities, so why do I have such vanilla options? it just seems such a shame, especially since so many other games and doing much more. 

Adding on to this. I appreciate getting to make my character transgender, however how it is implemented just isn't quite right. It makes no sense as to why the voice options determine your pronouns, its unnecessary and just puts more boundaries on who your character can be. It's just a shame they slightly missed the mark on that one. And want to be some kind of Nonbinary? nope, that just doesn't seem to exist in this universe for some reason. But I still appreciate what is there and I look forward to how they might better it in future games.

City immersion. I appreciate that a lot of the updates have helped with the immersion, such as using the metro and enjoying a drink in your apartment, but it still feels a little lacking in some areas. This could just be very specific to what I want from a game, but I want to be able to do EVERYTHING. for example the food vendors. They don't really serve a real game play purpose, so why not allow my character to properly sit down and animate them eating? I know it's not important but it makes the world feel real and lived. The clubs are all so cool but you can only dance in one of them. Why cant V sit on most empty seats? Why cant V get black out drunk after too much alcohol and wake up in a ditch? I want the world to feel real and not just a set for V to walk around. Maybe future updates might add them. 

Last but not least. I cant romance Claire, Takemura or the hot bartender at Lizzie's bar. Not important at all. But I want to KISS them and i'm SAD that i CAN'T :( 

Anyway this is the biggest review I have ever written and I only write it because I am waiting for the game to finish updating so I can keep playing it. Overall I really like the game and I think now is the best time to get it, it's constantly getting updated and things being added. I understand it really was a bit of a shit show when this game first came out, but I'm glad CD project red didn't just abandon it. They are still working on making the game better and I think that's real cool of them.

 Cheers if you took the time to read this.

Another review, though less of a review, and more of me rambling about stuff while playing through the game. Cyberpunk is great at times, but only if you focus on the main quests. 
I can’t leave a neutral review score, but I don’t want to give it the thumbs up either, sorry.

Note: I didn’t play at launch.


Spoilers below:


Controversial or not, *** [i]Male V and Keanu’s voices are bad. Their performances are wooden and insufferable. Especially Keanu’s . (After finishing the game, they became tolerable)[/i]


**[i]The radio is simply unplayable. Songs constantly repeating. Barely any good songs, or radio hosts, and on top of that, you have the terrible driving system (physics all messed up) which renders the radio pointless, in my opinion. Comparing it to San Andreas (which is my favourite GTA), where I had the radio constantly on, with great songs on every station, and you could ride and play music and do nothing else. You can do this in Cyberpunk too, but it’s not even remotely pleasant. Yes, you can just listen while walking around, but I only like a couple of songs, at most. I just couldn’t be bothered, after a point.[/i]


*Driving just sucks, in terms of handling, sounds, looks and lack of customization in garages. Also no garages for V and his fleet of cars.


*Gameplay wise, stealth sucks at the beginning with a silenced pistol (You can one hit kill with a thrown weapon, you can’t one hit kill with a headshot.), and enemies are bullet sponges. Especially cyberpsychos. 


NPCs just wander around doing nothing. Or endlessly doing the same thing.


Melee fighting is awful, enemies just hit the air and somehow you get hit, or they teleport to you hitting. Really bad mechanics.

Showering with clothes on and sleeping weirdly on your own bed.

You can’t buy anything from the million street vendors, who are useless.

*Wish you could train on the punching bag and lift some weights with Coach Fred.

**Happy Together quest just fails in a day, if you don’t know what to do.


Cops homing in even if you stealth kill various NPCs (like Fingers, or Lenny Nero).


**[i]JoyToy moments and various Red Districts quite tame and disappointing. Only 2 in the entire city? With all the crazy sex ads and merchandise, you’d think there’d be more. It seems like cut content. And censoring.[/i]


***[b]No braindances outside from scripted ones, even though there are many vendors with so many BDs.  So many more things could have been done with the BDs. Detective V and Johnny on the case? Another missed opportunity.[/b]


*[i]I stealth kill an enemy with a silenced pistol, and Judy says, “I heard shots, you still alive?” – “I’m here, got No time to creep around”, V yells. Enemies getting alerted, through walls, even though there were no cameras, and kills were silent.[/i]


Setting a trap which falls, killing 2 NPCs who were further away, but scripted to patrol there.

We see the same NPCs even after a few days have passed. For example, in Afterlife, the mercs crying about the ripperdoc, yelling “why aren’t we at a hospital”.

With Panam, silent killing with a pistol an enemy – “I’ve been made”. 

NPCs start running way if you bump into one. 

NPCs following system is too slow. 

After killing various gang members, and saving civilians, too many NPCs remain there, as if nothing happened.

Wish there was a way to show weapons being in some holster, anywhere. You’re just pulling them out of your pants. 


***[b]So many missions talking about “need you here”, “hurry up”, “tonight”, “tomorrow”, “in the evening”, “now”, when nothing really happens if you take your time. There is no sense of urgency in the game. And that’s the problem with the entire game design and quest system. The Relic is killing you and you can just waste time sightseeing, because ultimately the game doesn’t account for that. Which is why I hope the next Cyberpunk game won’t have anything to do with a relic, disease, or anything else that is supposed to kill you soon.[/b]


Clipping through NPCs. There’s no collision. Important characters walk through you, or you through them. Others are solid.

While talking to Karim Noel and proving I’m a big Samurai fan, after going back to him, he just asks “do I know you?”. Okay, thanks.


You don’t sleep, you just wait. 

*Using Overwatch to stealth from behind cover, all enemies immediately turn and home in on your position.

The Sinnerman quest – Scripted cars just ramming into the NCPD armored vehicle again and again. A bit absurd, looks weird. Also, we are a few meters behind, and Bill is screaming “We can’t lose him”, or other grunts. “Brake I said, BRAKE!” when nothing is happening. And then Bill gets out and dies. Of course, it’s a random semi blocking the road. 

The NPCs driving you around make the car camera go crazy.

Can’t give spare eddies to street performers. But you can help veterans.


***[b]No consequences to V killing countless gang members, no gang wars, no turf wars, nothing. The fixers aren’t bothered by your killing their goons and ruining their operations. No consequences. [/b]


Wish you could turn off all the various lights in bases. Hack everything. Every little panel. Unfortunately, it’s not about light detection when you’re stealthing. 

I walk the line quest - if you bait the Undertaker, the robot keeps fighting by himself.

Scripted car chase scenes are so slow and ugly.

Wearing a coat in cutscenes has V’s arms clipping through.


**[i]Beat Razor, no reaction from the crowd, no cutscene. As if nothing happened. Coach Fred remained quiet and in the same position as before the fight. Then he sent a text message calling me legend. Really lame.[/i]
*In a club you can stealth kill an enemy or walk through a “restricted” door, and the normal NPCs start yelling and running, even though they didn’t see or hear you, but no one gets triggered. When you use your technical ability to open a door, random NPCs lose their minds “Mercy I did nothing to you”. 


Killed the 1 beat cop and two Tyger Claws goons at the Snagged Synapse Roasters corner, and they respawned a few days later with the exact same dialogue as if nothing happened.

The attachments/modding part is not really that good. Especially since you can’t remove the mods. Same with crafting, not really that interesting.


*The same repeated intro shows when you start the game are just annoying.


**[i]Street rep is gained way too fast, especially if you’re clearing random enemies. You can become a legend in no time. The bonuses are lame.[/i]


**Going to the same location multiple times, and you see the same NPCs with the exact same dialogue (example at Clouds the guys talking about blow-up dolls and infidelity).

Always funny when you just go through NPCs personal computers right next to them and they don’t mind.

[i](I need the Sasha Devon 3 mouths 1 desire experience.)[/i]


Takemura is sending me a message just as he is leaving in front of me.



Review continued here: telegra.ph/Cyberpunk-Review---Continued-01-31

Cyberpunk It's amazing for those who are seeking a game with a deep and detailed story with characters that you will create a lot of affection for because they're absolutely well written, each with their own personalities and backgrounds, and the game knows when to introduce them to you, which in my opinion is probably the strongest point of Cyberpunk. Another thing that has caught my attention is the gameplay, because I loved it. The game has dozens of different gameplay styles; if you like stealth, you can do it; if you like explosions, you can have massive explosions; and if you want to hack everyone, you can do it. Want to be a futuristic ninja? Don't worry; you'll become one. I also strongly recommend playing this game slowly because, as I mentioned in the story, it's incredible, and there are numerous side quests with interesting missions. But the main reason for taking it slowly is that Night City is an absolutely stunning scenario, arguably the best I've seen in a game. So my advice is to spend some time simply enjoying the scenario; believe me, it's an incredible experience.
Of course, Cyberpunk still has some issues (in my case, they didn't interfere with anything), but if you've played RDR2, you'll be irritated by some details (side effects of releasing an incomplete game), and in these cases, Cyberpunk won't be rated ten out of ten. However, if you're a gamer like me who enjoys action RPGs with multiple choices, you'll consider this game a masterpiece. (After all, one of the reasons I don't get annoyed by some minor details is that I've already played Bethesda Games a dozen times, so yeah, if you've played, don't worry, there's nothing you didn't see in there.) So just go ahead and give it.

So I've been playing since the release day, and I never had game-breaking bugs as everyone said there were. It was good then, and now it's quite perfect with the recent care and polishing along with the DLC. The recent updates and dlc really have changed the game by adding more content, perks and ways to play and many more quality of life aspects. Plus, you can't forget the addition of mods now, so you can freely change different items or how stuff works to your liking. The game still has divine graphics and a thrilling story based in the beloved night city that you can get lost in and have a blast exploring.

I have sunk 300hrs as of right now and I had fun and enjoined every bit of those hours of playing. Keep in mind I have also 100% it and the achievements but this game is defiantly a game I'd recommend it to any one who likes single player games. And reminder its a RPG but it is still on tracks, given that the story is still a rich one worth trying.

TLDR: A great immersive game with beautiful graphics and a medium-length story, but DLC and side quests make up for it. It has great character development along with immersion, and the music is fantastic and fits perfectly with the setting and voice acting. If you haven't checked it out, I would recommend it. It's polished and has more activities than before.

I first picked up Cyberpunk 2077 back in 2020. However, I didn't quite listen to any of the hype in the buildup for it. Honestly, I picked it up because I had exhausted my other games and wanted to try something new. The bugs aside, it was a fun game then with the voice cast being a standout hit. I suspect because I hadn't let myself get too hyped up back then, there was no let down on promises not kept by CDPR. 

Flash forward into 2022 with Edgerunners' release and I found myself playing another run through of 2077. Add in 2.0 and Phantom Liberty in 2023 and well...I'm glad I almost let myself forget about this game. The return experience was the reserved enjoyment I had of it in 2020 but multiplied by 5. The combat, skills, how the game ran, all of it improved! Phantom Liberty was a masterpiece with newer characters only adding to the excellent cast introduced in the base game.

I whole heartily recommend this game!

As an avid gamer and tech enthusiast I am quite disappointed .This game is still highly unoptimised. Performance is still very inconsistent. After 4 years of " optimisation" and patches the game still runs horrendous.( I still don't know how people ran the game 4 years ago, looking at the state of the game now). This brought forth a "sub par" gaming experience and in all honesty it was not enjoyable. I spent to majority of my game time , trying to optimise the graphics , performance and visuals to figure out and try to resolve why the game looks so blurry. Running this game in 1080p is a no go , the visuals seem smudgy , flat and blurry. The game relies too heavily on Fsr and Dlss to make it playable. This inturn also scales down your resolution and creates weird sharpening artefacts and a variety of visual problems that make the game unplayable to the point that ps3 graphics look a whole lot better than this. Unless you are running a 2000 $ rig than can handle this " beast " at 1440p or 4k , I would not suggest playing this title. It will save you a lot of head scratching and headaches. I really tried to love this game , but it still is not worth it.

In the wake of Patch 2.0 and Phantom Liberty, this game is a must-play masterpiece that lives up to the very high standard set by CDPR with the Witcher 3.

I didn't buy the game at launch because I normally wait for sales and because I'd heard a lot about how disastrous it was. It was unfortunate to see the reputation of such a top-tier studio damaged by corpos failing to listen to devs, which is ironic considering the themes the game explores. 

After a decent sale sprang up and Phantom Liberty was announced, I purchased the game and dove right into it when the DLC released. I was not disappointed in the slightest - the worldbuilding, story, characters, gameplay and music are masterful. You feel fully immersed in the plausibly grim future that Cyberpunk 2077 portrays, and the combat and progression system are incredibly satisfying. Keanu Reeves and Idris Elba both deliver in their performances, without any of the cheesiness that sometimes comes with stars featuring in AAA games. The regular voice actors also did an excellent job, particularly the voice actress for female V.

Had this game been released in 2023 I think it would have been seen as a generational work of art. I'm glad I waited it out and got to experience the completed product, even if it took 3 years for it to get there. Although a big mistake was made in rushing out an unfinished game, in my eyes CDPR have totally redeemed themselves and I can't wait for the sequel!

I'm giving this a review well after launch, though I did play during it's rough launch.

The build-up to this game was not only over hyped but by contrast well under delivered. Their promise of customization and 'be who you want in night city' was a lie. You did get to choose dick or vag tho, gotta love that pandering for no real integration. NPCs are still really jank and serve little to no point other than the countless bodies waiting to die in little pockets around the city. Cops are still pretty pointless, get out of sight and suddenly you're crime free. As much as they expressed this game being 'immersive', there's not a lot that actually gives any part of the external world atmosphere. If it's not a quest or story set piece, you can tell it was just slapped together to fill the empty city with content. Also, still regularly found people walking into the floor, cars clipping into each other (Including in cut scenes). Open RPGs like Skyrim are fun because of the nonsense that can come from sandbox elements. Nothing happens when civvies are basically mindless, cops are pointless and enemies just hang out until you shoot them.

The skill tree is fun since the overhaul, lots of little choices that do impact gameplay rather than just % bonuses to stuff. One of the only games I can say satisfied the netrunner/hacker fantasty for me though in an action combat style. Shooting is fine, hard to fuck that up much especially at this budget level. 

The story is mid, at best, and the night city dialect dialog wears off pretty quick which then show really low effort writing. Take out the 'chooms' and other NC specific words and you get bland, mostly flavorless conversations. To be fair, it could be much worse. Neat ideas, like the ramp up to the end and the firewall - but Keanu was basically there for star power to sell the game and his character serves little purpose. Choosing an origin is almost entirely pointless, as are any plots or dialog that might stem from it.  For that matter, why did we get 'V' instead of a fully custom character?Sure, voice acting might be an excuse but they could have chosen any word to refer to your player character that wasn't a specific name. Which is what they implied when the game was first being announced, that we'd get to build our person in night city. They had a clear vision for who V is, your choices don't usually matter and come down to 'Do you want to be agreeable? Or sassy?' Clearly they had to cut back to even make it to launch, barely getting the core story out nevermind side quests or the vast emptiness of most regions. 

All in all, the game is a fun time and I could recommend it now. I'm not sure 60$ worth of recommend, maybe wait for a sale. Especially since there's a DLC. 60$ would have been fine, if I weren't salty about it's launch state and the amount of lies we were fed for publicity prior to launch for features and concepts to just never made it into a game, which is now just a bounty hunter sandbox with a disfigured, choppy story placed on a top.

If you played prior to 2.0, honestly outside of the skill trees nothing much of note has changed. If restarting your skill tree doesn't interest you, probably just pass on coming back.

Originally I purchased it on release but refunded as my hardware wasn't strong enough (no upscaling/perf fixes on release, but I had upgraded by the time I did play later on).

I did a full play through on Version 1.5 in Feb 2022, and I felt the game was pretty complete by then and I had a blast.
Never was one to do side quests etc so I finished the game and left it at that, however since 2.0/2.1 update the game is better than ever with new fixes, activities, romance options, complete overhauls of certain systems, physics etc. I've played through Phantom Liberty which introduces lots of new content and have gotten multiple endings (not really a fan of the new alternate ones). While the game still has small bugs, I've been completely immersed in the cyberpunk world and going around completing every side quest I can and I am now considering a 2nd play through. One of my favourite games of all time, everything is amazing. Compared to what I played on 1.5 its a whole other level, and even back then I was completely captured by it.

Although it probably won't happen I'd love an expansion focused around what everyone considers the canon & best ending (Panam, Aldercados) to see what happens to them, some sort of story in the badlands and whether V can be cured as we know from Phantom Liberty that its possible.

You truly have outdone yourselves CDPR, I'm excited to put many more hours into this incredible world you've created.

After a few years and hearing about the updates i've come back to revise my review.

Every. Single. Complaint. I. Had. Has. Been. Fixed.

To be clear, there are still some bugs and visual glitches, and certainly some areas still need polish if you look closely, but nowhere near as bad as before.

Driving feels great, combat feels more fluid and alive, VEHICLE CHASES ARE HERE BABY. The police system has been completely overhauled and fixed, corpos/gangs will hunt you down if you piss them off, random events and gigs are actually worth doing, and it actually feels good to explore the world without feeling like you're wasting your time.

Phantom liberty was an excellent and content packed expansion, as expected from a CDPR game, once again be-clowning other publishers like Activision and Ubisoft who pretend a new multiplayer map or character skin is "content" worthy of a $20+ price tag.

With that said, I will qualify that CDPR should have never released the game in its original state on launch, and they should not be forgiven just because they fixed it years later. This shameful practice of "kick it out the door now, fix it later" must be chastised by players every time it happens, and we must vote with our wallets or it will never stop. I'm looking forward to the next CDPR game, but I will not be buying it as soon as it comes out like I did with Cyberpunk for this reason, until I see the reviews. In fact i've made it a habit to stop doing that with all games.

The game will never be what they initially advertised it as, however CDPR managed to salvage what was one of the most disastrous game launches ever and turned it into an incredibly fun and enjoyable experience! 

The most glaring issues the game had have been fixed, almost every aspect of the game has been touched in some way, some got a complete overhaul.


It has an incredibly enjoyable combat and stealth, fascinating and deep world to explore, an amazing story and some of the most high quality character animations in dialogues I've ever seen. 


However, I wouldn't call this a role playing game. There's very few actual choices you get to make throughout the game. The majority of the dialogue is painfully linear with most options coming down to "Yes", "Angry Yes", "Nomad Yes".
It's more like a high quality Far Cry game in a cyberpunk world. 


One aspect that is mostly unchanged from release is the absolutely shallow crowd behavior. It's not as janky as it used to be, however most crowd NPCs simply do that Joe Biden walk and nothing else. It doesn't feel as lively and natural as say Watch Dogs 2, that game's crowds are so alive!


Definitely worth your time and money to experience it! Including the Phantom Liberty expansion. Highly recommend seeing every ending both for the main game and the expansion, there's a lot of effort put into each outcome and there's a lot more to them than just watching a different cutscene.

Played an hour at launch and can't go through the starting area due to game-breaking bug. Finished a run when Phantom Liberty got announced, with some minor bugs all around. Currently on Phantom Liberty run and this game is smooth, with only some minor-moderate bugs (e.g. cars or bikes randomly falling and getting damaged when called to clipping out of bounds) in my experience.

The update they did on 2.1 massively revamped the game, giving me a lot of stuff to play and experiment  with, and the build diversity is quite fun as well. Even without the Phantom Liberty DLC, I think it's worth it to play, just so we can see the initial vision of the game that was promised, but not met.

While certainly a redemption arc for CD Projekt Red, the initial launch of the game was one of the biggest fumble in gaming history, alongside No Man's Sky and should be a reminder for everyone in the future about the danger of over-hyping and not meeting the expectations of players. However, in it's current state, I can highly recommend this game, as while some of the content are quite repetitive (NCPD Scanner), the gameplay is really fun once your build are starting to come together.
Great game, heavy on your graphics card if you have an older computer but worth the money, even without the Phantom Liberty DLC.

Initially played it at launch where I had fun but endured a lot of bugs. Eventually, I dropped it 16 hours in because of a game breaking bug and forgot about the game for 3 whole years until now. Cyberpunk 2077 with its 2.1 update is one of the best games I've ever played. The quality and amount of quests are really engaging and well written. The gameplay is incredibly fast, detailed and satisfying (must play on Hard or Very Hard). Night City is very detailed and lore heavy with distinct districts, giving off the perfect Cyberpunk vibe. Additionally, with path tracing this game looks stupidly good, I have taken over 3000 screenshots with the photo mode. The endings are the weakest part of the game in my opinion but Phantom Liberty fills that void for me with being insanely good in its own right. The expansion is a must play. Overall, I highly recommend Cyberpunk 2077 + Phantom Liberty.

This game had one hell of a comeback. It is rare to see developers stick with a game that was so poorly received at launch but I am so glad they did. 
Cyberpunk 2077 has a lot going for it, and so it is hard to really sum it all up in a short form review. So instead, I'll list the things I liked and didn't like! 

What I enjoyed: Night City itself is fantastic, it is so well detailed and thought out, it feels so real and clearly had a lot of love and care put into it. The score is brilliant, it has quickly become one of my favourite video game scores ever, everything is a banger. The gunplay is super fun, I enjoyed the variety of loot and attachments you can use, along with a really fun skill tree that lends itself to lots of different play styles. Also, the graphics are insane, this is easily one of the best looking games I've ever played and it scares me how demanding the sequel will be.

What I didn't enjoy: while most of my time spent with Cyberpunk was overall positive, I did have a few gripes with it. Mainly the story. It is a very solid story, but somehow the side quests outshine the core beats of the main campaign and I wasn't really invested in V's struggle. It started off really strong, and I quite liked the ending (at least the route I took), but everything in between felt like a wild goose chase. Besides the story, some minor things like the game feeling very gamey at times, you'll know what I mean if you have played it, and this is mainly a nit pick and won't be for everyone, but I so wish there was a third person version. I don't think I was a fan of the first person stuff, but it didn't bog down the game enough for me and I was able to look past it.

Overall, if you are a fan of RPGs and are looking for a really immersive world and really fun gameplay mechanics, as well as just some awesome sci-fi stuff, then I can easily recommend this to you.

Short:
Wait for a discount. If you have patience for a buggy game, I think it's worth the discounted price.
In the other hand, it's so buggy, that whoever signed this off for release should feel bad, it's shameful. And this is 2 years after the release, on version 2.0!
Sometimes you can get stuck, need to reload, fiddle with stuff, but you can make it work. These big bugs are very rare, but still too frequent. Small bugs happen left and rights, but it's fine.
Story is also fine, just don't expect too much from it. If you have the expectation of a GTA V or Fallout 4, you will be in for a pleasant ride. People who expect Witcher 3, but neon signs might have their heart broken.

Longer. RPG exists, but it's kinda lightweight. You most of the time can choose between dialog options, but the exact text is not shown. Like fallout4. Dialog options usually not that very influental, but you definitely can take a few different roads, you can lock yourself out of characters/sidequests, or get some unobtainium car/equipment.

People who you interact with have some nice stories, some are very lovable, others are very hateable, but rarely bland, like they are actually a person, not just "Bring 10 iron to the iron smith so he can do his favourite hobby: making swords" kind of things.

Music is very nice, city vibes are also very nice, the different parts have different vibes, I love to just drive around doing fetch quests while listening to the radio. Fast travel has fairly good coverage who doesn't like it, tho it has quite a bit of public transport vibes to it. The city is fairly walkable.

Shoutout for accessibility features, vast majority of the voices can be shown on screen in a text form, including useless ped chatter, TV shows in the background, etc. It will even visualize if the voice is in another language.

Wait, if it's so good, why I'm downvoting?
Well, whenever I feel good, something throws me off. Usually a bug or bad design.
I called my car. It has a small animation as it arrives in the traffic. After frame-by-frame analysis of the InstantReplay footage, only thing I can say, is that under like 3 frame the care got teleported under a van, which got yeeted into the air a bit, and touched a cop. The cop started shooting at the car, but couldn't hit the driver from 5m. Driver just gone forward and backward for quite a few seconds, until he left.
Our cop did a 180° and started shooting at another seemingly innocent driver, shouted get out, then another cop started shooting. A text appeared above the cop "I really don't like you" but that sentence wasn't said. The only thing was said, while the driver was getting out, that "No, you will put that away". Then the cop hit the guy, and the guy got onto the ground, not sure if he died or not.

Then going home I got a notification that the NCPD want someone to help them with a shooting, and at the next left turn 3 people is shooting at the ceiling, many innocent citizens are dead, so I checked the guys out and started shooting at them. Then the cops started shooting at me... it seems i have to wait until at least one cop dies to be sure I can engage in these things.

The UI can be very confusing, sometimes after completing these NCPD tasks, I'm receiving notifications like +50xp or whatever for minutes! It even delays the reward, and the completion message.

Hitboxes are funky too, sometimes you cannot access the thing you need. Sometimes things just don't work. I had to get a certain item from a cars trunk and give it to the NPC: I took 12 reloads. I had to jump into the trunk, crouching, because otherwise couldn't reach the container. Getting the item wasn't smooth sailing, as sometimes I just coudln't give the item for the ncp, or the objective wasn't updated.
Other times I was hit by a car coming from the wrong direction. Where my car was shielding me.

At this point I'm not even sure if it's worth mentioning the countless cosmetic bugs, like when you open a gate or barrier, there's a good chance, that the lights on it will stay in the closed position

Ignore anyone who continues to criticize this game because of its launch. Despite all the problems that the developers have faced, I’ve adored this game since its launch. I pre-ordered Cyberpunk on my PlayStation when the world was still on lockdown, I still had enjoyment out of its initial release after the amount of delays it had received. Nearly four years later, I can definitely say that the franchise has earn its redemption. A lot more content, a lot less issues. The story is absolutely phenomenal, plus the DLC. The dialogue, the flow, the open-world environment, and the endings, but most importantly the characters. All the characters throughout the story are incredibly well written. Two of them happen to be played by very talented Hollywood actors (Keanu and Idris). Gameplay is both solid and satisfying too, both combat and driving feels a lot less dull than it was at launch. The DLC feels much more than an expansion, like you’re playing a totally brand new game. New play area, over 100+ weapons/vehicles added (including ones that were scrapped at launch), longer game duration but in a good way, and more endings, not just the DLC but the game too. Also check out Edgerunners too, easily one of the best animes I’ve ever watched. It will without a doubt make you see the game in a much more different perspective. That being said, this is personally my favorite RPG game of all time. Now that’s just an opinion, but this game is WAAAAAAAAAAAY better than Bethesda’s Starfield. Huge props to CD Projekt Red for taking their time to put this game back the way we thought before launch.

[h1] GOTY 2024 [/h1]

[b] What I Liked [/b]

I played at 1.0.  "Played" being the word here since I felt played that I bought into the hype.  The game looked bad, played bad, felt bad.  Bugs everywhere.

Now, with 2.1, the game is an absolute gem.  It looks better, plays better, and is mostly bug free.  Minor bugs are mostly related to visual effects (enemies fall through ground, float in air, etc.).  Bugs are game breaking.

The storyline is good, the side quests are incredible.  A couple side quests I took a break from the game after since they were really morally challenging.

I am playing on "hard" difficulty - and at this point it's dead easy.  I am running with a throwing knives and grenade build, and it works like a charm.  The first time I have seen a game get throwing weapons right in a very long time.  I am just having a blast with it all.

[b] What I Did Not Like [/b]

Honestly - not much.  The cars feel a bit light and flighty, but I mostly stick to motorcycles since it's easier to lane split.  The swearing gets to be too much.  I get it, it's part of the game.  I swear.  But eventually it stops adding flavor to the game and just becomes cringe.

[b] Why I Stopped Playing [/b]

Haven't yet.  I am trying to complete everything I can before beating the game.  We will see!  I wholeheartedly recommend this game now.  It's a complete blast to play.

And yes, it's my game of the year in 2024.  Been one of the best games I have played in a long, long time.

[b] Disclaimer [/b]

I have been a gamer for over 30 years.  I tend to play mostly PC games.  I also bounce around between games A LOT.  I may purchase a $60 game and play it for 2 hours or spend $10 on a game and spend 50 hours on it.  Even if I played a game a short time, it does not mean it is bad.  It just means another game caught my attention.  I also complain about flaws in games a lot, even about the littlest of things.  Keep that in mind when reading my reviews.  If I do not have a complaint, then the game must be special!

"What did you expect?"
"I don't know.  A happier ending...For everyone involved."
"Here?  For folks like us?  Wrong people, wrong city."

Cyberpunk 2077 : By Triple F

In the sprawling landscape of gaming, few titles dare to plunge players into a world as dense, dynamic, and daring as "Cyberpunk 2077". CD Projekt Red's long-anticipated opus is a thrilling symphony of neon-soaked streets, visceral combat, and morally ambiguous choices that beckon players to tread the thin line between hero and villain. Despite its share of glitches and controversies, "Cyberpunk 2077" emerges as an ambitious masterpiece that melds spectacle with substance in an unforgettable way.

Visually, "Cyberpunk 2077" is nothing short of breathtaking. Night City is a kaleidoscope of colors and contrasts, where towering skyscrapers cast long shadows over seedy alleyways, and bustling marketplaces create a symphony of urban life. The attention to detail is astonishing; every nook and cranny tells a story of a society torn between its technocratic dreams and its dystopian realities. Character models boast lifelike expressions and nuanced animations, drawing players deeper into a world teeming with personality.

The narrative is where "Cyberpunk 2077" truly shines. Inhabiting the role of V, a customizable protagonist, players navigate a complex web of alliances, betrayals, and personal quests that resonate with humanity's most profound desires and vulnerabilities. The writing is a blend of gritty noir and speculative futurism, tackling themes such as identity, corporate greed, and the cost of unchecked technological advancement. Every choice has palpable consequences, forcing players to grapple with the shades of gray in a world devoid of clear-cut morality.

Combat in "Cyberpunk 2077" is a frenetic ballet of bullets, blades, and brain-hacking abilities. The gun-play is satisfyingly punchy, offering an array of weapons that cater to diverse play-styles, from guns-blazing aggression to stealthy precision. The introduction of "braindance" sequences - where players explore memories from other characters' perspectives - adds an innovative layer to both storytelling and game-play. However, while combat is generally exhilarating, some issues like enemy AI and occasional technical hiccups can break immersion.

The soundscapes of Night City are an auditory marvel. The synth-heavy score, composed by the legendary duo of Marcin Przybyłowicz and Refused, infuses the game with a pulsating rhythm that underscores every triumph and heartache. The voice acting is top-notch, with Keanu Reeves' portrayal of the enigmatic Johnny Silverhand stealing the show. The city's ambient sounds, from blaring advertisements to muffled conversations, contribute to a sense of immersion that envelops players in the urban cacophony.

Yet, "Cyberpunk 2077" is not without its share of flaws. At launch, the game was plagued by technical glitches that tarnished the experience for many players. While subsequent patches have addressed numerous issues, some players might still encounter occasional bugs that detract from the otherwise seamless world. Additionally, the grandiosity of the world sometimes clashes with the limitations of last-gen hardware, leading to compromises in graphical fidelity.

In the end, "Cyberpunk 2077" is an audacious triumph that melds its awe-inspiring spectacle with an engrossing narrative and complex themes. Despite its initial stumbles, CD Projekt Red has crafted a game that invites players to lose themselves in the labyrinthine streets of Night City, encouraging them to question the nature of progress, power, and the price we pay for both. As patches continue to refine the experience, "Cyberpunk 2077" stands as a testament to the unyielding ambition of game development and the enduring allure of cyberpunk storytelling.

I like many others pre-ordered this game before it came out. what we asked for was the best game to come out in the last milennia. CD Projekt red promised us an expansive open world with tons of fun shit to do and a great story with more than One or two romantic partners in game. what we got was a buggy shity compromising game which lacked any of the major features we were promised. 
    lets start with the basics shall we? 
firstly there is the supposed open world. the world in this game is huge but it's not entirely open, for starters you can't even access most of the map until you finish the very long introduction. in the introduction you really fall in love with how the characters as portrayed. spoiler alert ahead as I explain why this is the case. 
    Firstly there is your pal Jackie. you spend the entire introduction with him. you complete missions with him and rob what could be the wealthiest family in the world, then he gets killed off on the last mission of the game. WHAT THE FUCK!? CD projekt red included what probably is the most fleshed out character in the game and you spend the rest of the game mourning him while trying to save yourself. The best character isnt even part of the main game. 
     while Jackie lays dead you have Johnny Silverhand... a virus trying to eat your brain while pretending to be your friend. there is ligterally no hope. (more on that later) 
      Johnny Silverhand played by the uber talented Kianu Reeves has a personality of his own. true.
      you even see parts of his liefe story. However He's not the best in the game. what of your unlikely ally Goro? he's a great help in trying to get Johnny out of your head but...what's this? they kill him off too... and one of the women you try to save who is also a major character. 
     That could be forgiven. 
what can not be forgiven though is the fact that we didn't get multiple romancable npcs and the only really attractive one is gay. This holds true for both genders. They clearly spend maybe a tenth of their budget on this game and skimped on creating any of the features we wanted. 
     my issue isnt only with the fact that no matter what you do the main character vincent still dies at the end of the game; therefore this game becomes not even open world. it gets close after the introduction but it never truly becomes open world because... at the end of the game you are dead. no new game plus mode, no exploring the world completing quests, no interactions with characters not in the quests or missions. 
    Red Dead Online had stranger missions and NPC interation... Cyberpunk 2077 does not. 
       there are missions but these side missions are so mechanically handled that they break immersion. 
Cd Projekt red promised so much and delivered so little. perhaps instead of releasing the game in this state they shouldve managed expectations so that the game would not be so overhyped. they Didn't think and what we were left with was a $60 piece of garbage that should be left in the bargain isle and not on steam. 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
After Numerous updates i am still not satisfied again more spoiler alerts ahead. 
    They added a way to save the MC but this does not lead to the ability to continue exploring the world of the game after the game's end, and you lose your romanced companion... let me say that again. YOU LOSE YOUR ROMANCED COMPANION and the ability to use your implants. They added more interactions with companions so thats a plus but do i need to repeat the final outcome of the game? They added more apartments but due to the nature of the game you have very little time to visit them. They added more interactions with NPCS but theirbudget shouldve been spent changing the ending to allow for the abilityto continue playing after the end of the game. All in ALL i am not satisfied and the game shall remain shelved for the rest of time.

In the sprawling metropolis of Night City, where neon lights paint the skyline and cybernetic enhancements are a way of life, Cyberpunk 2077 emerges as a gaming masterpiece that transcends boundaries and immerses players in a breathtakingly vivid dystopian future.

From the moment you step into the shoes of V, the protagonist navigating the tumultuous streets, you are thrust into a world teeming with life, intrigue, and danger. The sheer scale of Night City is awe-inspiring, a testament to the meticulous attention to detail that CD Projekt Red poured into every corner of this digital playground.

The narrative is the heartbeat of Cyberpunk 2077, pulsating with emotion and unexpected twists. The story is a rollercoaster ride through the underbelly of a society obsessed with power, technology, and the pursuit of immortality. V's journey is a heartfelt odyssey that resonates on a deeply human level, making every decision you make feel like a moral dilemma with consequences that ripple through the meticulously crafted narrative.

The characters that inhabit Night City are not just NPCs; they are living, breathing entities with their own dreams, fears, and motivations. The relationships you form are dynamic and evolving, creating a sense of attachment that is rare in the gaming world. Johnny Silverhand, portrayed with unparalleled brilliance by Keanu Reeves, is a standout character, adding a layer of complexity and depth to the story that elevates it to unparalleled heights.

While Cyberpunk 2077 is a triumph in many aspects, it's essential to acknowledge that a few quests may be marred by the occasional bug. Yet, it is a testament to the sheer brilliance of the overall experience that these minor glitches pale in comparison to the grandeur of Night City and the depth of its narrative. CD Projekt Red has been proactive in addressing these issues through updates, showcasing their commitment to delivering an ever-improving gaming experience.

The gameplay mechanics seamlessly blend gunplay, hacking, and stealth, allowing for diverse playstyles that cater to individual preferences. The sheer variety of cybernetic enhancements and weapons at your disposal ensures that each playthrough can be a unique and exhilarating experience.

In conclusion, Cyberpunk 2077 is a magnum opus that transcends the boundaries of traditional gaming. Its breathtaking visuals, compelling narrative, and immersive world-building make it a timeless masterpiece. While a few bugs may momentarily disrupt the flawless façade, the overall experience is nothing short of extraordinary, making it a title that beckons players to dive into its neon-soaked streets time and time again. Cyberpunk 2077 isn't just a game; it's an immersive journey that leaves an indelible mark on the soul of every player fortunate enough to step into Night City.

Fist let me start by saying Wow! ... I bought this game two years ago. I was so not working, I set it down and time passed. ... Recently, I decide to take another look at Cyberpunk 2077.  I was looking for a game that could give me the same type of experience (in all categories), as the Mass Effect Series did with Shepard. This was my bar. So with that, I took another look at Cyberpunk 2077. ... From the moment I started my new experience with Cyberpunk 2077, I felt myself being drawn in more and more. The game took me to a new level of submersion I had not experienced since my ending and choice of Mass Effect 3. Cyberpunk 2077, is clearly the next evolution of this genre' of game. The game has been fixed!!! and it is so good!!! ... I still find a few glitch'y things here and there, but over all the game runs really smooth. All my setting are maxed :) ... With this being said, Cyberpunk 2077, has and still is effecting me (as I am still playing through everything, but had to stop to do this review). in a deeply profound way. ... My Female "V" is now one of my most favorite Protagonist. ... Being a Mass Effect Player, once I realized the commons, I stopped, took a step back and reflected and what was happening. The Acting, the Story, the Music, Character Creation, the Action, the Submersion, the Mini Games, the Amazing Artistic Beauty that is Cyberpunk 2077 (and it is really a Beautiful Game), led me to a place of stillness. ...

Once I understood what was happening with Cyberpunk 2077, as I was progressing. ... I made a choice.
 
Since I now had a better understanding of "V's" future (as mentioned I am still playing through the game), Since I felt and feel this crazy connection with this Character (a genuine concern for "V", even though this is just a game), ... I actually truly felt and feel that I desired to give "V", the best life and game out come that is possible. This Character is such a great Character (She reminds me of my Female Shepard in Mass 
Effect), She deserves my best and I am giving Her this (playing "Very Hard Mode" and luv'in it). ... Like in Mass Effect, I will be lead to a choice. ... Because "V", is so deserving, I decided to re-make "V" and start the game clean. In this, giving "V", the best Character Creation possible with the idea of creating the best ending for the game I can possibly play. ... It is my pleasure, honor and privilege to play Cyberpunk 2077, in it's new improved state. ... This game has drawn me in. ... My hope, is that Cyberpunk would continue beyond Phantom Liberty. If there is a way to keep this game going, to continue what you all have started at this level of game play, I would be so in! ... So please! continue the Master Piece that is Cyberpunk 2077. 

Thank you Keanu, Cherami Leigh, Carla Tassara, Emily Woo, Cast, the Dev.'s and All, that created and fixed the game so that Gamer's (like myself), could actually play the game, enjoy the game and discover all it's Glory. My thanks and appreciation to All, who have made this project of Love such memorable experience! ... Well Done! "Muuah" Magnificent! :) ,,, Cyberpunk 2077, is truly a work of Art! ... Peace <><

> The Good:
- This game has come a long way since launch. Optimization is shockingly good for me being on a graphics card which released all the way back in 2016. There's areas where I drop frames for sure, but it is MILES ahead of other open-world games in the past three years.
- Gameplay loop is nothing new for an RPG but there's a surprising amount that helps set it apart, like the recent reworks to things like the Cyberware- it REALLY helps set this apart from similar games. Gone are the days of wearing ugly stat-based clothes with V, now I can wear whatever I want while my Cyberware does all the stat lifting.
- Speaking of, I'll give a mention to Cyberpunk's choice of weapon categories which again helps it separate from similar games, some of the builds you can do are just bonkers and I will do multiple playthroughs just for that.
- If you ignore the massive overhype on launch, the world of Night City is breathtaking with a LOT to do. There's even a lot of minor details that show the effort that was put in to make it feel more alive, even on a mix of medium and low settings the visuals are still quite stunning.
- While there's a lot of 'forced' story direction for V, there's still a degree of freedom when it comes to the fact this game has like a half dozen different endings now. Game's kept me hooked for this long and I haven't seen all the endings yet.
- The overall story is FANTASTIC with plenty of good twists and turns to keep you gripped.
- Overall actor performance is unreal, and thank you, Keanu Reeves for your AMAZING performance as Johnny Silverhand.
- Bonus points for CDPR's use of their unique REDEngine. Doesn't have the same optimization flaws that UE has, a shame considering this may be their last game using their own engine.

> The Bad:
- Bugs still exist, so far nothing has been absolutely "delete my save, start a new run" level of game-breaking, anything that could be near that is fixed quickly by reloading your save, minus the severe light flickering bugs I had early on (which was fixable, and the only MAJOR bug I ran into.) I've also had less gamebreaking but still very annoying bugs relating to movement, sound, and sometimes the game's awesome soundtrack flat out refusing to play. (EDIT): 2.1's new sidequests are broken, avoid 'em for now.
- Sadly there was no New Game+. Not a dealbreaker but worth pointing out.

> The Ugly:
- Nothing! CDPR is a pro-consumer developer who will NEVER force ugly DRMs on our heads.

Final Verdicts:
Cyberpunk 2077 these days is a MASSIVE leap from what it was, and is a true testament to CDPR's dedication to turn this game around. Gone are the days where Cyberpunk 2077 was plagued by bugs.
If you've been waiting to buy the game, now that 2.0 is well out, this is the BEST time to buy it and give this game a spin, if you like RPGs with a degree of power fantasy, you're likely to enjoy it, and it may even be well worth the full price for the amount of time you can sink into it.
