Going out of my way to recommend this despite never reviewing games, also meaning I'm way out of my depth. This really has become my number 1 comfort game, despite only having 157 hours on steam I have more than double that on XBox. Especially with the state it's in now, I will yap about this game to literally anyone who listens. 

The main thing that draws me in and keeps me around is the story and the life brought to Night City, and even on my fourth play-through I'm still discovering things I've never seen before. Not only that but I've found myself spiralling down the rabbit hole of the entire Cyberpunk TTRPG lore and STILL can't get enough.

I've never been the biggest fan of skill trees in any game, and even when I've played games like Skyrim and Fallout I normally dump points without really thinking about it, this is the first game where I've made specific builds and put a reasonable thought into each point spend, all of which have made each play-through feel unique and different enough for me to be excited for my next one. 

I think the biggest thing for me against this game is the unneeded crafting system. Something I never used until my most recent Netrunner build, this is probably extremely biased though since whenever a game has something like this I either roll my eyes and never use it or it just kills the game for me. Personal issue, I think.

But yeah, sorry to my friends that get spammed with screenshots of funny/cool moments I have in the game, and bigger apology to my partner who I dump the lore onto almost every night. If you're looking for a deep, story driven game with lots of things to explore and uncover, I can't recommend this enough.

Cyberpunk 2077, much like any creation from CD Projekt Red, was met with immense excitement and anticipation, and rightly so. With their previous masterpiece, The Witcher, hailed as a pinnacle of gaming and narrative storytelling, our expectations soared. However, let's address the initial disappointment head-on.

The game's early release left us grappling with a buggy mess, especially on the cusp of a new console generation. The pressure to meet deadlines tarnished what could have been perfection. Yet, beneath the chaos, a glimmer of brilliance remained. The narrative and branching outcomes were nothing short of extraordinary.

Graphically, it strained the limits of our hardware, and it didn't play smoothly across the board. But here's where CD Projekt Red's true mettle showed. They acknowledged their missteps, pledged to improve, and they delivered. What followed was nothing short of a gaming miracle.

Nearly every complaint was addressed, often surpassing our expectations by addressing issues we hadn't even recognized. They remained steadfast in their commitment, providing transparent updates. The result? Phantom Liberty, an exhilarating, emotionally charged rollercoaster ride.

The world they crafted is steeped in lore, offering incredible missions and a vast landscape to explore. It's a testament to what transpires when a dedicated team of creators, writers, designers, and coders pour their passion into their craft. Cyberpunk 2077 has transformed into an exceptional experience, a must-play for all.

If you hesitated before, hesitate no more. The game now runs seamlessly, and the addition of ray tracing enhances the experience even further. CD Projekt Red's journey of redemption has culminated in a masterpiece that demands your attention. Embrace the world of Cyberpunk 2077; it's a triumph of dedication and artistry.

I dismissed this game for over 3 years -- starting well before its tumultuous release -- because I assumed I'd find it off-putting.

When I bought this game on sale, I had low expectations yet had high demands for how well it would need to capture my attention in order to not immediately refund it. I had no interest in immersing myself in a "cyberpunk dystopia" filled to the brim with violence, sex, drugs, greed, corruption, escapism, and dehumanization. In other words, a derivative product that's simply edgy for the sake of being edgy. ...or so I thought.

The first hint that this game would defy my expectations was when it came time to choose an "origin story." Both Nomad (Mad Max) and Streetkid (Akira) seemed tired to me, but "Corpo"... Well, starting the game in an immaculate office tower as a willing cog in the machine of deadly corporate espionage, THAT grabbed my attention.

CP2077 is a narrative powerhouse that unleashes the full potential of its premise through incredibly well-directed voice acting and motion capture (except for Keanu Reeves, funnily enough, unless he was directed to sound tired on purpose). The stories it has to tell are compelling; the relationships you forge and interactions you have with people feel real. It was enough that I've now experienced every major ending branch, even going as far as to start a new game in order to fulfill a hidden requirement for one of the ending achievements.

There are definitely times where I consider the gameplay itself to be average at best, particularly the combat, where poor AI and sparse, uninteresting boss encounters bring it down. I also find Night City itself to be "just okay" on a macro scale, with the roads+highways in particular having a weird "Hot Wheels" feel to them. I think the indoor spaces are very well done however.

Also, since this is a AAA open-world game, I feel I need to compare it to (read: defecate on) Starfield. The quality difference between these two games is startling, especially considering Starfield came out 3 years later. CP2077 set a bar for AAA production that went completely over Bethesda's head. I rarely engage with AAA games nowadays, and I will continue to be uninterested as long as studios fail to meet the modern expectations that CDPR established with this game.

I won't call CP2077 a masterpiece as it IS flawed, but it's a solid 9/10 must-play experience. Get it.

"Cyberpunk 2077" is a video game experience that transcends expectations, unfolding a universe of unprecedented visual and narrative richness. CD Projekt Red, the master storytellers behind "The Witcher" series, immerse us in a dystopian future where technology and humanity intertwine in fascinating ways.

From the very first moments, the game captivates with its metropolis of Night City, a vast, vibrant, and richly detailed urban playground. The graphics are breathtaking, with lighting effects, textures, and animations that redefine the standards of realism in video games.

The heart of "Cyberpunk 2077" lies in its captivating story and deep characters. The protagonist, V, is a fully customizable character, allowing for total immersion. Every choice, every decision influences the story, creating a unique experience for each player.

The RPG aspect of the game is exceptionally well-executed. The skill system and various progression paths offer great freedom, encouraging players to explore different strategies and playstyles. The missions are varied, combining intense action and complex intrigue, all supported by superb voice acting and a soundtrack.

Although the game experienced a difficult launch with some technical bugs, successive updates have greatly improved stability and the overall experience. It's evident that the developers are passionate and dedicated to their craft, working tirelessly to refine and improve the game.

In conclusion, "Cyberpunk 2077" is a tour de force in terms of storytelling and game design. It's a bold and memorable adventure in an enthralling futuristic world. For RPG and science fiction fans, it's a must-play, a jewel in the crown of the video game industry.

Despite the release's problems, the ideas, story, and artistically stylized world made it worthwhile. Now, despite that shaky start that left a terrible stain, the game is completely fixed and a joy to play. 

I finished it once near after release, I'm replaying it all over again with Phantom Liberty. The gameplay has been completely refined and is a lot more fun than it was before. The truth of the matter is that it has no waste and I can't stop recommending it. 

It is important to mention the robust modding support that it has, you can tweak the experience as much as you want to.

The city itself is just an amazing place to spend time. The characters, combat and story had me hooked until the end. Up there with Elden Ring and Baulders Gate 3 as my top games over the past few years.

This game does have some awesome graphics, superb character customization, and a top notch environment, but those things are HORRIBLY offset by the down sides.
---------
1. The story and language makes no sense. 

This game REEKS of poor, nonsensical writing. Now, I'm not asking for Pulitzer Prize material here, but if I'm going to shell out $60 for some entertainment, it should have a story that I can at least follow.
In addition to this, the characters are constantly talking in some sort of "high tech slang". This jargon makes it impossible to understand what's going on or what you need to accomplish. In other words, it really takes away your motivation to continue on.
---------
2. In game conversations and interactions drag on forever, and you can't skip most parts.

Blah, blah, blah.... the cutscenes with characters talking to each other are PAINFULLY long and really cut into the action of the game. I'd say about half of the time you can skip them, but when you can't, strap in.... because you're in for the long haul. I've literally fallen asleep before just waiting for the action to start up again. Who knew that BOREDOM would be a problem in this game?
---------
3. Too many controls and menus. 

This is a problem in many newer games; nothing is on automatic (even in cutscenes). This requires you to memorize or assign a bunch of key strokes, mouse clicks, or controller functions that aren't used anywhere else in the game except for one small scene or part of a stage. I can't believe the developers wasted time and money on this instead of just having the character do stuff on their own. 
Also, the character menu is set up to where you pick a menu, then a tab, and that goes into a sub-menu... and further and further down until you finally find whatever you were looking for. Then, there's little, if any, explanation on how to use an item or what it's for.  This misorganization makes your gear hard to find and understand. 
---------
4. "Braindances" are VERY annoying. (A "needle in a haystack" problem.)

A "braindance" is your character using a VR like program to go into a video recording and actually interact with the recorded environment; you can look at things from a different perspective or listen to other parts of the area for clues about something. The problem here is that you have to pause the playback on EXTREMELY specific times and find some teeny, tiny, BARELY detectable visual, auditory, or heat signature clue using different forms of the program. This is BEYOND frustrating. 
---------
5. Vehicles don't drive very well.

Anything you drive in this game slips and slides all over the road and turns way too wide. It's like driving on an oil slick with a broken steering column.
---------
6. The content of the game is too racy.

Overpowering sexuality and anti-religious themes are constantly slapping you in the face. There's no reason for this level of filth in the game.
---------

FINAL RATING: 3/10, and that's being generous.

Finally, I can write a full review. I postponed playing the game all this time, waiting for the moment when I could finally play it without battling numerous bugs, sometimes critical... But without going far, I'll say that bugs still exist, though not as critical.

After the release of the anime, this game gained a second wind. After patches 2.0, 2.1, and the DLC, the game gained a third wind. Finally, I can proudly say that Cyberpunk feels like a finished product. Not without flaws, not without problems, but finished.

The best part of this game is the story, atmosphere, and lore. Sometimes, it's like being a little child, joyfully discovering hidden details that delve deeper into the lore of everything happening. I enjoy the role-playing aspect of the game, which, while not having super-global changes from your choices, allows you to immerse yourself in this world and feel like V. I can't remember the last time I could simply sit in a car in a game and drive around a very large city, listening to the radio. I give 10 points to the people who worked on the story, universe, music, and visual aspects of the game. It's evident that these individuals gave their all to make this product feel like a unified world, wher each element seamlessly interacts, creating a sense of a lively and authentic universe. Not a thousand randomly generated soulless planets (yes, Starfield, I'm talking about you!).

Questions arise regarding the game's optimization and its technical aspects. The game lags, even on decent hardware. It still can't consistently deliver stable 60 frames on most machines, even with minimal settings. Texture issues, animation bugs, or game physics mishaps are not uncommon. Visual bugs in this game seem to be a staple that they may not be inclined to remove.

The gameplay is captivating but doesn't reach for the stars. It's dynamic and flashy. Gunshots are felt, as are strikes with a katana or fists. However, an unbalanced aspect is apparent, confirmed by the recent complete overhaul of all skills and balance. Even now, I can say it's interesting to play, and it's probably the first game where I eagerly ran to clear another "question mark" on the map, anticipating a good shootout.

This game will stay in my heart for a long time. There are many things that make me upset, but it all fades compared to how much I love it and how much I want to spend a little more time in it, trying to discover something new or simply enjoying something I liked before

TLDR: Fantastic open world game that is easily worth its full asking price.

In preface of what will certainly read as a very long winded review, this review is being written shortly after initial completion of the base and DLC content with no replays under my belt. I'm bored at work and don't feel like studying, let's see how many notes I remember, and how much steam lets me fit.

The general experience: Cyberpunk 2077 is still very much a jack of all trades game that tries to be part bethesda rpg, part GTA, part Hollywood blockbuster, and part dating sim. The odd thing is that it manages to do all these things surprisingly well and in a way that feels like a unique cohesive package. The basic loop of explore the world, talk to characters, shoot stuff, talk to characters, explore the world, do it again, works well and has enough mix-ups to keep the player engaged. The game does have some general issues though. For one, bugs and poor performance are a curse that often can't be fully banished. The bugs during my experience were largely trivial and if anything, watching my car fall from the sky directly onto some poor pedestrian only added to my experience. However, many sidequests in this game lack a bit of polish around the edges and many times I would break a sequence of events accidentally, causing quest items to bug out and be impossible to interact with, or the dialogue trees would skip a couple lines and give me a bit of conversational whiplash, or characters would simply freeze up and take 10 seconds or so to continue moving or talking. I will note, no bugs were game breaking, only resulting in minor inconveniences or unintended humor. Performance issues fall on the same scale. My performance was overall fantastic, though I'll note that I did turn off ray tracing because despite my good frames, it gave the game a strange "floatiness" that in an fps I just couldn't accept. The only real performance issues I had were in select parts of select missions (so not an issue really), and in certain sections of the DLC's Dogtown (which was concerning). However, I played the whole game with no crashes which is always great and even if frames dropped for a time it was still entirely manageable. That said, I should expand on what I organize as the main aspects of this game.

Narrative: I'll start with the narrative part of the game as it's definitely where the game falls most in the first few hours of playtime. This game's story is fantastic and unique. The main missions play out like movies and do a great job of putting you on edge even in a video game where you can just restart a save if you mess something up. The mix of small scale but tense dialogue sections with the often bombastic action set pieces make for a campaign that carries some actual weight with it and brings you along on a Hollywood ride that you're the main actor in. Its largest shortcoming is something shared by most open world games and that's the story's pacing. This is an open world game where you can choose where you go and the order in which you tackle available missions, so why in god's name is your character's primary driving force a countdown to your death. While it makes sense from the Hollywood perspective this plot point makes zero sense in the confines of an open world game where the player dictates the pace of the main story's progression. This issue steals quite a bit of the significance from anything revolving around this clock as a time bomb can't create tension if it's always getting paused. This issue comes back in the DLC too, I swear, characters are only ever in danger when I'm actively doing their quest and their on screen, so stop giving me holocalls telling me to hurry up when I'm busy trying to find the one gun store in NC selling an LMG. Moving on, side missions in the game are fantastic too. Offering unique, smaller scale stories that still contain fun characters and varied approaches the likes of which are often so good they blur the line between what is a main quest and what is a side quest. Moving past this, characters in this game as well as their dialogue and writing are fantastic across the board. The main characters have depth and a distinct personality about them and lines that stay largely consistent to that personality. The voice actors do a bang up job as well. Although, with voice acting so good, I should note the weak spot, and that is the man himself, Keanu Reeves. A lot of lines just sounded kinda like he was reading them directly off the page. Idris Elba on the other hand has a voice perfect for his character and overall does very well with it. 

Combat and RPG stuff: Moving on to the game's combat, it's surprisingly fun. For a game with such a strong narrative focus I expected combat to take a back seat but in all honestly I quite enjoyed myself with it. I don't think it's the deepest thing ever, especially for an RPG but it serves its function and then still goes a bit further. The main thing I appreciate about the combat is that it offers ways to play that actually feel unique to one another. Nethacking is an interesting take on an alternative to the typical fps combat without being completely removed from it and each weapon type can play quite differently after acquiring the relevant skills. This variance can keep the game interesting if you invest in mixing things up occasionally. All the weapons have decent feedback and control and the gibbing of enemies ensures the power fantasy can really come to fruition. I do have issues though, and I'm sure any playstyle will result in your own personal gripes. I played as a high speed, nigh invincible, tank with a shotgun. My main issue is that despite my having beaten the whole game and doing every side mission I encountered, I got zero unique shotguns. Got more unique handguns and snipers than I can count on three hands but zero shotguns, actually boggling. More specific to the RPG mechanics in the game, builds are pretty simple to make but there is still some good depth to it. The cyberware system is quite fun even if I wish you could receive progression shards for it a bit faster and being able to trade off nethacking (something I don't want) for localized time dilation (something I do) was certifiably dope. Missions really are quite open to completing in whichever way you want. This goes for both the combat and the dialogue. Combat rarely seemed to start without offering you a chance at stealth and the different routes you can take through areas based on your stats is a simple way of reinforcing your build decisions. In dialogue, the options available are admittedly limited, but it's fully voiced so what can you expect. The important thing is that the dialogue that is available works well. I rarely picked options thinking it would say one thing only for it to be some snarky remark out of left field and in general the options did a good job of allowing me to carry conversations where I naturally think they should. Again, big ups for the writing team on this game. However, I do wanna note that many of the stat specific dialogue options you can pick feel a friend gave you a "really funny" joke to tell, but then you tell it and not even your friend laughs. V will often spout some overly specific jargon that seems like it should be impressive, but then the response you'll get won't reference it and will have obviously not been written for your dialogue making the option entirely pointless.

Edit on 3/23/2022
After the last few updates I decided to give this a try again and it's pretty good actually. The devs seem to be improving things. 
The game is really good FPS and has very strong setting and story. Very glad that I revisited this game and did not miss out on the good things it presents.
Rating going up to a strong 9/10 and could go higher as I progress through game.

PROS:
> breathtaking story
> believable character interaction that make you care and emotionally invest in them (or hate their guts) 
> NIGHT CITY IS INSANEE, you could spend hours and hours just for sightseeing & lollygagging
> the aesthetic, design & visual elements are meticulously crafted, the artists really put their heart and soul into it.
> melee combat is super fun, snappy and satisfying to execute
> the soundtrack & score are amazing, how it build up tension, the anticipation and during intense and chaotic combat situation. \m/ 
> you could flip keanu
> there are two option for peepee

CONS:
> DRIVING IS ATROCIOUS, WHAT THE HELL CDPR???
> movement kinda janky, again, WTH CDPR? 
> some keybinds are hardcoded and also theres no aim-toggle.
> despite of all the immersion and beautifully crafted city, the world is rather static, your choice and action don't really matter on larger scale. there are no karma system, or gang/faction reputation system. no "special encounter" or the feeling like the world is alive outside of you. it just feel static after a while.
> the game direction seem to have some kind of identity crisis issue, try to be both immersive-RPG like F:NV & casual open-world arcade like GTA and manage to fail at both.
> i cannot install cyber peepee

NEUTRAL:
> try to play on hardest difficulty to appreciate and savor the experience. it forces you to actually think, plan and analyze the situation and not just speedrunning the gigs. the game is rather easy to begin with.
> because of how the story is structured, there are no real incentive to replay the game except for trying different build, or different roleplay experience, but who cares, its a solid 100++ hours preems


CONCLUSION:
update 2.1 is a redemption arc for CDPR and if you're into cyberpunk genre, just do yourself a favor and buy the game, it's a breathtaking experience regardless of the cons.

Honestly the optional missions are better and more intriguing than the main storyline (not that the main story is bad) pretty fun open world game.

I like the game-play. The game is beautiful, smooth, optimised, and the first FPS I can actually play without nausea. However, the whole premise of the game is completely contradictory. You are supposed to be this bad-ass thug of Night City, dealing and wheeling as much as you like and build your reputation and skills, while the main story is effectively suffocating that basic idea. The short main story, together with the endings especially, is just flawed.

Since launch this game has been plagued with bugs that completely dislodged the player (I.E. Me) from the beautiful world Project Red has made, time, and time again. as of writing this review, it's been over 3 years since the game came out. Things have completely changed, and tiny insignificant details have been added that genuinely bolsters the experience as a whole. However, it just isn't fun to keep coming back to this game and realize that all of my skills, builds, and everything set up prior now doesn't functionally work, or works in a completely different way. I DO LOVE the improvements they continue to add to this game, but I'd just say come back to it in another 3 years. Maybe then it'll be more optimized?

This game is the best example of ''Whatever doesn't kill you, makes you stronger''. When it came out 3 years ago, it was pretty much an abomination of a video game and luckily for me chooms i did not pack the hardware i own now to support such a beast of a game (luckily meaning i did not feel the disappointment many gamers did due to high expectations and low results).
   So i'd said nova let's see the reviews and let it play out. You know the rest of the story...BUT the developers (same developers that made one the best games in the world and my personal all time favorite called The Witcher 3) decided to fix slowly but surely every aspect of the game.
   I mean i guess the story probably was already amazing back then, but who could really focus on the story or its characters when your character shifted through the street into the depths of hell or when your car disappeared when driving around etc.
   So after a ton of updates and three years of struggle while facing with the game's backlash and initial failure the developers finally delivered to us a preem product full of action, a riveting and emotional story, top notch gameplay with a wild approach on the term variety, some of the most memorable and interesting characters the gaming industry has ever witnessed, some of the best graphics and visuals we've ever witnessed, spectacular ost, a jaw dropping and beautiful city to explore in a massive map that is now considered a high standard for video game maps.
   Well chooms i could go on and on forever drooling over the benefits that come with playing this game but you really should discover that for yourselves. Also high praise for the DLC the Phantom Liberty, it is officially in my top 4 dlcs of all time along with The Ringed City from Dark Souls 3, Hearts of Stone and of course my favorite Blood and Wine from The Witcher 3.
   I did not expect nor aimed to 100% this game since it's massive and i thought ''oh it will get repetitive'', but no it barely got repetitive only towards the end while finishing the ncpd scanners but even then it was still addicting and dopamine inducing. What i really want to express with probably the largest review i've ever written is my genuine gratitude for CDPR for having the balls, patience and determination to transform the embarassing mediocre piece of crap game they made unintentionally in the beginning to a literal masterpiece and goliath of a game that i wish i would turn back time and make this GOTY for 2020 or even make it now in 2023.
    THANK YOU CDPR from the bottom of my hungry gaming heart and i appreciate your immense effort. I'm looking forward to The Witcher 4 and whatever comes next!

Disappointment to Redemption

When CD Projekt Red announced "Cyberpunk 2077," expectations were high, but its December 2020 release was met with widespread disappointment due to numerous bugs, performance issues, and unmet promises, especially on older console generations. This review delves into the game's transformative journey from a rocky start to its current acclaim, bolstered significantly by the impressive "Phantom Liberty" expansion.

At launch, "Cyberpunk 2077" was a hotbed of technical problems. Performance on consoles like PS4 and Xbox One was particularly poor, marked by low frame rates, texture pop-ins, and frequent crashes. The PC version, while somewhat better, suffered from its own set of bugs and AI inconsistencies. The fallout was severe, leading to full refunds and the game being temporarily delisted from the PlayStation Store.

CD Projekt Red embarked on a mission to rectify these issues, releasing numerous patches and hotfixes that gradually improved performance, squashed bugs, and enhanced overall gameplay quality. This period was crucial in stabilizing the game and setting the stage for future content.

The release of "Phantom Liberty," a story-driven expansion, marked a pinnacle in Cyberpunk 2077's redemption arc. Set in a new district of Night City, the expansion offers an intriguing spy-thriller storyline, introducing new characters, environments, and gameplay mechanics. It builds upon the main game's narrative, adding depth and complexity to the Cyberpunk universe. The expansion has been praised for its captivating storytelling, improved NPC interactions, and thrilling espionage missions, providing a fresh yet coherent experience that seamlessly integrates with the base game.

Today, "Cyberpunk 2077" has metamorphosed into a title that not only delivers on its initial promises but exceeds them, especially with the inclusion of "Phantom Liberty." The game runs smoothly across platforms, including significantly enhanced performance on older consoles. Night City feels vibrant and dynamic, with the expansion adding even more depth and intrigue.

An essential factor in this turnaround has been CD Projekt Red's proactive communication and community engagement. Their transparent approach in addressing issues and keeping players informed has been instrumental in rebuilding trust.

"Cyberpunk 2077," with its "Phantom Liberty" expansion, stands as a remarkable example of a game overcoming its troubled past. The expansion not only adds to the narrative richness but elevates the entire experience, making the game a must-play for both returning players and newcomers. It's a vivid representation of the gaming industry's potential for growth and redemption, and a testament to CD Projekt Red's commitment to their vision and their fans.

There's a lot to like about this game as well as a lot to dislike. It's essentially a story game with RPG elements of the quality you'd expect out of a 2016-2018 release. There are some serious mechanical issues that hurt the gameplay, which is less diverse and 'open' than the cutscenes shown in the main trailer imply. I'd give it a 7/10 if I had to score it but since Steam uses a binary system, I'd say 'not recommended' in its current state and price, but recommended on sale. Most of my mechanical gripes could be solved with post-release patches.

EDIT:
Well, it's the end of January in 2024 now and most of the horrible glitches have been fixed. I'm playing through it again and apart from some AI vehicle pathing, which is still wonky, everything seems to be functional. Driving cars is fun now because they fixed the terrible KB+M controls, and the entire combat mechanics system has been overhauled to accommodate the Phantom Liberty expansion. This is how the game should have been released. The world still feels kind of shallow if you get too close to it, because very little of Night City is intractable outside of quests and gang fights, but I still stand by the quests being well-written, the voice acting being good, and the world being visually stunning. It's a normal AAA title that doesn't live up to the 'best game ever' hype that surrounded it, but is absolutely worth a playthrough - especially now that it's been out long enough to get some good sale prices.

[h1] You can see the stitches from all the patching they had to do, but there is a very good game in here. [/h1]

Despite a few flaws and bugs the core gameplay and quest design of Cyberpunk feels very satisfying. Combined with some excellent writing and role playing moments I can certainly recommend it in it's current state.

I won't spoil the story, if you're interested in the genre this game does it justice. For those of you more concerned with mechanics, well, the game wants you to play it a certain way at times. You WILL need stealth for some missions for example, and many many more support a stealth build (Even non-lethal, yes even for assassinations), so I would recommend getting used to crouching around and disabling cameras. Beyond that each 'class' of weapons (Tech, Power, etc) has it's own quirks you can lean into. Play around before investing too many points, and save up that precious re-roll for once you're certain of the build you want. There IS a level cap, so look out for it.

I ran with Tech Sniper, precision rifle, and pistol myself. Combined with hacking (Which is very overpowered but also gives you great story options) I found the combat to be just interesting enough that I sought out fights instead of avoiding them.

I suspect, but can't confirm, that they focused more on the melee abilities, they seemed a bit more fleshed out. The enemies certainly dropped enough high tier Katana's to outfit a weeb army.

TLDR: If you enjoy RPG's, cyberpunk, or slicing people in half with a monofiliment wire pick this up when it hits your personal pricepoint.

Catch you later chooms.

When I first played this game prior to the DLC (but after bug patches), the game ran perfectly on my system on the lowest settings, I have a pretty shit computer but it still complies with the minimum required specs for the game.

Now NPCs in cutscenes don't load or even render until, their animations never load in either and they're in a constant "idle" animation; not a t-pose but, for instance, like Jackie Welles has his hands constantly on his hips and doesn't move his legs and just sort of "glides" or "slides" across the ground. Dialogue audio simply doesn't play when the subtitles appear, the game randomly freezes or crashes, meshes look like their moving in and out of the LOD range constantly and constantly look like horrific acid trip monsters.

I would love to give this game a thumbs up, the writing is absolutely amazing and the worldbuilding is done so well that the world just *feels* real. I hate that I can't play this game like I used to.  My first playthrough I got *hooked* I no-lifed an entire playthrough in one sitting (with food, water, and bathroom breaks) and it really helped me find an escape from the issues in my real life.

The fact that I can no-longer do that hurts me to my core. Maybe when I can afford to upgrade my computer (if that ever happens) the game will run better without the issues I mentioned above. I'm so disappointed.

Alright, I wasn’t sure if I should write a review for this game because, well… There is so much I wanted to say, but at the same time it’s got too difficult to describe the feelings after completing the plot for ~ 4 times. It is not about me finding additional cons of the game after each time I complete it, just the opposite, [b] I COULD NOT FIND ANYTHING [/b] that will make myself love this game less.
For me, this game is a perfect example of how developers put their souls into the product, how much effort and time it took… They love their own creation, and it makes me love too. Anyway, let’s move on to looking at the pros and cons:
What makes [h2] CYBERPUNK 2077 good[/h2]:
-	Let’s start with the most obvious, but valuable – [u] DAMN GRAPHICS [/u] is absolute next gen. Even now, after few years since the game has been released, it blows my mind. All the traces, details, shadows, colour correction etc., these make the game wanted, and make you feel like you are IN this game. I will never be tired of looking at the bright Night City, sunny desert, and not even a bit less beautiful character.
-	Moving on to the [u] Plot & Characters! [/u] I decided to put these section together as, personally, they make each other complete. The plot is: unique, deep and mature (NO KIDDO STUFF). While you play, you want to stay focused on what’s happening around you. Personally, I would never think that the idea of the future where people living in dark, contrast, and so dangerous environment can be [b] SOO INTERESTING [/b]. Meeting every character is absolutely special, every one of them has got a story behind, every one of them has got a ‘soul’. They push you into them, make you feel what they feel, and empathise. There are no ‘heroes’ & ‘villains’, all of them hide something dark and this is so much like in real life.   
-	[u] MC personalisation [/u]. Starting with the first window that opens as you start the new game, where you are allowed to create your own character. Alright, we all saw this feature in most of the RPGs, the difference is in quality. Well, honestly, I haven’t seen such a good-looking customisation of the character. I fell in love with my own creation xD. And, yeah, I played with a woman MC most of the times, and, yes, this is because of Judy… (Like her too much) … Also, I don’t have a gf… Well, never mind, just keep in mind that your character will look great if wish so. 
-	[u] MC developing [/u]. The second window that shows up is skills allocation. In Cyberpunk 2077 you’ve got a choice of playing the way you like and there are 5 main classes to choose. Basically, as you are up to the end of the game, you can reach max stats in 3 classes, and in this moment the variability of the ways to complete missions rises up to your imagination, however, at the beginning and till the middle of the game you will have to choose what style you prefer to play, otherwise it gets difficult to develop, especially, after the last update of the skills tree. 
-	[u] Implants and body improving [/u]. Since the last update a lot changed. You must choose correct set of implants to have a maximum superiority over the opponents. This feature basically supports your skills and helps them to be even more effective, either its shinobi skills, Solo destroying or smart net running. However, it does not make your life like ‘walking in the morning park’. Remember, it is a Night City, wanna be alive? You still must think, plan, and rely on your personal skills and combat intellect.
-	[u] Side quests & References (Features if you like) [/u]. This part is slightly correlated with a plot section; however, I would like to talk about it separately. First of all, sides are interesting and take a huge part of the playing time. Of course, there are some absurd quests like buying cars or flats, but generally speaking, I loved almost all the sides that appeared during the game-play, and I spent quite a lot of time on them. To mention, why are these side quests are interesting? Well, because of the characters you see: actors, AI machines, gangs, cops, spies, etc. You will meet absolute psychos, and loved ones, funny, and sad stories. The variety is huge, and it makes you dive in it.  
-	[b] Music [/b]. Personally, I AM THE FREAKING MUSIC GEEK. Just cannot live without some good music, my own player has got thousands of songs and hundreds that I listen to daily. At first, I was a bit sceptical about the music that is written for games, but the play list in CP 2077 is insane. While you drive, there are a lot of radio to meet any preference, starting from metal rock finishing with blues. Main soundtracks, combat tracks are great as well. These create the feeling of being the part of the virtual world, which is, from my point of view, the most important in any game. 

[i] Alright, I think, I have mentioned enough of good points, but there is still a lot to talk about and we will be moving on to the [h2] cons [/h2]: [/i]
-	And again, starting with the obvious, [u] DAMN GRAPHICS [/u] can’t be seen without DAMN NUCLEAR STATION by your table. Even the high specs PCs will run the CP 2077 in ultra settings at about 40-45 fps. I had to put down the graphics significantly in order to have stable 45-60 fps even tho my PC is not that bad. Of course, the quality of the picture was still impressive, but not as great as it could be. Rarely my fps dropped to 15 which wasn’t great, but it went back up in a few seconds. Sure, people can play at low settings, but the feeling after the game will be different. 
-	[u] Difficulty level is imbalance [/u]. I’ve played on all difficulty levels and should say that if you are a hardcore player, it gets complicated to use your abilities in right way. As you set the highest level of difficulty, some abilities, perks and implants become useless as, either you will not be able to kill with the first shot or punch as supposed to be according to the MC build, or will be killed with the first or second bullet, which is fine, but some missions may become almost impossible to complete (For example, the mission where you rare required to escape the car chase playing Johnny Silverhand). I did play the Dark Souls series a few times and even with this could not complete that bloody mission on the highest difficulty level because got killed with 2-3 bullets being shoot all together at the same time.
-	[u] Background of the MC [/u]. When you are about to choose the background of your character, you should not expect the high difference between 3 of those in the future. Basically, the only difference is in the beginning of the game where you are required to complete different types of mission which last for 10-15 minutes of the game-play time. Further, you will just see a few ‘unique’ phrases in a dialogue which can be told with a specific background, but these does not influence much in the main plot. Personally, I would live to see a higher level of differentiation between a corporate and a street-man for example. 
-	[u] MC Development and Implants [/u]. This section was included in the pros; however, I would like to mention some disadvantages: It is complicated to create a specific build (e.g., Improving Reaction to fight with swords and blades only), especially on the high-level difficulty. As even if you are using Sandevistan/Berserk, the close combat becomes unreal with 4 and more opponents; their HP is simply too high to be killed fast which makes the whole build almost useless… unless you are choosing to have, for example, tactic of killing weak first with a sniper rifle, and then dealing with the rest of the enemies using blades. There is no such problem if you are playing on medium difficulty levels though.

[i] There are a lot of things that I would like to mention, but sometimes you just need to stop and feel it. [/i] 
Anyway, in my subjective opinion, Cyberpunk is a piece of art. I hope to see the next creation and surely it is going to be different, but great.

I'm not typically one for singleplayer games, yet since cyberpunk got back on track to be released a few years back the game excited me, similar to that of spiderman when that came out for the PS4, it was one of those singleplayer games that had something to pull me in, luckily I didn't get it when this game released seeing how buggy and broken everyones experiences were, I waited until it was on-sale to actually buy the game, the first few sales were still not anything until a sale in 2023 where the game was heavily reduced and so I decided to then pick it up. 

After such a long time being released with numerous updates I had hoped this game would be in a better state and... it's not. I have a pretty good system I'd say, not top of the line but very well near that. I found that the game was very poorly optimized, I had searched a bunch for fixes, I tried playing at different graphics qualities and I was stuck at 50-60fps (rarely) with very poor looking models and barely rendered in textures almost all the time whilst having numerous crashes, drops in fps to 15. and huge memory leaks even with replacing/updating my parts the game would sap so much out of my system to barely work.

I would have probably finished the game a lot faster had I not needed to replay the same few missions again and again as the game would crash or simply not work as I'd not be able to understand what was going on with overlapping/broken dialogue, animations and that as an experience was not enjoyable at all it felt like i was dragging my feet through the entire game, although there were a few sweet spots in the game where I was able to actually experience it at a very bare minimum level the game's story just felt severly lacking , not to mention the 'romance' options were.. lackcluster at best.

Think back to November, 2011, Skyrim just dropped and took the world by storm. Everyone's losing their minds. That feeling of 'wow here's an RPG with near infinite possibilities and flexibility for how you wanna play and build your character' felt like something that we'd see more of due to the success of the game, but no. Nothing of the sort. Nobody could recapture the magic of that feeling. 2 Years after that we got the trailer for Cyberpunk before CD Projekt RED, our favourite Polish devs, went ghost on us for another 7 years. Then out of nowhere, they drop this bad boy onto the market. It was a mess. Most people hated it, but the devs didn't give up. 4 more years, thousands of hours of dev time and community feedback later, we got 2.1 and this thing is now the gold standard for what Bethesda used to be like, adjusted for modern standards. You wanted to recapture that feeling you had with Skyrim in 2011 but with a next-gen experience set in a dystopian cityscape played out as an absolute weapon of a main character built to your exact preference? This is it.

The DLC is also killer. Loads of love and care went into it, calling it a DLC is a disservice. It's a proper game expansion, like how Blizzard used to do back when they gave a shit too. If you're tired of crap single player RPGs and are craving that gold-standard immersive experience that got you into this kind of game in the first place, this is your ticket to fall back in love with the genre.

Cyberpunk 2077 ranks among the most transformative video game experiences I've ever had. It's a close second to Red Dead Redemption 2. 

I bought this game on Day 1, enjoyed it immensely (I was one of the few people who didn't suffer any serious issues with the game early on), and would come back to it over the years. 

I've finished the base game for the fifth (and final) time now, having just played through the Don't Fear the Reaper ending for the first time. I've also finished Phantom Liberty for the second time.

This game inspired me to literally change careers into a much more technical, data analytics-driven role. 

I'm uninstalling this game now. For the first time since 2020. But I'm sure I'll come back to it in a few years' time.

Heard this game did a complete 180 since release which is 100% false. The game is horribly optimised to the point where I can't get a stable 60 fps anywhere in the city. Running a i7 8700k oc'ed to 5GHZ and a 2080 super. Cops materialise out of thin air and npc's still run into walls. The world still feels empty and 99% of the structures are vacant/you can't enter them. If you've got a crazy modern rig you might have a different experience but overall its hard to enjoy this game due to poor performance alone.

Cyberpunk 2077 has come a long way since its launch, and it's evolved into a game that's truly a must-play for any RPG or open-world enthusiast. Night City is a place I can't get enough of, and I'll be exploring its neon-lit streets and tangled mysteries for years to come. Kudos, CD Projekt Red, for creating this masterpiece!

Cyberpunk 2077” is a role-playing game developed by CD Projekt Red. The game is set in Night City, a diverse near-future cityscape. The game offers a vast array of side missions around the main story.

You play as V, a mercenary who ends up with the psyche of long-dead rockstar and anti-corporate terrorist Johnny Silverhand trapped in their head. Johnny, played by Keanu Reeves, forms the anchor of the story.

The game’s open-world structure is not without its faults. It was initially plagued by a multitude of bugs. However, CD Projekt Red has released multiple patches attempting to improve the performance and fix these bugs.

Despite these issues, the strength of the missions and the choices within them make “Cyberpunk 2077” one of the most exciting, emotional, and fun RPGs in recent years. The game features some nice characters and stories nested in an astounding open world.

However, it’s worth noting that the game’s performance varies dramatically across different platforms. The PC version of the game generally offers a better experience compared to the Xbox One and PlayStation 4 versions.

In conclusion, “Cyberpunk 2077” offers a rich and immersive gaming experience, with its detailed world design and compelling storyline. However, the presence of bugs can be a distraction. If you can look past these mechanical missteps, there’s plenty of bang for your buck.

Now, let’s delve deeper into the game’s aspects:

Visuals and Sound “Cyberpunk 2077” boasts impressive visuals and sound design. The city of Night City is beautifully rendered, with animated billboards and neon lights that create a vibrant and immersive atmosphere. The sound design complements the visuals, further enhancing the player’s immersion in the game world.

Story The game’s story is compelling and emotional. The relationship between V and Johnny Silverhand forms the core of the narrative. Despite Johnny’s initially dislikable personality, the growth of their relationship over the course of the game is engaging and satisfying.

Gameplay The gameplay of “Cyberpunk 2077” is diverse and exciting. The game offers a wide array of missions, both main and side, that provide the player with a lot of choice. The missions are well-designed and often have a significant impact on the player’s journey.

Bugs and Performance Issues Despite its strengths, “Cyberpunk 2077” was initially plagued by numerous bugs and performance issues. These issues were particularly prominent on the Xbox One and PlayStation 4 versions of the game. However, CD Projekt Red has released multiple patches to address these issues and improve the game’s performance.

In conclusion, “Cyberpunk 2077” is a game with a lot of potential. Its rich world, compelling story, and diverse gameplay make it an engaging experience. However, the presence of bugs and performance issues can detract from the overall experience.

[h1] Cyberpunk is finally worth it![/h1]
Cyberpunk had a infamous launch and people were rightfully upset. I decided to make my official review of the game following the 2.1 update which adds several features, including a fully fleshed out metro system.

[h2]General Consensus[/h2] 
Since its launch, the game has continued to improve, with new features, items, vehicles, quests, and fixes being added over the years. While there is still room for improvements, overall the game is in a significantly better state than it was at launch. 

Night City has left an impression on me that I cannot forget. The architecture is breath taking, and each district has its own distinctions and charms. The new metro system gives you a whole new perspective of NC, and I honestly prefer walking and using it over cars, it simply allows you to slow down and soak up all the details and characteristics.

Each quest line feels unique and fits well with their corresponding factions and characters. In addition to countless mercenary jobs from various fixers and the NCPD reaching every corner of the map. I do wish you could replay quests, as after a certain point of game completion there is little incentive to return to the game. 

Appearance, items, and cyberware come in many customizable varieties, including the famous Sandevistan featured in the Edgerunners anime. Dozens of options allows you to pretty much create whatever you desire. I do think the skin textures and hairstyles could use some polish, most of the hairstyles aren't appealing in my opinion. 

Since the 2.0 update the skill trees and cyberware have seen significant improvements. There is now a limit on how much cyberware you can have (it can be increased through gameplay), which pushes specializing your character towards a specific skill set, at least early on. 

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Overall Cyberpunk has come a long way since its launch, and I can whole heartily recommend it!

Fantastic story and game play.

Cyberpunk 2077, a vision of the future where greed corruption and hedonism reach an apex. You play as V, a merc of the city with a dream of being a legend of night city by either dying in a blaze of glory, or with a whimper. Its your choice.

Developed by CD Project Red Cyberpunk 2077 launched in a failed state, with massive technical issues and wasn't feature complete, Fast forward nearly 3 years and Cyberpunk 2077 has pulled 180! With multiple large patches fixing the majority of bugs, adding secrets, a gameplay overhaul, vehicle combat, and additional mission content. The transformation from launch to now is Night and Day.

Night City is truly an immersive experience, with a scale and density that I've never seen in any game. Then combine the visual splendor of night city with downright the best selection of radio and synth based scores I've ever had the pleasure of hearing in any game. And you've got a title that is not only immersive but truly captivating. That not even to mention the story, which might just be the crown on top Cyberpunks experience.

Lets touch on that for a brief period. Before release we were promised a certain type of "web of branching mission paths" based on choices, and at release that's what a large portion of the player base was expecting. We did not receive this experience, instead we got a more straight forward story experience with about 7 different endings base of a final choice. Phantom Liberty does rectify this with a point where you get completely new content depending on choices you make, and I truly think that the base game would've benefited from a system like this. However the story that is currently in the game is fantastic and leaves a decent amount of player choice. Especially how this story concludes based of relationships made while completing the main and side content. 

Overall Cyberpunk is in my top 5 games of all time. The setting, story, music, gameplay all fit my tastes, And I am very happy that with the final updates coming in, Cyberpunk is now in a place past where I visioned it on release. That not to mention Phantom Liberty, which might just be my new favorite DLC CD Project Red has made. 10/10 Breathtaking.

Never Fade Away.

It's definitely a fun game that has its moments. The story isn't half-baked and you're expected to be engaged with it even if all you wanna do is just shoot people like a maniac (to some extent you will be engaged with it, just enough to follow the events happening). It has a really slow beginning that you'll have to bare with until you're given the freedom to do what you wanna do. The shooting itself is pretty fun and the customization options you're given for both weapon and body mods is a cool feature to have, giving you some extra freedom with how you wanna play your character. Melee combat is equally as enjoyable if not more and you can go as a full-melee build if you like. The world is  decently sized, feels rich and immersing enough to make you feel like you're in a futuristic city and for the most part really impressively designed. Missions are OK - varied, usually slow to start but generally interesting enough for you to care just enough to hear out the NPC's and follow what's going on. Driving is really enjoyable and I'll give that a 5/5, though the traffic is weird because I've seen cars ahead of me vanish while I was driving for fun as though to get out of my way and allow me to enjoy the road to myself, while at other times (during missions involving tailing someone or races), I've realized that traffic will deliberately target you and spawn from nowhere just to get in your way - not that I mind it but the scripting is obvious and the immersion on that could've been improved. Likewise the characters in this game are 5/5 - really well-portrayed and seem like believable people or at least in some sense relatable to being human. Some characters you really don't wanna see and others you might end up getting to like without intending it. Lastly optimization, which was really fine and the game ran smoothly without hitches - no game-breaking bugs, might've experienced one or two bugs but they were usually weird happenings during scripted cut-scenes for missions - nothing major.

It's a good game, I'd recommend it as it's sure to give you enough hours to enjoy your money's worth even if you buy it at full price. 

TLDR: This is what I expect from a AAA game with a AAA price-tag; guaranteed entertainment with a decent amount of replayability and this game achieves that.

It's time to reset our original experience on this game.  I remember all the terrible bugs, janky movement and uninspiring tech/skill tree.  

Those days are gone.  This is a completely different game and there is NOTHING else out there that is similar.  It's a unique experience and worth us supporting, hoping for a sequel or similar structured game from these developers.

Honestly, I was so deeply disappointed when the game was so busted in December 2020 that it bugged and froze my PC beyond my 3hrs refund window. 
I am so glad that happened now, because I wouldn't have experienced the rich (and often heartbreaking) storytelling, the interesting cast Night City has, and the incredibly varied and fun combat. After 30 hours, I had to buy Phantom Liberty which just expanded on what I love about this game. 
I played two builds - primarily a sniping netrunner, but then reset everything for a katana wielding Sandi run for the *secret* ending. Both were incredibly fun and engaging in two very different gameplay methods, and I can see how you can easily rack up the hours playing with loads of different builds. 
Gotta appreciate the polish that revealed this diamond, and thank heavens they updated the fashion of this game and the wardrobe function - I don't think I could have handled V's outfits in the early game! 
Give it a go, if like me, it was collecting digital dust in your steam library. It's worth it.

Update: 01/27/2024 - I gave it another shot after all the updates. It's much better and I can say it is actually a really good game. Very fun and very immersive. 


Graphics look great, some story is gripping but doesn't feel/look like anything they promised years ago. It appears they either rushed it out or lied. The game features that were promised and advertised were all gutted to a shell of what it was intended to be. 

I don't know about the rest of you, but I'm not to fond of being tricked into beta testing a game for $60. Did anyone actually play through the game at all before it was released? $$$ is king though. I'm sorry to say that CDPR is up there with Activision & EA as far as "Screw the customer, get that money".

CD Projekt Red have once again created one of the games of all time. Night City is one of the most immersive open-worlds in the history of gaming. There is always something to be found in every nook and cranny, as the entire game is littered with detail. Night City is so well made that I never wanted to use the fast travel in the game, and rather drove my vehicles to the places I needed to go to. There was not a single questline which was boring to me: and the game really feels like it was made with love and ambition. Graphically, it is of an insanely high quality, however you need a really beefy PC to be able to go on the highest settings + ray tracing (I have a 3070Ti and i5-12600k and I couldn't use RT with the highest settings). The soundtrack is probably the best I have ever heard in a videogame, and with a dynamic music player you can listen to your favourite tracks on the go. The gameplay is magnificent and satisfying, with every build being viable, and later even overpowered in the endgame - you really can't go wrong. It even has Keanu Reeves, whose character was amazingly well written. 

On the topic of bugs: CDPR have fixed the game really well, but there are still some problems. One of them is that you if you install the game on an HDD instead of an SSD, if you're going fast in a vehicle the roads won't render, which was easily fixed by moving the game files to my SSD.

Mods. The Cyberpunk 2077 modding community is as good as it gets. There is a plethora of mods you can use, which are really easy to install. The discord servers are all happy to help and any problems I had were quickly solved by friendly people on them. The mods made my experience indescribably good, and I would definitely recommend getting at least some QoL ones. 

Final Score: 10/10

Despite being a big fan of the Witcher series and loving The Witcher 3 in particular, I did not pick up Cyberpunk 2077 at release, as the game seemed to be getting a mixed reception, and back then I did not really have the time and energy to play these massive games anyway. With the hefty 2.0 update, it came back onto my radar, and I decided to give it a chance. Therefore, keep in mind that everything I'm about to say applies strictly to the post-2.0 state of the game, 2.1 specifically.

First, to address the elephant in the room, I did experience a number of bugs, but most of them were harmless visual glitches, e.g. a procgen NPC getting stuck in the stairs. Just once did I have a major game-breaking bug, when I was simply no longer able to save for unclear reasons, no matter what I tried, which led to me losing a chunk of progress. My game also crashed a handful of times. Ideally, that number should be zero, but since these crashes and show-stoppers occurred only sporadically across 88 hours of game time I wouldn't say that CP2077 is currently a particularly buggy game.

It is fun to move around in this game, and it has satisfying gunplay for an RPG. The shotgun in particular feels really meaty and allows you to blast enemies into a different dimension, as all good video game shotguns should. The fact that there are various combinations of perks and cyberware possible means you have a lot of tools at your disposal when it comes to dealing with enemies. I started out always going in guns blazing, because I'm the impatient type and I thought it was funny to immediately fail the stealth conditions on purpose (and sometimes get berated for it), but later on I started experimenting with stealth, and I have to say that it makes for engaging gameplay as well. Said stealth is not particularly complex, as in, there is a limited number of basic options you can play around with, but I don't necessarily consider that to be a bad thing.

CP2077's writing, themes, and sense of aesthetics are where it truly shines for me, but they might turn you off if you're not as inherently receptive to them as I am. Without going into detail, most quests and characters are not black-and-white, you often have to make difficult morally grey choices, and the sense of hopelessness and cynicism that pervades the world will not appeal to everyone, especially since it is already so pervasive in modern entertainment. I myself do not mind this so much, because it lends more weight to those moments where you actually [i]can[/i] influence the world in some way, and/or build meaningful connections with other characters.
Nearly all quests after a certain point are named after song titles, which I personally loved. They seemed to lean especially towards punk and new wave, both of which I am a fan of (and I assume the year 2077 itself is a reference to punk). I recognized songs by The Ramones, Dead Kennedys, Blondie, and the Smiths, among many others. One of the quests is named after I Don't Wanna Hear It by Minor Threat, which is just amazing to see in an AAA game released in 2020. Once again, your mileage may vary.

The main criticism of Cyberpunk 2077 for me is that it sometimes fails to stick the landing. There are many well-written and engaging quests or quest chains that just fizzle out or end anticlimactically, both narratively and mechanically. Typically, if you've gone above and beyond, you end up getting a garbage-tier weapon that is not worth making a detour for, or another car you'll never use, and regardless you basically never hear from that character again, except for maybe a text, no matter how long and closely you've worked with them.

This final point is specific to the minority of losers such as myself who use azerty keyboards, so you can skip this if that doesn't apply to you, but CP2077 does NOT play nice with azerty (and presumably anything else that deviates from the standard qwerty lay-out). Not only did I have to rebind the WASD controls to ZQSD, which fair enough, but certain keybinds (such as q to drop a body you are carrying, which obviously conflicts with movement for azerty users) are impossible to change in-game, and I had to manually go into the config files to modify them. You can ask why people in Flanders would use azerty to begin with, and that's a good question, but it does actually come in useful sometimes for work, on those occasions where I have to communicate in French. So I have to dock points for the devs' decision to ignore us, but obviously this is not enough to tip the scales, and it will not affect most people reading this review.

All in all, despite the bugs that do persist to some extent even post-2.0, and the fact that it often has difficulty wrapping things up in a satisfying manner, CP2077 does many things right, and the average gamer will find it to be an enjoyable, cinematic experience. If you suspect that the game's themes and aesthetics might resonate with you, as they did in my case, it becomes an absolute must-buy.

This is actually a pretty great game, with a massive amount of content. They did a great job bringing the city to life with random interactions, dialog between strangers, shop stalls, little easter eggs, different districts/areas and other stuff. The voice acting is generally quite good, the plot is pretty decent, there's a *lot* of side missions. Different playstyles based on how you build your character.

I've had a few crashes, perhaps a half dozen in 70+ hours, but nothing like the stability problems that I've seen talked about in the early release. Also the audio gets weird sometimes, usually when there's a continuous background noise. 

My only complaint with the gameplay is that they only let you re-spec your character one time. Why be so stingy? There's a lot of options for character builds, I want to try them all without sinking another 70 hours into leveling another character.

I started playing the game at the best possible time; with Patch 2.0. So I missed out on the shitshow the launch was.

And boi, is it a great game! I had barely any issues on the technical front. It ran as well as a polished, modern game should. Some NPCs getting stuck in the floor, or some general clipping bugs were the worst I encountered.
And it just is a lot of fun to play. Not as much as a "choices matter for the story" title as The Witcher 3 for example. But the story is good, the voice acting is done great with a lot of fun cameos. And running, gunning and sneaking around Night City is an experience I can highly recommend.

Not a perfect game. But its flaws are forgiveable to me. Especially if you stood clear for now, it is well worth giving it a shot - if you got the hardware!

Also, the expansion is amazing! It's map, gigs and storys are great. And it's characters are even better. A shame we only get this single expansion. But it is a worthy expansion to what has become an awesome game.

This game introduced aggressive level scaling with it's 2.0 DLC which sadly destroys the feeling of progression and introduces an artificial and cheap way to "balance" the game that is in stark contrast with the portrayed worlds realities and makes some build not viable (e.g. as a netrunner with maximum intelligence and the best available cyberware- why cant i hack other netrunners while they have no issues hacking me?). I am trying to finish the Phantom Liberty DLC but the frustrations just force me to take long breaks.

After the release of Phantom Liberty expansion, I decided to do my second play through of this game on patch 2.0. 

"Can't stop digging Night City." - Jackie Welles, 2077.

Walking around Night City was always a treat, more so now that I could now run the game with RTX enabled. There was something special, watching how the wet surfaces reflect the neon light. A visual feast for the eyes, such a delight I didn't want this ride to end. Wandering the city and soaking it all in, CDPR has crafted an astoundingly beautiful world that, against everything that has been shown to me, I can't help but love. 

Phantom Liberty was an incredible experience, with Dogtown introducing a new location to explore as well as a spiralling plot of espionage and betrayal. The cast of characters were interesting, and I enjoyed spending time with them, learning more about their past and their dreams for the future. Idris Elba was a standout for me, with Reed being an amazing addition to the game. 

The Tower ending was what lead me to believe that the Wands was the best outcome. V may live, but at what cost? I wasn’t satisfied with this ending, so I made sure to meet the conditions for the secret ending to storm Arasaka Tower with Johnny, and it was a thrilling experience. It’s tied with the Star as my favourite ending. 

This was me vomiting up words to help deal with the fact that I won't be playing this game again for a long time. Cyberpunk 2077 is masterpiece of a game, and I'm glad that CDPR has continued to polish it.

--- Original Review ---
I played this game on version 1.5.

Spoilers ahead, this review will be more of me spilling my guts about what I feel about this game, and I'm not eloquent enough to do so without spoilers.

I bought this game day 1 and played it for a bit before deciding to shelve the game for another day, this was mainly due to performance of the game being lacklustre on my GTX 1060. Now, with an RTX 3070, I was able to properly experience this gorgeous game.

Main Story: while shorter than what I was expecting (especially after The Witcher 3), I had a good time going through Night City with Johnny by my side. Also don't be fooled by the trailers, I should have expected that they would alter a few details so not to spoil the first act. While I wish they would expand the first act to expand the backstory of V a bit (honestly, the life paths don't really do much apart from a few choice conversations in the game), I have hope that they'll expand on this in a future patch, and I would happily replay the whole game again to experience this once more.

Gunplay: enemies felt a tad too much like bullet sponges if you decided to roll with AR / SMGs, so I often found myself using a sniper to one tap everyone from a distance. Not that I mind, in universe it makes sense to augment yourself as much as you can to take a hit if the option is there for you.

Driving: like you're on ice. The only redeeming factor is that you can take in the sights of Night City and appreciate what CDPR built. I'm still amazed at the scale of what they have done.

Music / OST: they don't miss in this game, all songs and combat music just slaps hard. Most songs are on Spotify, and if they're not there you can find them on YouTube. My personal favourites was when they wove in a violin to play a hauntingly beautiful melody, I didn't expect it to mesh so well with the violent music of Cyberpunk, but it did it well. I only wish that you could have bought a music player add on to listen to the radio while you're out and about walking through the city.

Johnny: having a companion on this journey helped to alleviate the loneliness that might come about, hearing his thoughts and his advice was good fun. Keanu did a great job with Johnny, I hope they expand on his character in the expansions.

Side characters: for the most part, everyone was decently fleshed out with numerous side quests and the down time you have with them to bond with. Also, my only main love interest was Panam.

Side stories: I did every side story available to me as I craved more story and content in the city, and for the most part, each one was interesting in some way to me. Either expanding on the world that we are trespassing on temporarily or helping build bonds for the future. I only wish that gigs had more story with them as I found them bland to do after a few. A feature I did really enjoy was that a lot of the major side quests came to you via the phone. So instead of having to travel out to a point to talk to someone, they just used the magical device that everyone carries in their pocket (or skull). There were some side quests that you had to travel to in the world, but for the most part these weren't so bad to get when you're cleaning up side quests. This style of quest giving really helped to make the game feel effortless to play, as is a big reason why I actually did all of the side quests (normally I'd avoid them in open world games because the effort to get to the quest location was too much).

Endings: I've broken down my thoughts of the four endings you can get in the game, as each one left a different impression on me. Also again, heavy spoilers.

The Devil: the bad end, but that doesn't mean I found it to be done poorly. This explores what it's like to have betrayed everyone you've had a relationship with, and ultimately, yourself. I felt dirty as I played through, knowing that I only have myself to blame for being in this position. Never trust the corps.

The Sun: the path to becoming a NC legend is not easy, but damn was this ending fun to play through. Having the chance to blast through Arasaka as Johnny felt like fate circling around to finish what he started all those years ago. Thematically,  a very satisfying ending (especially getting to kill Smasher as Johnny). I do hope we get an expansion to do the final BIG job that was shown in the final cutscene as well.

The Star: I feel like this is the good ending of the game. Taking Judy's advice and just leaving Night City behind for a hopeful future feels to be the most sensible option to do in this situation, as NC has nothing left for V. Also, watching the sun set on Night City through the car window with RTX on was magical to look at.

Temperance: I left this for last, as this was how I wanted to leave the game (for now, at least) as I wait for expansions to come out. I tried to explore the city as Johnny but was forced back to the mission area sadly. Seeing how Johnny had matured and mellowed out as he comes to grips with dealing with V's sacrifice was touching when compared to how he was in the game. 

Also listening in on the final voice messages was a nice touch, like the characters in the game were saying goodbye to us, the player. Helps with closure, I found. 

If you made it this far, I'll leave you with this. Something my friend told me that I can't not see anymore. When driving around NC and you approach a set of traffic lights, the lights will automatically turn green if they were red before.

Great game, I'm happy to have paid full price for this experience, and I will happily pay full price for the expansions as well when they come out.
