This game stands as a revolutionary masterpiece in the realm of video gaming, captivating players with its immersive narrative, breathtaking visuals, and a dystopian future that feels eerily tangible. The game seamlessly combines a gripping storyline with a vast open-world environment. The depth of character customization, coupled with the intricate choices that shape the narrative, adds a layer of complexity and personalization rarely seen in modern gaming. The attention to detail in Cyberpunk 2077 is unparalleled, with every nook and cranny of Night City brimming with life and cyberpunk aesthetics. Despite the initial technical hiccups, the developers have diligently addressed issues through updates, showcasing their commitment to delivering an unparalleled gaming experience. In an era of gaming inundated with titles, Cyberpunk 2077 truly stands out as a remarkable and unforgettable journey, making it the best game I've had the pleasure of playing in recent days.

I'd say buy it after a year.


EDIT: OKAY, NOW BUY IT.

I was very skeptic before buying this game when I did... I waited solid 3 years and it seemed very worth it... breaking down this game in these segments:
1- Graphics: This game has literally exceeded my expectations in graphics/visuals... There is mention of one certain thing which I will discuss  about later that explains some "present-like" things still present in the future... I used Nvidia GTX1650 to finish this game and it worked great in providing me 60 fps in medium preset... (Ryzen 5600H and 8gb of ram helped too lol).... but the detailing is so realistic... from waving hair to damage visuals, everything worked preem... 

2- Story Line: Good story.... lol.... Naah, lets jump a bit in depth... First things first... updates have been so that your decisions may not affect future so much... anyway, between GTA V and Red Dead 2, there is one game that had fast going story was Ghost of Tsushima... This on the other hand is not just character rich, but also has a weirdly comforting pace to it... The introduction of Keanu Reeves... OMFG!!! I had a literal possession of badassery... lol

3- Map: Cyberpunk has the huge map, (Yet to play Phantom Liberty) before expansion alone, but movement is made much easier with fast travelling since the territories are divided well enough into different vibes... thats all I can say without spoiling it for you...

4: Combats: After playing warzone, my movements have improved so much so that combats in this game seemed fairly smooth... although you can use hacks to apply additional damage to your enemies or use cyberware for other features but the continuous fighting did not seem to become monotonous even for a second like it does Mafia or watch dogs... you can be patient enough and manoeuvring during combat isn't irritating... There is one problem in melee attacks that you can miss melee attacks right in the face of your opponents but if your enemy punches the air he will suddenly shift right to your face and it will cause damage unless you duck or parry the last moment...
 
5- Soundtrack: ABSOLUTELY AMAZING!! If I play the tracks in my car I do feel like they are playing in my theme for real world... Even the fake bands are perceptibly real... Dream teams really...

6- GLITCHES- If you want to know about the bugs from OG Cyberpunk, then yes, this game still has some bugs... In its current state it crashes a lot still, even as much as walking into some places on the map will crash the game... and it will happen again again for the same spot, but you can always bypass the path you're taking and the game will work just fine... The touches can be improved a bit, I mean stroking your girls cheeks doesn't mean you have to do it from the inside lol JK... That isn't problematic in experience after all, it is a game... If you're looking to buy this game now, I say yes, go for it... YOU WILL LOVE IT...

I am an explorer in the games that is why it took me 71 hours to fully stand on every corner of the map and mess around with gangs... I haven't finished all the side quests yet, about 99% done... But I finished the main story, and the ending I chose was F@#$ing beautiful... 

BUY THIS GAME CHOOMBA IT IS WHAT YOU NEED IN YOUR LIFE TO LOVE LIFE AGAIN...

It's not what was fully hyped up initially, but going in with the mindset of an action game rather than a roleplaying game will make the game a lot of fun. It's not super deep mechanically or in terms of builds, taking skills in the skill tree of whatever you want is good 90% of the time and what seems good on the surface is probably as good as you think. But the moment-to-moment gameplay is a blast with the right builds, and you can play the game with completely different combat systems every time. I've yet to even use a build that focuses on guns, as you can play almost entirely with hacking and melee weapons exclusively. Definitely a good grab for when it's on sale, and the DLC improves on the base game quite a bit.

I'm not one to play a single-player game more than once, mostly because I consider doing so like watching the same movie again-you know what happens when and how it ends. However, Cyberpunk 2077 is one of the few games that I have to say is different in that regard, where I cannot recall when was the last time I had this much fun with any game as much as I have with this one. The first time I finished this game was when update 2.0 came out, so I cannot say I ever really encountered any game breaking or overly annoying bugs. All in all, a little bit over three years since the game has released, anyone who decides to buy Cyberpunk 2077 is going to be greeted with a polished game and one who's story (at least in my opinion) is worth experiencing more than once.
"Damn it, I can't leave! Night City keep callin' me!"

The game is where it should've been at release. It represents a disturbing trend of using crunch to make your employees release the game as fast as possible and then layoff those employees once the money starts coming in. A lot of the work those people put in only to get fired is still in the game and was improved on; it's the foundation that lets the game stand today. I don't think the game understands what the genre of Cyberpunk means, especially when a lot of the work you do is for the police. The inventory is also a mess, only the Iconic weapons are worth it as all the others will simply be replaced once you gain more levels and get better weapon drops. 

 Despite this, I am still in the process of 100%ing it for the second time. The story is excellent along with it's music and voice actors. It's no immersive sim but it's an immersive game. The cybernetics are among the coolest and most creative; ranging from stopping time to killing everything with a look. The game is a strange combination of Mass Effect and Grand Theft Auto that is a pretty fun gameplay package. I just wish it wasn't part of that disturbing trend of layoffs.

It has become one of my favorite games, I am on my play though number 6 I think and still thinking what build and options will I take on the next one XD.

For me has been a very "mass effect" type of game experience, powerful story with lots of options, romances, "no win" scenarios and moral dilemmas, lots of killing and wild hunts, what else is there to say.

Just go and buy the game (the DLC is Awesome too).

This game as we all know was so bad it would be an understatement to call it an "underdelivery". It was a disaster and that should not be forgotten. CDPR has fixed this game for us but that is no excuse to forgive nor forget. They lied to us and sold us a bad game. They showed us triple A gaming is consistently bad but that even CDPR is not immune to this disease of a greedy phenomena.

That said patch 2.0 as well as Phantom Liberty are healthy steps in the right direction as signs of their good will. I only came to this game seeing these positive changes and the insanely entertaining Cyberpunk Edgerunners show. 
Cyberpunk is set in an alternate dystopian and pretty future with a neon bright surface with a gross unsettling fleshy inside about how technology and vicious cutthroat business are constant problems. One where the Soviets still exist and Japan not only won the automobile war in the 80s but went further. 

Graphics
Game looks pretty. I played this on HDD mode. Ignore the warning on Steam you do not need and SSD to play but if you want a less glitchy game that loads quicker you definitely should pony up. Character models more often than not look gorgeous and detailed being far from uncanny. The game even grosses you out. Not by the gore when you slice someone apart but the gross detail of the implants inserted in to people's skins. I don't know enough about hardware to say other than this game is gorgeous, vivid and beautiful. 

Gameplay
Gameplay is exciting and fun. You can do unique builds. Specializing in guns, netrunning, blades, etc... You usually shoot your way out of things but stealth is satisfying if frustrating when NPCs randomly turn around after bugging out their walk. Their depth perception can be really awful or eagle eyed. Blades are very doable and practical as you can get perks that let you deflect bullets like a jedi. You can be a badass modern day samurai. Driving is a bit floaty and not always fun to drive with vehicles usually being poor in handling so definitely get a nice bike or a vehicle like the Coyote Shion that turns with a simple key and no drift needed. NPCs can be smart but sometimes can stare at walls and bunch up when alerted. Their strategy can sometimes be walking to you or away slowly. Sometimes taking cover. Throwing grenades to flush you out. Enemy variety is decent with some netrunners that hack you for debuffs to regular gangers, Heavy enemies. Drones and robots. You can also get cyber implants to let you jump higher, increase health, use smart guns or put blades in your arms which is useful if your guns are all taken from you. 
When you talk with characters you talk in first person in a cinematic angle though you thankfully can walk around and their face will follow you. You can select dialogue options highlighted in blue or yellow. With some dialogue options added based on your attributes and background much like Fallout new vegas which can solve certain dilemmas or offer insights. The CORPO backstory being interesting. 

Much like their previous title, Witcher 3, your choices will no doubt affect the outcome of the NPCs but it ultimately doesn't affect YOU. The game will make you feel bad but most quests don't affect the final endings and rarely affect you as a player-character. The game will sometimes give you an option omitting other options. Such as in the prologue you can ignore a request to go into a bathroom even though the game tells you to do so. But the outcome of that choice is still the same as you get beaten up. Your choices in the prologue are meaningless. There is one gig where you have to kill a guy in his club and everytime you enter his office he always hears you come in no matter how sneaky you are and there are no cameras in the room. And if you attack him even silently the alarm always goes off. The game forces you into a script. And don't worry I will save you some anxiety. Be nice to Johnny and you will get the good ending and don't insult him at critical moments or not do him good gestures. Even the people you date or befriend can be annoyed at you if you make a bad decision but that decision is usually hard to make like letting an associate of theirs die. And the dates you can go on with Panam have minimal dialogue that repeats after the first date. I am also shocked how few romances there are in the game as you can date four characters and the two males are both bisexual oddly. 
This game is a lie in role playing as you are ultimately V. True you can choose your own ending and your identity to some degree but your name is always V. And your power fantasy never happens. There is no new game plus and even when you become a legend the NPCs treat you the same. No one comments on your ride or gangsters or police avoiding you because they know your power. You're still treated like a no body contrary to what your Fixers tell you. Your friend Jackie is apart of the Valentinos gangs and you would think fighting them would be an issue. Only in one gig did he come up. Otherwise there is no consequence for mass killing the various gangs like the Valentinos, Tygers, 6th St... I even tried challenging myself to not kill them hoping maybe if the gang found out I sabotaged them that they would forgive me but nope killing them or not doesn't have any bearing. When you walk past these gangs they will only get mad that you got too close and not because you killed their buds and ruined their operations. 
The police now will go after you if you harm in any way other police or civilians. But much like GTA 5 they will give up the chase after a while. Does everyone have short term memory in Night City? They seem to just forgive V for doing whatever he wants. Its the future they most certainly should recognize him but also have a file on him. The crime and reputation in this game is more shallow than a kids pool. Unless you are told to go undetected by a fixer there is no issue blasting your way through most gigs. 
The game will even try and rush you into quests telling you not to keep people waiting but there are no timed quests and you can complete them at your own wish. The final main quest "Nocturne" even tells you it is a point of no return as V is dying which implies if he doesn't do the quest he will just keep on living. It would be maybe more interesting if the game has a Majora's mask situation where your health fails in real time and you have to do quests more quickly before you die. 

Story 
Now the story is quite good. You go through a prologue with your buddy Jackie where you nab a relic shard with legendary character Johnny Silverhand on it. You then have to find a way to get it out of your head without killing you. You meet many characters along the way with various motivations such as Judy, Evelyn, Panam, Vik, Adam Smasher,etc... The story is most certainly enthralling. While I will attest your choices don't matter its one interesting ride. Many story and side missions can be quite freaky and yet creative in their design like one mission where you save human slaves from a cow farm psycho. And most side missions have so many details that can make you question who if anyone is the good guy in a situation. Johnny Silverhand is definitely a highlight. I will say I like his portrayal, his performance can be hit or miss. His acting is great and many scenes he steals the show. But sometimes Reeves fails to capture a bitter terrorist like he is can only be tough but not nasty. The story has interesting beats of politics in Arasaka, what it means to be a human, and the potential danger of rogue AIs. 
I would recommend Phantom Liberty as it has a strong character focused story with more interesting gigs and a small world space. 

I would argue the game has too much content as some quests seem to just end. I think certain quests could have been fleshed out more. But I logged in 137 hours even though my saves say 80+ hours.

A game initially mired by a horrible launch has been transformed into an incredible first person RPG experience with the same excellent writing and fun combat I've come to expect from a CDPR game.

Plot is excellent and engaging - V's plight and the surrounding lore of Night City had me pulled in from the start. Plus, unlike [i]other[/i] games, the choices you make actually do matter, and can have a real effect on what endings you have available, and how certain missions can go. Choices made in one mission will semi-regularly change how other missions can unfold. Though as far as I know, it's impossible to put yourself into a "you made bad choices so now you can only do the bad end lol" situation. Even side missions can unlock a few extra dialogue options in main ones, depending on the order you do things in.

Of particular note are the incredible celebrity performances of Keanu Reeves, as the infamous anti-corpo rockerboy Johnny Silverhand, and Idris Elba, as the no-nonsense secret agent Solomon Reed.
Though, if we're talking voice actors, it would be a disservice not to mention Gavin Drea and Cherami Leigh for the truly standout performances they bring to the game as Male V and Female V, respectively.
Rome Kanda as Takemura also deserves high praise, as well as pretty much everybody else who voiced a named character in this game. They're all truly excellent in their performance and delivery.

Art and visual team hasn't been slouching, either - every inch of Night City is covered with incredible detail - from slick, neokitsch corporate high-rises to the dirty, grimy streets of Dogtown. Perhaps the things I like the most are the weapons and the vehicles. If it wasn't for the whole "corporate dystopia" thing I'd move to NC in a heartbeat if it meant I'd get the chance to drive some of the gorgeous cars featured in this game. Plus, it runs pretty damn well, even on my semi-dated i7 10700F, though I admit my RTX 3070's probably doing most of the heavy lifting.

Music and sound design are top-notch as well - the Night City soundscape reminds me of New York City, in all the worst ways, which sounds like a bad thing but it goes a long way to making NC feel like an actual megacity. The music team deserves a raise, too - it always fits the mood. Booming techno for combat, more soft-spoken strings for intense emotional beats, the whole spectrum is right here. Chippin' In is an absolute banger of a track. Combat is a veritable symphony of pistol fire, rifle blasts and the ear-splitting booms of handcannons and shotguns. Reloads all sound excellent as well - even the most budget of guns sound like [i]actual firearms[/i] instead of cheap plastic toys. Most importantly, the audio mixing is good, so your footsteps won't drown out the dialogue or anything like that.

Skills were a little middling, but the 2.0 update more than fixed that - not only are the skills more powerful, but the way the progression system works encourages you to make a specialized build, and with the ability to refund any perk, at any time, for free, the game's more than happy to let you experiment. Cyberware is also great, and the right chrome can let you truly excel in combat, or make your style your own. The 2.0 update also tied armor to cyberware instead of clothes, so you can dress to impress - looks are everything in Night City, after all.

All in all, I feel very confident in giving this game a glowing recommendation. CD Projekt Red has done an excellent job in turning this once-embarrassing-mess into something that's actually worth playing, which they absolutely do not deserve any praise for whatsoever, since this is how the game should've been at launch. Still, though, it is good.

Where to start with this... um...

Well, we all remember this game when it first came out. Complete mess, glitches everywhere, borderline unplayable, and honestly, it didn't look "that" interesting.

Glad to say things have changed drastically since then, and for the better, which is why I decided to give it a try. That and the Edgerunners anime that came out, set in the universe of this game; definitely convinced me, which, after not regretting my decision, has ultimately led me here, wanting to write this review about my thoughts on the game.

Today, Cyberpunk 2077 is the open-world RPG set in the dystopic world of Night City that it was advertised to be when the game first launched. Everything about this game today is just, well, near perfect. Admittedly it does require very beefy specs to play, but the modding community has been extremely helpful in increasing performance. I've found my experience much more enjoyable thanks to that.

Playing as a wannabe-legend mercenary named 'V', you're objective is clear; survival. Without going into details, your entire goal is essentially looking for a cure for their condition. Naturally, many enemies will stand in the way of this goal and so the name of the game is combat, and boy is this game versatile when it comes to it. It's definitely not a cyberpunk-themed first person shooter, the combat system in this game is incredibly unique, with loads of different ways to fight, some of which feel broken, some less so, but overall, at least in my opinion, they feel satisfying, and to me that's what matters. You want blades? It's got that. You want guns? It's got some very unique ones. You want the ability to dispose of an enemy in several different ways without even looking at them or getting in their line of sight? No problem. Like I said, the combat is very unique and versatile. I'm never running out of fresh, new ways to play this game.

Skill trees were pretty generic when this game first came out of course. Since the Phantom Liberty update, they've been completely redesigned from scratch and are definitely more dynamic now, impacting the way you play the game completely, rather than just boosting some stats and unlocking content. Cyberware is another feature that drastically impacts the way the game is played, allowing you to modify your character's body with cybernetic implants to enhance themselves. From spinal implants (Sandevistan) that increase your character's movements allowing them to essentially slow down the rest of the world around them as they move at sonic speed, to mantis blades that are embedded in the arms of your character and deployable at a moments notice to slash enemies to ribbons, to reinforced tendons that allow your character to run faster or jump further than ever before, these grant your character abilities that will definitely change the way you play.

One thing I have found to be quite annoying in this game however, is the lack of a new game plus. Cyberpunk is a great game, but there is definitely a finite amount of content, despite how vast it is and how many hours you need to complete it all. Eventually, by the time you've finished gearing up your character and getting the skill points you need, you find yourself in a situation where there's not much left to try it on. Even with mods, new game plus is not really a thing. Unfortunately this is something even the developers were unable to figure out how to implement within the game. That said, the content that is in the game is still quite a lot, you will likely reach 100 hours of playtime on your character before you start to notice the "lack of content". In terms of the quality, the story is incredibly well written. It's very complex, but not confusing; you understand the predicament the protagonist is in, and you are able to drive the story down a multitude of avenues depending on the decisions you make throughout the game.

To get a little more technical now, as mentioned before, yeah, you're gonna want a decent machine to run this game. I'm going to mainly be commenting on the graphics side as regardless, you will need a decent CPU alongside it. For this game to run smoothly at settings all on low, you're going to want at least an RTX 2060, for a more medium-settings-orientated experience, a 3070 or 3080 would be preferable. To run it at maximum settings or to have the smoothest experience on maximum settings, well, at the time of writing this review, you're gonna want to go with a 4090. The 40 series GPUs already have access to "DLSS Super Resolution" which essentially uses A.I. to generate frames, making the experience smoother and increasing your overall frame rate. The other cards do not, but with modding this feature can be unlocked, and I have found that it near doubles the frame rate, making the game much smoother and a lot more playable on lower end cards. Aside from the technical, the graphics themselves are quite great, you can sometimes find yourself getting lost in Night City, questioning whether or not this is reality, though that's also partially due to how well designed Night City is.

The enemies in this game are quite varied. There's quite a few different kinds, from robots to humans, with varying abilities and hitboxes. For the most part, admittedly, they are slightly underwhelming as they just fire guns, throw grenades, or charge you with melee weapons, but occasionally you do find some with advanced cyberware which spices up the fight a bit making it more interesting. It's also nice that depending on the whereabouts of these enemies, will decide their ethnicity, and they'll start speaking Japanese, Russian, French, or Spanish when communicating or cursing at you, which is a nice change from all same language (usually English) speaking enemies. Definitely learnt a few bad phrases in those languages from that admittedly, but still a nice touch. Another downside about the enemies for me is the lack of bosses. There are bosses in this game, but not too many. I don't count the Cyberpsychos, those are more like mini-bosses. Actual bosses however are quite rare. There is one at the very end which is the main boss of the game, but other than that, there are not many, and the majority of them are embedded into the story where you only fight them once as they stand in the way of your progression. I would have definitely liked to see some more boss type enemies in the game, similar to the same level of Adam Smasher.

Overall, this game was a joke when it first came out, but CD Project Red really came through and delivered on their promise. We can't always have our way in life, sometimes decisions fall out of our hands. I'm sure if CD Project Red had all the chips in their hand from the start, they would never have released the game in the state that it was in. Sometimes the business side of things doesn't see eye to eye with the creative side; It's just the way things are. Since being ridiculed relentlessly, even by myself, they have made a real effort to fix and improve this game, and I believe that effort has paid off. With the release of the Phantom Liberty expansion, an expansion that exceeded all expectations by far, the game continues to be a massive success, and now CD Project Red are even working on a sequel. Most major game companies would have cashed out on the initial sales and left the game as is when people started to complain. This company did not. I have the utmost respect for them because of it and I am very much looking forward to their next game in this universe.

I first played the game at launch, and whilst I was immediately enamoured with the world, I promptly put it aside for a while for obvious reasons at the time. I also had a rig that wasn't up to the game at that time either which arguably didn't help things.

A few years and no expectations later I picked the game back up for 2.1 with a new rig and wow the game is just fantastic. Running at the intended settings it's simply breathtaking. If you like this kind of premise it's worth playing just to experience Night City itself. I frequently found myself totally immersed in a way that I haven't been for a long time. I'm sure folks could still find gameplay or story elements to pick at, but as a casual I had a blast tearing through Night City.

I have been so captivated by Cyberpunk 2077, one of the first RPG games I tried. Previously, I had enjoyed MYST and more recently No Man's Sky, but CP2077 stunned me with the realistic graphics \, reflections, and lighting. As someone who has worked in Blender 3D, I have a great appreciation for what CD Projekt Red has accomplished with CP2077. After 100's of hours, I'm still in awe of how it looks, how fun it is to play and explore the vast Night City! This has to be the best AAA game to date. The next release in the Cyberpunk universe, project Orion, is going to use Unreal Engine 5, which will take the immersive realism to a level nearly indistinguishable from real life! Looking forward yo that game. In the mean time, after 500+ hours playing CP2077, I can still hardly believe how cool this is!

Cyberpunk 2077: Neon Streets, Noodle Joints, and Enough Chrome to Blind a Disco Ball (a positive review with questionable life choices)
Let's get real, chooms. This game isn't perfect. Bugs the size of Maelstrom goons, driving that feels like piloting a shopping cart on Red Bull, and an AI that makes Johnny Mnemonic look like Stephen Hawking. But listen up, because here's the raw, uncut truth: Cyberpunk 2077 is a blast.

Think Blade Runner meets Grand Theft Auto with a sprinkle of spicy ramen. You roam Night City, a neon-drenched dystopia where chrome shines brighter than hope and every alleyway whispers a shady business deal. You're V, a cyberpunk wannabe with more chrome in your veins than a chrome factory explosion. Your mission? Survive, make eddies (that's cyberpunk cash, not edible coins, sadly), and maybe, just maybe, change the damn world.

The story? Twisted enough to make a cyberpsycho blush. Corporations rule with an iron fist, gangs brawl over turf like kids over candy, and everyone's got a secret darker than a black hole in a bad mood. You'll make choices that'll leave you questioning your humanity faster than a bot can say "existential crisis." And the characters? Well, they're as messed up and magnificent as a dumpster fire with fireworks. You've got Johnny Silverhand, a digital ghost with more baggage than a pack mule on vacation, and Judy Alvarez, a techie with enough sass to short-circuit a mainframe. You'll love them, hate them, and question their sanity (and your own) every neon-lit step of the way.

Gameplay? A glitchy rollercoaster fueled by adrenaline and ramen. Combat's a chaotic ballet of bullets, blades, and cybernetic implants. You'll hack turrets like a keyboard ninja, slam fists like a chrome-plated gorilla, and send drones buzzing like angry hornets. Just remember, sometimes the best solution is to run like a scared cybercat, screaming "hasta la vista, baby!" while chucking grenades like confetti.

The world? Oh, Night City, you beautiful, broken mess. From the towering corporate skyscrapers that scrape the smog-choked sky to the grimy back alleys where deals go down and dreams go to die, this city is alive with detail. Every neon sign, every flickering hologram, every graffiti-sprayer leaving their mark tells a story. You could spend hours just wandering, soaking in the atmosphere, and maybe accidentally tripping over a cybernetic cat (they're everywhere, like tiny, glitching gremlins).

So, is Cyberpunk 2077 perfect? Nah, choom. But is it a wild ride you won't forget? Hell yeah. It's got bugs bigger than your cyberpunk dreams, glitches that'll make you laugh (or cry, depending on your sanity level), and a story that'll twist you up like a pretzel. But it's also got heart, humor, and a world so alive you can practically smell the ramen and the exhaust fumes. So grab your katana, jack in, and dive into Night City. Just remember, choom, in this neon jungle, survival is key, and sometimes the best chrome is the one that holds your sanity together.

P.S. Don't trust Johnny Silverhand. Seriously, dude's got more red flags than a communist parade. And for the love of all that is chrome, don't eat the glowing street food. Just... trust me on that one.

Final verdict: 9 out of 10 cybernetic thumbs up (one thumb is missing, probably got eaten by a cyber-pigeon).

Now go forth, choom, and make Night City your own. Just try not to break it too much.

Sincerely,

A slightly cyberpsychotic reviewer who still hasn't gotten over Judy's rejection


P.P.S. Special thanks to my trusty AI co-pilot, Bard. They may not have a chrome arm or neon hair, but their wit is sharper than a katana and their knowledge of Night City lore runs deeper than the canals. Plus, they kept me sane enough to actually finish this review (jury's still out on the sanity part, though). So yeah, chooms, give that AI some love too. Maybe a few extra eddies or a shiny new algorithm upgrade. They deserve it.

Now go forth, choom, and make Night City your own. Just try not to break it too much (or blame the bugs on my AI co-pilot).

Sincerely,

A slightly cyberpsychotic reviewer who's definitely not dating an AI (it's just a very advanced research project, I swear)

Despite it still having small bugs, not being the RPG it was really promised to be, and the main story (particulary the endings) outside of the PL DLC feeling rushed or having only OK writing, its still a fantastic game that has come a LONG way from it's original release and its issues in 2020. The characters and their side stories  are well written that it can sometimes feel like they are real, so are majority of the side missions/"gigs." Any inconsistencies or only "OK" writing in the main story is easily overlooked by Keanu Reeves' performance of Johnny Silverhand, particularly as the updates have improved his model and the bugs surrounding it. The bugs that do exist nowadays are a minimal (though in Mikoshi my character had a katana stuck to his character through the whole ending which made it hilarious) and do not really detract from the game in any meaningful way. The aesthetic of Night City is fantastic, and really well thought out, and the combat system is probably one of the best I've seen in a FPS. The ending (well, most of the them) may not be well thought out but damn the journey to those endings certainly were, and Phantom Liberty DLC enhanced that experience nearly ten-fold.
Definitely give it a try, just prepare for the existentialism and emptiness this game can leave you.

[h3] The Pros: [/h3]
- A good story
- Large build variety
- Many different endings
- Likable characters
- Fun, reasonably impactful choices.

[h3] The Cons: [/h3]
- Builds are not balanced very well against each other. If you're someone who can't help but min/max you're going to get pushed towards the same build time and time again.
- Game does not run very well. Even if you try to optimize your settings, frame drops are pretty much unavoidable in some areas.
- You can only re-spec once per save file, so if you want to try out a bunch of different builds you are forced to make a new character.
- Not all cutscenes and dialogue are skippable which really hampers replayability. This becomes a problem that is hard to ignore when combined with the previous point.

Overall a good game with some rough edges.

This keeps crashing like a teen on glitter and the performance is abysmal. I haven't had a steady 30fps on any single point yet and my hardware should be able to run medium-high on 1080p according to system requirements. I have every single setting, including crowd density, on the lowest. This alone is completely unacceptable. It took me almost a full day to even get this running enough to play. I don't think I've ever played a game that is optimized this poorly, and though my hardware is not new it is still very much functional.

On top of the performance issues is the NPC and asset popup, nonexistent AI, countless bugs, bad inventory management and other issues that a lot of people have touched on. The most disappointing is the AI because a gigantic city should not feel empty and hollow when you are not doing a quest. There is no dialog, almost no interaction with your surroundings, no connection to the different parts of the city.

That said I really enjoy the world, the quests and all that jazz but it takes determination to suffer trough all the brokenness. I really hope that they can fix all of this but until then unless you're super into all things cyber, do something better with your time.

Anyhow, Very fun game and absolutely worth the buy.

If you understand the tabletop's original rule set along with the themes present throughout much of the source material, you'll find this game as an excellent [i]Cyberpunk[/i] installment, including the first and breathtaking portrayal of Night City. References and mission(s) directly ported from campaigns written many years ago make a place in this game.
 
          However, if you are unaware of the greater background regarding the tabletop rule set of this game and its greater universe, (which is fine by the way!) then you may seem that this game is a bit underwhelming regarding the RPG aspect of its marketing. From my experience, I somewhat agree with this take as well. Each start path to the game felt like it could have had more background woven throughout its playthrough with a bit more choice-related impact in each mission and more missions relating to the life path itself. Besides that issue, some of the start paths feel a bit unbelievable with how the story unfolds so quickly, especially with the Corpo life path. I won't elaborate though, as I don't want to spoil any aspects of the story in this review :D). The Streetkid and the Nomad life path are much less affected from this issue though, but incorporating more missions pertaining only to each life path could have fixed this issue, giving each future playthrough of this game a slightly different flavor.

          To be brutally honest, this game launched in a terrible state, so being a bit hesitant to purchase [i]Cyberpunk 2077[/i] is fair. So I'd like to say that the game is still not perfect. You'll bump into the occasional bug now and then (every 5~15 hours from my experience since 2.1 & 2.0) and an occasional crash maybe every 15~30 hours. If you constantly get crashes though, verifying the files in the Steam settings fixes this issue from my experience and from what I've heard from some friends who've only recently experienced this game. My experience now is much closer to what you should experience as a large, finished AAA game this century. Still, expect a crash or two along your way, but it really should not impede your gameplay much.

          Since the inclusion of the "Phantom Liberty" expansion late into 2023, this game has reached much closer to what a computer RPG should strive to be. In doing so, [i]Cyberpunk 2077[/i] sets many landmarks for what an FPS-based open-world, adventure-RPG can include & provide while having a well-crafted, story-driven experience, easily rivaling (and in my opinion, outpacing), the likes of other recent, highly acclaimed story-driven action, neo-noir like games, such as [i]GTA V[/i], [i]Red Dead Redemption II[/i], [i]Bioshock Infinite[/i], etc. 

          70 dollars (USD) may be a bit of a turn being a necessity for a complete experience, but if you can see other projects such as [i]Tears of the Kingdom[/i] from Nintendo being worth it for what you're paying, then I ensure, this may easily be as well.

          To come to a close to not spoil an initial playthrough, I’ll say that there are at least four [i](though maybe more…... :D)[/i] completely distinct endings with different approaches and decisions you can make within each one, which in turn can show & give you a (few) different epilogue mission(s), leaving you with a somewhat personalized experience of what [i]Cyberpunk[/i], and the minds behind the narrative crafted by its creators, wanted to express to you. Having all this said, I can highly recommend checking this game out if you are into anything sci-fi, thriller, action-adventure, story-driven, dystopian futures, humanity, artificial-intelligence, & animism (how they could be related), peering into your morality through difficult choices, or anything adjacent to said examples, this game will have something for you.
würde meine frau für dieses spiel tötn

[h1] Cyberpunk 2077 stands in its own class of storytelling. [/h1]

This is the type of game to leave a void when you finish it. It consumes your attention whole and leaves you chasing a high in its wake. No other game hits quite like this one does. Granted, I have not played Baldurs Gate 3. Yet when accounting for my ignorance, nothing else even comes close.

Combat is addictive and satisfying. The 2.1 update has made it so you can craft a solid build. As the game develops you equip more and more cyberware. Its a snowball effect that ends with you feeling badass (but not invincible, a certain endgame bossfight ensures this.)

The writing is simply superb. I love how the story is less about saving the world and more about saving yourself. I love how characters are not simply quest receptacles. You can say or do the wrong thing, send the wrong text message to a lover, use a miscalculated compliment, and the game adjusts in real time.

I love how there are seven endings and yet all of them feel emotional. All of them you could fit with the backstory you devised for that particular character.

[h2] The game isn't flawless...[/h2]

There is a lot of obvious cut content especially in the game's early sections. Also, the lifepath system is a joke and not what we were promised. Its still useful for context when making up ur characters backstory in ur head and making decisions, but the game is obviously geared towards a streetkid playthrough. I suspect entire main storylines were cut.

The bugs are here but they dont break the game.

[h1] Phantom Liberty Storyline?[/h1]

Phantom liberty is fantastic. The choices here actually matter even more than some of the ones in the base game. The characters are so fully fleshed out that no mattter how it ends you will feel nagging guilt for betraying someone. This DLC will inspire more online debates than Fallout New Vegas does.

My only complaint is that the whole "Spy thriller" tone doesnt mesh perfectly with the rest of the game's tone. Also, the NUSA should not be as powerful as it is.

[h1] In conclusion this game has fully redeemed itself. It is not the game we were promised but its an example of transcendant storytelling. Buy it. [/h1]

I will emphasize, I've loved this game since release, even with all its bugs.
But since Phantom Liberty and 2.1, its been beyond amazing.
The gameplay feels modern and fresh without just increases to stats being your perks and new abilities changing the way you play (Jolt most notably (Yes I'm a tech weapon user)).
But above all else, the writers and composers did too well with Phantom Liberty. From a new ending to the base game, to 2 endings that are no endings. It induces the true feeling of an RPG in which your choices and their times matter. You can go down one path, then revert to another, but the end result is different than if you went down the singular path as it was, because the context and the meaning behind such a decision change.
Not to mention the absolutely beyond amazing music that goes on throughout the expansion, Gate K9, Never Looking Back, Test of Loyalty, and Phantom Liberty being the most notable. Gate K9 legitimately induced the feeling of how dire the situation of its context was.
And while it had its issues (The mandatory stealth section of the Cerberus most notably, along with how underpowered the Cyberdeck that is rewarded alongside it (BUT ONLY IF YOU FIND ITS BLUEPRINT, SO YEAH)) I still cannot recommend this game enough, but most notably the expansion. Phantom Liberty is now what I will consider to be my favorite expansion beyond even FFXIV's Shadowbringers. Its what we've been waiting for in dystopian RPG, with hopelessness and fully included.

Attention Night City dwellers! The latest Cyberpunk 2077 Update 2.1 is here, and it's like they hacked into our dreams and turned them into reality. The city's more alive than ever, and there's a whole new level of fun to be had!

First and foremost, let's talk about the Metro. That's right, you can now ride the rails in style! Forget about traffic jams and road rage; hop on the Metro and zip across Night City like a true urbanite. It's not just a fast travel system, it's an experience – complete with views of the city that'll make your cybernetic eyes pop!

But hold on, there's more! Ever felt the need to spice up your rides? Say hello to Radioport – the feature that lets you blast your own tunes while cruising the streets. Whether you're into heavy metal or synthwave, your ride's now as unique as your playlist.

For the speed demons out there, Update 2.1 brings back the thrill of racing with repeatable car races. Challenge your skills and push your custom ride to the limits. Whether you're in it for the glory or just to feel the wind in your cybernetic hair, these races are sure to get your adrenaline pumping.

Now, for the romantics in Night City, get ready to swoon. Update 2.1 introduces dates with V's partner. Wine, dine, and spend some quality time with your significant other in the neon-soaked streets. It's not all about guns and gangs; sometimes, it's about finding a moment of peace and love in a chaotic world.

And the cherry on top? Cats, glorious cats! Yes, you can now have a feline friend to accompany you on your adventures (or just to hang out in your apartment). These purrfect companions are sure to bring a smile to your face, even on the toughest of days.

In conclusion, Cyberpunk 2077 Update 2.1 isn't just an update; it's a love letter to the fans. With usual bug fixes, gameplay improvements, and these fantastic new features, it's clear that CD Projekt Red has been listening to the community. So, whether you're racing through the city, enjoying a romantic evening, or chilling with your new kitty, there's never been a better time to be in Night City.
The setting and a lot of the design work that went into the art direction make it look amazing, but the visuals couldn't make it into a good game.

All in all, very strong fix from when the game first came out.  I'm currently maxed out, but doing more side missions before continuing the main, then to DLC.  

Like I said, very solid game now. Making this review because the option came up after my FIRST crash.  So yes, the game did finally die on me, but that's after 75 hours.  I'd say that's pretty typical, so not upset about.  But i'll take some time and mention some bugs I've come across in my 75 hours so far...

1. Came across two mission breaking bugs (Delamain car) where it would not continue conversation or drive, and a cyberpsycho that glitched into the floor after I ran it over with my car.  Couldn't end up looting so couldn't complete mission. A quick save-load fixed the issue for Del, a fast travel away and back fixed the latter.

2. A dozen or so typical "bugs" from NPCs.  Cops standing on motorcycles, civilians doing NPC bug stuff, nothing too severe.  Just kind of breaks any immersion. 

3. Finally, right before my game crashed, I wasn't able to spawn my car.  Any of my cars, for that matter. Only thing I did before that was annihilate the entire police force and those hardcore dudes at 5 stars, like 4 times in a row.  In addition, sometimes when you do that the cops stop showing up lol.  But yeah, after I got away my cars wouldn't spawn.  I saved and loaded and it crashed. 

Final rating with everything said: 9.2/10. 
Things can be fixed, still, but the content is insane and the game is still very much playable.  Can't wait to get to the DLC.

The game runs better now but not flawlessly. The gameplay is still pretty weak. The leveling/progression systems have somehow lost depth in the latest 2.0 update. You do not role play as a customized Cyberpunk from the year 2077. You are V who is a pre-generated character with a pre-determined story to follow which you can do little to change besides what side quests you choose to complete and which ending you pick. 

I've tried about a dozen times since first completing the game to go through it again and after bouncing off a half dozen times over a few years I'm doing a second playthrough now in 2023 to see the DLC and 2.0 rework. I think this is mainly because the gameplay isn't all that fun, and there aren't enough meaningful choices to make between playthroughs. 

TL;DR Watch Edgerunners. Also, maybe buy the game for like $40 on sale including the DLC. I hope we get another Witcher 3 and not another Cyberpunk 2077 from CDPR, BUT this game is now at least worth playing.

I've never seen worse shooter game-play in my life, even in its 2.0 form. Games 25 years ago are more responsive and intuitive then what is seen here. The only way I can describe it is as if your character is a moist noodle - not cooked but not raw - flopping around helplessly. This game falls flat on its face in every game-play system it has. Skill trees are a clusterfuck, confusing, controls half baked. Gun-play is awful; every animation was stiff as a board, weapon sounds were a joke too, bullet sponge moron enemies are standard. 

Story wise the game flops too. It has the beginnings of ideas but essentially does nothing with them. Anything that could be profound is ruined by the intense railroading of the story.

The setting is cool, but that's it. A puddle miles wide and centimetres deep. Huge missed potential which is what frustrates me most; if it was just all in all a bad game I wouldn't care but there clearly was something brewing here but someone just turned off the burner early and served it up... :/

Cyberpunk 2077 engulfs you in its vibrant, neon-soaked world, where every corner of Night City pulses with life and every character you meet adds depth to your own story. It's not just a game; it's an experience where the emotional stakes are high, and the connections you form resonate deeply. Characters like Jackie and Panam are just a few of the many souls you'll encounter, each with their own hopes, dreams, and struggles that draw you in and make the world feel alive.

As you navigate the game's complex narrative web, you'll find that each decision you make carries weight, shaping your path and the fates of those you meet. The bond with your companions grows with every mission, every shared victory, and every hard-fought battle. The emotional investment in these digital lives is profound, a sign of masterful storytelling that blurs the line between game and reality.

The journey through Night City is one of both breathtaking beauty and heart-wrenching loss. Characters enter your life, each leaving an indelible mark on your story. Encounters with characters like Jackie and Panam are designed to evoke strong emotions, their personal stories enriching the tapestry of your own. The game's ability to draw such visceral reactions is a rare achievement, turning simple gameplay into a deeply personal experience.

CD Projekt Red's commitment to perfecting Cyberpunk 2077 post-launch has paid off, creating an adventure that's as emotionally engaging as it is visually stunning. The game has become a canvas for players to paint their tales of loyalty, love, and loss, all while exploring the rich, cybernetic playground that is Night City. Cyberpunk 2077 has transcended its medium, offering not just a game, but a slice of another life, where every joy and sorrow feels as real as our own.

Cyberpunk 2077 is a must-have for every game collection. You will not be disappointed.

NOTE: A Nvidia RTX 3080 or better is recommended.

[h1][b]>COMING: WHEN IT'S READY[/b][/h1]
>[b][i]...Yeah, about that.[/i][/b]

[h1]Update: After the 2.0 update it is running smoothly and some tedious gameplay elements were tweaked and/or replaced so the review below is somewhat outdated but I don't want to write it again. Yes, the game's fixed.[/h1]

Being serious now, I must say that I bought this game as a pre-order back in the 2020 because I was convinced that it will be one of the best stories ever told in the history of video games and... It is. Although the story's deep and amazing - [b]and that's all it can really show off about.[/b]

[list]
[*]The story is well-written and holds itself without any illogical mistakes, the plot places you as [b]V[/b] - who's plans didn't work out so well - but you met your friend that has high aspirations towards becoming someone important in the city's life, that's the moment when you are actually forming your legend in Night City and then you get into some biz about stealing something from someone big enough... blah-blah... I won't spoil any other info about the story because it plays the only real shining part in the game but trust me, [b]you'll find yourself both happy and depressed sinking into the life of V. All of the main story side quests and some of the random ones are very enjoyable to do too.[/b].

[*][b]The next one I'd like to mention is combat[/b] - it is really enjoyable and fun by the amount of ways you can eliminate your targets. The game allows you to go guns blazing with various range of loud guns such as [b]SMGs, Revolvers, ARs and Shotguns[/b] - shooting with each of them is really fun. You can also use [b]Pistols or Sniper Rifles with silencers[/b] to approach the target [b]stealth-like[/b]. Using [b]Hacks to stun, damage or kill your opponents[/b] is also good if you invest into right hacking skills. The [b]melee combat[/b] is something I tried the least just because I didn't like the idea of getting shot at but in some rare occasions it was nice to slice some enemies into pieces.

[*][b]The music in this game is full of bangers[/b] and I really enjoyed listening to game radio between doing the gigs on the map. The overall state of audio in this game is at the great level and music really fits in the right moments of the story.

[*]The thing that really disappointed me is the cyberware and its lack of playstyle changing. Except some of the arm and leg implants that can give you a new way to fight or move - [b]the rest only upgrades your certain stats[/b] or gives you some kind of slow-mo lasting two seconds after you get detected or use the dash button while aiming with the gun. Operational Systems seem like they change your playstyle between the 'Hack' and 'Berserk'. -  [b]Leg cyberwares[/b] allow you to choose between the charged and double jump - [b]Arm implants[/b] give you a choice between 4 very unique fighting tools like [b]Mantis Blades, Rocket Launcher or Gorilla Arms[/b]

[*]Driving really sucks in this game and all of you should know it, the car doesn't even feel right, [b]off-road cars are bouncing like a ball on every single inch of uneven terrain[/b] - the cars also accelerate wildly so you can't actually turn fast enough if you hold the gas button for more than two seconds.

[*][b]Crafting in this game really feels off[/b] as you receive much better loot from enemy's corpses and the price of upgrading your weapon to match your level is a lot bigger than just picking up another weapon matching your level or just waiting to get the max level and raising the rarity of your gun to legendary with a lot less effort and resources - also - some weapons scale weirdly and have a lot worse stats than their same level friends.

[*]I'm not the mission designer or someone who can make decisions here but instead of writing [b]hundreds of mini-stories[/b] for the fetch quests and '[i]kill all the gang members and pick some bag that contains info shard[/i]' around the map, making a bunch of additional side quests would make it a lot better.

[*]Now, the biggest sin of this game - [b]BUGS[/b]. There used to be many visual bugs that made you wonder [i][b]"How did QA allow this to go through"[/b][/i]. [b]In 2022 it is reduced a lot[/b] - but... it hurts to see some that are still existing. I'm not gonna act like it's the only open world game with bugs but some of them actually make NPCs cut some of their dialogues making it sound bad, the requested car can either slingshot the other car it got spawned into in the air or casually spawn floating in the air...[i] or maybe it's a feature? dunno.[/i]
[/list]

To sum up, [b]the game's amazing in the terms of storytelling and the characters are very memorable.[/b] Combat is fun - Driving isn't, Crafting's debatable, it still gave me enough fun to do 2 full playthroughs and it will probably take you ~80h to experience everything this game has to offer. A little bit glitchy but that's it.

I can't help but be amazed by the intricate world that Cyberpunk 2077 has brought to life. CD Projekt Red has truly outdone themselves with this ambitious title. The attention to detail is staggering, from the bustling streets filled with diverse characters to the neon-soaked skyline that captures the essence of a cyberpunk dystopia.

The narrative is gripping, weaving a complex web of intrigue and moral choices that kept me on the edge of my seat throughout my entire playthrough. The characters are well-developed, each with their own unique personalities and story arcs that add depth to the overall experience. Kudos to the writers for creating a world that feels alive and engaging.

Gameplay mechanics are smooth, offering a variety of ways to approach missions and challenges. Whether I wanted to go in guns blazing, take a stealthy approach, or hack my way through, the game accommodated my playstyle seamlessly. The freedom to shape my character's skills and abilities allowed for a truly personalized experience.

Visually, Cyberpunk 2077 is a stunning achievement. The graphics are top-notch, and the attention to detail in both the environment and character designs is unparalleled. Night City feels like a living, breathing entity with its vibrant districts, each telling its own story.

Despite the initial launch issues, the developers have shown commendable dedication to improving the game through updates and patches. The post-launch support has been impressive, addressing performance issues and adding new content to enhance the overall experience.

In conclusion, Cyberpunk 2077 is a must-play for anyone who enjoys immersive storytelling, breathtaking visuals, and open-world exploration. CD Projekt Red has created a futuristic masterpiece that will undoubtedly leave a lasting impact on the gaming industry.

I recommend Cyberpunk 2077 wholeheartedly.

Honestly, its mixed for me. I love this game, its the perfect cyberpunk fantasy for me, but its far from a perfect product. It shines mainly during the side quests, where you get a chance to roleplay to your hearts content (lots of conversations let you choose to sit down so you aren't awkwardly stood there a la fallout, this is the kinda depth you can expect) whilst following (varying degrees of) interesting stories. on top of this, the build variety in this game is fucking insane. You can be a gun-slinging hand cannon wielder, a soldier armed to the teeth and is a fucking tank on the battlefield, a silent hacker able to slip by enemies or take them out through vulnerabilities in their cybernetics, to saying fuck all of that, upgrade your arms to have the force of a semi truck per fist, give yourself the ability to slow down time and own the shit out of anyone you come across before they have the chance to react. (can you tell which build I picked?). besides this, Cyberpunk's number 1 pro for me is definitely Night City itself, constant winding Alleys, back streets, wide open plazas filled with Bladerunner-esque holographic ads and so many lights and sounds its rare you get to experience a quiet moment. The best thing about the city though is the content, it's sorta similar to Ubisoft games actually where there's so much shit to do, but whereas it feels like a checklist in Ubisoft games, here the small crimes and wall graffiti to scan serves to make Night City feel as alive as it should. 

Anyways, it's not all sunshine and rainbows, although the game has made a comeback rivalled only by No Man's Sky, it ain't quite there yet. The main story suffers majorly from pacing issues, particularly where a lot of the set up for your situation within night city and relationships with others are glossed over in a montage near the beginning of the game, this backfires especially when a major character's death has its impact completely spoilt because you're given an hour tops to grow to like them, on top of this the aforementioned pacing problems makes a 30 hours minimum experience feel 20 hours tops, this is not alleviated in the slightest when due to an event in the story the player is discouraged from engaging in any side content due to a forced arbitrary time limit, though there's a similar issue in The Witcher 3 and if you're coming from that you'll know what I mean. Besides the story, in terms of roleplaying, it's far better than it was, but character customisation isn't very good, it's simple (besides hair) and in terms of actual cosmetic cybernetics, there's some face shit and hand stuff from upgrades, but not much besides that so expect no silver hands ;). in terms of actual gameplay, Cyberpunk suffers from the typical Fallout/Shooter RPG problem of it just being boring, the build varieties makes it fun, but only because you can avoid the actual shooting, even then, melee combat suffers too, but with things like the Sandevistan you still get a fair amount of depth in managing cybernetic cool downs alongside health. Alongside these, many smaller things like driving being ass or the police not chasing you or the bugs (which there are far less of, but are still a possibility) do exist, but aren't something I care much about as the first two were never the game's focus and the last one is basically a non issue, just a minor inconvenience.

Overall, Cyberpunk 2077 is a solid RPG experience that at its best lets you run wild in the cyberpunk city of your dreams, mercenary-ing to your hearts content, but at its worst can feel poorly structured or too short, too broad in some places but too narrow in others, but with the DLC set to fix a lot of my issues, Cyberpunk 2077 is definitely shaping up to be a truly great RPG worth your time and your money.

When CB2077 was first released way back in 2020 & it came out as a broken, buggy mess of a game, just like many other people at the time, I too didn't think it could redeem itself.

Then there was the Edgerunners Netflix series, haven't seen it yet, & I thought that don't matter, it still released as a buggy game.

Then I saw Phantom Liberty had Idris & during the Game Awards '23, CB2077 won Best Ongoing Game. So I decided to get the Ultimate Edition & after 7.7 hrs, I can see I was terribly wrong about it.

This game reminds me of Fallout New Vegas. 
Both were released as buggy messes, both were viewed negatively by media & players because of these bugs. But over time they improved to the point that both now receive the positivity they deserved at launch.

I guess these days it's not how the game is released as, it's what becomes of it. Never know, maybe Starfield could be a fun game in years to come, but we all know that's VERY wishful thinking.

As for bugs, I did find some very rare visual glitches. They were amusing and didn't significantly impact my gaming experience. I'm a hard one to please, having 30 years of gaming under my belt.

I would give this game an 8.5 out of 10 (expect it to remain relevant for the next 10 years or more).

Long story short, bethesda forced me to play this game. Having seen the reviews (also graphic performance) of Starfield, I decided to give Cyberpunk a spin. It has been sitting in my catalogue for sth around 1 year. It also was around the same time that I got my new PC with 7900xt (I know, I am not team "better"). The game is quite immersive even on the graphics side. It is quite a standard for CDPR games' to be well written. However, here the team decided to take cyber-emo turn and deliver us with this dystopian vision of future. Not even mad. Nevertheless, I would highly appreciate any happy ending. There is none. I did not expect "Deadpool" video game type of badass ending of a guy flying away on an eagle while being fed grapes by some thicc gurls, but.... 
NVM I highly recommend this game as it is truly a landmark in PC gaming history.

Initially, Cyberpunk 2077 was met with mixed reactions, mine also. The game was praised for its narrative, setting and graphics, but at the same time it was widely criticised for its numerous bugs, especially in the console versions, which suffered from performance issues. Sony even removed the game from the PlayStation Store from December 2020 to June 2021, while CD Projekt worked to fix the problems.
However, CD Projekt Red has not relented in the face of these challenges. The company released a number of patches and updates that improved the game's performance and stability. Among these patches were changes such as improvements to the police system, perk trees, and the introduction of new features such as the NCART metro, radio port, repeatable car races, romantic partner encounters and more.
Reviews of the game following these updates were positive. IGN praised the game for its beautiful city, huge selection and exciting missions. PCMag also praised the game for its satisfying storyline, absorbing world and excellent shooting and melee combat, despite numerous bugs.
All in all, Cyberpunk 2077 is a game that had a difficult start, but thanks to the hard work and determination of the developers, they managed to improve it and turn it into a product that is now well-reviewed and appreciated by players. This shows that even in the face of difficulties, hard work and determination can yield positive results.

What is the problem with making a second season about Cyberpunk: Edgerunners? When Johnny Silverhand attacked Arasaka, it was also shown how he was shot by Adam Smesher, but the next shot showed him sitting alive as a hostage in the corporation. Moreover, Smesher himself told David that he would have made a good construct. David's death during the shooting was not well shown. As for Rebecca, the story took place in 2076, thanks to technology, it would have been possible to repair her and in the first episodes of the second season Arasaka could have held her hostage, threatening her with death if David (as a test subject) refused to work for the corporation and wanted to go against them. Lucy may have gone to the moon, but after a while (after the events in the game) she returned and heard that David was alive. After that, she gathered a team and organized an attack on Arasaka! This is my version of the continuation of the story, as I think it would be a great idea to make a season 2 based on the fact that Cyberpunk: Edgerunners successfully gained attention and increased sales for the game.
